webTitle: Pestered all the way into the red

fields.headline: Pestered all the way into the red
fields.standfirst: Advertisers are milking the power of children with a will and a wish list, writes  Barbara Oaff
fields.trailText: Advertisers are milking the power of children with a will and a wish list, writes Barbara Oaff.
fields.body:
Pester power may do more harm than simply provoking conflict between parents and children. In some cases it may be at the root of real financial hardship.

Relentless pleading by children for particular items is contributing to family debt problems, says Paul Millins, general manager of the National Debtline. 'Pester power is becoming one of the reasons that a household budget goes into the red. It is a particular issue for those on lower incomes because their children go to school and want the same clothes, games, computers and what-have-you as everyone else. The parents can't seem to say no to the request. So they fulfil them, even though they don't really have the means to do so.'

But this pressure is not the preserve of the poor. Millins points out that even parents with higher incomes are putting costly kids' products on to their credit cards only to find, later on, that they can't always meet the repayments.

Eileen Jones, founder of the charity PositiveParenting.org, says that regardless of class, 'the commercial focus on children has led some people into money troubles'.

Rebecca Thomas, a trained social worker and mother of three, agrees. She takes a 'firm but fair' approach to her children, telling them 'very clearly' what they can and can't have and coming up with a compromise where appropriate. But she admits: 'It can still be very difficult to simply say, "No, we can't afford that".

'Children are no longer content with just teddies or dolls or footballs. Now they not only want more, they want more expensive things, and those things have got to be the "right" brand.'

Psychologists and retailers agree that children's demands depend on several factors, not least their age. The accepted wisdom is that the older they get, the more expensive they become.

Jamie, a 12-year-old from Wales, has a personal wish list of kit worth several hundreds of pounds. It includes a colour Game Boy, a DVD player, Play Station 2, all the Pokémon cards, the James Bond Thunderball and tickets to see Liverpool play Manchester United.

But haven't children always wanted particular things and done their best to get them? Is pester power really new? Yes, says the 18-month-old National Family and Parenting Institute, which claims that the pressure for purchase has become greater.

It is perhaps no coincidence that a conference called Kids 2001 will be held next month aimed at companies keen to capitalise on what has become known as the 'playground market'.

The value of this is impossible to estimate, according to Peter Lancaster, joint managing director of the youth market consultancy Teenzworld. 'It runs into billions and billions of pounds. It is astronomical.' And, he says, it's going to get bigger.

Marketing professionals admit they have only recently started to milk its potential. Nic Jones, who has long worked with leading international children's brands, says: 'Five or 10 years ago if a company had a kids' product in their portfolio they wouldn't really take it seriously. Now they take it very, very seriously.'

This summer, Jones will launch his own brand. Pesterpower.com will invite children aged between seven and 12 to fill out their own wish list, which will be sent off to their parents. This is one of several sites being launched directly at children's spending behaviour.

As for teenagers, there is Teenfront.com, Worldpop.com, Gameplay.com and Mykindaplace.com - most featuring big name sponsorship. Shopping on these sites is becoming easier for young people with the introduction of payment systems that don't require a credit card.

On Uksmart.co.uk, for example, visitors pay with a type of token available from Post Offices. They simply quote the number on the token and away they go. As the site's splash page declares: 'Age is no barrier'.

But all this is about 'empowering children', not harassing parents, says Nic Jones. He insists that websites like his are 'a way of children expressing their identity and their own opinion. It gives them a voice.'

Others may disagree, but to date it is not the web that is the main focus of parental ire, but TV advertisements. 'They are pernicious,' says Mike Jempson, director of the media ethics charity PressWise. 'Their message is, "If you haven't got this product, you are abnormal". This is designed to get kids to pressurise their peers and parents.'

Not so, insists Adrian Furnham, professor of psychology at University College, London. He analysed 20 international studies of children as consumers and has published a report called 'Children and Advertising: the allegations and the evidence'. In it he concludes that the cause of pester-power is not advertising but 'irresponsible parenting'.

Furnham says what is needed to combat it is an 'authoritarian' approach, where rules are established, expectations are managed and decisions are explained, all with the child's point of view kept in mind.

Mother of four Sue Jupp, aspires to this and claims to get it right most of the time. 'It is very easy to respond to a child's immediate request, especially when you know they want it so they can fit in with everyone else, but you just have to set boundaries,' she says.

'If there is something they are particularly keen on, they have to work towards it, doing extra jobs around the house to earn the extra money to pay for it.'

Rebecca Thomas thinks that doing anything else sets a bad example, especially in households where money is tight.

Thomas says: 'Kids need to learn the value of things. If they just get whatever they want whenever they want, even if it means mum and dad are going into debt to pay for it, then what are we teaching them about money management?' Some might ask what are the parents teaching themselves?

So how do you fight pester power? Best-selling author Elizabeth Hartley Brewer offers these tips:

 Give regular pocket money, and stick to the limit. This encourages children to learn a sense of value.

 Show them how to collect their 'wants' over two or three weeks, so they can prioritise them.

 Put the waiting back. It's amazing how the 'must have now' soon fades in urgency.

 Ask for a contribution towards the cost of expensive items.

 Wherever possible, buy online, so your children can't be seduced by displays.

 When you go shopping, be very clear what it is for. This makes it easier to stay firm.

 If you decide to buy something, don't do it to assuage guilt: love shouldn't be measured by price tags.

 Don't be frightened to say no. Children can learn that family and real friends don't judge by possessions. It is who they are inside that matters.

Elizabeth Hartley Brewer has written 'Positive Parenting', 'Self-Esteem for Boys,' and, 'Self-Esteem for Girls'.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Why it's time to stock up on stocks

fields.headline: Why it's time to stock up on stocks
fields.trailText: 'As interest rates fall, those looking for income are being forced to look for alternative places to put their money.'
fields.body:
Put your money in the highest-paying savings account from Egg, the internet bank, and you will get a 5.75 per cent return, though that could fall if interest rates continue their downward trend. Buy into the average high-income unit trust and you will be lucky to get more than 3.5 per cent. But buy shares in some of Britain's largest companies and you could get a yield of 7.5 per cent on your investment.

As interest rates fall, those looking for income are being forced to look for alternative places to put their money. Corporate-bond funds are one possibility, but the highest-paying funds in this category tend to be high risk. There are split-capital investment trusts, where one type of share takes the capital growth and another takes the income, but the turbulence in the market has increased the risk in the portfolios underlying these shares. Direct investment in some of the high-yielding shares in the stock market is, therefore, a sensible alternative.

There are, of course, risks with such a strategy. There is usually a reason for a com pany having a high yield, calculated by showing the dividend as a percentage of the share price. It may be that the market expects the dividend to be cut, in which case the yield is far less generous than it seems. Or it may be that there is little prospect of growth in the dividend, as is the case with the utilities.

If you buy a selection of high-yield stocks, you do reduce the risk. Look at the performance of the Dogs of the FTSE 100, the 10 highest-yielding stocks in the index. These have held level, in aggregate, for the past five months, compared with a 6 per cent fall in the index itself.

Companies with generous dividend policies tend to be in defensive industries such as water, electricity, tobacco and retailing. Their profits may be resilient to recession; we eat, light our homes and smoke regardless of what the economy is doing, but they are unlikely to grow much.

If you are looking to the stock market for income, be selective. Some you may like to consider are: tobacco stocks Imperial Tobacco and British American Tobacco, offering 5.5 per cent as compensation for the risk of litigation; utilities Scottish and Southern Energy or Scottish Power, paying 4.7 per cent and 6.6 per cent respectively, though price regulation means that may not rise much; and Lloyds TSB, so out of favour that it is offering a generous 4.3 per cent and rising.

webTitle: Sir Brooke Boothby, Joseph Wright of Derby (1781)

fields.headline: Sir Brooke Boothby, Joseph Wright of Derby (1781)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Joseph Wright of Derby (1734-97), a painter of nature at its most sublime and violent and an artist of intense dramatic power. Wright of Derby belonged not to the polite world of aristocratic art - his attempt to set up as a posh portraitist in Bath failed - but the regional middle class. He was the son of a Derby lawyer and spent most of his career there, sharing the intellectual interests of Midlands industrialists such as Josiah Wedgwood his An Experiment on a Bird in the Air Pump (1768) at the National Gallery depicts people transfixed by the theatre of science. Wright trained in London then went to Italy, apparently eloping with a bride of whom his family disapproved. There he painted fiery night vistas of Vesuvius and a firework display in Rome. He finally settled back in Derby where prosperous industrialists and enlightened landowners took to his grand, European manner in portraits and landscapes.

Subject: Brooke Boothby, a Derbyshire landowner and intellectual. Boothby was involved in the thriving literary community of Lichfield in Staffordshire, the birthplace of Samuel Johnson. In 1766-7 Jean-Jacques Rousseau, prophet of the cult of nature, stayed in Staffordshire while in exile from France, and Boothby was part of the enlightened circles in which he was feted. In the late 1770s Boothby visited him in Paris and was presented with Rousseau's autobiography in manuscript in 1780 Boothby published, in Lichfield, the posthumous first French edition of the First Dialogue of Rousseau Juge de Jean Jacques.

Distinguishing features: Brooke Boothby lies, punningly, beside a brook, opening himself up to nature. His pose, finger to his face, suggests a delicate sensibility. It's a flamboyant departure from the conventions of the society portrait in which people in wigs would sit or stand authoritatively - they certainly didn't lie down. Boothby's relaxation is an act of intimacy with the viewer. He has nothing to hide or hold back. He is as pure as a rustic stream, not in society but in nature that is, he rejects the formal and indirect relationships of cultivated modern life in favour of a direct and authentic act of communion, as if this were the Golden Age and we were all shepherds together. As if his pose did not make this plain enough, in an untamed woodland with open country and the glowing sky behind him, he holds a work by Rousseau, whose arguments for simple living and a return to nature shook 18th-century Europe and were holy writ for the French Revolution.

People read a lot in 18th-century art. Reading is an image of introspection, and Rousseau was a man dedicated to promoting feeling and sensitivity through books. The edition of Rousseau on which Boothby rests his gloved hand - presumably the book he himself published - is a sensual object, bound in calf skin, a book not of hard facts but tender emotions. Through this book we are invited to see the landscape itself as loving and meaningful, a place to dream and escape the shallow world of the city.

Yet if Brooke Boothby is an early Romantic, he is not any kind of savage, noble or otherwise. He is a gentleman, fashionably dressed in broad-brimmed hat, ruffled collar and elegant suit. Any sentiment Boothby espouses will be a well-dressed one and the revolution will not overturn standards of tailoring.

Where is it? Tate Britain, London SW1 (020-7887 8008).

fields.headline: Your rights in the sky
fields.standfirst: The airlines are soon to announce a new code of practice.  Roger Bray looks at the likely benefits
fields.trailText: The airlines are soon to announce a new code of practice. Roger Bray looks at the likely benefits.
fields.body:
European airlines are expected to allow customers a 24-hour cooling-off period after booking flights, when they will be able to cancel without losing money.

Though the move will apply only to flights booked direct, rather than through travel agents, it will allow consumers to hang on to a seat while they continue shopping around for a lower fare, increasing pressure on airlines to offer them the cheapest deal in the first place.

It is part of a new voluntary code of practice, agreed by scheduled and charter carriers from 38 countries, which is due to be unveiled early next month at a meeting in Lisbon. It includes other advances for consumers, not least a promise to respond to complaints within 28 days. But in other respects it threatens to be a damp squib, watered down by airlines terrified of committing themselves too far.

And while major UK airlines have said they will comply with it as soon as it is generally agreed, some others may choose not to implement parts of it - or simply ignore it altogether.

For example, while it looks likely that airlines will agree to offer the lowest available fare, they will continue to insist that they cannot do so unless travellers first provide them with a proposed departure date. Simon Evans, industrial affairs adviser for the British watchdog Air Transport Users Council, says: "We would much rather they promised to come up with their best offer over a period of weeks, say, for passengers who are flexible, and just want to travel when they can get the cheapest deal."

Passengers whose luggage goes astray will be promised that it will be delivered to them within 24 hours of the bags' arrival at their final destination, though in practice this usually happens already, and efforts will be made to speed up refunds for unused tickets, so people using credit cards will get their money back within seven days and those paying by cheque or in cash will have to wait no more than 20 days.

The airlines are believed to have agreed to seek travellers who are prepared to give up their seats voluntarily on overbooked flights and travel later, rather than just bumping passengers. Some do this already. But, while it seems unlikely that anyone would volunteer unless there was something in it for them, there appears to be no commitment to pay compensation.

And although airlines will agree to provide "appropriate assistance" for passengers delayed at airports for more than two hours, which means handing out refreshment or meal vouchers, this clause in the code also includes a get out - they will do so only if local conditions allow.

The code is based broadly on the one launched just over a year ago by the US airlines in an attempt by to head off a government crackdown on service standards. While it represents a leap forward for air passengers who, until recently, enjoyed remarkably few consumer rights, the American experience does not give grounds for huge optimism. Reports suggest most consumers there feel that airlines have yet to live up to their promises.

However, the new code is not the only improvement promised for air travellers. Following pressure from the Office of Fair Trading, the International Air Transport Association, which represents most of the world's leading carriers, has agreed to recommend its members change their conditions of carriage.

Previously, passengers with advance purchase or other non-refundable tickets who were prevented from flying by unavoidable circumstances would have lost their money. Now they will be able to get a voucher which they, or someone else, can trade in for a future flight. Even this conces sion comes with a caveat, however. The agreement speaks of "force majeure", which normally means events that are not covered by travel insurance.

Will airlines cough up if passengers cancel for reasons that could have been insured against? The OFT says there is nothing in the deal to suggest they won't. Other observers are not so convinced.

fields.headline: The beautiful north
fields.standfirst:
These once-forbidding cities have woken up after a long hibernation, Andrew Spooner selects the five coolest spots.
Who goes where? Our guide to the airlines and operators who will take you around Europe
fields.trailText: These once-forbidding cities have woken up after a long hibernation, Andrew Spooner selects the five coolest spots.
fields.body:
While Southern Europe is unlikely ever to lose its holiday appeal, a sophisticated crowd are increasingly heading north, attracted by good design, jaw-dropping scenery, a friendly atmosphere and a distinctly positive attitude to partying.

Reykjavik has won a well-deserved reputation for its funky bars, clubs and other-worldly feel. Yet it is only one of a number of cities booming with new-found confidence. There, exuberant, well- educated and youthful populations enjoy life amid excellent design and architecture and, during the summer, almost endless sunny days. Here is our list of the five brightest northern stars.

St Petersburg

After the 1917 revolution, Peter the Great's baroque capital was relegated to a provincial city, but with the collapse of the Soviet Union, it began to claw back its status and now easily rivals Moscow in terms of cultural appeal. There's a great summer performing arts festival - the Harms Festival - as well as Russia's wildest and most innovative live music/club scene.

What to see: The Hermitage, housed in the sumptuous Winter Palace, is one of the world's great art collections and must not be missed. You should also take a boat cruise down the Neva.

Where to eat: The popular Durak - the Idiot - provides authentic gloomy 19th- century Russian decor that conjures up Dostoevsky's time and serves excellent borscht, rustic rye bread and chilled vodka. Kavkaz offers Georgian cuisine.

Nightlife: Many of the more interesting nightspots spring up and then close rapidly. Look in Friday's English- language St Petersburg Times for up-to-date listings. Long-standing favourites include Griboedov, housed in a bomb shelter and one of the coolest places around, and Manhattan for smooth, intellectual jazz.

Where to stay: In order to get a visa, you must have a hotel booking. All-inclusive package deals offer the best value - try Russia House on 020-7407 3558. Otherwise try the luxurious Hotel Astoria (+7 312 2105757) in the city centre. £150+.

Helsinki

In summer, the city is a joyful mix of parks, open-air bars/ cafés, public art, great architecture and almost endless sunshine. And, at any time of year, you'll be greeted by one of the hardest drinking and partying cities in Europe,.

The Russian influence still looms large, particularly in the area around the cathedral at Senate Square, a pretty neoclassical quarter modelled on St Petersburg. However, most of Helsinki's architecture is thoroughly modern. The Finns have a real appreciation of design and form, which has led to some of the north's sleekest new buildings from Alvar Aalto's sweeping curves of Finlandia Hall and the post-modern Kiasma.

What to see: The exhibitions at the Museum of Contemporary Art at Kiamsa are a bit hit-and-miss, but the building is fantastic. Also take a day-trip to Suomenlinna, an odd inhabited island fortress.

Where to eat: Try fantastic - and expensive - Russian cuisine at Bellevue, behind the Orthodox Uspenski Cathedral. The Lapp restaurant serves sautéed reindeer.

Nightlife: Moskva bar has great retro-Soviet chic, Saunabar mixes essential sounds with steamy saunas, and Tori spins chilled-out jazz-funk and serves great food. For serious drinking, head to Corona or, for legendary tango dancing, Vahna Maestro.

Where to stay: The new swish Scandic Hotel Simonkentta (+385 9 68380) is perfectly positioned, and some rooms even have their own sauna. £60-£200.

Aarhus

The Danish second city has a massive student population giving the place a zesty and friendly atmosphere along with the country's most vibrant live-music scene - many of Denmark's top acts originate here.

The compact city centre has recently undergone massive renovation, and the bustling waterfront area, Vadestedet, is full of bars, restaurants and cafés spilling out into the long summer nights. The Latin Quarter has a string of designer outlets, including Munthe + Simonsen - Helena Christensen's favourite - and one of Denmark's few boutique hotels. And, if you just want to get some fresh air, nearby blue-flag beaches, parks and woodlands provide a great counterpoint.

What to see: The Art Museum houses a fine collection of Danish art, including Asger Jorn's dramatic abstracts. Den Gamle By is a collection of medieval housing from around the country turned into a living museum.

Where to eat : Emmerys provides great organic cakes, coffee etc in a simple Scandinavian atmosphere. Poeme offers excellent fusion food.

Nightlife: Voxhall hosts the underground live acts, while Casablanca is for a more refined and chilled crowd. Head for Vadestedet for bar crawling.

Where to stay: Guldsmeden (+45 8613 4550) is a friendly boutique hotel right in the city centre. The rooms are simple and elegant. Some have four-poster beds. £60plus.

Oslo

For hundreds of years, Oslo - or Christiania as it used to be known - was a far-flung outpost of the Swedish and Danish empires. Since independence at the start of the 20th century, it has struggled to shake off its provincial chains and finally become the sophisticated capital of one of the world's richest and best-educated countries.

Like most northern cities, Oslo comes alive during the summer months. A stroll down the main thoroughfare, Karl Johans Gate, reveals a bustling city filled with cafés and street performers while statues of figures such as Ibsen remind you of the depth of Norwegian culture. Drifting past the twin modernist brick towers of the R dhus - city hall - leads to Aker Brygge, a collection of excellent waterfront bars, restaurants and cafés. Nearby, you can take a ferry to the numerous wooded islands scattered around Oslofjord.

Oslo's nightlife doesn't really get going until about 11pm, but when it does it's a serious party town with many bars staying open till 4am. The Norwegians are a hospitable bunch who generally speak perfect English, and with virtually no crime this has to be one of Europe's most user-friendly capitals.

What to see: The open-air sculpture park devoted to the work of Gustav Vigeland and the Munch Museum are must-sees, while the ski jump/ museum and surrounding woodlands of Holmenkollen make for a good day-trip.

Where to eat: Det Norske Hus serves excellent reindeer and salted cod, while the groovier Sjakk Matt offers inexpensive Mediterranean-inspired grub.

Nightlife: Jazid focuses on bigbeat, jungle and underground techno, while Head On serves up smoother soul and hip-hop. For a beery night in fashionable surroundings, try Barbeint or the Beer Palace.

Where to stay: Noble House Hotel (+47 23 10 72 00), cool modernist decor and a fantastic central position. £80+.

Riga

With a population approaching one million, the Latvian capital is the Baltic's biggest and most cosmopolitan city. Celebrating its 800th birthday this year, it was a wealthy trading post between the West and Russia before being occupied by the Nazis and then the Soviet Union. It regained its independence in 1991 and is once again rebuilding ties with the West.

The nightlife provides plenty of options from the coolest clubs to the downright sleazy. If you just want a romantic evening stroll, head for Bastejkalns park and the surrounding boulevards. Just outside the western fringes of the city, there's a string of beach resorts backed by pine forests. There, you'll also find some hedonistic nightclubs, outdoor bars and more examples of well-preserved early modern architecture.

What to see: Just behind the bus station, the covered market housed in five old Zeppelin hangars is a phenomenal sight. The 12th-century cathedral is worth a visit and also houses a history museum.

Where to eat: Staburags provides a feast of Latvian cuisine in a labyrinth of oak-furnished rooms. Nostalgija serves Russian food amid pure retro-Soviet chic.

Nightlife: DECO has great furniture and cocktails, Aligators trades on tacky Americana and rock'n'roll while Groks Stacija plies techno in a strange underground station set.

Where to stay: Konventa Seta (+371/7087501) is set in a complex of nine medieval buildings equipped with all mod cons. £45.

Tomorrow's world

Walking on sunshine
Author Chris Stewart kicks off our Tomorrow's World special with a hike through some of Europe's most spectacular country - in southern Spain

Basque it
The glitterati head for nearby Biarritz. But the homeliness of St Jean de Luz is where Alex Ninian's heart is

Curtain raiser
It's not an obvious choice for a weekend away, but the capital of Lithuania is a treasure waiting to be discovered

Foreign fields
If your boots were made for walking on something other than paving stones, Simon Birch suggests five real hikes for the weekend

Is this the new Caribbean?
People still live in caves and travel by camel on this island in the Arabian Sea. But plans are afoot to turn it into a holiday paradise over the next 10 years. Erland Clouston takes a look

Viewing recommended
Alf Alderson on how to enjoy Montana - a piece of splendid isolation in the wilderness

fields.headline: Hotel Honolulu by Paul Theroux
fields.standfirst:
Hotel Honolulu by Paul Theroux
(Hamish Hamilton, £16.99)
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount at BOL
fields.trailText: Fiction meets autobiography as 80 vignettes of sex and death get rolled into 450 pages of low-maintenance unhappiness
fields.body:
I came to Hawaii because I couldn't write any more; within a year I had a new life. I was sitting in the bar of an 80-room rat-nibbled hotel at the seedy end of Waikiki chatting to the owner, Buddy Hamstra.

"What would you call the bar?" he asked.

"Paradise Lost," I quipped.

"I like that," he returned. "Howdya like to be resident manager?"

I kept Room 409 empty, because the sounds of raucous sex coming from above kinda got me in the mood. It did the same for Sweetie, the 27-year-old daughter of local Whyan good-time girl Puamana. Our afternoon lovemaking graduated to a marriage, and a child - the precocious Rose. Strange thing, though. It turned out the guy in Room 509 wasn't fucking; he was carving his coffin.

The hotel was crammed with losers, hustlers and hookers. Madam Ma, the island's gossip columnist, used to drink there. In between sightings of Jack Lord, she was never that nice to Rose. Changed her tune when her son, Chip, murdered his gay lover when he found him raping his mom. Only it wasn't rape as Madam Ma was having a scene with her son's lover behind his back. Kinda nice Whyan symmetry.

Buddy was getting lonely. "I need another wife," he said, before flying to Manila to get Pinky. On his return he went missing presumed drowned, and we all gathered in his lawyer's office. "Hi," he grinned, "I'm back." Buddy sure kept Pinky on her toes.

The locals used to mock my reading. Except one. Leon Udel was Henry James's biographer. He knew who I was and I knew who he was. "I feel like Rimbaud," I moaned. "Know how you feel," he replied. "You should try writing some short stories."

I began to hear voices. "You're a failure." "Just another middle-aged howlie who married a local."

"What's it matter if they're real or not?" argued Sweetie. "It's the truth."

"Keep on going," said Udel. "Deep down, you're a genius."

Buddy had an experimental op to help his breathing, but couldn't quit the vodka and cigars. Pinky inherited the hotel after he croaked. She made it turn a profit, but for me it lost its charm. So I quit. But I had me a book.

And if you really are pressed - The digested read, digested: Fiction meets autobiography as 80 vignettes of sex and death get rolled into 450 pages of low-maintenance unhappiness
fields.bodyText: I came to Hawaii because I couldn't write any more; within a year I had a new life. I was sitting in the bar of an 80-room rat-nibbled hotel at the seedy end of Waikiki chatting to the owner, Buddy Hamstra. "What would you call the bar?" he asked. "Paradise Lost," I quipped. "I like that," he returned. "Howdya like to be resident manager?" I kept Room 409 empty, because the sounds of raucous sex coming from above kinda got me in the mood. It did the same for Sweetie, the 27-year-old daughter of local Whyan good-time girl Puamana. Our afternoon lovemaking graduated to a marriage, and a child - the precocious Rose. Strange thing, though. It turned out the guy in Room 509 wasn't fucking; he was carving his coffin. The hotel was crammed with losers, hustlers and hookers. Madam Ma, the island's gossip columnist, used to drink there. In between sightings of Jack Lord, she was never that nice to Rose. Changed her tune when her son, Chip, murdered his gay lover when he found him raping his mom. Only it wasn't rape as Madam Ma was having a scene with her son's lover behind his back. Kinda nice Whyan symmetry. Buddy was getting lonely. "I need another wife," he said, before flying to Manila to get Pinky. On his return he went missing presumed drowned, and we all gathered in his lawyer's office. "Hi," he grinned, "I'm back." Buddy sure kept Pinky on her toes. The locals used to mock my reading. Except one. Leon Udel was Henry James's biographer. He knew who I was and I knew who he was. "I feel like Rimbaud," I moaned. "Know how you feel," he replied. "You should try writing some short stories." I began to hear voices. "You're a failure." "Just another middle-aged howlie who married a local." fields.headline: Curtain raiser
fields.standfirst:
It's not an obvious choice for a weekend away, but the capital of Lithuania is a treasure waiting to be discovered.
Who goes where? Our guide to the airlines and operators which will take you around Europe
fields.trailText: It's not an obvious choice for a weekend away, but the capital of Lithuania is a treasure waiting to be discovered.
fields.body:
When I was a child, I used to visit Vilnius a lot in my imagination. Other kids were probably transported to more exotic locations, but I was always drawn to the birthplace of my father. In reality, it took me 39 years to get there. And when I did go, it wasn't on a mission to discover my roots. I simply went to satisfy my curiosity.

The things I knew about the place could be written on the back of a postcard in a child's handwriting. I knew that it was sometimes cold enough for your spit to freeze before it hit the ground; that people fished for eels through holes they cut in the ice; and that they kept warm by eating livid-looking bowls of soup made out of beetroots. In summer, though, it was hot enough for the soup to be served cold.

Listening to my father's stories as I grew up, it never occurred to me that Vilnius could be a city, let alone the capital of Lithuania. I knew it better as Wilno, a Polish town since 1920, the place where my dad was born in 1932 and where he lived for the first few years of his life until my grandparents were evicted from their smallholding by Red Army soldiers in the early 1940s. Wilno then became Vilna, it was swallowed up by the Soviet Union and any discussion beyond that point would see my father's eyebrows descending as heavily as the Iron Curtain.

It certainly never occurred to me that it might be somewhere I would one day consider going for a weekend break. It's not an obvious contender, after all. And it came as a bit of a shock to discover that it was not, as I had imagined, a grey Soviet city jerry-built on top of someone else's ruins. Here instead was a bright, clean and colourfully-restored old town with cobbled streets and a castle perched on top of a hill, a Unesco World Heritage site separated by a river from the utilitarian tower blocks of the new town.

Many of the buildings have been painted pink and blue and green and yellow, and the atmosphere is much lighter and warmer than you could reasonably expect for a place that only gained its independence 10 years ago and that saw the last Soviet troops leave as recently as 1993.

You will be hard-pressed to hear another English accent in Vilnius. The occasional American drawl from a member of the returning diaspora maybe - the Lithuanian president, Valdas Adamkus, counts himself among their ranks. But unlike Prague, say, Vilnius is not yet overrun with tourists. As a result, there's a genuine feeling of discovery when you walk around recently-restored buildings in the miraculously-preserved old town.

In the central market, Belorussians with faces the shape and colour of beetroots sit by their meagre piles of potatoes or carrots. And 20 minutes' drive out of Vilnius, I did see men fishing on a frozen lake, looking like garden gnomes, with the magnificent castle of Trakai towering behind them. Further on, a haystack came wobbling up the opposite side of the road towards us - the driver perched on top of the load and linked to the carthorse by two impossibly long reins. In Lithuania, the echoes of the past are never too far away.

It's like lifting the lid on a box of treasure that has been forgotten about for more than half a century. You can still find churches that would have been "exploded" by Stalin and his henchmen had the Lithuanians not been quick to turn them into museums. The stunning neoclassical cathedral was an art gallery for 32 years, but also had $10 million worth of religious artefacts hidden from the Soviets within its walls; and the baroque Church of St Casimir survived, ironically, as the museum of atheism. In all, 21 churches escaped Stalin's purges, including a gothic masterpiece, the Church of St Anne's. When Napoleon saw St Anne's, as he marched towards Russia, he was so impressed he said he wanted to take back to France in the palm of his hand.

The three saints on the roof of the cathedral did not, however, survive Soviet destruction and were only replaced in 1996 after a 46-year absence. Now they look over the stebuklas (miracle) tile, the spot between the cathedral and the bell tower from where in 1989 a human chain of two million Lithuanians, Latvians and Estonians stretched over 650km to Tallinn to protest against Soviet rule. People now come to make a wish on the square at which the miracle of freedom was born.

The novelty of this freedom perhaps explains why the streets can still be spookily deserted at night. But you'll find the bars and basement clubs busy until the small hours pumping out danceable music and serving drinks at prices that won't stop you in your tracks: around £1 for a pint of local lager and £1.50 for a cocktail.

Or, if you're feeling more sophisticated, you can secure the best seats at the opera for around £6, and follow it with a traditional Lithuanian meal for two with wine at Zemaiciu Smukle for around £20. For this, you can get a bowl of delicious beetroot soup, and a mixed grill of beef fillet, pork ribs, salmon, baked potatoes and courgettes plus a bottle of very drinkable Chilean red.

Odd then that we should choose to spend an evening drinking Russian "champagne" at 60 pence a glass served by waitresses dressed in Russian sailor outfits in a bar decked out with Lenin memorabilia. You'd think it would leave a bad taste in the mouth, but the style of Naktinis Vilkas (The Iron Wolf) is intentionally kitsch, almost mocking.

The following morning, though, sobriety returns in the form of the KGB Museum or, to give it its proper title, the Museum of Genocide Victims, which is around the corner from the bar. Here you can rent an audiophone and tour the cells where, between 1958 and 1987, thousands of Lithuanians were detained, interrogated, tortured and executed. Many who entered this building were subsequently deported to the gulags in Siberia.

It is a relief to be back on the main street of Gedimino again. We fortify ourselves with coffee and cake in a café opposite the square over which a giant statue of Lenin presided, but which was ceremonially removed by crane in 1991 when the Soviets finally gave up the ghost of trying to impose their will on the people. Now the 20ft tall icon - minus the thumb on his outstretched hand - has come to rest in the Soviet Sculpture Memorial Park two hours south-west of Vilnius in the town of Grutas.

More than 60 statues and busts of former Soviet despots are on display in a place that is being billed as Stalin World, a theme park said to recreate the atmos phere of the gulags, with a cattle truck at the entrance, guard towers overlooking the statues and patriotic songs playing over loudspeakers.

The park is owned by Viliumas Malinauskas, who bought all the statues and busts that were junked across Lithuania after independence. It officially opened on April 1, costs £1 to enter and there's a café, a children's play area and even a little zoo. But this is no theme park. Instead, you will find an extraordinary collection of ideological sculptures presented with thoughtful biographies. There's also an excellent information centre stocked with badges, busts, portraits and pamphlets from the Soviet era. The only bizarre sight is seeing Lithuanians draping themselves over these symbols of repression to have their photographs taken.

On my final morning, I visit Adakris Marcinkus at his apartment set in a cobbled square in the old town. A former film director now in his seventies, Adakris offers B&B to tourists in his home. They come mostly from the US, Sweden and Norway, and he tells me how pleasant it is just to be able to hear different languages being spoken again after so many years of listening purely to Lithuanian and Russian. His eyes light up when he describes the restoration of colours to buildings that had long lain under a thick layer of Soviet grime.

Adakris could only be a few years older than my father. His earliest memories would be of a similar place. And, although I had not come looking for the land of my father, it felt almost as though I had stumbled across it sipping coffee and listening to the stories of this elderly gentleman in his apartment off a cobbled courtyard in the heart of old Vilnius.

Where to eat, drink and party in Vilnius

Lunch

Mano Kavine
Boksto 7 Ave.
Cost: £3.

Hidden away off the Town Hall Square, this fresh and funky caf offers the best salads in Vilnius. The light airy atmosphere is a relief from the dark cellars that pervade the indoor scene.

Uzupio Kavine
Uzupio 2 Ave.
Cost: £3.50.

Relax on the wooden terrace as the river winds beneath your feet in the "Rupublic" of Uzupis, the city's arty quarter.

Outdoor dining

Savas Kampas
Vokieciu 4 Ave.
Cost: £3.50.

Next to the Town Hall, the outdoor gallery is the perfect setting for people watching.

Amatininku Uzeiga
Didzioji 19/2.
Cost: £2

Highly recommended for roast chicken, garlic sauce and beer.

Dinner

Lokys
Stikliu 8.
Cost: £5-£6 a head; more if you want exotic game.

One of the oldest restaurants in Vilnius: surviving the transition from Soviet service to respectable Lithuanian hospitality.

Literatu Svetaine
Gedimino 1
Cost: £6.

Unquestionably the best food in Vilnius. This new Lithuanian/Scandinavian outfit delivers fine cuisine with the ultimate view - Cathedral Square beautifully illuminated at night.

Bars

Busi Trecias
Totoriu 18.

Soak up rural Lithuania in this tavern before hitting the more intense side of Vilnius.

Brodvejas
Mesiniu 4.

"Broadway" has live music, a decent selection of beer, including Lithuanian Guinness at 80p a pint. Regularly packed.

Clubs

Indigo
Traku 3/2.
Special-offer beers at 80p-£1 every week, Vodka Red Bull £2.40.

Happening nightclub on the edge of the old town. Spacious and friendly with frequent promotional nights to please the classy Lithuanian crowd.

Gero Viskio Baras
(Good Whiskey Bar)
Pilies 34. Beer £1, Whisky mix around £2.

Three floors of variety: brightly-lit upstairs with comfy sofas and MTV, a leather-clad middle floor for the discerning drinker and a jumping cellar where it all goes off.

Way to go

Lithuanianholidays.com (0161-286 0830) offers three nights' B&B at the four-star Sarunas hotel in Vilnius for £329pp, including return flights from Heathrow and transfers. Extra night supplement costs £30pp per night. Three nights' B&B hosted by Adakris and Grazina Marcinkus costs £289pp. Extra night £20pp. Lithuanianholidays.com can organise opera tickets for the price of the ticket plus a £9 charge per person; a ticket for Tosca on May 18 in the best seats will cost £16. Car hire with an English-speaking driver costs £40 for the day. A guided walking tour of the old town costs £60 for the guide, or a student can show you the cafs and bars that tourists don't normally discover for £15. Vilnius In Your Pocket is the invaluable quarterly guide to the city and can be bought from most newsagents and hotels for 80p a copy. Further reading: Baltic Capitals, Bradt Travel Guides, £10.95.

Author Chris Stewart kicks off our Tomorrow's World special with a hike through some of Europe's most spectacular country - in southern Spain

Basque it
The glitterati head for nearby Biarritz. But the homeliness of St Jean de Luz is where Alex Ninian's heart is

If your boots were made for walking on something other than paving stones, Simon Birch suggests five real hikes for the weekend

Is this the new Caribbean?
People still live in caves and travel by camel on this island in the Arabian Sea. But plans are afoot to turn it into a holiday paradise over the next 10 years. Erland Clouston takes a look

The beautiful north
These once-forbidding cities have woken up after a long hibernation. Andrew Spooner selects the five coolest spots

Alf Alderson on how to enjoy Montana - a piece of splendid isolation in the wilderness

webTitle: Matt Thorne:  a CD Walkman | A keychain fob in the shape of a cat | A pen and paper

fields.headline: Matt Thorne never travels without...
fields.trailText: A CD Walkman | A keychain fob in the shape of a cat | A pen and paper
fields.body:
A necessity: A CD Walkman - even though I'm always breaking them, and taking them into repair shops only to find out that it's cheaper to buy a new one. I love music, and can't be without it for too long.

A lucky charm: I have this ridiculously large keychain fob which is in the shape of a cat. It's special because it can open beer bottles of any size, and always comes in handy.

A luxury: A pen and paper. I'm always carting about whatever novel I'm working on at the time - I write longhand - much to the irritation of whoever I'm travelling with. I hate being away from novels when I'm in the middle of them, and am superstitious about leaving them at home.

If only: A desk. Or a portable office. Finding somewhere to write is always a nightmare. I love going to Miami as you can get relatively cheap rooms with lots of space, and spare space always seems a luxury when you're away somewhere.

 Matt Thorne's third novel, Dreaming of Strangers, was published this week by Phoenix Paperbacks at £6.99.

fields.headline: Is this the next Caribbean?
fields.standfirst: People still live in caves and travel by camel on this island in the Arabian Sea. But plans are afoot to turn it into a holiday paradise over the next 10 years.  Erland Clouston  takes a look
fields.trailText: People still live in caves and travel by camel on this island in the Arabian Sea. But plans are afoot to turn it into a holiday paradise over the next 10 years. Erland Clouston takes a look.
fields.body:
The first odd thing about Socotra was the airport terminal. There wasn't one. Or rather, there were concrete stumps and wooden scaffolding rearing out of the shrimp-coloured earth. The outgoing passengers stood just off the runway in an arc of breezy cotton, supervised by thin soldiers in peach-and-spinach camouflaged kit. Behind them was a double row of sagging 4x4s.

As we stood waiting for our bags to be unloaded, the 4x4 people scurried across the dust to grab the green bouquets of qat that the dealers had brought in from Yemen, the narcotic sheathed in three-feet tubes of palm fibre to keep it fresh. This is going to be different, I thought, sweating.

Socotra, 74 miles long by 22 wide, fell off the mega continent Gondwana 140 million years ago. The ancestors of the qat-chewers, shipwrecked sailors or refugees from Africa (170 miles to the west) or Arabia (300 miles north), arrived here, maybe 5,000 years ago. Since then progress has been leisurely. The inhabitants - 30,000 or 75,000, no one seems quite sure - survive by fishing and cattle herding. A great many still live in caves. Up to 1990, they ran a purely barter economy. A recent report found that ailing islanders frequently tried to cure themselves by laying hot metal bars on their skin. In this context, even half an airport terminal seemed a significant advance.

A dark, long-haired figure wearing a sarong and "US Embassy, Yemen" T-Shirt sauntered out of the crowd. Ferdinando was a former Italian Olympic horseman who had veered into the Indian Ocean leisure industry. "I came two years ago and I stayed," he shrugged. The Yemeni authorities have decided their island's almost blissful state of innocence is ripe for exploitation. A British company, funded by the World Bank, has drawn up a 10-year tourist develop ment plan. Ferdinando had become the front man for one of Socotra's first holiday ventures. His business partners include the nephew of the Yemeni president.

We climbed into a 4x4 and were catapulted along a crude, bulldozed track. Through the windows, we saw more pink rock topped by swollen-trunked shrubs crowned with what looked like dropping broccoli buds.

"Cucumber trees," declared Ferdinando. Cucumbers? On trees? But the cucumber trees swept past, to be replaced by rickety-looking stone huts, thatched with bleached palm leaves. In the front seat Ferdinando craned forward, shielding his eyes against the sun. He was hunting for a village that could be converted into a tourist camp, he explained.

We crashed to a stop. If Socrata's first hotel (there already is a guest house) looked like a barracks, that was because it was one, or had been before conversion by Ferdinando's colleagues. It had 10ft-high armoured doors, white painted concrete walls, no hot water, and no electricity for part of each night. One evening we met a goat scampering down the hall. Still, it was correct, in its stark practicality. The hotel was one of only half-a-dozen two-storey buildings in Hadiboh, the very humble capital composed of flat-roofed, mud brick dwellings; anything less fundamental would have been a culture shock to Hadiboh's 2,000 hard-pressed citizens.

The first written reference to Socotra, by an anonymous Greek Sailor in 60AD, noted that the inhabitants traded in tortoise shells and cinnabar trees and cooked with lizard oil. Tourism hopes are pinned on the island's still exotic bio-diversity. The United Nations is already halfway through a $5m conservation programme. At a spartan compound surrounded by cardboard-chewing goats, a weary Sudanese, Dr Salah Hakim, handed over a collection of scientific papers.

The dossier read like Sindbad's mystic Isle of Serendib where "rare plants grow abundantly, with cedar trees and cocoa palms". Socotra has 273 botanically unique species. It also has the world's greatest variety of frankincense trees (seven). The red sap of the endemic Dragon Blood tree was prized by gladiators for its antiseptic and cosmetic properties. The Socotran aloe is farmed over the Middle East for its healing powers. Although the Socotran crocodile has gone the way of all flesh, the island still boasts 21 types of reptile, six birds and 113 insects found nowhere else.

The only sad news concerned the sharks, which were now being plundered with impunity by rapacious Pakistani and Chinese fishermen, Dr Hakim claimed. There may be a geo-temperamental factor here. Ferdinando, a diving specialist, claimed Socotran fish were less nervous (and bigger) than any others.

Certainly what was good for fishermen could be good for tourism: Ferdinando boasted he had already identified 10 sub-sea exploration sites, including a 1990 wreck. The next day, we jumped overboard from a shark-hunter's 25ft canoe. The fish were certainly prolific and, as far as anyone could tell, relaxed.

Inland had another kind of magic. The Hagier mountains in the east are rich with red oxide and rear up from dried wadi beds in shaded dabs of aubergine and ginger. We lurched wildly in two 4x4s past groves of date palms and clusters of semi-derelict native huts.

"Something like this, exactly what I want," Ferdi nando cried. One of Dr Hakim's UN reports had described the higher ground as ideal for coffee-growing, but all we saw were shattered rocks and a cobweb of spindly shrubs in which young goats twitched like flies. The driver told us that an entrepreneur had tried to grow qat here, but gave up when it was stolen in the night.

Dragon Blood trees sprouted like giant emerald mushrooms along the skyline. Below them, the spindly branches of the Socotran fig wriggled from a trunk that resembled a deflated barrage balloon. A column of Bedouin tugging fawn camels lurched past us.

The jeeps jolted up a track and finally stopped before a cave where two Socotran families lived. It was about 200 yards wide and 100 deep, and subdivided here and there by low walls of limestone rock and sticks from which clothes and lamps dangled. Eighty feet above us, white-feathered Egyptian vultures drifted in between gnarled, water-dripping stalactites. I felt eerily as if I had strayed into some museum diorama.

We were received courteously by a spry, treacle-faced figure in white cotton trousers whose hair had been stained tangerine with henna. He handed around glasses of tea and said he owned 10 camels and five goats. He was called Aissa and seemed shrewd and quite at ease. In the background, brightly-shawled women and children gazed, mutely, from behind their stone partitions. Aissa agreed to pose for photographs, provided his family were excluded, and stretched out like a pasha on the cave floor. Indeed, once you had swallowed the concept, a warm, roomy cave with fine views over the Indian Ocean had much to recommend it. I wondered how long this neo-prehistoric existence would survive.

That evening we went to a shisha den and, for 15p each, lounged with 40 tawny islanders on cheap blue cushions, drawing strawberry molasses fumes from a gilded water pipe. On the last night, we stretched out on the barracks roof watching acrobatic goats slither over lorry bonnets. Two fireworks whirled pink and green across the sky like modern djinn, telling Moslems they could break their fast.

Would sophisticated Europeans go for this delightful chaos, I wondered. Probably they should, I thought, before it is changed for ever.

Way to go

Summer offers botanical, birdwatching, diving and general exploration holidays on Socotra for around £400pp per week between November and May. The price includes half-board accommodation, transport and guiding but not the air fare. For independent travellers, half-board at the Summer Hotel costs £26 for a double room, less for singles; jeep hire is £46 a day, cross-country camels £13. Yemen airways (020-7491 7186) has two flights a week between Gatwick and Sana'a. Prices vary according to season, but a return flight between the UK and Socotra will cost well under £500.

Author Chris Stewart kicks off our Tomorrow's World special with a hike through some of Europe's most spectacular country - in southern Spain.
fields.body:
Most people haven't a clue where or what the Alpujarra is; to have heard of it, you need to have read Gerald Brenan's South from Granada or the turgidly romantic 19th-century travelogue by Pedro-Antonio de Alarcón - or indeed my own book. The only quotable quote about the place comes from Fernando of Aragón: "I'd rather a grave in Granada," he quipped, "than a palace in the Alpujarra."

Still, through one means and another, I came to know the Alpujarra 14 years ago and, having seen it, made up my mind to live in it, which I've been doing ever since.

The Alpujarra is the system of hills and valleys that make up the southern slopes of the Sierra Nevada in Andalucía. As an area for walking, it is difficult to beat: sunshine is constant, and the beauty and variety of the landscape, the character of the villages and the richness of the botany are a real delight.

The Alpujarra starts at what is known as the Granada coast. From here, you can head up into the hills of the Contraviesa, the long counterscarp of the Sierra Nevada. The hills are cloaked in Mediterranean maquis, lavenders, thymes, sages, rosemary, genista, asparagus and pines. The Contraviesa botany reaches its crescendo around the pretty village of Polopos, set in a bowl of hills overlooking the sea. Polopos produces a wine that is unaccountably famous locally. It also has a particularly delightful little guest-house and restaurant - la Posada.

Nobody goes walking on the Contraviesa; it's too hot and dry in summer, but in spring it's a feast of flowers, and from the old ways that follow the contours from village to village, there are unforgettable views of the high mountains and the sea. Apart from Polopos, there's Sorvilán and Rubite, unspoilt and baking in the spring sunshine, and at Haza del Lino there's a restaurant, el Paso del Jabalí, which specialises in wild boar.

The southern side of the Contraviesa is covered in vines. The wine that is produced here, costa, is believed by locals to be the only wine on earth worth drinking. This is, in fact, far from the truth; until now costa has been a dismal brown wine with a bouquet that puts you in mind of wet dogs.

It needn't be so though. Over to the east, near Murtas, are the vineyards of Barranco Oscuro. Manolo Valenzuela claims his vineyard is the highest in the world so close to the sea, a fact that gives his wines inestimable advantages. He produces a wine known as 1368 - the altitude of the vineyard - and a number of other whites, reds and rosés, as well as a delicious cava, a worthy rival to good Champagne. His wines are so good, and now so sought after that it's often difficult to get hold of them.

Manolo, who is a man mad for winemaking, bursting with energy and passion, is now spreading his outrageous ideas of hygiene and consistency among the more traditionally-entrenched local producers. The results promise to be good.

This is the New Alpujarra. Twelve years ago, the region was a forgotten backwater, stagnant and brown like its wine. Now, little by little, it is being shaken from its sloth by imaginative and energetic dreamers. And it's often in the manifestations of this change that the pleasure and excitement of the area lies. In the wake of the innovators comes the rural tourism, and it's doing just what rural tourism ought to do, injecting the influences, the ideas and the cash right where they are needed rather than passing them through unwieldy, organisations.

From the almonds and vines of the high slopes, you could drop down the north side of the Contraviesa to the valleys of the Guadalfeo river. Here you can wander among the fertile vegas watered by the river. Oranges and lemons fill the air with their scent in April, May and June, and there are bananas and avocados and even custard apples at this level. Or you can walk in the riverbeds among the canebreaks and the tamarisk with its odd scent of burnt raspberry jam, to the singing of frogs, nightingales and golden orioles. From Órgiva, the main town of the Alpujarra, you could walk in a day all the way up to the beautiful Alquería de Morayma, another fine example of new Alpujarra.

The Alquería de Morayma, near Cádiar, is the creation of another inspired Alpujarreño, Mariano Cruz. Mariano bought a ruin of a wayside inn and rebuilt it with all the beauty and none of the squalor of 200 years ago. Here you can eat well, stay in exquisite rooms, swim in the pool, go walking, riding or engage in one of the many pursuits organised by the hotel.

At about 1,000m, you leave the citrus and olive zones and enter the chestnut woods and cherry orchards of the high villages. Up here, too, the flora is dazzling in its richness and variety. There are ancient paths, mule roads, engineered by sorcery and arts long forgotten, their stone cut steps and walls leading you effortlessly up seemingly impossible hills. In the spring months and early summer it's like walking through an endless herbaceous border.

The Sierra Nevada is known for the richness of its flora. A richness that is a result of the different geographical influences that bear on the Sierra Nevada - Atlantic, Mediterranean, North African, European and Alpine. Even when the spring flowers have withered away, there are still the summer plants - the lavenders, thymes, various brooms with their sweet-scented yellow flowers, thorny wild asparagus, lavateras, cistus, wild pistachios, mountain ash, holm-oak and hollies, phlomis and vile-smelling rue. The smell of it all is almost overpowering and when you come down out of the scrub, your trousers smell sweet with rosemary and thyme.

There are creatures, too, to delight the foot-traveller - Swallowtail butterflies, small blues, orange tips, hosts of them. There are ibex everywhere, a fine sight as they dance gracefully across sheer rockfaces, their young skip ping behind. There are boars, too, lurking timidly in the undergrowth by day, ready to ravage the potatoes and maize at night. Then there's bats at sunset, and hoopoes, too, and kestrels and rollers and Bonelli's eagles and vultures and at dusk the sky is full of bee-eaters like rainbow parrots when the sun catches their wings. Higher up, above the tree-line, live the solitary desperadoes of the animal kingdom, the ravens and choughs and a curious high mountain beetle.

You can stay in the villages or in outlying cortijos - there's a proliferation of guest-houses and country hotels. in Mairena, in the quieter but equally beautiful Eastern Alpujarra, close to Gerald Brenan's Yegen, there's the enchanting Las Chimeneas run by an English couple. a little more opulent is Prado del Toro above Pitres, where you stay in the most beautiful neo-moresque rooms deep in the countryside above the village. similarly, above Capileira, there's Catifalarga, where you can enjoy concerts on summer nights beneath the stars.

Alpujarran gastronomy is, to be truthful, not among the world's best, but things are on the move here, too. El Jardín in Pitres serves vegetarian food but it's good, and the setting and ambiance are spectacular. A similar treat is Jean-Claude's L'Atelier in Mecinilla, and the better products of the pig are to be had at La Forja in Trevélez.

In Lanjarón, you can eat good fish at la Marisqueria, and in Órgiva you could do worse than la Almazara or Ramón's Mirasierra. In Bubión, you can sip mint tea and nibble Arab pastries while you fool around on the internet in the neo-andalusi Cybermonfí tea-house.

If you're desperate to go for a walk - and you may be by now - you could be in Malaga in two and a half hours from London, and within another two hours, you're deep in the mountains.

'The most beautiful walk in the Alpujarra'

ë don't know why I'm telling you this; it's a sure way to louse up a favourite walk. But it would be wrong in a way not to share it. After all, it isn't mine . . .

There are countless beautiful walks in the Alpujarra, but it's hard to beat the Carihuela de Mecina Fondales for flowers, vistas, atmosphere and the beauty of the path itself.

You could start in Fondales, deep down in the gorge of the R'o Trevlez. Wind your way down to the bottom of the village and leave through the covered wash-house. The path cuts steeply down through a poplar and chestnut wood, and finally down to what is known as the Roman bridge. Cross the bridge and follow the path uphill.

There follows about 45 minutes of gentle climbing on an ancient rock-built road that curls and twists among the crags and pinnacles of the river gorge. Steep stone steps lift you easily up the more dramatic bits, while on the gentler gradients the path passes between banks of flowers. It's difficult to believe you're not walking through a cultivated garden. Savour this, because there are not many paths quite like it anywhere.

At the top, you are rewarded with magnificent views of the mountains receding to the west and of the villages on the other side of the gorge with the Sierra Nevada in the background.

You could turn and go back the way you came; it looks different from the other direction - or you could turn east along the wide track cut into the hillside. About 40 minutes along here, through a forest of pine, spruce and holm oak, you come to a bulldozed track leading back down into the gorge, opposite a little huddle of mineworkers' cottages. Follow this down to the river by another beautiful ancient way of steep rock-cut steps. Cross the river by the ancient hydro-electric station of Ferreirola - turn of the century and the first one in the province of Granada - and take the steady ascent back towards the west.

Twenty minutes among lush agricultural terraces brings you to the lovely village of Ferreirola (several excellent guesthouses: www.nevadensis.com) and from Ferreirola, it's but 20 minutes back through the woods to Mecina.

The only quotable quote about the place comes from Fernando of Aragón: "I'd rather a grave in Granada," he quipped, "than a palace in the Alpujarra." Still, through one means and another, I came to know the Alpujarra 14 years ago and, having seen it, made up my mind to live in it, which I've been doing ever since. The Alpujarra is the system of hills and valleys that make up the southern slopes of the Sierra Nevada in Andalucía. As an area for walking, it is difficult to beat: sunshine is constant, and the beauty and variety of the landscape, the character of the villages and the richness of the botany are a real delight. The Alpujarra starts at what is known as the Granada coast. From here, you can head up into the hills of the Contraviesa, the long counterscarp of the Sierra Nevada. The hills are cloaked in Mediterranean maquis, lavenders, thymes, sages, rosemary, genista, asparagus and pines. The Contraviesa botany reaches its crescendo around the pretty village of Polopos, set in a bowl of hills overlooking the sea. Polopos produces a wine that is unaccountably famous locally. It also has a particularly delightful little guest-house and restaurant - la Posada. Nobody goes walking on the Contraviesa; it's too hot and dry in summer, but in spring it's a feast of flowers, and from the old ways that follow the contours from village to village, there are unforgettable views of the high mountains and the sea. Apart from Polopos, there's Sorvilán and Rubite, unspoilt and baking in the spring sunshine, and at Haza del Lino there's a restaurant, el Paso del Jabalí, which specialises in wild boar. The southern side of the Contraviesa is covered in vines. The wine that is produced here, costa, is believed by locals to be the only wine on earth worth drinking. This is, in fact, far from the truth; until now costa has been a dismal brown wine with a bouquet that puts you in mind of wet dogs. It needn't be so though. Over to the east, near Murtas, are the vineyards of Barranco Oscuro. Manolo Valenzuela claims his vineyard is the highest in the world so close to the sea, a fact that gives his wines inestimable advantages. He produces a wine known as 1368 - the altitude of the vineyard - and a number of other whites, reds and rosés, as well as a delicious cava, a worthy rival to good Champagne. His wines are so good, and now so sought after that it's often difficult to get hold of them. Manolo, who is a man mad for winemaking, bursting with energy and passion, is now spreading his outrageous ideas of hygiene and consistency among the more traditionally-entrenched local producers. The results promise to be good. This is the New Alpujarra. Twelve years ago, the region was a forgotten backwater, stagnant and brown like its wine. Now, little by little, it is being shaken from its sloth by imaginative and energetic dreamers. And it's often in the manifestations of this change that the pleasure and excitement of the area lies. In the wake of the innovators comes the rural tourism, and it's doing just what rural tourism ought to do, injecting the influences, the ideas and the cash right where they are needed rather than passing them through unwieldy, organisations. From the almonds and vines of the high slopes, you could drop down the north side of the Contraviesa to the valleys of the Guadalfeo river. Here you can wander among the fertile vegas watered by the river. Oranges and lemons fill the air with their scent in April, May and June, and there are bananas and avocados and even custard apples at this level. Or you can walk in the riverbeds among the canebreaks and the tamarisk with its odd scent of burnt raspberry jam, to the singing of frogs, nightingales and golden orioles. From Órgiva, the main town of the Alpujarra, you could walk in a day all the way up to the beautiful Alquería de Morayma, another fine example of new Alpujarra. The Alquería de Morayma, near Cádiar, is the creation of another inspired Alpujarreño, Mariano Cruz. Mariano bought a ruin of a wayside inn and rebuilt it with all the beauty and none of the squalor of 200 years ago. Here you can eat well, stay in exquisite rooms, swim in the pool, go walking, riding or engage in one of the many pursuits organised by the hotel. At about 1,000m, you leave the citrus and olive zones and enter the chestnut woods and cherry orchards of the high villages. Up here, too, the flora is dazzling in its richness and variety. There are ancient paths, mule roads, engineered by sorcery and arts long forgotten, their stone cut steps and walls leading you effortlessly up seemingly impossible hills. In the spring months and early summer it's like walking through an endless herbaceous border. The Sierra Nevada is known for the richness of its flora. A richness that is a result of the different geographical influences that bear on the Sierra Nevada - Atlantic, Mediterranean, North African, European and Alpine. Even when the spring flowers have withered away, there are still the summer plants - the lavenders, thymes, various brooms with their sweet-scented yellow flowers, thorny wild asparagus, lavateras, cistus, wild pistachios, mountain ash, holm-oak and hollies, phlomis and vile-smelling rue. The smell of it all is almost overpowering and when you come down out of the scrub, your trousers smell sweet with rosemary and thyme. There are creatures, too, to delight the foot-traveller - Swallowtail butterflies, small blues, orange tips, hosts of them. There are ibex everywhere, a fine sight as they dance gracefully across sheer rockfaces, their young skip ping behind. There are boars, too, lurking timidly in the undergrowth by day, ready to ravage the potatoes and maize at night. Then there's bats at sunset, and hoopoes, too, and kestrels and rollers and Bonelli's eagles and vultures and at dusk the sky is full of bee-eaters like rainbow parrots when the sun catches their wings. Higher up, above the tree-line, live the solitary desperadoes of the animal kingdom, the ravens and choughs and a curious high mountain beetle. You can stay in the villages or in outlying cortijos - there's a proliferation of guest-houses and country hotels. in Mairena, in the quieter but equally beautiful Eastern Alpujarra, close to Gerald Brenan's Yegen, there's the enchanting Las Chimeneas run by an English couple. a little more opulent is Prado del Toro above Pitres, where you stay in the most beautiful neo-moresque rooms deep in the countryside above the village. similarly, above Capileira, there's Catifalarga, where you can enjoy concerts on summer nights beneath the stars. Alpujarran gastronomy is, to be truthful, not among the world's best, but things are on the move here, too. El Jardín in Pitres serves vegetarian food but it's good, and the setting and ambiance are spectacular. A similar treat is Jean-Claude's L'Atelier in Mecinilla, and the better products of the pig are to be had at La Forja in Trevélez. In Lanjarón, you can eat good fish at la Marisqueria, and in Órgiva you could do worse than la Almazara or Ramón's Mirasierra. In Bubión, you can sip mint tea and nibble Arab pastries while you fool around on the internet in the neo-andalusi Cybermonfí tea-house. If you're desperate to go for a walk - and you may be by now - you could be in Malaga in two and a half hours from London, and within another two hours, you're deep in the mountains. 'The most beautiful walk in the Alpujarra' ë don't know why I'm telling you this; it's a sure way to louse up a favourite walk. But it would be wrong in a way not to share it. After all, it isn't mine . . . There are countless beautiful walks in the Alpujarra, but it's hard to beat the Carihuela de Mecina Fondales for flowers, vistas, atmosphere and the beauty of the path itself. You could start in Fondales, deep down in the gorge of the R'o Trevlez. Wind your way down to the bottom of the village and leave through the covered wash-house. The path cuts steeply down through a poplar and chestnut wood, and finally down to what is known as the Roman bridge. Cross the bridge and follow the path uphill. There follows about 45 minutes of gentle climbing on an ancient rock-built road that curls and twists among the crags and pinnacles of the river gorge. Steep stone steps lift you easily up the more dramatic bits, while on the gentler gradients the path passes between banks of flowers. It's difficult to believe you're not walking through a cultivated garden. Savour this, because there are not many paths quite like it anywhere. At the top, you are rewarded with magnificent views of the mountains receding to the west and of the villages on the other side of the gorge with the Sierra Nevada in the background. You could turn and go back the way you came; it looks different from the other direction - or you could turn east along the wide track cut into the hillside. About 40 minutes along here, through a forest of pine, spruce and holm oak, you come to a bulldozed track leading back down into the gorge, opposite a little huddle of mineworkers' cottages. Follow this down to the river by another beautiful ancient way of steep rock-cut steps. Cross the river by the ancient hydro-electric station of Ferreirola - turn of the century and the first one in the province of Granada - and take the steady ascent back towards the west. Twenty minutes among lush agricultural terraces brings you to the lovely village of Ferreirola (several excellent guesthouses: www.nevadensis.com) and from Ferreirola, it's but 20 minutes back through the woods to Mecina.  Chris Stewart's Driving Over Lemons is published is published by Sort Of Books at £6.99. Way to go Chris Stewart guides for Andalucian Adventures (01453 834137), which offers guided walking holidays in the Alpujarra with selected departures in spring and autumn. It has added an extra departure date for spring - June 3 - and also has availability for departures in autumn on October 7, 14, 21 and 28. The June 3 departure costs £579pp and the October departures cost £619pp, to include seven nights' full-board accommodation and wine with dinner, all tuition/ guiding and excursions. The prices do not include flights to Malaga, which cost £70 - £200 and are available from 15 UK regional airports. The single supplement is £58 for the week. webTitle: I lost my heart in Las Vegas

fields.headline: I lost my heart in Las Vegas
fields.standfirst: Belinda Jones, author
fields.trailText: Belinda Jones, author.
fields.body:
Why? Not being a big fan of real life, I love Vegas because it's so surreal. It's such a kitsch, over-the-top, mind-boggling fantasy land that I feel like a kid again when I'm there. No matter how many times you've seen it in the movies, the scale, the lights and the insanity of the town are still completely overwhelming.

What's the best thing? The shows. Tom Jones is there every couple of months, and seeing him live is a must. Over here, you can only see him in stadiums, but out there, he's performing to a room of 650 people. He's a lot saucier out there, too.

My perfect day: I'd nurse my hangover over breakfast at the Peppermill, a tacky den that has been around since the days of the Rat Pack. Then I'd go and see the lions at the MGM. To relax, I'd go to the pools at the Bellagio. Then I'd head out to Red Rock Canyon to watch the sun go down over the dramatic rock formations. In the evening, I'd stuff myself with a buffet dinner at the Bellagio, go to a show and then go out drinking and dancing. For the full 24-hour experience, I'd top it all off with a visit to Olympic Gardens, a lap-dancing club that has men upstairs.

My advice: Plan ahead by visiting the hotel websites. Prices fluctuate dramatically, and if you do your homework you'll be able to get the plushest suite imaginable for the price of a crappy motel room. Above all, let go of your inhibitions and your cynicism: Las Vegas doesn't take itself seriously and neither should you.

Getting there: British Airways (0845 7733377) offers flights from London to Las Vegas via San Francisco or Los Angeles from around £370 return. For hotels, visit www.lasvegashotels.com.

 Belinda Jones's debut novel, Divas Las Vegas, is published by Random House at £5.99.

fields.headline: Pot luck with WAP
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor braves a multitude of '500: Internal server errors' to size up a host of WAP sites.
fields.body:
I own a WAP phone. And while setting it up wasn't easy - thanks to my stubborness in refusing the mobile phone shop assistant's offer to set it up himself, and five subsequent calls to BT - I've occasionally found it useful, particularly for weather forecasts, football scores and news updates.

But given the poor press that WAP receives, and the occasionally desperate slowness of the service, a surprising number of travel companies and organisations have joined Genie Internet's Travel channel. Time, I thought, to see if they worked.

Expedia

I need to find a hotel in Rome.
Something appears to be amiss here. The list of Roman hotels provided by Expedia seemed rather unlikely. Could there really be a Candlewood Hotel in Italy's capital? Certainly, clicking on it produced the unhelpful response: "Sorry, we have no hotel for you". More positively, Expedia offers a flight status service. You'll need the flight number to use it. Travellers who have already created an itinerary on www.expedia.co.uk can call up the details on WAP.

British Airways

Are there any seats left on tonight's flight to Hamburg?
"Economy is full, try Club", replied BA. According to BA's rather convoluted WAP help page, customers can check in using their WAP phone. Since I'm not a member of the BA Executive Club, I couldn't try out the service, but it could be useful if you're stuck in a taxi on the way to Heathrow.

Train Times

When is the next train to Shrewsbury from London?
The site gave a full and detailed reply, with the option of choosing other departure times. Like the main Railtrack site, this is an invaluable service with far more potential than most current WAP offerings.

Which buses travel between Essex Road and Shaftesbury Avenue?
No help here. But www.transportforlondon.gov.uk knows about the Number 38.

London Travel

Are there delays on the Northern Line this evening?
No - and no reported incidents either! (The exclamation mark is London Transport's own).

lastminute.com

Can I book a Lebanese restaurant in London next Thursday?
Yes. Lastminute gives the price (£28 for two) and a number to call or the option of a free callback. If you don't have access to the website and want to arrange a date quickly, WAP makes a useful substitute.

MapQuest

How long will it take me to drive from Birmingham to Edinburgh?
The first attempt provoked a 500: Internal Server Error. The second returned me to MapQuest's home page each time I tried to type in the word Birmingham.

ebookers.com

I'd like to check flight prices to New York during June.
Another 500 Internal Server Error. Three times - on two different days. Still, ebookers.com has been very busy getting a London stock-exchange listing this week.

LeisureHunt

Are there any B&Bs in the SY4 postcode area?
A promising postcode-based accommodation search resulted, infuriatingly, in another 500 error.

What about Teletext Holidays, Thomas Cook, Fly321 and Travel Choice?

I'd spent so long dialling up that my battery was almost dead - and I couldn't face another costly 500 Error.
