fields.headline: Viewing recommended
fields.standfirst: Alf Alderson on how to enjoy a piece of splendid isolation in the wilderness
fields.trailText: Alf Alderson on how to enjoy a piece of splendid isolation in the wilderness.
fields.body:
The US Forestry Service's idea of a good holiday home is a single-room cabin with no running water, a view across half of America and no neighbours for tens of miles in any direction. To get there, you may have to walk or ski through forests, you'll need to know what to do should you encounter a bear, and you'll have to bring all your food, bedding, water and beer on your back. In short, it's the sort of place Jack London would have felt at home.

Surprisingly, lots of Americans appear to feel the same and many Forestry Service cabins are rented out year-round to outdoor types looking for something that sits at the very end of the road less travelled.

The service has hundreds of properties scattered throughout some of the most spectacular and unspoilt landscapes in North America. They were built in the first half of the 20th century as lookout cabins and towers, guard stations or work centres in remote forest and mountain locations, but in recent years their use by the service has declined, so many are now rented out to people wanting to get as far away from it all as possible.

The lookout cabins and towers in particular are great if you're after a cheap room with a stunning view, the view being their raison d' être. In the past, Forest Service employees would spend entire summers alone in these cabins, scanning the horizon for the first signs of smoke that indicated a forest fire.

To use the Forestry Service's own terse description, their cabins are "rustic and primitive". They all come with bunks (but not necessarily mattresses), a stove, propane cooker, tables and chairs - but that's about it. The chemical toilet may be more than 100 yards away in the woods; you'll need to bring your own drinking water (and it's surprising how much a person uses in a day, and how heavy it is); you'll have to chop your own firewood; and, thank God, mobile phones generally don't work in these necks of the woods.

Such basic accommodation means that cost isn't a consideration - the cheapest cabins are around $20 a night and sleep four, and even an eight-person unit will only set you back $50-$60 a night.

When I stayed at West Fork Butte Lookout Cabin, 6,000ft up in the Bitterroot Mountains of north-west Montana, my biggest concern was whether I should prioritise water over beer in terms of the liquids that I'd be lugging to my lodgings. But that was before I'd realised I could drive to within half a mile of the cabin.

West Fork Butte wasn't the classic lookout tower on top of a rickety timber frame (although these can also be rented, and involve scaling a ladder or wooden staircase and scrambling through a trapdoor). My accommodation was a 14ft by 14ft timber structure perched on top of bare rock slabs and secured with steel hawsers bolted into the rock.

Inside were two squeaky bunks, a stove, a cooker and a chair; outside, through huge windows, a view across the blue ridges of the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness Area, rolling west into Idaho, snow patches still visible on the summits, although it was summer. I couldn't see a road or a building in any direction, and all that could be heard was the soughing of a warm wind from the south, the creak of the trees in the wind and the clink of rocks as chipmunks scittered around under the cabin. This was a place where you could really feel alone, even if your car was only half a mile away.

The visitor's book was full of glowing comments on the great views, proximity of nature and often God.

Had I been a real fire lookout man, I'd have had work to do that evening, as a purple mass of cloud to the south began spitting lightning down into the forests below - I found out the next day that this was one of the storms that was responsible for the huge wildfires that burnt throughout the region last summer.

There is actually quite a lot you can do at a lookout cabin besides admiring the view, reading books and writing postcards. There's the wildlife to watch, for starters. The chipmunks living outside are cute, but are to be discouraged as they can pass on diseases. I suppose bears and mountain lions ought to be discouraged, too - this is grizzly as well as black bear territory - and there are deer and birds as well. There's no end of trails to walk or bike if you have a good map, and some cabins are close to mountain lakes, where you can swim or fish. And, if you're so minded and have the licence, you could go out and shoot something.

There's also work to be done - if you use firewood, you're expected to cut more for the next visitors; the cabin should be cleaned before you leave; and all rubbish must be "packed out".

Evening was the best time at the cabin - a basic meal cooked on a basic stove and a warm beer (no fridge, no ice) may not appeal to more refined palates, but the liberating sensation of being totally alone on top of a mountain in a landscape way more remote than anything Britain has to offer more than made up for the food. And I like baked beans anyway.

In winter, the cabins are popular with cross-country skiers, and I imagine it must be an equally wonderful experience to sit on top of an isolated, snowy mountain with a few friends, a fire roaring in the stove, skis propped outside and a glass of whiskey in your hand. According to the visitors' book at West Fork Butte, plenty of people had spent Christmas or New Year up there.

Whether I'd go and eat my Christmas pud at West Fork Butte, I'm not sure. But if you're looking for a summer weekend out in the American wilderness, a lookout cabin has a lot going for it.

Way to go

For details of staying in US Forest Service cabins and lookout towers, contact USDA Forest Service, Recreation, Heritage and Wilderness Resources, PO Box 96090, Washington DC, US 20090-6090 (tel: 001 202 205 1706). Advance reservations of a week or more may be required, and some cabins have a maximum stay of three days. The Forestry Service discourages children under 12 from staying in lookout towers, and if you're travelling in winter, you should check on local weather conditions.

There is actually quite a lot you can do at a lookout cabin besides admiring the view, reading books and writing postcards. There's the wildlife to watch, for starters. The chipmunks living outside are cute, but are to be discouraged as they can pass on diseases. I suppose bears and mountain lions ought to be discouraged, too - this is grizzly as well as black bear territory - and there are deer and birds as well. There's no end of trails to walk or bike if you have a good map, and some cabins are close to mountain lakes, where you can swim or fish. And, if you're so minded and have the licence, you could go out and shoot something. There's also work to be done - if you use firewood, you're expected to cut more for the next visitors; the cabin should be cleaned before you leave; and all rubbish must be "packed out". Evening was the best time at the cabin - a basic meal cooked on a basic stove and a warm beer (no fridge, no ice) may not appeal to more refined palates, but the liberating sensation of being totally alone on top of a mountain in a landscape way more remote than anything Britain has to offer more than made up for the food. And I like baked beans anyway. In winter, the cabins are popular with cross-country skiers, and I imagine it must be an equally wonderful experience to sit on top of an isolated, snowy mountain with a few friends, a fire roaring in the stove, skis propped outside and a glass of whiskey in your hand. According to the visitors' book at West Fork Butte, plenty of people had spent Christmas or New Year up there. Whether I'd go and eat my Christmas pud at West Fork Butte, I'm not sure. But if you're looking for a summer weekend out in the American wilderness, a lookout cabin has a lot going for it. Way to go For details of staying in US Forest Service cabins and lookout towers, contact USDA Forest Service, Recreation, Heritage and Wilderness Resources, PO Box 96090, Washington DC, US 20090-6090 (tel: 001 202 205 1706). Advance reservations of a week or more may be required, and some cabins have a maximum stay of three days. The Forestry Service discourages children under 12 from staying in lookout towers, and if you're travelling in winter, you should check on local weather conditions. People still live in caves and travel by camel on this island in the Arabian Sea. But plans are afoot to turn it into a holiday paradise over the next 10 years. fields.headline: The Packable Bucket Hat
fields.trailText: It's light, looks good, protects against the sun, doesn't crease and takes up less space than a pair of socks.
fields.body:
It's hard enough to find a hat that suits me but even harder to find something that doesn't crush, crease or isn't a nightmare to pack. Any ideas?
Try the Packable Bucket Hat from Columbia Sportswear. It's light, looks good, protects against the sun, doesn't crease and takes up less space than a pair of socks.

How is it "Packable"?
The hat folds into a pocket in the crown, which zips up and has a fabric loop if you want to attach it to anything. It weighs only 25g.

What's it made from?
Omni-tech, a lightweight, breathable fabric that's supple and doesn't crease. The hat is waterproof, windproof an constructed in the traditional bucket style.

How can it be completely waterproof?
It's coated with an invisible water repellant and the seams are sealed for complete protection. It is designed to be effective even after 20 home washes.

How many sizes does it come in?
Just the one, but the size is adjusted by a Velcro strap so it can be as tight or loose as you want it.

How much does it cost and how many colours does it come in?
It comes in black, midnight blue and tan, and costs £19.99.

Where can I get one?
Call Columbia Sportswear for stockists: 020-8996 8000.

webTitle: Peace breaks out in aid of British art

fields.headline: Peace breaks out in aid of British art
fields.trailText: An unprecedented collaboration betweeen national and regional museums and galleries will result in a festival celebrating six centuries of British art and design, from medieval furniture to the fashion creations of John Galliano, next autumn and winter.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
An unprecedented collaboration betweeen national and regional museums and galleries will result in a festival celebrating six centuries of British art and design, from medieval furniture to the fashion creations of John Galliano, next autumn and winter.

Their customary internecine warfare has been suspended, and the museums in London, Liverpool and Edinburgh have come together to create and market the six-month British art season, which will also be launched in New York and Paris in the coming months.

The project was greeted yesterday with a sigh of relief by the arts minister Alan Howarth. 'It will refute the heresy, which has been spreading like a virus, and demonstrate that Britain is not a land simply ridden with pestilence and desolation but a land containing the greatest beauties, natural and artistic,' he said.

The exhibitions will feature everything from contemporary sculpture and fashion to an exhibition of pastoral landscapes on banknotes at the British Museum.

The sculptor Tony Cragg will get one of the most spectacular outdoor spaces in London, the restored riverside terrace at Somerset House, for a free exhibition of new work. Rachel Whiteread will mount her first major solo show, in London, and in Edinburgh where she is creating a new piece, a cast of the space beneath a mortuary slab in a historic graveyard.

Exhibitions of painting and prints, sculpture and photographs, fashion and furniture will be mounted at museums including the V&A; the Design Museum, which will examine John Galliano's work at the couture house Christian Dior; the Royal Academy, a restrospective of Frank Auerbach; the Dulwich Picture Gallery; and the Scottish National Galleries of art and photography.

The British Museum will hold an exhbition marking the centenary of Stanley William Hayter, a British-born painter who moved to Paris and later New York, and became one of the most influential print makers in the world.

At the National Portrait Gallery, Painted Ladies will feature portraits by Lely of some of the beauties of the court of Charles II.

The season will coincide with a string of lottery-funded museum openings and extensions, including Tate Britain's centenary development, which will increase the gallery space at Millbank by over a third; the new British Galleries at the V&A which will bring together 3,000 objects and five restored period rooms; and the Handel museum in his London house.

The final opening will be in February, at the Museums and Galleries of Merseyside, where staff are still in shock after the recent suicide of their founding director, Sir Richard Foster. His massive development project, which attracted the largest ever heritage lottery museum grant of over £23m, will come to fruition with the reopening of the Walker Art Gallery, the classical temple in the heart of the city, with the first major study of the 18th-century art of George Romney.

fields.headline: Hoffman's tale
fields.standfirst: Eva Hoffman's Jewish parents survived the Holocaust in hiding in Ukraine. She was born in Poland two months after the war and, as a teenager, moved to the US. She was groomed as a concert pianist but instead chose to be a writer and academic, shedding light on the tangled roots of racial prejudice in Europe. Andrew Brown reports
fields.trailText: Eva Hoffman's Jewish parents survived the Holocaust in hiding in Ukraine. She was born in Poland two months after the war and, as a teenager, moved to the US. She was groomed as a concert pianist but instead chose to be a writer and academic, shedding light on the tangled roots of racial prejudice in Europe. Andrew Brown reports
fields.body:
Eva Hoffman stands at the lectern at the Sheldonian theatre at Oxford University like a bird drinking. Her head dips down in sharp, refreshing pecks to the manuscript in front of her. She stands as she writes, poised high above sentimentality or excess. Malcolm Bowie, professor of French at Oxford, compares her to Primo Levi. It is difficult to imagine higher praise for a writer. She was born in 1945 in Cracow. Her parents had survived the Holocaust by hiding in a bunker in the Ukrainian forest; they then hid for a further year among hay bales in an unheated barn, concealed by a mute peasant. When Hoffman was 13, the family emigrated to Vancouver without a word of English: a city on the opposite side of the world in every sense.

Everything changed. Her father, Boris Wydra, was, she writes, almost overthrown by the order and predictability he found there, like a sailor whose legs betray him on the dockside. But she and her sister, Alina, who is three years younger, somehow found their balance in the New World. She gave up her ambition to be a concert pianist and, aged 19, emigrated again to Texas, before moving to New York, where she became what she had discovered she wanted to be - a metropolitan intellectual.

Nowadays she lives in Hampstead, in London - "halfway between Manhattan and Cracow" - just down the road from the Freud museum. She commutes to her job in the US - she is visiting professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology - and has taught creative writing at the University of East Anglia. Yet this life of free-floating sophistication is rooted in her extraordinary understanding of the confined and tangle-rooted cultures of eastern Europe. Hoffman's mother, Maria, though she survived the unimaginable privations and dangers of the war, never ran or swam in her entire life. Respectable girls from a religious Jewish background could not do so. This was so ingrained that Maria Wydra did not bother to mention it until the subject came up when her daughter was 20. "Every immigrant," says Eva Hoffman, "becomes a kind of amateur anthropologist."

Everything is strange to the eye of a stranger. What makes her extraordinary as a writer is that she can recapture the sense that life must be constantly made understandable, yet will never become familiar. This trick is most subtle when she writes about things we already think we understand: Polish anti-semitism in Shtetl, her history of a settlement on the borders of Poland and Belarus; and in Exit into History, the aftermath of the Velvet Revolutions. In both cases, she looks at the fine detail of people's lives and waits until they appear before the reader, as serious, knotty and untranslateable as we appear to ourselves.

Roy Foster, professor of modern history at Oxford, says: "She writes about ethnic or racial relations, which are sometimes treated in a very simplistic way, and she makes it clear how complicated they are."

She understands that everyone is on someone else's periphery: when, in Shtetl, she visits the market in a small town in eastern Poland, where the Jews were exterminated, she sees: "Ruddy-faced farmers in sheepskin coats with high leather boots . . . stomping their feet in the snow for warmth. I observe them with a double vision. They are rough-and-ready looking men, huddling in small groups, exchanging idle remarks. That is all. But in post-Holocaust ethnography, they have come to be seen as allegories of anti-semitism. In their faces, if you look at them a certain way, nothing but this essential hatred can be discerned."

But she flips the mirror so that she shares their intolerance. "The way, undoubtedly, that to some of them a Jew was a pure type, of greed, cleverness and manipulativeness. I know that there may be some truth to the Polish stereotype: that in some of their hearts, anti-semitism sprouts. But I also know that, on both sides, these are reductions, pure, simple and sometimes very dangerous."

Her picture of the complexities of the Holocaust grows out of family experience. Her parents were betrayed several times by Gentile peasants to the Germans who would have killed them, as all their relatives were killed. But they also survived because of the bravery and self-sacrifice of other peasants - who would themselves have been killed had the Wydras been discovered. And Hoffman's aunt and niece were betrayed to their deaths by other Jews. This is why she is able to say: "An injunction to remember can become an injunction not to think, not to grapple with the past: such an injunction seems to me to verge on bad faith." In other words, a facile and distorted memory is almost a greater insult than simply forgetting. No wonder Foster sees in her an example to be followed by everyone who writes Irish history.

He likes her, too: "She has a compelling personality. Charming would be the wrong word - but I have seen her in a long and very absorbed conversation with Isaiah Berlin [the late philosopher] the first time they met. Obviously he was a great charmer, but she was exerting her own compulsion, too, on him."

Much of her historical writing is concerned with the intricacies of individual memory, as a guard against the blurring sweeps of collectivism. Her own memory, as revealed in the autobiographical Lost in Translation, has a most extraordinary vividness and purity. Her childhood, sealed off as it was by exile and loss of language, re-emerges in a continuous present, full of all the small anchoring details that make our surroundings real. When they reach Vancouver, she cannot believe that lavatory paper comes in different colours.

In Cracow they had been happy without any of that. "I didn't know I was economically deprived. There were so many things that are important for a child. There was a sense of community and solidarity and neighbourliness because of the terrible times that everyone had been through. The barriers were lower between people. And as a child I was not overstimulated. There was human intimacy, but also a lot of space to muse, to play and to imagine."

In Cracow, her parents had been happy. They had lost their families, their religious faith, their trust in any institution. But they had survived. They were among people who had also suffered and were making the best of a new world; soon they emerged towards the top of the new society. The Wydras might have had only three rooms in their flat, but there was a maid who slept in the kitchen - a Jew who had been a servant in the house of the peasants who had sheltered them, though they had not known then that she was Jewish.

Boris Wydra made his living hustling and trading, seldom legally - to break communist laws was a patriotic act in Poland. But he managed to accumulate enough money for his family to have a middle-class life, with restaurant meals and concerts and piano lessons for his daughters: he even obtained a Russian motorbike in 1956: the magnitude of this achievement is reflected in the fact that no one they knew owned any sort of motorised vehicle, let alone a car. The traffic on the cobbled streets consisted of trams and horse-drawn carts, "although in the busiest parts of the city there are occasionally several cars in a row, which seem to tear by at enormous speeds".

But the real distance of this past comes out in its pictures of femininity. Her mother did not just avoid running because it was ill-bred. She also had, writes Hoffman, a peasant's "ancient notion - which came from centuries of hard labour - that the ideal state of life is getting enough rest . . . laziness shows a certain luxuriance of character, the eroticism of valuing your pleasure. 'You know, Ormianska calls the maid from the kitchen to get her matches, which are lying 10 centimetres away from her', my mother says, half in criticism, half in admiration. Such egotism is at the heart of feminine power, which consists in the ability to make others do things for you, to be pampered."

Her friend, the novelist Lisa Appignanesi, says: "The Poles, like the British, have internalised an ideal aristocracy and this comes through very clearly in Eva's work. The importance given to music, the sense of being cultivated. Jews carried that as well. They carried it into the countries where they went - the women wore gloves, I mean, everyone wore gloves. My mother had, like, 100 pairs."

Appignanesi, although another Polish Jew, whose parents emigrated to Canada when she was two, does not have Hoffman's keen sense of Polish life as a living undercurrent to all other possible ways of living. Hoffman says: "I am interested in how we are constructed by language and by culture. There is some kind of dialectic going on, but we can never grasp what it is that engages with language."

The great dislocation which made this process visible to her was emigration and the change of language. But after seeing it in her own life, she sees elements of the process everywhere. Her book Exit into History is really an account of how people coped with being exiled into the future at the end of the Cold War. Shtetl is in some ways an account of an emigration that never was; and of the way in which Jews and Christians were never forced to come to terms with each other as living complicated beings, in need of translation, until it was too late. They lived side by side as strangers until catastrophe overwhelmed them both. The Jews, of course, were more thoroughly overwhelmed, but though others escaped with their lives, they were still forced to flee. When Hoffman and her sister finally visited Zalosce, the small town near Lvov where their parents came from, they found three Jews living there, of whom one, she says, was a "public" Jew. But Jews were not the only people to have disappeared. Zalosce had in 1939, when it was part of Poland, been one third Polish, one third Ukrainian and one third Jewish. Today there are three Poles left, to go with the three Jews.

Indeed, Hoffman was hardly aware of her own Jewishness until she was seven or more. Most of her Cracow childhood was unaffectedly Polish. Michael Ignatieff, who has known her for 30 years, since they were at Harvard together, says: "She doesn't shut off any side of her. Most people who are Polish-Jewish decide to be one or the other. She has decided to be both."

Now Hoffman sees that her father was a shtetl trader, one of a long line of Jews who had made their livings in the markets of eastern Europe for centuries. In Vancouver, he started a business selling second-hand furniture, which eventually prospered. But he never really adjusted to life in Canada. "I would find it very hard to live without a piano," she says. "At the moment I am reading my way through all the Beethoven sonatas, even though I have played most of them. Otherwise, I play for myself the classical Romantic repertoire - Chopin, Schumann."

She gave up on a musical career because she felt she would never reach the top. "There are so many peerless pianists and the repertory has been recorded at a super level 20 times over. I could have been good but I didn't think I had anything to add to that."

He got his PhD and went into advertising, where he prospered. They had no children and she has not married again.

But she was finding success elusive. She had, she says, none of the pain and active discrimination that earlier immigrants experienced - it is hardly a disadvantage, if you want to be a New York intellectual, to have started off as a Polish Jew. Within the limits of her ability and ambition, she could go anywhere she wanted. "The only joke is that there's no there when you get there."

She discovered psychoanalysis, which she took, and still takes, very seriously. Perhaps it supplied a way of trying to find that core of human personality which seems so elusive when moving from culture to culture. A down-dragging grin stabs at the corner of her mouth when she says this. "I started doing some essayistic, journalistic writing."

Then she returned to Poland, to try and rediscover where she had come from and the language which once she had spoken.

"Poland had really obliged by staying really static", she says, conscious of the irony. Her successful friends now had cars, but communism had slowed the pace of change in most of the city. She found that her past had been conveniently relocated to a foreign country a manageable plane ride away; and so she wrote Lost in Translation. It was praised enormously from the moment of publication in 1989. Czeslaw Milosz called it "graceful and profound", an opinion which is worth having from a man whose memoirs of his own Lithuanian-Polish childhood had helped to win him the Nobel prize. Americans seem to have taken it as a story of how one becomes a successful American; outsiders as a story of how to keep your distance from the country. Foster says: "It is one of those books you keep on giving to people."

What makes it astonishing for a first book in a second language is the immediate, natural tone. She has brought to writing something of the same freshness that springs from the sort of unending discipline a classical pianist needs. It comes as a shock to discover that someone who writes English with such liquid and transparent grace has a pronounced Polish-American accent.

Her next book, Exit into History, was not a history of the revolutions in eastern Europe, but an examination of how particular lives had been changed by them. Some were friends of hers, but the most remarkable passages concerned former communists. The good ones tended to have been imprisoned. They had at least suffered for their beliefs, and so had their parents, at a time when communism was a faith full of hope. One story concerns a friend of Hoffman's generation who was imprisoned by the communists in 1968. Because the woman's father was a high-ranking communist, she was offered a pardon if she made an apology. Her father was allowed to visit her, and told her how he had been imprisoned as a communist by the pre-war Polish government, and had been offered an amnesty if he would disavow communism. He was then visited - the chain goes back into history - by his own father, who told him: "As you know, I am not a communist. I don't agree with you. But as for mercy, we don't plead for it."

So the friend knew what to do, and served her sentence out. Courage and style, Hoffman sees, have a value which quite outlasts the causes that they serve.

She did not really suffer under communism. One of the reasons she did not move back to Poland, when it became possible, was that, "My generation in Poland had such a shared experience of coming through things of history and I would be partially an outsider to that." None the less, her magnanimity towards the communists is astonishing. The true believers appear to her more comic than anything else, in their sudden dispossession. When they ruled the country, they were "Them" with a capital T. Robbed of their power, knocked down to a dismissive lower case, she still finds in the best of them some dignity. One Polish communist, aged 84, "puts me incongruously in mind of a minor character in one of Tolstoy's novels - an outmoded Enlightenment rationalist who has outlasted his time, and who continues to putter in his private laboratory, ignoring the world which has overtaken him, performing his pointless scientific experiments with great clarity of mind and sturdy cheerfulness".

She has just finished her first novel which will be published in the autumn. She won't say much about it, except that it is set in the near future and deals with a strong mother-daughter bond. But there is a sense in which all her work has been examining a novelist's questions.

The personal and the political are welded together in all her books and in all her characters. Her one subject is the way that the individual and society construct each other, just as the pianist and the music do.

Life at a glance

Eva Wydra Hoffman

Born: July 1 1945, Cracow, Poland.

Emigrated: 1959, Vancouver.

Education: MA English literature, Rice University, Texas, 1966; Yale School of Music 1967-68; PhD, Harvard, 1974.

Married: Barry Hoffman,1971 (divorced 1976).

Career: Worked New York Times 1980-90; Guggenheim fellowship; Visiting professor Massachusetts Institute of Technology, present; Visiting fellow, Townsend Centre, Berkeley, 2000; Visiting fellow, Clare Hall, Cambridge University, 2001; Amnesty Lecturer, Oxford University, 2001.

Some books: Lost in Translation, 1989; Exit into History, 1993; Shtetl, 1997.

But she flips the mirror so that she shares their intolerance. "The way, undoubtedly, that to some of them a Jew was a pure type, of greed, cleverness and manipulativeness. It's hard to believe that anyone so warm can be so self-contained." Surely she uprooted and came to London for love. "I wish I could say so but it's not the case. I wanted to be in Europe. There was always for me a fruitful tension about being in America, but I found I didn't want quite so much tension." At the time, she was studying psychoanalysis seriously. She had been introduced to the work of Freud in the 1980s when her reading group in New York chose one of his books. Then she was analysed in New York and in London started a training analysis, with a view to setting up in practice herself. "I thought I would see four patients every morning and write every afternoon," she says, and laughs at the ambition of the plan. "Her natural distinction reasserted itself and she returned to literature," says Foster. Yet her interest in the system remains deep: "Psychoanalysis seems to me to use the Socratic method. It leads us out of the cave of our own ignorance." She says: "I adore Freud." This is not the same as believing everything he said. But psychoanalysis, she says, has taken over many of the essential questions that used to be thought of as philosophical. It deals with the central questions of human life. Talking about the need to understand atrocities, she has said: "Tyrants and torturers go into therapy much less frequently than their subject and victims." In her recent lecture given on behalf of Amnesty International at Oxford, she quoted a South African torturer forced to explain himself before the truth and reconciliation commission. The man expressed shame or embarrassment only once: it was not when he was confronted with his victims, but when he had to admit that he had himself consulted a psychiatrist. She went on to say: "It is the victims who, in addition to the sufferings they have undergone, are left carrying the burdens of trauma and great loss. The perpetrators - especially the instigators of violence, at whose door the ultimate responsibility lies - seem to suffer such consequences much less. They may fear retribution but they continue to uphold the rightness of their conviction and to live in fair psychological health." When the camps empty, the survivors need counselling but the guards, if they get away, may live fairly happily ever after. The problem, she says, comes with the children of the guards. She has just finished her first novel which will be published in the autumn. She won't say much about it, except that it is set in the near future and deals with a strong mother-daughter bond. But there is a sense in which all her work has been examining a novelist's questions. The personal and the political are welded together in all her books and in all her characters. Her one subject is the way that the individual and society construct each other, just as the pianist and the music do. Life at a glance Eva Wydra Hoffman Born: July 1 1945, Cracow, Poland. Emigrated: 1959, Vancouver. Education: MA English literature, Rice University, Texas, 1966; Yale School of Music 1967-68; PhD, Harvard, 1974. Married: Barry Hoffman,1971 (divorced 1976). Career: Worked New York Times 1980-90; Guggenheim fellowship; Visiting professor Massachusetts Institute of Technology, present; Visiting fellow, Townsend Centre, Berkeley, 2000; Visiting fellow, Clare Hall, Cambridge University, 2001; Amnesty Lecturer, Oxford University, 2001. Some books: Lost in Translation, 1989; Exit into History, 1993; Shtetl, 1997.

fields.headline: All woman
fields.standfirst: Georgia O'Keeffe thought God was a woman. So, of course her art was wedded to the female principle, and the hell with phallic symbols. Sally Vincent hails an artist who has had the last laugh on her prurient critics

fields.body:
Georgia O'Keeffe was a woman of few words. Had verbal eloquence been her bag, doubtless she'd have talked up a storm and written screeds, since she clearly had a great deal to say and was not given to reticence or false modesty. She once remarked that she could see no reason for painting anything that might be put into any other form as well. So far as she was concerned, she would rather we looked at rather than read what she had to impart. She wasn't being dictatorial about it; "arting", as she called it, was just what she did best.

When she was an old lady, she wrote that her first memory was of light; the brightness of light, of light all around. An artist's sensibility, if you like. But when you think about it, nobody on earth could make a truer statement, unless they were either born in some way insensate or had determined for reasons of squeamishness to consign their personal experience of the universal birth trauma to oblivion. The biological fact is that you get squeezed through this pulsating chamber and suddenly there's a piercing, shaft-shaped blaze of light at the end of the tunnel that envelops you as you draw your first breath. Why would anyone forget such a drama? O'Keeffe remembered, which is probably why she thought "God" was a woman and didn't in the least mind when people thought she was a bit crazy. Still, she retained several of her more blatant manifestations of God's uterine potencies in her private collection until the day she died, doubtless in the knowledge that the world was not quite ready for them. She was probably right. The world is rarely ready for the likes of her.

O'Keeffe was born in 1887, the second child and first daughter of second-generation Americans, Irish on her father's side, Hungarian on her mother's. Five younger siblings, one boy and four girls, came later; seven being the average number of progeny for late-19th-century farming folk. She was not the favourite child, and she later confessed that she often craved the affection that her mother either withheld or gave elsewhere; at the same time, however, O'Keeffe appreciated that not being overly favoured gave her the freedom to find her own autonomy without undue pressures and expectations. She was lucky, too, to have been born into the strident light of Wisconsin, where very little need ever come between the mind's eye and the horizon but space, more space and the perspective of imagination. Her parents' peer group was the product of a pioneering spirit, men and women who distanced themselves from the oppressions and privations of their homelands, and who worked their socks off to create a brave new world. Reading about it, seeing it on the cinema screen, that part of American history always has a sort of Utopian edge to it. The sense of human co-operation between farming communities and members of large families, the prospect of social egalitarianism growing naturally from a life where everyone, man, woman and child must pull their weight for survival. And the whole thing held together by a simple, Episcopalian decency.

People like the O'Keeffes gathered in their sitting rooms after dark and entertained themselves by reading aloud the heroic literature of the day, stuff that gloried in romantic individualism: The Last Of The Mohicans, life of Hannibal, Stanley's adventures in Africa, tales to transcend the cloying concerns of sexual discrimination and male chauvinism. Wisconsin was the first American state to introduce women's suffrage. You can see why. Georgia was 13 when Freud discovered the subconscious mind; older still when Jung came up with the collective unconscious. Yet these things weren't inventions; they were already there, and always have been. Some people never needed to be told about them with words.

As she passed through childhood, Georgia experienced the longing for solitude common to members of large families. "I don't take easily to being with people," she once said. Her placement in the family gave her something of an advantage in that, as the oldest girl, she was expected to mind her younger siblings, a task that exempted her from strict obedience to those above her in the pecking order. So long as she kept the kids in hand, she was her own child. So far as her vision of her future was concerned, she was stuck in a culture where girls grew up to be wives and mothers - capable, accomplished, happy, loved, admirable women, but essentially wives and mothers. The worst-case scenario would be to grow up and not find a husband, in which case you would use your capabilities and accomplishments to teach other little girls how to achieve wife and mother status for the future glory of God and America. Georgia's options were well covered in this respect. She and her sisters were given paintboxes and coloured pencils to play with, and all but one of the O'Keeffe girls displayed a facility for making pretty pictures from an early age. When she was 11, such was her evident talent, her parents paid for her to have art lessons.

One of her earliest exercises in life class was to draw the figure of a stooping man. Always anxious to please - herself and her teachers - she did her best with the project, but was severely displeased with the result. There was, she thought, something absurdly unbalanced about her drawing. The man looked as though a puff of wind would bowl him over. She couldn't leave it alone. Then she turned her picture on its side and solved her problem. Balance restored, it was a picture of a man lying on the floor with his legs in the air. When she grew up, she said, she was going to be an artist! Children say things like that. I'm going to be a film star, an astronaut, the president. There are precedents for such ambitions, role models, possibilities - besides, you don't have to mean it. Georgia did mean it. And went on meaning it.

In her teens, the O'Keeffes resettled in Virginia. They believed, wrongly as it turned out, that they would escape the tuberculosis that was in the process of decimating their numbers. Georgia was sent to a girls' convent school where all the budding Scarlett O'Haras were amused and a little nonplussed by the new girl's resistance to their preoccupation with the bows and frills of femininity. It was as if Georgia knew that she was female as surely as she knew that the sun would rise, and so felt no great compulsion to gild the lily of her true nature. She plaited her thick, black, Irish hair and wore plain, severe jackets over plain, severe skirts. By the time she got to art school in Chicago, she presented a quaint, androgynous exterior that, far from repelling young men, drew them to her in droves. In common with many women who feel no need to be aggressively feminine as opposed to frankly female, she posed no immediate threat to the male ego. Young men befriended her, adored her, admired her and worshipped her.

At the same time, she was an exemplary student, an inveterate winner of prizes for technical excellence, yet the more she strove for perfection, the more constrained she felt, the further away from her dream of becoming an artist. The conflict of possibilities occupied her mind. Was she active or passive? When she agreed to pose for an art class, which in her generous way she often did, she was being passive. When she absorbed herself in her own canvas, regardless of the outcome, she was being active. She knew which she preferred. She sensed, too, that to love and be loved by a man involved a sexual commitment, a self-surrender that would effectively annihilate her creative spirit.

There is a wonderful account in Roxana Robinson's scholarly and insightful biography of O'Keeffe of the moment when these twin oppressions, men and academic convention, combined and exploded into one unforgettable moment of truth. As a young woman she spent a lot of time in upstate New York at Lake George, wandering alone, painting landscape after landscape. One day, she was joined there by a group of friends, at least two of whom were young men with designs on her. Unknown to each other, both swains suggested to Georgia that they row across the lake to buy groceries. She accepted each invitation and the trio set off, each man failing to disguise his irritation and frustration at the presence of the other. They moored their boat, grumpily bought their groceries and returned to the mooring, only to discover that someone had stolen their boat. This meant they had to trudge all the way around the lake, toting their groceries, to get home again. It was not a pleasant trek. As they walked, Georgia looked around herself at the familiar landscape, and as she did so she realised that it had taken on a dark, brooding, gloomy aspect she had never seen before. Later, she wrote to one of her sisters about her revelation: "How you feel affects what you see." And that was it. The big breakthrough. Emotional content overrides technique. "Nothing is less real than realism," she said in that pragmatic yet enigmatic way of hers.

There was still the problem of men. She was only 20 when she arrived at the Art Students' League, New York. Twenty, and beautiful in the heart-wrenching way young women can be when they haven't the faintest idea that that is what they are. Men wanted her. They wanted to take her out, dance with her, take her home to meet their mothers; they wanted to take her brush out of her hand, put her on their pedestals and paint her. They saw her work, they looked into her face and they told her she was Truth and Clarity and Purity. They said she was better than them. A higher form of life. And so she danced and posed, posed and danced for as long as it took to realise she was falling into passivity. Idealisation and idolisation are snares and delusions. Inevitably, to be the focus of such male projection makes you every bit as much of a victim as does ostracism.

Georgia pulled herself together. She read a book, the title of which she could never recall, which must have been the 20th century's first How-To manual. From it she learned that if you want to get the best out of life, you have first to know what you actually want before you can see how to achieve it, then learn the price you have to pay for getting what you want. It made sense to her. She bought herself a little notebook, wrote "Yes" on the left-hand page, "No" on the right, and set about the scrupulous business of self-determinism on a daily basis. When she taught, it was because she had to earn her own living. The decision went in the left-hand column. She went on "arting".

Her first one-woman show appeared at Alfred Stieglitz's temple of modern art, the 291 Gallery, so named for its location at that number, Fifth Avenue. It was 1917. O'Keeffe was 29. Stieglitz, for better or worse, was in love with her. Twenty years her senior, he was a married man and a father. He was probably the first photographer to bring photography into contention as an art form, a move that, despite the extraordinary quality of his work, earned him rather more kicks than ha'pence from the conventionally entrenched art world's critical establishment. He perceived himself as a sort of impresario of all that was alive and kicking, high priest of the avant-garde, promulgator of hidden talent, reaper of delicate plants - Svengali to O'Keeffe's Trilby. The immediate response to that first show essentially created a template for art critics wishing to comprehend and classify O'Keeffe for the next 70 years.

Typical of the male-oriented reaction was one Henry Tyrrell, writing in the deeply respectable Christian Science Monitor, who found himself struggling between his frank admiration for her technical ability and some kind of personal fantasy induced by his emotional response to the content of her work. "Miss O'Keeffe," he wrote, "has found expression in delicately veiled symbolism for 'what every woman knows' but what women heretofore have kept to themselves, either instinctively or through a universal conspiracy of silence." He couldn't leave it alone. He goes on to build himself a fantasy about her based on nothing but his gut-reaction to her pictures, in which he concludes that her natural temperament must have been informed by loneliness, privation and suffering. She was, after all, A Woman Artist, a thing unheard of, eternally esoteric and destined for punishment, whether before or after the event.

It was as A Woman Artist that Stieglitz successfully promoted O'Keeffe throughout the 20s and 30s. Her paintings were, and remain, inimitably female. The earth and rocks of her landscapes undulated like human flesh, her plants and flowers were uterine, labial, vulval, clitoral creatures; she was innocent as a petunia. In the early throes of her affair with Stieglitz, she allowed him to take a series of photographs of her body that made landscape of flesh much as her paintings made flesh of landscape. They also contributed tiresomely to her personal notoriety. The scandal of Mrs Stieglitz walking into her boudoir one day to discover her husband and O'Keeffe in the flagrant act of photographing and being photographed upon the matrimonial bed didn't help. Mrs S threw her husband out, bag and baggage, thus taking full responsibility for putting him exactly where he'd wanted to be for years, while Georgia, poor Georgia, was more or less morally railroaded into doing the only decent thing and marrying the fellow.

In her Yes/No account book, she doubtless noted the price she must pay for their union, and she afforded it with good grace until the day Alfred died.

Meanwhile, the 20s roared on in New York City. The movers and shakers found a new game to play as Freudian theories of sexual symbolism began to lap in from Europe. Old Sigmund carefully explained to his students in Vienna that the cigar he was smoking was only a cigar, nothing to get excited about, but they didn't hear him in America. The intellectually challenged went on a sort of witch-hunt for subconscious sexual symbolisms arising from repressed and perverted minds, which might, unchecked, sully the entire nation.

Emerging from her most intense period of flower painting, O'Keeffe exhibited in New York to an audience of self-appointed Freudianists. Suddenly, the entire art establishment ganged up to bawl in unison, "These are not phallic symbols", as though she had committed the greatest heresy in the history of art. The phallus simply was the aesthetic shape of all that was true and beautiful in the civilised world, so much went without saying or interpreting. And this woman had gazed into the unspeakable folds of an arum lily and challenged the supremacy of the power structure that holds us all together. These were not depictions of Nature at Her most flamboyant, nor erotic images stemming from an intractably female mind-set; this was Pornography.

O'Keeffe was pestered to defend herself and could not. She was damned if she did, damned if she didn't. Part of the Freudian doctrine suggested that to deny an accusation meant you were doubly guilty of the charge and - as in the current psychobabble - "in denial".

In her gentle way, O'Keeffe remonstrated to the effect that, perhaps, people were merely presuming that what they read into her flowers was what she had written in them, and that she had done no such thing. Others reasoned that the botanical facts of, say, a wild orchid were not Miss O'Keeffe's fault and that the eye of the beholder should cease to search for a scapegoat. It all got so silly that O'Keeffe eventually refused to comment at all. "Oh," she'd say when invited, "not that rubbish."

In the second half of her life, O'Keeffe found her spiritual home in the unadulterated vastness of New Mexico. She expressed her antipathy towards modernity in general and city life and male oppression in particular in a painting of a worm's eye view of skyscrapers raping an innocent night sky. Perhaps it was the cock she snooked at her detractors, as in "How's this for phallic symbolism?", but she was not a natural ironist and it is not her best work, bordering as it does on the merely decorative.

The coincidence of widowhood and middle age offered her new freedom from compromise. The horizontal peacefulness of desert plains gave her the perspective she longed for, and her work somehow exchanged depth for breadth in terms of emotional content. Her fascination with rocks, stones and bones and objets trouvés of desert wastes was one focus, the call of space and light another. As she grew older, she delighted in flying in aeroplanes, partly to travel to other spaces and lights, partly to view the horizon from a whole new vantage point. She'd touch down after a flight unable to wait to get out her easel: this time she understood how clouds behave, this time she knew how sand scintillates, this time she really, really had seen the light.

She was famous, she was rich, she was a legend. As she turned 80, then 90, she hoped, she amused, that she might possibly make a century of herself. She had reason to believe, if she ever dwelt on such matters, that she was off the hook of prurient speculation into her supposedly aberrant erotic field-force. And then a young man came knocking on her door. Sixty years her junior, John Hamilton was a bohemian drifter, a dropout from a middle-class, educated background, a disaffected American who called himself "Juan" and lived by casual labour. Anyway, the 30-year-old Juan met the 90-year-old O'Keeffe and swiftly made himself indispensable to her. The solitary, ailing nonagenarian acquired muscle-power and an un-selfconscious, friendly garrison figure; the wandering boy found a use for himself, stability and the affection of a wise and rather wonderful friend. The scandalmongers didn't see it that way. They saw the ultimate in sexual aberrance, a handsome gigolo in thrall to a geriatric siren who, in photographs, now began to resemble the stubbornly defiant Big Chief Sitting Bull.

O'Keeffe was sanguine enough with the situation to let them get on with their twittering without comment from her. Juan, silly boy, would occasionally shape up to them with specious ramblings about how it would be if he was a girl and O'Keeffe an old man, which tended to make things still muddier. "She likes me," was one sensible thing he said of their friendship, "because I never put her on a pedestal."

As an artist who continued to paint well into her 80s, when failing eyesight moved her in a more sculptural direction, O'Keeffe's work developed far, far beyond those sexually explicit botanical adventures and into a deeper, more ethereal relationship with the natural world. Which is more than can be said for her more determined detractors.

In 1946, for instance, the critic Clement Greenberg took male chauvinism to its logical conclusion in his review of the O'Keeffe retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. "The importance of Georgia O'Keeffe's pseudo-modern art," he wrote, "is almost entirely historical and symptomatic. The errors it exhibits are significant because of the time and place and context in which they were made. Otherwise her art has very little inherent value. The deftness and precision of her brush and the neatness with which she places a picture inside its frame exerts a certain inevitable charm which may explain her popularity; and some of her architectural subjects may have even more than charm - but the greatest part of her work adds up to little more than tinted photography. The lapidarian patience she has expended in trimming, breathing upon and polishing these bits of opaque cellophane betrays a concern that has less to do with art than with private worship and the embellishment of private fetishes with secret and arbitrary meaning."

What Greenberg had no way of knowing, besides how to tread softly on dreams, was that O'Keeffe had another 40 years of private worship still to come and that her mark on American culture is indelible. Not that she would have minded one way or another. As she once remarked in a moment of rare loquacity, "I see my little world as something that I am in - something that I play in. It is inevitable to me. But I never get over being surprised that it means something to anyone else."

O'Keeffe's O'Keeffes: The Artist's Collection, by Barbara Buhler Lynes & Russell Bowman, is published by Thames & Hudson, priced £29.95. To order a copy at the special price of £25.95, plus £1.99 first-class p&p, freephone CultureShop on 0800 316 6102.

From it she learned that if you want to get the best out of life, you have first to know what you actually want before you can see how to achieve it, then learn the price you have to pay for getting what you want. It made sense to her. She bought herself a little notebook, wrote "Yes" on the left-hand page, "No" on the right, and set about the scrupulous business of self-determinism on a daily basis. When she taught, it was because she had to earn her own living. The decision went in the left-hand column. She went on "arting". Her first one-woman show appeared at Alfred Stieglitz's temple of modern art, the 291 Gallery, so named for its location at that number, Fifth Avenue. It was 1917. O'Keeffe was 29. Stieglitz, for better or worse, was in love with her. Twenty years her senior, he was a married man and a father. He was probably the first photographer to bring photography into contention as an art form, a move that, despite the extraordinary quality of his work, earned him rather more kicks than ha'pence from the conventionally entrenched art world's critical establishment. He perceived himself as a sort of impresario of all that was alive and kicking, high priest of the avant-garde, promulgator of hidden talent, reaper of delicate plants - Svengali to O'Keeffe's Trilby. The immediate response to that first show essentially created a template for art critics wishing to comprehend and classify O'Keeffe for the next 70 years. Typical of the male-oriented reaction was one Henry Tyrrell, writing in the deeply respectable Christian Science Monitor, who found himself struggling between his frank admiration for her technical ability and some kind of personal fantasy induced by his emotional response to the content of her work. "Miss O'Keeffe," he wrote, "has found expression in delicately veiled symbolism for 'what every woman knows' but what women heretofore have kept to themselves, either instinctively or through a universal conspiracy of silence." He couldn't leave it alone. He goes on to build himself a fantasy about her based on nothing but his gut-reaction to her pictures, in which he concludes that her natural temperament must have been informed by loneliness, privation and suffering. She was, after all, A Woman Artist, a thing unheard of, eternally esoteric and destined for punishment, whether before or after the event. It was as A Woman Artist that Stieglitz successfully promoted O'Keeffe throughout the 20s and 30s. Her paintings were, and remain, inimitably female. The earth and rocks of her landscapes undulated like human flesh, her plants and flowers were uterine, labial, vulval, clitoral creatures; she was innocent as a petunia. In the early throes of her affair with Stieglitz, she allowed him to take a series of photographs of her body that made landscape of flesh much as her paintings made flesh of landscape. They also contributed tiresomely to her personal notoriety. The scandal of Mrs Stieglitz walking into her boudoir one day to discover her husband and O'Keeffe in the flagrant act of photographing and being photographed upon the matrimonial bed didn't help. Mrs S threw her husband out, bag and baggage, thus taking full responsibility for putting him exactly where he'd wanted to be for years, while Georgia, poor Georgia, was more or less morally railroaded into doing the only decent thing and marrying the fellow. In her Yes/No account book, she doubtless noted the price she must pay for their union, and she afforded it with good grace until the day Alfred died. Meanwhile, the 20s roared on in New York City. The movers and shakers found a new game to play as Freudian theories of sexual symbolism began to lap in from Europe. Old Sigmund carefully explained to his students in Vienna that the cigar he was smoking was only a cigar, nothing to get excited about, but they didn't hear him in America. The intellectually challenged went on a sort of witch-hunt for subconscious sexual symbolisms arising from repressed and perverted minds, which might, unchecked, sully the entire nation. Emerging from her most intense period of flower painting, O'Keeffe exhibited in New York to an audience of self-appointed Freudianists. Suddenly, the entire art establishment ganged up to bawl in unison, "These are not phallic symbols", as though she had committed the greatest heresy in the history of art. The phallus simply was the aesthetic shape of all that was true and beautiful in the civilised world, so much went without saying or interpreting. And this woman had gazed into the unspeakable folds of an arum lily and challenged the supremacy of the power structure that holds us all together. These were not depictions of Nature at Her most flamboyant, nor erotic images stemming from an intractably female mind-set; this was Pornography. O'Keeffe was pestered to defend herself and could not. She was damned if she did, damned if she didn't. Part of the Freudian doctrine suggested that to deny an accusation meant you were doubly guilty of the charge and - as in the current psychobabble - "in denial". In her gentle way, O'Keeffe remonstrated to the effect that, perhaps, people were merely presuming that what they read into her flowers was what she had written in them, and that she had done no such thing. Others reasoned that the botanical facts of, say, a wild orchid were not Miss O'Keeffe's fault and that the eye of the beholder should cease to search for a scapegoat. It all got so silly that O'Keeffe eventually refused to comment at all. "Oh," she'd say when invited, "not that rubbish." In the second half of her life, O'Keeffe found her spiritual home in the unadulterated vastness of New Mexico. She expressed her antipathy towards modernity in general and city life and male oppression in particular in a painting of a worm's eye view of skyscrapers raping an innocent night sky. Perhaps it was the cock she snooked at her detractors, as in "How's this for phallic symbolism?", but she was not a natural ironist and it is not her best work, bordering as it does on the merely decorative. The coincidence of widowhood and middle age offered her new freedom from compromise. The horizontal peacefulness of desert plains gave her the perspective she longed for, and her work somehow exchanged depth for breadth in terms of emotional content. Her fascination with rocks, stones and bones and objets trouvés of desert wastes was one focus, the call of space and light another. As she grew older, she delighted in flying in aeroplanes, partly to travel to other spaces and lights, partly to view the horizon from a whole new vantage point. She'd touch down after a flight unable to wait to get out her easel: this time she understood how clouds behave, this time she knew how sand scintillates, this time she really, really had seen the light. She was famous, she was rich, she was a legend. As she turned 80, then 90, she hoped, she amused, that she might possibly make a century of herself. She had reason to believe, if she ever dwelt on such matters, that she was off the hook of prurient speculation into her supposedly aberrant erotic field-force. And then a young man came knocking on her door. Sixty years her junior, John Hamilton was a bohemian drifter, a dropout from a middle-class, educated background, a disaffected American who called himself "Juan" and lived by casual labour. Anyway, the 30-year-old Juan met the 90-year-old O'Keeffe and swiftly made himself indispensable to her. The solitary, ailing nonagenarian acquired muscle-power and an un-selfconscious, friendly garrison figure; the wandering boy found a use for himself, stability and the affection of a wise and rather wonderful friend. The scandalmongers didn't see it that way. They saw the ultimate in sexual aberrance, a handsome gigolo in thrall to a geriatric siren who, in photographs, now began to resemble the stubbornly defiant Big Chief Sitting Bull. O'Keeffe was sanguine enough with the situation to let them get on with their twittering without comment from her. Juan, silly boy, would occasionally shape up to them with specious ramblings about how it would be if he was a girl and O'Keeffe an old man, which tended to make things still muddier. "She likes me," was one sensible thing he said of their friendship, "because I never put her on a pedestal." As an artist who continued to paint well into her 80s, when failing eyesight moved her in a more sculptural direction, O'Keeffe's work developed far, far beyond those sexually explicit botanical adventures and into a deeper, more ethereal relationship with the natural world. Which is more than can be said for her more determined detractors. In 1946, for instance, the critic Clement Greenberg took male chauvinism to its logical conclusion in his review of the O'Keeffe retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. "The importance of Georgia O'Keeffe's pseudo-modern art," he wrote, "is almost entirely historical and symptomatic. The errors it exhibits are significant because of the time and place and context in which they were made. Otherwise her art has very little inherent value. The deftness and precision of her brush and the neatness with which she places a picture inside its frame exerts a certain inevitable charm which may explain her popularity; and some of her architectural subjects may have even more than charm - but the greatest part of her work adds up to little more than tinted photography. The lapidarian patience she has expended in trimming, breathing upon and polishing these bits of opaque cellophane betrays a concern that has less to do with art than with private worship and the embellishment of private fetishes with secret and arbitrary meaning." What Greenberg had no way of knowing, besides how to tread softly on dreams, was that O'Keeffe had another 40 years of private worship still to come and that her mark on American culture is indelible. Not that she would have minded one way or another. As she once remarked in a moment of rare loquacity, "I see my little world as something that I am in - something that I play in. It is inevitable to me. But I never get over being surprised that it means something to anyone else." webTitle: Review: A History of Celibacy by Elizabeth Abbott

fields.headline: The opposite of sex
fields.standfirst: Hywel Williams  curls up with A History of Celibacy by Elizabeth Abbott
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams curls up with A History of Celibacy by Elizabeth Abbott
fields.body:
A History of Celibacy
Elizabeth Abbott
448pp, The Lutterworth Press, £15
Buy it at a discount at BOL

What do you do with an early-medieval girl called Uncumber? Her father, a pagan Portuguese ruler, found a Sicilian king to take her off his hands. But Uncumber wasn't like the other girls. Her mother was a Christian, and the daughter wanted to stay a virgin: power politics collided with the sage and serious business of chastity. But Uncumber, the Morrissey of her age, knew that the advertised absence of sex was a powerful weapon. And so she grew a beard. Confronted by a follically enhanced virgin on the eve of his marriage, the Sicilian sailed away. The princess's victory is, allegedly, memorialised in our "unencumber".

It was victory at a price: crucifixion. However, since martyrdom offers cultic charms, Uncumber had her hairy followers in death. Medieval bearded ladies - saints on the make - took over where she left off. Paula of Avila sprouted a particularly fetid growth as a weapon in her armoury. Militant Teresa of the same town would have known of Paula as a role model - the local girl kept good or, at any rate, chaste. These and others of the gang questioned what was "natural" in a counter-revolution of the mind and body executed with charismatic poise. The comfortable equation of Christianity and of Judaism with sugary family values ignores these fierce forms of dissidence and emancipation. Modern liberals - even in the age of the STD - find the virgin with a cause equally hard to take.

The point about celibacy, either imposed and cruel or chosen and free, is that it is unnatural: a withdrawal from the chain of procreation. It also rejects the idea that there is some other half waiting in the wings to make complete that which is divided and forlorn. Therein lies its appeal, its power and its offence: it can both empower the self and wither it. Un-sex can be sexy too - and not just through the promise of gratification deferred.

Italian castrati made themselves eunuchs both for art's sake and for jobs in baroque Rome. But these fundamentalist celibates were only the latest in a long line linking sexual denial with power display. The first eunuchs are seen in the courts of ancient Persia and recur in both Byzantium and the Forbidden City. Those without families proved more loyal to rulers than men who dallied with the hope of establishing dynasties for their progeny.

Is celibacy creative? The ideology of spermatic economy insists that it is, maintaining that no drop may be spilt if greatness is to be achieved. The Greeks called the penis "the necessity"- and most of us are the heirs of Hellas in this regard. But their medicine men, such as Pythagoras and Galen, thought that there was only so much of the stuff around, so it was best to look after it. When Balzac groaned post-coitally "there goes another novel", he was subscribing to an old code.

The gods of the field incline with the solitaries of the study. Peruvian soccer fans still blame their 1982 World Cup loss to Poland on those players who broke the ban on pre-match sex. Indian wrestlers, the pahalwans , are life-long celibates as well as full-time sportsmen and get in a terrible state over the tiniest nocturnal emission. For Hinduism, also the sexiest of religions, agrees with Galen that semen is the essence of life. Hence the "langot", a G-string trussing the wrestlers' genitalia up between their legs. Happily, the players' regular hashish consumption may ease this particular pain. But the changing-room authorities seem to be evolving: Glenn Hoddle listened to the spirits and allowed England players their girlfriends during the 1998 World Cup.

Celibacy can be just misery. Newton went on an 18-month depressive rebound from a 23-year-old Swiss. Deprived of dishy Fatio, who sensibly refused to move to Cambridge, Newton lost his early creativity. As Master of the Royal Mint, he displayed a rather anal concern with guarding the nation's currency and prosecuted counterfeiters with unwonted savagery. But Gandhi showed all the manipulativeness of a Middle Temple lawyer in using celibacy as a way of testing himself and of teasing the teenage girls, whom he alternately slept with and dispatched back to the village. For the Mahatma, sex meant always having to say sorry. One memory haunted him - that of seizing a brief session with his wife and thereby missing the death of his terminally ill father.

Elizabeth Abbott mixes anthropology with history in her confection of insights. We discover Athenian women going on a three-day binge every autumn, gleefully burying models of male genitalia. Here also are rich Babylonian women going one further and creating life-long communities of celibates who ran their own estates and traded in silver; Aztec aristocratic males with pierced penises preserved from contact; the Enga society in New Guinea, whose bachelors are fined a pig for mentioning sex in conversation. The pages of Abbott's lucid, exciting book throb with both life and its denial.

The emphasis is on the feminist-liberal-Christian end of things. Joan of Arc - whose sin was her cross-dressing - is a particular heroine, as is that crazed and cross 12th-century power-broker (as well as literary and musical genius), Abbess Hildegard of Bingen. What Abbott has done, in effect, is to write a history of civilisation from one particular angle, gliding through world civilisations with a compelling ease. There is plenty of anecdotage along the way to ease the journey. There is anger too - as in the account of Chinese foot-binding, where fashion statements colluded with masculine control as tiny feet were sucked, nibbled and stroked for more than 1,000 years until the official prohibition in 1906. Clerical celibacy comes in for some special anger, with Abbott's focus on the treatment of the 1970s "Third Way" movement, full of sophistry, as such movements tend to be: nuns and priests were allowed to date, neck and pet without sex. But it is a strength of her moving and dazzling achievement that Abbott is never conventional, preachy or platitudinous. Like all good history, her book is a signpost to the strangeness of a world that has such deviance in it.

webTitle: Review: The Madness of Adam and Eve by David Horrobin

fields.headline: The human stain
fields.standfirst: The Madness of Adam and Eve by David Horrobin asks the question: did schizophrenia make us sapient? By  John McCrone
fields.trailText: The Madness of Adam and Eve by David Horrobin asks the question: did schizophrenia make us sapient? By John McCrone
fields.body:
The Madness of Adam and Eve: How Schizophrenia Shaped Humanity
David Horrobin
275pp, Bantam Press, £18.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Do the shelves have room for one more bonkers theory about how apes became human? You know the story: for millions of years we were big-brained but dull-witted hominids. Then, about 100,000 years ago, our brains were touched as if by a burning finger and we lit up with self-consciousness and creativity. We immediately started painting caves and worshipping gods, and became rational. The question is: what could have caused this abrupt change?

Well, here is a suggestion to wet your socks: the first humans were schizophrenic. A small band of smart apes lived by a lakeshore in east Africa on a diet rich in fats, which allowed their brains to grow very large. Then a genetic defect in fat metabolism led to one child having faulty brain connections; the signalling became slightly variable. The result was a brain prone to schizophrenia, psychopathy and mania, but also creativity, curiosity and ambition. As David Horrobin imagines it, this child with "a divine discontent with the way things were" spawned a family of proto-Medicis, brilliant and ruthless, who slaughtered their neighbours and spread out to rule the world.

Then comes a second part to the story. The founding of civilisation resulted in another big change in diet, initially to farmed grains and later to the high animal-fat consumption of modern times. Thus those individuals with schizoid genes (who tended to form the ruling classes) were no longer getting the right fats, so their brain-wiring really did start to go wrong. No longer were they simply touched with a little creative madness, but they had to be locked up in asylums. And guess what? Simply taking fish-oil capsules might cure modern schizophrenia - and depression, criminality, dyslexia and much else besides.

It would be easy to mock, except that Horrobin happens to be one of our finest original thinkers in medicine - and promising clinical trials of the fish-oil treatment (eicosapentaenoic acid) are taking place right now. Horrobin's life story is a tale in itself. He was a professor of medicine researching the role of essential fatty acids in human health when a sudden revelation led to the schizophrenia theory, which he published in 1979. Thunderstruck to find that no one was interested, he started his own drugs company, whose first big product was evening primrose oil - a fatty-acid treatment now used to treat ailments as wide-ranging as premenstrual syndrome, multiple sclerosis and eczema. He now has a new start-up with a new range of diseases in his sights.

So is his book just advertising for a coming range of fish-oil treatments? Well, if the capsules work as well as he claims, the world will be beating a path to his door anyway. What he really wants to do is to shake up the staid thought processes of conventional science.

His book is brightly written and certainly deserves to be read. But it is one thing to claim that schizophrenia is a legacy of our hominid heritage, and quite another to say it was the essential spark that made us human. The truth is that the schizophrenic brain makes disorganised connections, not creative ones. And Horrobin barely mentions the more usual explanation for what made Homo sapiens different - the evolution of grammatical speech and the highly organised thinking that goes with it. Instead, his contrary streak leads him always to shun the obvious and see an adaptive advantage when things go wrong. So, dyslexia was the crucial step needed to produce a few skilled tool-makers in each tribe; psychopathology created a pioneering spirit; a tendency towards paranoia was essential for intricate patterns of thought. His revisionism makes exciting reading, but clouds the issue of how the brain actually functions.

The book also has a huge hole in its central premise. Horrobin never spells out how a faulty fat metabolism could change the connectivity of a schizophrenic brain. He assembles much circumstantial evidence that the fats that make up cell membranes are an important part of any explanation of schizophrenia, and probably any cure. But he is always vague about that final, clinching step of how the neural machinery is changed.

John McCrone wrote Going Inside: A Tour Around a Single Moment of Consciousness.
