webTitle: Review: Enduring Creation: Art, Pain and Fortitude by Nigel Spivey

fields.headline: For the delight of vultures
fields.standfirst: Why do we enjoy looking at pictures of pain? Andrew Miller examines Enduring Creation: Art, Pain and Fortitude by Nigel Spivey
fields.trailText: Why do we enjoy looking at pictures of pain? Andrew Miller examines Enduring Creation: Art, Pain and Fortitude by Nigel Spivey
fields.body:
Enduring Creation: Art, Pain and Fortitude
Nigel Spivey
272pp, Thames & Hudson, £24.95
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Nigel Spivey's ambitious study of the relationship between suffering and its depiction in art opens with a visit by the author to the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camps. Here, in the judgment of the critic Theodor Adorno, events of such magnitude and vileness occurred that afterwards there could be no more painting or poetry, no culture, no art. "Alle Kultur nach Auschwitz . . . ist Müll" - trash. Enduring Creation is, in part, Spivey's attempt to argue art free from its supposed terminus in the final solution - to show how it retains, in spite of the extravagance of our crimes, the power to civilise.

After such a charged and somewhat self-conscious beginning (but then, how do you write about visiting Auschwitz?), the book assumes a more settled and scholarly manner with the consideration of a masterpiece of the classical world, the sculpture of the Trojan priest Laocoon (he who was wary of Greeks bearing gifts). Spivey describes this work, fashioned by unknown hands between 2BC and AD1, as "the prototypical icon of human agony". Condemned by Apollo, the priest stretches out in a perfection of well-muscled torment that post-classical admirers have saluted as an exemplary depiction of heroic suffering and endurance intended, surely, to conjure in the observer an ennobling sense of pity. Yet to a contemporary audience, the piece may have been not an incitement to pathos but a satisfying illustration of how the gods justly punish the impiety of mortals. There was a shrine to pity in classical Athens, but it was, apparently, a small one. Plato thought that pity sullied reason.

Whatever the sculpture may have meant to its first audience, the outlines of the priest's agony were to reappear in the work of numerous Renaissance painters (the sculpture was excavated at Rome in 1506). Now, however, the context is thoroughly Christian. Suffering has moved on; suffering is victory. These paintings served as props to faith: educative, inspirational, the focuses of veneration in churches and chapter houses across Europe. Spivey devotes half the book to the contemplation of Christian art, from the earliest crucifixion pieces - the cross was unseen for 500 years after the death of Christ - to the myriad depictions of martyrdom (roastings, disembowelments, mutilations, stonings, impalements etc), and finally to a comparison of the many versions of that biblical spine-tingler, the massacre of the innocents. Guido Reni, Raphael, Tintoretto and Nicolas Poussin all painted versions of the fabled slaughter, Poussin's canvas having, according to Francis Bacon, the best scream ever painted. But it is Brueghel's version (circa 1566), set in a contemporary Netherlands with soldiers garbed as Spanish halberdiers, that seems, with its air of mingled violence and normality, the most unnerving, the most likely.

One 17th-century owner of a Brueghel "massacre" canvas had the more upsetting parts painted out: some things we don't want to look at. How realistic, how blunt, should an artist allow himself to be in the depiction of what is most disturbing? Spivey relates how in the 19th century Théodore Géricault observed wasted bodies in Paris hospitals and filled his studio with the limbs of executed criminals in an attempt to bring authenticity to his epic The Raft of the Medusa , a painting of the survivors of a shipwreck off the west coast of Africa. Displayed in the Paris Salon, it was dismissed by one critic as "a work for the delight of vultures".

On the other side of the Pyrenees, a court painter was busy pushing back the boundaries of the drawable, though on a more intimate scale. Unfettered by considerations of public exhibition, Francisco de Goya sketched the realities of the Peninsular war in a series known as The Disasters of War . He did not directly witness all that he set down in his sketchbooks (those horrors he did see are marked " Yo lo vi "), but the authenticity of his work as a record of what people performed upon each other in that protracted conflict is not in doubt. In private work, of course, the question of what such images were intended to provoke is redundant: artists, contrary to popular belief, are not necessarily interested in communicating anything at all. The etchings are a record of the times. Such things occurred. Why would an artist of Goya's energy and honesty avoid such subjects?

In our own age, news footage and photojournalism have given us a certain casual, second-hand familiarity with the disasters of war. Spivey has interesting material on the early war photographers such as Roger Fenton, who was sent to the Crimea in 1855 with strict instructions to take no pictures of dead or wounded men, but who nonetheless conveyed something of the grimness of the campaign through barren, cannonball-strewn landscapes, photographs "rendered elegiac by understatement". No such restraint can be found in the work of Fenton's counterpart in north America: Mathew Brady's civil-war photos are as explicit as anything we have been fed more recently from Bosnia or Kosovo. They are a bold effort to show what had not generally been seen other than by those caught directly in the rip-path of fighting: the real character of a war, how inglorious it is, and how sad.

But there is a problem here; Spivey, "the bewildered liberal soul", is uneasy. How pure is our regard of these images? Is it all noble pathos, the pictures instructing us in right perception, helping us, through some mysterious transaction, to be larger, sweeter people? What is the full character of our reaction to Brueghel's Massacre of the Innocents , or Singer Sargent's 1919 depiction of gassed soldiers on the western front, or, God help us, the anonymous pictures of crumpled, frightened families arriving at Auschwitz to a fate of which they were still ignorant, but which we know?

There must, of course, be some clinical insight, and Freud provides something of the kind in his essay published after the first world war, " Das Unheimliche " (The Unhomely), in which he considers the curious and persistent human desire to entertain ourselves with the sensation of fear. Repression, he argues, makes the direct contemplation of our deaths impossible for us, so we peep at mortality in, for example, the nightmare canvases of Fuseli or the novels of P D James. As we are both safe and alive, the whiff of mayhem stimulates without traumatising. We need, it seems, a sense of what is coming if we are to enjoy life at its proper pitch. In 1915, as the casualty figures were beginning to impress upon the world the magnitude of the carnage unleashed by a bullet in Sarajevo, Freud wrote: "Life has become interesting again; it has recovered its full content."

But back to Theodor Adorno. What did he mean, really? That we cannot trust art when the executioners themselves seemed to place such a premium upon it? (Hitler, of course, started out as a painter, and to the end of his life had a genuine passion for architecture.) Or was it just a general expression of nihilism, a feeling that the Holocaust had seared all sense and meaning from the world - 2,000 years of western art leading only to the crematoria?

"Adorno," writes Spivey, "never had the intellectual largesse to admit what we must reclaim as a durable truth: that 'culture' is a salve of our being." We are not - he cites as evidence Colin Turnbull's study of the Ik people in Uganda - naturally compassionate. Pity for our fellows is something we must be taught, and the depiction of the pitiful in art is one of the ways in which this is achieved, though paraphrasing Spivey in such a manner does little justice to the intelligence and density of this book. There are many fascinating insights here: I particularly valued the chapter on Rembrandt's self-portraiture and the 17th-century vogue for melancholy. The illustrations, an average of two a page, are a plentiful mix of the familiar and the less so. He writes extremely well, and despite an occasional weakness for alliteration ("the moguls of modern media", etc), most of the book has an enviable fluency and wit. This is a genuinely scholarly work, but also a very personal one; a heart-piece that makes of its difficult subject matter something urgent and relevant and brave.

fields.headline: Casualty of a cultural coup
fields.standfirst: Sofia Imber created a first-class museum of contemporary art in Caracas - so why has the Venezuelan president fired her?
fields.trailText: Sofia Imber created a first-class museum of contemporary art in Caracas - so why has the Venezuelan president fired her?
fields.body:
The museum she built from scratch, and directed for more than 25 years, continues to bear her name and imprint, at least for the moment. But Sofia Imber has become the most prominent victim and symbol of the "cultural revolution" unleashed by the president of Venezuela, Hugo Chavez, in his campaign to free the country from a "rancid oligarchy".

Imber, a 76-year-old art critic, founded the Caracas Museum of Contemporary Art in 1971 in a garage. She built it into one of Latin America's most admired arts institutions, with a collection that includes major works by Picasso, Braque, Botero, Bacon, Chagall, Kandinsky and Rauschenberg. But somewhere along the line she fell foul of Chavez, a left-wing populist who took power in 1999 with ideas of his own about the proper role of the arts.

"Culture has become elitist as a result of being managed by elites," he complained in January on a weekly radio programme he hosts. "Princes, kings, heirs, families took over institutions, institutions that have cost the state millions and millions. They wanted to do whatever they wanted. They thought they were autonomous governments, principalities."

Chavez has described the subsequent purge of Imber and others as the start of a "Bolivarian cultural revolution", a reference to Venezuela's national hero, Simon Bolivar. But that term has generated apprehension, especially in view of Chavez's declaration: "I am a Maoist", made during the visit this month of President Jiang Zemin of China.

Last year, Chavez appointed Manuel Espinoza, 64, a former Communist party member and painter, as director of the country's national council of culture.

In an interview, Espinoza said that Chavez's summons to a "cultural revolution" should be no cause for alarm. "It is a mistake to tie a word to a particular historical experience," he said. "Revolutions are not defined just by China's deplorable experience, and if you look up the word in the dictionary you will find no reference to China there. What we want is a transformation, a rapid change that liberates the creative potential of all the people."

As part of that process, Espinoza said that the government had begun building community cultural centres in rural and provincial areas. The government's cultural budget is also being increased by more than $100m (£69.5m), twice as much as under the previous government.

But "redefining culture," as Espinoza calls it, also involves shifting the focus away from the fine arts toward artisanship and other forms of expression with a practical political purpose. "It is necessary for the state to stimulate the creative powers of the people so as to encourage their participation in the process of social mobilisation and integration," he says.

Little is known about Chavez's tastes in the arts, other than his habit of singing folk songs or quoting the poetry of Walt Whitman during his speeches, but his views on the relationship between politics and culture could not be clearer.

"Culture needs to be at the service of development, not at the service of elites which have led a distorted cultural process," he said in a recent speech. Speaking of his government and its policies, he said he aspired to "a culture that is at the service of the human revolution, of creation, of the liberation of the Venezuelan people".

Chavez's purge has affected all 36 government cultural institutions, from museums and orchestras to theatre groups and the state publishing house, Espinoza says. But the ousting of Imber as the head of a museum that added her name to its title a decade ago in homage to her work is seen by Chavez's critics as emblematic of the increasingly sectarian nature of the revolutionary process.

"I think this museum is not to their liking because they only want art that is nationalistic and patriotic," says Imber, who was born in Russia and came to Venezuela as a child. "In a certain way, they are right when they say that the art at my museum is elite and cosmopolitan, because I have always believed that when you give people something good, something that elevates their taste, they like it."

But under Imber's stewardship, the museum has also run programmes to take art to the city's slums and to bring poor children to the museum for art classes. In addition, admission to the museum, as it is to most cultural institutions in Venezuela, is free - a legacy of the oil boom of the 1970s, which led to lavish government spending on the arts.

Imber's work at the museum and her efforts to promote 20th-century Latin American and Spanish art made her an important cultural figure throughout the continent. Several foreign governments have awarded her medals, and in 1998 she won Unesco's Picasso prize.

"This is a world-class museum with a first-class collection that she assembled. Plus it's well managed, beautifully installed and has a great reputation," says William H Luers, a former US ambassador to Venezuela and a former president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. "It's due to her, and everyone knows it, which makes it a national outrage that she should be dispensed with so unceremoniously."

Imber has been an outspoken critic of Chavez and is the widow of Carlos Rangel, a political writer who was an adversary of many of the Marxist theorists who have risen to power with Chavez. But Espinoza denies that politics or personal revenge were factors in Imber's dismissal, saying that her ousting was part of "a natural process of renovation and renewal" intended to end what he described as a stagnation of culture.

"I am a personal friend of Sofia's and I continue to admire and esteem her," he says. "But I am absolutely convinced that to preserve and guarantee her work, it was necessary to replace her."

Imber's successor as director of the museum is Rita Salvestrini, one of her former deputies. Salvestrini says the museum must "reflect the will of the state, not of a single person" and indicated that her management and collection philosophy will be different from that of her predecessor.

"I must say that I do not know why there has been such an emphasis over the past decade on acquiring 20th-century Spanish art, some of it by minor names. If you try to find a Latin American artist, you will find Botero but no one else, so I think the correct path is to fill that vacuum and open more toward Latin American art."

Salvestrini's approach dovetails with Chavez's attacks on what he calls the political and cultural hegemony of the United States and Europe and his constant calls for pan-Latin American unity, or Bolivarianismo , as he labels it. Salvestrini also talks of strengthening the museum's website (www.maccsi.org.ve) to make art more accessible to ordinary Venezuelans. "We need to communicate more effectively to shed an elitist image," she says. "If you look at the attendance figures, you will see that they have dropped dramatically in recent years, to a level I find worrisome."

But others in the art world say it is the apparent application of overtly ideological criteria that makes them uneasy. "I'm scared by this stuff, this utilitarian approach to culture, which just kills art," says Luers, who is now chairman of the United Nations Association. The danger exists, he says, that "by reshaping museums for purposes of national identity they will lose the broader impact on society, to see how Venezuelan art relates to the art of the world and in some ways is superior".

webTitle: A brief history of mob rule

fields.headline: A brief history of mob rule
fields.standfirst:
As the threat of May Day riots looms, John Mullan traces the chaging nature of a very British tradition

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: As the threat of May Day riots looms, John Mullan traces the chaging nature of a very British tradition.
fields.body:
As May Day approaches, warnings have grown louder about impending riots in the capital. Where will they be? Two years ago it was the City, last year Westminster and Whitehall. This year the rumours - fuelled by internet announcements by would-be protesters - point to that canyon of Mammon, Oxford Street. "Mayhem" (the favoured word in the popular press), it seems, is to be the order of the day. Stores are said to be hiring extra security staff; litter bins will be removed so that they cannot serve as missiles. Particular outlets that have been singled out for attention are Starbucks, Gap and, predictably, McDonald's.

The idea of agitators giving prior notice of their intended targets might seem odd, but Britain has a long tradition of riots and, down the centuries, mobs have often made their intended targets clear in advance. Protesters have realised that the anticipation of a riot can be as disruptive as any actual assault on property, and riots are more often remembered for their targets than for their causes.

While the May Day protests are a relatively new phenomenon, they share many of the historical protocols of the British riot. The disturbances in Elizabethan and Jacobean England, for example, especially those directed against the enclosure of common land, frequently took place on traditional holidays. The rioters would throw down the fences erected to deny access to land on which they had once been allowed to graze their animals, demonstrate their contempt for the landowner (occasionally by surrounding his house or burning him in effigy) - and then would dutifully return to work the next day. Holidays were used for the brief expression of a long-nursed discontent. Nearly 500 years ago, on May 1 1517, riots were directed against the property of affluent foreign merchants and craftsmen plying their trades in London. These became known as the "Evil May Day" riots.

The idea of targeting buildings that stand for conspicuous consumption, too, is an old one. The peasants' revolt of 1381 saw ferocious disturbances in London, and what was called "luxury" was one of its targets. Various palaces and grand houses were attacked; Lambeth Palace, the home of the Archbishop of Canterbury, was sacked - not because he was head of the church, but because it was his seat of opulence. At the height of the riot, the Savoy Palace, the most magnificent private mansion in England, was systematically demolished. The Savoy was the huge riverside home of John of Gaunt, Richard II's uncle and the nation's power broker. Standing on what is now the Strand, it was famous for its owner's magnificent collection of furniture, tapestries, jewels and ornaments. The rioters, who blamed John of Gaunt for the introduction of the poll tax that had detonated the revolt, destroyed everything. What could not be smashed or burned was thrown into the river. Jewellery was pulverised with hammers, and it was said that one rioter found by his fellows to have kept a silver goblet for himself was killed for doing so.

Looting, however, has rarely been controlled so strictly by protesters. Before the 19th century, food riots, usually set off by price rises, often led to the looting of warehouses, and occasionally even of ships carrying food for export. Those who wished to mock the political radicals behind the so-called Pall Mall riots of 1886, which arose from a socialist demonstration against government policies, were quick to publicise the rioters' thefts from St James's vintners. These campaigners for a new social order, unable to resist the temptations on offer, had drunk the finest brandy from their cupped hands.

fields.headline: 11th-hour gremlins dog Tito's star trek
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Dennis Tito may have to wait a little longer to become the world's space tourist.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor in Moscow, and agencies
fields.body:
Dennis Tito may have to wait a little longer to become the world's space tourist.

Yesterday Nasa requested that the space shuttle Endeavour spend at least one extra day at the International Space Station because computer gremlins have delayed tests of a new robot arm.

Ideally, Nasa wants a two-day extension, but the second day depends on Russian space officials agreeing to postpone today's launch of the Soyuz spacecraft from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, with Mr Tito and two other cosmonauts.

Yuri Semyonov, the head of Russia's space programme, said that Moscow would not delay lift-off because the Soyuz lifeboat now at the station must be replaced this month. But Nasa spokesman Rob Navias said that no decision had yet been made.

`We're still in negotiations with the Russians,' he said.

Yesterday 61-year-old Mr Tito accused America of erecting political obstacles to the pioneering journey that he paid £14m to make.

Mr Tito said that his preparations had been arduous but that he felt fully fit. `The training was most difficult. It was made more difficult by political problems,'' he said.

Referring to US objections to his week in space, Mr Tito added: `I have the support of the Russian people and the Kazakh people and we came through. The politics is over and I think now the flight is ahead of us.''

Russian officials met last night to consider whether or not to delay the launch by at least a day.

webTitle: Unsavoury BT game plays out in private

fields.headline: Unsavoury BT game plays out in private
fields.standfirst: With the pressure for greater transparency, quarterly company reporting would reduce the scope for market abuse
fields.trailText: With the pressure for greater transparency, quarterly company reporting would reduce the scope for market abuse.
fields.body:
At times like these, you'd be forgiven for wondering why anybody bothers with the stock market. Investors have suffered negative returns, boards of directors are under fire from said investors, and intermediaries such as us stockbrokers are squeezed between high overheads and low revenues.

When the going gets tough, the weak look for somebody else to blame. And in the current tough times, blame is being passed around as if it were a ticking parcel with TNT stamped on the side. Those left holding the bomb are urged to 'accept responsibility'', thereby exonerating all those whose sweaty hands had seconds earlier touched the brown paper wrapping.

The latest example of this rather unsavoury 'game'' is the unseating of BT's chairman, Sir Iain Vallance. The telecoms dinosaur has squeezed itself into an enormous pickle jar with debts that dwarf those of many small nations. Credible alternatives for reducing this burden are few. In the current bear market, buyers for peripheral assets are few - and likely to see BT as a panic seller. The banks will be pressing for some loans to be repaid rather than lining up to extend further credit. Which only leaves shareholders.

It is an open secret that BT would like to raise at least £5bn from its shareholders. It has been widely reported that these shareholders - in practice a handful of fund managers at the leading investment institutions - demanded changes to the board as the price for their support. Sir Christopher Bland's arrival is probably only the first of these changes.

Responsibility clearly must lie in large part with BT's most senior stewards. But it cannot rest there alone. What of the anonymous 'City sources'' who have con ducted a material part of their campaign against Vallance and his chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, through the press?

These sources will include a number of fund managers, broking analysts and bankers who had repeated opportunities to influence BT's strategy long before circumstances revealed it to be misguided. Blame the fund manager - he bought the shares. Blame the analyst - he wrote the "buy'' note. Blame the banker - he proposed the deals.

Of course, each of these market participants is subject to its own - much less public - punishment. Trustees can seek alternative fund managers. Analysts' reputations are tarnished. Bankers' deal pipelines dry up.

The boardroom change at BT and the remuneration rows at Marks & Spencer and Royal Bank of Scotland might suggest that shareholder activism is on the increase. However, these recent cases seem to me to constitute merely the natural cyclical upswing associated with economic and stock market downturns.

The National Association of Pension Funds and the Association of British Insurers have been vocal in demanding more accountability in setting of executive remuneration - and for remuneration to be effectively performance related. Members of these associations are rarely prepared to stand up and be counted individually. Hermes, the pension fund manager, is an honourable exception.

On a case by case basis, one can see that the conduct of relations in private between company management and institutional shareholders achieves results. Indeed most major corporate transactions are floated past fund managers before they are subject to the public glare. Similarly, most boardroom coups are almost over before they hit the press - and are all the less painful for it.

However, when such a system backfires, it does so spectacularly. The debate between BT and its owners has spilled into the public domain and must have damaged the company in its attempts to sell businesses and to raise new funds. Perennial complaints.

The trend in the regulatory regime in Britain and US financial markets is towards greater transparency. Price sensitive information is to be disseminated to all shareholders simultaneously. Selective briefings of analysts and fund managers should become increasingly anodyne.

It will be interesting to see where this leaves debate between management and fund managers about strategic alternatives and possible deals. Companies are typically paranoid about developments being taken amiss by the markets. Although they pay their advisers substantial sums to second-guess fund managers, there is no substitute for certainty.

For all their mutual interdependence, there are perennial complaints from company executives about the collective of fund managers and vice versa. It is as if the two breeds find it impossible to imagine confronting each other's day to day challenges. Greater enforced formality in the interface between the two will probably place increased strain on their relationship.

One solution might be more frequent announcements of results and strategic thoughts by all companies. Quarterly reporting might be a bore, but it would reduce the scope for market abuse - and lower the blood pressure.

webTitle: Review: A History of the Wife by Marilyn Yalom

fields.headline: Trouble and strife
fields.standfirst:
Frances Wilson investigates the wife's lot in A History of the Wife by Marilyn Yalom
Read an excerpt
fields.trailText: Frances Wilson investigates the wife's lot in A History of the Wife by Marilyn Yalom
fields.body:
A History of the Wife
Marilyn Yalom
408pp, Rivers Oram Press, £20
Buy it at a discount at BOL

And they lived happily ever after. Marriage is the end of the story as far as the literature of childhood is concerned; unlike romance, it comes unscripted, but the plots we impose on it are fairly predictable. Within and outside fiction, marriage is mostly limited to tales of male authority and female servility, female suffering and male protection. Stories about wifely stillness are perennial favourites. Witness our most treasured spouses: Penelope at her loom, waiting two decades for Odysseus to return home from work, or Queen Victoria mourning her husband for half a century. Jackie Kennedy was the embodiment of patience until she married Onassis and fell off her pedestal, while Hillary Clinton was loathed by the American public until she stood by her man during the Monica Lewinsky debacle.

Marilyn Yalom's A History of the Wife is timely because, now that so many women choose not to marry and so many marriages fall apart, we might expect the imaginative patterns of married life to have expanded their range. This seems not to have been the case; while, beyond the home, married women are often able to construct their own stories, back within domestic confines the traditional paradigms still prevail. The history of wives cannot change until the history of husbandsdoes, and Yalom, never radical in her analysis or ambitious in her vision, feels that this male "revolution" has begun. Husbands now help their pregnant wives with "breathing techniques" and "carry their infants in frontal pouches". That these examples of revolutionary fervour seem so pitiful is less a sign of Yalom's analytical weakness than a reflection of how much more of a bargain marriage is for men than it is for women.

A History of the Wife is not a penetrative analysis of the peculiar state into which women have been given, bartered, bought and sold for the last two millennia, but a survey of the roles and expectations of wifehood from biblical and classical times to contemporary America. It is a gentle sociological consideration, nurtured by the vagaries of women's studies and frequently brought into focus by sharp sets of statistics.

The book has two objects: first, to show how the expectations that women "rebel" against today - "the wife as a man's chattel, as his dependent, as his means for acquiring legal offspring, as the caretaker of his children, as his cook and housekeeper" - are ancient obligations against which rebellion is nothing new. Unbeknown to her husband, the medieval mystic Margery Kempe wore a hair shirt in bed as penance for sexual intercourse. While documenting the history of resistance to marital duty, Yalom argues that marriage in the west has changed dramatically: it used to be a religious duty and is now a secular choice. She illustrates this with a brisk journey, full of wonderful quotations, through medieval Europe, Reformation Germany, the French and American revolutions and the English and American Victorian age, before reaching the wives of the 20th century.

Today, Yalom regrets, "young people engage in sex with several partners and then 'fall in love' with one of them". Although she acknowledges that the place of romantic love in the story of marriage has a history, emerging alongside the romantic novel at the end of the 18th century, Yalom does not regard its construction as in any way ideological.

Thus she accepts that "love" is the strongest basis on which to ground a marriage, and is astounded by those cultures that think otherwise. "Both for traditional Indian families and for classical Romans, it was normal for love to come after marriage. How different from our own idea of choosing a mate for oneself because one has fallen in love!" Whatever love means.

webTitle: Review: Fools Are Everywhere by Beatrice K Otto

fields.headline: A mad world, my masters
fields.standfirst:
Nicholas Lezard finds an eclectic history of the court jester in Fools Are Everywhere by Beatrice K Otto
Read an excerpt
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard finds an eclectic history of the court jester in Fools Are Everywhere by Beatrice K Otto
fields.body:
Fools Are Everywhere: The Court Jester Around the World
Beatrice K Otto
444pp, University of Chicago, £28.50

It is a good enough title to be getting on with: fools are, indeed, everywhere. Just look around you. While this is the kind of accusation that goes down well until it dawns on you that it applies to you too, the point is that no one is free from folly; the trick is to be aware of the fact. Let us consider the most pompous and self-important ass in the public sphere at the moment. For no reason in particular that I can think of, Lord Irvine of Lairg springs to mind. He it was, you will recall, who compared himself to Cardinal Wolsey. Would he have done so, one wonders, if he had recalled that Wolsey was for years the exasperated butt of Henry VIII's irrepressible and in some ways archetypal jester, Will Somers? Or that John Skelton, whose learning, buffoonery and general lack of respect for established orders brought him into the realm of court jesting, also couldn't resist having a go at him?

Wolsey, apparently, had a jester, yet history forgets his jests; the king's jester will trump your own. And he will almost always trump the king. If Beatrice K Otto's summary of thousands of years of wizz-taking at despots' expense is to be trusted, then the number of monarchs who have wearied of their fools and executed them is strikingly low. Something of a Sinophile, she has at her disposal a wealth of information about the antics of Chinese jesters, whose techniques and ends bespeak an unrivalled cultural continuum of satire at the courts' expense. She translates their names, too, so instead of the monikers Zhou Za and You Zhan we have the striking Going Round in Circles and Twisty Pole. Their jokes do not survive the passage of miles and centuries intact, but their attitudes - skirting dangerously the limits of an emperor's tolerance - are recognisably admirable today, although many of Otto's chosen anecdotes from Chinese annals end with the otherwise bloodthirsty dictator being temporarily mollified or swayed by the wit of a clown, as if that makes things all right. There is obviously a bigger picture here, though one concedes that to illuminate it would exceed Otto's brief.

Sometimes one wonders not so much at her equanimity in the face of outrageous despotism as at the impression she gives of being entirely wrapped in her subject: speculating, for example, how a jester at modern arms-limitation talks would speed up the proceedings immensely, had either side the wit to hire one. Or this: "Court jesters are very much alive and kicking in the collective memory of most places that fostered them, with the exception of China, although it is hard to find reasons for this oriental amnesia." Let me speculate: it may have something to do with living under a brutal and inordinately repressive dictatorial machine with a strong inclination to stifle even the idea of dissent. (In the meantime, the Chinese novelist Wang Shuo seems to be making a decent fist of reviving the satiric pulse of his nation.)

Less worrying but more mystifying is the way she takes at face value the notion that "[Sir Jimmy] Savile . . . plays the part of the court jester to the establishment with consummate skill, is a regular visitor to Kensington and Buckingham palaces, as well as the prime minister's country residence at Chequers. As the unofficial clown he articulates opinions which courtiers can only think." That this comes from a 1990 article by Andrew Morton in the Sunday Times, with the headline "The Royal Marriage: Happy Ever After?" shows us, if not Otto, what we can make of it. It also at least demonstrates that Otto has the integrity and good manners to cite her sources punctiliously.

It is probably unimportant whether she has chosen not to theorise about jesting or is incapable of doing so. It certainly bespeaks a lack of side: she is more interested in displaying her astonishingly eclectic source material than in gathering it together under some spurious umbrella. This is a book that gets you asking the right kinds of questions rather than supplying you with the answers. You may well wonder, after reading it, why the western mania for court jesters and fools died down suddenly in 17th-century Europe. Otto does, at least, supply one convincing contemporary theory for their disappearance, from Thomas Shadwell in 1679, which would appear to hold true to this day: "because nowadays [great men] are their own fools, and so save Charges".

fields.headline: Foreign fields
fields.standfirst:
If your boots were made for walking on something other than paving stones, Simon Birch suggets five real hikes for the weekend.
Who goes where? Our guide to the airlines and operators who will take you around Europe
fields.trailText: If your boots were made for walking on something other than paving stones, Simon Birch suggets five real hikes for the weekend.
fields.body:
With the prospect of much of the country's open spaces remaining off limits until well into the summer, frustrated walkers are now looking longingly across to foot-and-mouth-free Europe. Here are five top walking destinations that can be easily reached for a four-day weekend break.

Northern France

The walking is easy through the open, rolling countryside and farmland around the north French coast. Walking specialist Inntravel's "A Stroll to Market" is a three-day, 17-mile ramble along country footpaths and tracks. All walkers are given detailed maps together with background notes to the area. Picnic lunches are also provided, so a small daysack is a good idea and, to make it even easier, your luggage is ferried ahead to your evening's destination.

On the first day, you walk seven miles, starting from the village of Inxent, through quiet valleys before finishing at a farmhouse hotel. The next day, the 10-mile ramble winds through more Picardy hamlets before finishing in the market town of Montreuil. Finally, a taxi takes you back to pick up your car at the starting point of Inxent.

Best time to go: Right now, as spring has arrived and the hedgerows and woodlands are bursting into life.

Price: Between £215 and £224, depending upon departure. Includes three nights' half-board, two picnic lunches, two luggage transfers and return ferry from Dover to Calais.

Contact: Inntravel, tel: 01653 629010.

Bavarian/ Austrian Alps

The introduction of Ryanair's Stansted-Salzburg service has brought some of Europe's most dramatic scenery within the long-weekend walker's sights - and pocket.

Endless walking opportunities of every grade can be found within half-an-hour's drive of Salzburg. One of the highlights is a three-day hike through the Berchtesgaden National Park in neighbouring Germany. The 25-mile walk from Königsee to Wimbachtal, which straddles the German-Austrian border, offers scenery of towering mountains and crystal-clear lakes. The trail also involves staying in what the locals refer to as huts, but which are cosy guest houses set deep within the mountains.

It contains some long, steep climbs, so you do need to be in good shape.

Best time to go: Currently good, easy walking is possible in the valley bottoms and in the Salzkammergut, Austria's own Lake District. By early June, when most of the snow has melted, walkers can head up to the high mountain tracks.

Further information: A detailed guide to the Königsee walk is contained within the Cicerone Guide to Walking in the Bavarian Alps, though you will need a map as well. Cicerone also publishes a guide to walking in the Salzkammergut.

Accommodation: If you want to do the Königsee walk, you should check the availability of the huts before you leave the UK (numbers are listed in the guide). One night costs around £7 with evening dinner around £5. For information regarding staying in either Salzburg or Berchtesgaden, which is just 12 miles away and close to the trail head, contact the German Tourist Board (tel: 0900 1600100) or the Austrian Tourist Board (tel: 020-7629 0461).

Getting there: Ryanair (0541 569569) flies from Stansted to Salzburg twice a day from £103 including taxes.

Alpes Maritimes

At the heart of the Alpes Maritimes in south-eastern France lies the Mercantour National Park with its dramatic peaks, alpine meadows and extensive trails, which are relatively deserted compared with those in the more famous Alps to the north.

And while these tracks can challenge the most experienced walker, a network of trails linking the medieval Perched Villages that cling to the wild hillsides around the southern approaches to the park offer gentler gradients. These paths take walkers through olive groves and forests of chestnut and pine.

Breil sur Roya is typical of the Perched Villages and is a good base for exploring the area as a number of long-distance trails pass through it.

A great way to do sections of these trails is to take the train which passes through Breil higher up the valley and walk back down sections no longer than 10 miles in any one go.

Best time to go: Spring.

Further information: A walking guide to the Perched Villages is available in English from the regional tourist office in France (tel: 00 33 4 93 04 92 05). Sunflower Books publishes detailed walks in the region in its South of France guidebook, and the Lonely Planet guide to walking in France contains details of routes in the Mercantour National Park. Other useful websites include www.beyond.fr and www.provenceweb.fr.

Accommodation: The Hotel Roya in Breil sur Roya (tel: 00 33 4 93 04 48 10) offers double rooms from £27 a night. For other hotel options, contact the French Tourist Office (tel: 0906 824 4123).

Getting there: easyJet flies to Nice from Liverpool and Luton, prices from £123 and £103 respectively, including taxes. Breil sur Roya lies on the Nice to Cunéo railway line. Details from SNCF.

The Pyrenees

Long a favourite of British walkers, the Pyrenees offers some of the best hiking in Europe. For the long-weekend walker, the Pyrenees are an option by virtue of the Ryanair service to Biarritz. If you don't want to drive once you arrive, you can base yourself in the seaside resort of St Jean de Luz, just down the road from the airport, or in one of the many medieval villages nestling in the foothills, such as Ainhoa, which is 12 miles from the airport. From both, it's possible to walk small sections of one of the many long-distance trails that traverse the entire Pyrennean chain; in Ainhoa, for example, the trails pass right through the village.

However, if you don't mind driving from Biarritz, a two-hour journey takes you to Bedous to the south-east. This small town is a perfect base for exploring some of the most dramatic parts of the Pyrenees. For example, the tough 14-mile hike up to the Pic de Labigouer is a classic ridge walk that takes you high into the heart of the Pyrenees with stunning views down the valley and across into Spain.

Best time to go: The lower foothills are an ideal option now, the higher ridges being snow-free by late May.

Further information: A detailed description of the walk up to the Pic de Labigouer is contained in the Lonely Planet guide to Walking in France. Sunflower Books also publish details of easy walks in the western Pyrenees.

Accommodation: St Jean de Luz has a variety of accommodation; visit www.123voyage.com or www.tourisme.fr for details. In Ainhoa, the 400-year-old Hotel Oppoca (tel: 00 33 5 59 29 90 72) has rooms from £25 to £32pp per night. In Bedous, Le Mandragot (tel: 00 33 5 59 34 59 33) has basic rooms for £5 a night. Plus staying in one of the many Pyrennean mountain refuges is also a cheap option; for details, contact the local tourist office on 00 33 5 59 34 71 48. For other accommodation, contact the French Tourist Office in London (0906 824 4123).

Getting there: Ryanair flies to Biarritz from Stansted from £130 including taxes.

Norway

Quite why Norway has failed to register on the average walker's radar is one of life's great outdoor mysteries. After all, it has breathtaking fjords, endless mountains and wilderness together with a terrific network of walking huts.

For the weekend walker, the best way to tackle Norway is to aim for Bergen as there are outstanding hikes from within the city itself and the spectacular fjords are just a short distance away.

Take the funicular railway from virtually the middle of town up the 1,000ft Mount Floyen and walk on the well-marked trails through the woods before heading back down with views overlooking the city and sea.

Another option is to take the train for a stunning two-hour journey through the mountains to Myrdral. From here, walk down an old railway line for about 12 miles to Flam at the head of a fjord. The walk should take about five hours and being flat or downhill it's easy going and the views are terrific.

From Flam, you can either return by rail to Bergen or you can take a boat trip on the fjord to Gudvangen from where you get the bus to Voss and then the train to Bergen. This trip makes for a long day but is a great introduction to the fjord region.

Those looking for more challenging trails should head for Voss, a good base to explore the mountains and fjords north of Bergen. Walks can be strung together using the reliable local public transport links.

Best time to go: From late May onwards, most of the trails will be accessible and strewn with flowers, plus it will be light late into the evening.

Information: DNT is Norway's walking association and the DNT office in Bergen (tel: 00 47 55 32 22 30) will give details of the walks described above and background to walking in the region.

Accommodation: The Rica Travel Hotel in Bergen (tel: 00 47 55 31 54 00) has weekend offers on double rooms from £32. For budget trav ellers, the YMCA Family and Youth Hostel (tel: 00 47 55 60 60 50) offers clean and basic rooms for £10 a night, breakfast included. In Voss, the Norlandia Jarl Hotel (tel: 00 47 56 51 19 33) has double rooms from £38. For more hotel options, contact the Norwegian Tourist Board (tel: 020-7839 6255) and the Bergen tourist website.

Getting there: Braathens (0191-214 0991) flies to Bergen from Gatwick and Newcastle from £118 and £173 respectively, including taxes.

Tomorrow's world

Walking on sunshine
Author Chris Stewart kicks off our Tomorrow's World special with a hike through some of Europe's most spectacular country - in southern Spain

Basque it
The glitterati head for nearby Biarritz. But the homeliness of St Jean de Luz is where Alex Ninian's heart is

Curtain raiser
It's not an obvious choice for a weekend away, but the capital of Lithuania is a treasure waiting to be discovered

Is this the new Caribbean?
People still live in caves and travel by camel on this island in the Arabian Sea. But plans are afoot to turn it into a holiday paradise over the next 10 years. Erland Clouston takes a look

The beautiful north
These once-forbidding cities have woken up after a long hibernation. Andrew Spooner selects the five coolest spots

Viewing recommended
Alf Alderson on how to enjoy Montana - a piece of splendid isolation in the wilderness

Walking specialist Inntravel's "A Stroll to Market" is a three-day, 17-mile ramble along country footpaths and tracks. All walkers are given detailed maps together with background notes to the area. Picnic lunches are also provided, so a small daysack is a good idea and, to make it even easier, your luggage is ferried ahead to your evening's destination. On the first day, you walk seven miles, starting from the village of Inxent, through quiet valleys before finishing at a farmhouse hotel. The next day, the 10-mile ramble winds through more Picardy hamlets before finishing in the market town of Montreuil. Finally, a taxi takes you back to pick up your car at the starting point of Inxent. Best time to go: Right now, as spring has arrived and the hedgerows and woodlands are bursting into life. Price: Between £215 and £224, depending upon departure. Includes three nights' half-board, two picnic lunches, two luggage transfers and return ferry from Dover to Calais. Contact: Inntravel, tel: 01653 629010. Bavarian/ Austrian Alps The introduction of Ryanair's Stansted-Salzburg service has brought some of Europe's most dramatic scenery within the long-weekend walker's sights - and pocket. Endless walking opportunities of every grade can be found within half-an-hour's drive of Salzburg. One of the highlights is a three-day hike through the Berchtesgaden National Park in neighbouring Germany. The 25-mile walk from Königsee to Wimbachtal, which straddles the German-Austrian border, offers scenery of towering mountains and crystal-clear lakes. The trail also involves staying in what the locals refer to as huts, but which are cosy guest houses set deep within the mountains. It contains some long, steep climbs, so you do need to be in good shape. Best time to go: Currently good, easy walking is possible in the valley bottoms and in the Salzkammergut, Austria's own Lake District. By early June, when most of the snow has melted, walkers can head up to the high mountain tracks. Further information: A detailed guide to the Königsee walk is contained within the Cicerone Guide to Walking in the Bavarian Alps, though you will need a map as well. Cicerone also publishes a guide to walking in the Salzkammergut. Accommodation: If you want to do the Königsee walk, you should check the availability of the huts before you leave the UK (numbers are listed in the guide). One night costs around £7 with evening dinner around £5. For information regarding staying in either Salzburg or Berchtesgaden, which is just 12 miles away and close to the trail head, contact the German Tourist Board (tel: 0900 1600100) or the Austrian Tourist Board (tel: 020-7629 0461). Getting there: Ryanair (0541 569569) flies from Stansted to Salzburg twice a day from £103 including taxes. Alpes Maritimes At the heart of the Alpes Maritimes in south-eastern France lies the Mercantour National Park with its dramatic peaks, alpine meadows and extensive trails, which are relatively deserted compared with those in the more famous Alps to the north. And while these tracks can challenge the most experienced walker, a network of trails linking the medieval Perched Villages that cling to the wild hillsides around the southern approaches to the park offer gentler gradients. These paths take walkers through olive groves and forests of chestnut and pine. Breil sur Roya is typical of the Perched Villages and is a good base for exploring the area as a number of long-distance trails pass through it. A great way to do sections of these trails is to take the train which passes through Breil higher up the valley and walk back down sections no longer than 10 miles in any one go. Best time to go: Spring. Further information: A walking guide to the Perched Villages is available in English from the regional tourist office in France (tel: 00 33 4 93 04 92 05). Sunflower Books publishes detailed walks in the region in its South of France guidebook, and the Lonely Planet guide to walking in France contains details of routes in the Mercantour National Park. Other useful websites include www.beyond.fr and www.provenceweb.fr. Accommodation: The Hotel Roya in Breil sur Roya (tel: 00 33 4 93 04 48 10) offers double rooms from £27 a night. For other hotel options, contact the French Tourist Office (tel: 0906 824 4123). Getting there: easyJet flies to Nice from Liverpool and Luton, prices from £123 and £103 respectively, including taxes. Breil sur Roya lies on the Nice to Cunéo railway line. Details from SNCF. The Pyrenees Long a favourite of British walkers, the Pyrenees offers some of the best hiking in Europe. For the long-weekend walker, the Pyrenees are an option by virtue of the Ryanair service to Biarritz. If you don't want to drive once you arrive, you can base yourself in the seaside resort of St Jean de Luz, just down the road from the airport, or in one of the many medieval villages nestling in the foothills, such as Ainhoa, which is 12 miles from the airport. From both, it's possible to walk small sections of one of the many long-distance trails that traverse the entire Pyrennean chain; in Ainhoa, for example, the trails pass right through the village. However, if you don't mind driving from Biarritz, a two-hour journey takes you to Bedous to the south-east. This small town is a perfect base for exploring some of the most dramatic parts of the Pyrenees. For example, the tough 14-mile hike up to the Pic de Labigouer is a classic ridge walk that takes you high into the heart of the Pyrenees with stunning views down the valley and across into Spain. Best time to go: The lower foothills are an ideal option now, the higher ridges being snow-free by late May. Further information: A detailed description of the walk up to the Pic de Labigouer is contained in the Lonely Planet guide to Walking in France. Sunflower Books also publish details of easy walks in the western Pyrenees. Accommodation: St Jean de Luz has a variety of accommodation; visit www.123voyage.com or www.tourisme.fr for details. In Ainhoa, the 400-year-old Hotel Oppoca (tel: 00 33 5 59 29 90 72) has rooms from £25 to £32pp per night. In Bedous, Le Mandragot (tel: 00 33 5 59 34 59 33) has basic rooms for £5 a night. Plus staying in one of the many Pyrennean mountain refuges is also a cheap option; for details, contact the local tourist office on 00 33 5 59 34 71 48. For other accommodation, contact the French Tourist Office in London (0906 824 4123). Getting there: Ryanair flies to Biarritz from Stansted from £130 including taxes. Norway Quite why Norway has failed to register on the average walker's radar is one of life's great outdoor mysteries. After all, it has breathtaking fjords, endless mountains and wilderness together with a terrific network of walking huts. For the weekend walker, the best way to tackle Norway is to aim for Bergen as there are outstanding hikes from within the city itself and the spectacular fjords are just a short distance away. Take the funicular railway from virtually the middle of town up the 1,000ft Mount Floyen and walk on the well-marked trails through the woods before heading back down with views overlooking the city and sea. Another option is to take the train for a stunning two-hour journey through the mountains to Myrdral. From here, walk down an old railway line for about 12 miles to Flam at the head of a fjord. The walk should take about five hours and being flat or downhill it's easy going and the views are terrific. From Flam, you can either return by rail to Bergen or you can take a boat trip on the fjord to Gudvangen from where you get the bus to Voss and then the train to Bergen. This trip makes for a long day but is a great introduction to the fjord region. Those looking for more challenging trails should head for Voss, a good base to explore the mountains and fjords north of Bergen. Walks can be strung together using the reliable local public transport links. Best time to go: From late May onwards, most of the trails will be accessible and strewn with flowers, plus it will be light late into the evening. Information: DNT is Norway's walking association and the DNT office in Bergen (tel: 00 47 55 32 22 30) will give details of the walks described above and background to walking in the region. Accommodation: The Rica Travel Hotel in Bergen (tel: 00 47 55 31 54 00) has weekend offers on double rooms from £32. For budget trav ellers, the YMCA Family and Youth Hostel (tel: 00 47 55 60 60 50) offers clean and basic rooms for £10 a night, breakfast included. In Voss, the Norlandia Jarl Hotel (tel: 00 47 56 51 19 33) has double rooms from £38. For more hotel options, contact the Norwegian Tourist Board (tel: 020-7839 6255) and the Bergen tourist website. Getting there: Braathens (0191-214 0991) flies to Bergen from Gatwick and Newcastle from £118 and £173 respectively, including taxes. fields.standfirst:
The glitterati head for nearby Biarritz. But the homeliness of St Jean de Luz is where Alex Ninian's heart is.
Who goes where? Our guide to the airlines and operators who will take you around Europe
fields.trailText: The glitterati head for nearby Biarritz. But the homeliness of St Jean de Luz is where Alex Ninian's heart is.
fields.body:
I'll be in trouble for writing this because those who love St Jean de Luz don't want anyone else to know about it. It has no high-rise hotels and it's off the package-holiday track, so people have to discover it for themselves.

It is a homely place, small enough for the town's "character", with his umbrella and ankle-length tweed coat in mid-summer, to be given a patisserie or a slice of Bayonne ham by the shopkeepers as he passes by. But it is big enough to offer visitors (not tourists) dozens of small hotels and scores of restaurants as well as a clean, safe beach.

On the Atlantic coast, just south of Biarritz, St Jean de Luz is only six miles from the Spanish border and its skyline is dominated by the Pyrenees. It is French but only just; Basquedom reigns in this country within a country. The first time I came here was from the Spanish side, and the road signs were in Spanish plus another language I couldn't decipher. Across the French border the signs were in French plus the same impenetrable hieroglyphs. Basque is a unique collection of x's, double z's, tt's and rr's. Meet Monsieur Acoztarra, see rue Etcheverri garay, eat ttoro (fish soup), drink Izzarra. Related to Hungarian and Japanese, apparently. I quite believe it.

Once pirates, then whalers and now France's main tuna fishermen, the locals have always been tough and independent. Yet fine style and high culture have equally been a part of the history. The harbour is a postcard scene of half-timbered houses painted bright red and white, and the galleried church of St Jean-Baptiste is a bijou showpiece of gilt, statuary and stained glass. It was built in the 1400s and made famous when Louis XIV, the Sun King came here to marry Marie-Thérèse of Spain in 1660.

The air appears always to be filled with music: youngsters strum guitars in the street; there are open-air folk concerts; and the church and several halls have orchestras and choirs. Maurice Ravel was born here and professors give master classes to students of his piano music.

You'll also hear the sharp crack of the pelota ball carrying through the narrow streets. Some schools, and even pubs, have indoor and outdoor courts, where young men whack a hard-ball with wooden rackets against a wall in a style similar to squash. The fast version, cesta punta , is the traditional Basque game which attracts crowds and teams from all over the region. It is played with long wicker gloves which propel the ball like a missile. For those who like to hit a stationary ball, there is a picturesque golf course at the Club de la Nivelle, which runs through the hills alongside the river.

The curved bay is protected by a boom and nothing is allowed inside it except swimmers, so the water skiers and jet skiers and power boaters have to go out with the tuna boats.

In between sport and culture comes "thalassotherapie" - saltwater treatments - and many come here for a course which can last anything between one day and one week. The Hotel Hélianthal offers programmes of swimming, sauna, water aerobics, massage, and every kind of therapy in an attempt to straighten out mind and body.

At the end of the day, the bars in Place Louis XIV serve drinks to the sound of music from the bandstand, before everyone moves on to the restaurants of the port, Boulevard Thiers or Rue de la Republique. Being the south-west, duck appears on most menus, but the specialities are Atlantic fish, tuna, sardine and shellfish. Rioja is served as the local wine.

The best of all I leave till last: ttoro, which epitomises all the traditions of the region - the seafaring, the culture, the art ofgood living. Fish soup is on every menu and eaten in every home; there's even a f te dedicated to it at the end of September - the F te du Ttoro. After service in the church of St Jean Baptiste, the square is taken over by a couple of dozen cooks who set up their charcoal grills and cook their fish, vegetables, herbs and spices in pans swimming in butter and garlic. The aromas fill the air as the soups are left to simmer in vats for much of the afternoon.

Meantime, the town band leads a fancy dress parade of grotesque creatures through the streets before the panel of judges convene to taste the soup of each competitor. All the soup is then carried round to the town's restaurants and the day ends at midnight with a confetti fight in the crowded streets.

The fête marks the end of the holiday season, although more and more hotels and restaurants remain open all year for those in search of peace, bracing air and a bit of winter sunshine.

What to see

The church of St Jean Baptiste in Rue Gambetta is a wonder. Built in the 1400s like a small cathedral, the gleaming gilt altar and stained glass are must-sees.

Le Fronton Municipal, in Route de Bayonne, is the open air-stadium where cesta punta is played between teams from all over the Basque region.

Le Maison Louis XIV, just off Place Louis XIV, is a 17th-century house that's open to the public, showing the original bedrooms, kitchen, dining room and crockery.

The port has fish auctions.

Things to do

The beach is clean and safe enough for children to swim. Also sailing, windsurfing, water skiing and diving. There's tennis and squash (tel: 00 33 559 47 18 99), two golf clubs (Chantais 26 14 22; Nivelle 47 18 59); and sea and river fishing.

For shopping, there's Rue Gambetta, which has delicatessens, boutiques, beauticians and bookshops. Rue Victor Hugo is a "real" street with butchers and bakers, fishmongers and haberdashers and a covered market. And there's a casino (00 33 559 26 09 09).

Where to eat

The town has literally hundreds of places to eat, the greatest concentration being in Place Louis XIV and rue de la Republique, which has restaurants running the length of both sides of the street. Because of the intense competition, prices tend to be similar - main courses £6-£12, menus £8-£18, house wines £5-£10.

Restaurant Ongui Ethorri, 15 rue de la Republique, (00 33 559 26 85 07) specialises in fruits de mer and paella.

Taverne Basque, 5 rue de la Republique (00 33 559 26 01 26), has a pubby appearance and pubby food.

Kayola, rue de la Republique (00 33 559 51 01 12), has an unusual Basque-cum-mod-art ambience and a big à la carte menu of fish and meats.

Gillerie du Port - in the open area by the port where a number of restaurants have wide terraces overlooking the harbour - serves almost exclusively sardines and tuna and is usually packed out.

Where to stay

At the low-cost end, there are no fewer than eight camping sites in the vicinity plus a host of B&Bs.

The two-star Hotel Bolivar at 18 Rue Sopite (00 33 559 26 02 00) is two streets back from the beach and has 17 rooms ranging from wash basin and no WC to en-suite. Price £23-£33 per room per night.

Hotel Prado, Place Maurice Ravel (00 33 559 57 03 71) is on the front (its café is on the prom) and has 38 rooms, similar to Bolivar, ranging from £30-£45 per room.

Hotel Madison, 25 Boulevard Thiers (00 33 559 26 35 02) is three-star, five minutes' walk from the shore and has 25 rooms and a sauna. £28-£52 per room.

Hélianthal, Place Maurice Ravel. Higher class modern hotel with 100 bedrooms with all facilities, two minutes from the town centre and the beach. It has a thalassotherapie area with pools, Jacuzzi, sauna, steam and and treatments for which you have to pay extra. Prices for a basic room from £93-£119.

Parc Victoria, 5 rue Cépé (00 33 559 26 78 78), is further away from the beach and town centre and has only 17 rooms, but they are luxurious and feature lots of services, a swimming pool, beautiful garden and good food.

Around and about

Spain is six miles to the south, Biarritz nine miles to the north and within a radius of 100 miles are Bordeaux and Lourdes in France, Pamplona and San Sebastian in Spain.

Further information

The Office de Tourisme, Place du Marechal Foch, tel: 00 33 559 26 03 16.

Way to go

Rail Europe (08705 848848) includes Eurostar to Lille and then TGV, from £109 return. Ryanair (0541 569569) return from Stansted to Biarritz from £99.10 week days. The best weekend fare is £129.

webTitle: Colombia - From exile, we must educate the west

fields.headline: From exile, we must educate the west
fields.standfirst:
The role of the journalist in exile

Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Ignacio Gomez on why Colombian freedom of expression is no longer a local issue and the role which exiled journalists must play in the struggle.
fields.body:
In this age of globalization, Colombian freedom of expression is no longer a local issue.

The peoples of developed countries have the right to know what kind of deals their corporations are doing down there, in the midst of a 37-year-long war, to provide the fuel for their cars. Americans have the right to know how the government is spending at least two billion dollars over the next two years to 'fight the drugs (not, openly, to protect the oil).

So the Colombian journalists duty is, among many aspects in the armed conflict, reporting the behavior of oil corporations and foreign military help to the dirtiest Army in the continent.

But there have been not even a little piece about these issues in the Colombian media for a while.

In the last 20 years more than 158 Colombian journalists have been killed, most of them because of their reports on political corruption, drug trafficking and political violence. There are many factors to this violence and so we must confront it with a multi-factor strategy: pushing judiciary investigations, building a network to understand and to know the threats; moving threaten journalist to safer places through agreements between the local radio stations and newspapers; providing bullet proof vest, armored cars and easy communication with the protection police in some cases, and campaigning to convince the actors in conflict that they are going to need freedom of expression to build or sustain the country they are fighting for.

International NGOs have complained to the government not just because of the lack of protection to journalists, or the ineffectiveness with which attacks have been investigated, but also because of the involvement of some congressmen and Army officers in these attacks. As result of these complaints the general attorney office appointed a special unit to investigate the crimes against journalists two years ago, and the presidency gave some money to support protection measures for journalist.

In the case of Jineth Bedoya, who was kidnapped and tortured last year, the General Attorney office asked her to give a judiciary declaration, but three days latter she received a phone call from the right wing death squad's leader asking her specific questions about her declaration. In my case, three days after a failed kidnapping attempt by the same perpetrators of Jineth's attack the Police told me that I had to leave the country.

In some cases FundaciÜn para la Libertad de Prensa (Press Freedom Foundation) and the Commission to Protect Threatened People (funded by international aid given to the Colombian government) can provide at least temporary protection to journalists and move them to safety inside the country.

But most of them had to leave the country and very few are able to keep working for Colombian media. At least 25 of the most well known reporters and columnist left the country in 1999 and 2000, and more than 10 this year.

We are spread all around the world, mostly in developed countries, willing not just to preserve our lives but also our skills. We are still here - able to help the developed countries understand the complexity of, and the global responsibility for, the Colombian conflict.

Ignacio Gomez is Nieman Fellow at Harvard University. He was editor of investigations for El Espectador, the Bogota-based national newspaper. He won the Amnesty International Media Award for journalism under threat (2000) and was also named Colombian Journalist of the Year in the same year.

On this site: The inquisitors of press freedom in Colombia - Luis Fernandes of Prens@ Libre

So the Colombian journalists duty is, among many aspects in the armed conflict, reporting the behavior of oil corporations and foreign military help to the dirtiest Army in the continent. But there have been not even a little piece about these issues in the Colombian media for a while. In the last 20 years more than 158 Colombian journalists have been killed, most of them because of their reports on political corruption, drug trafficking and political violence. There are many factors to this violence and so we must confront it with a multi-factor strategy: pushing judiciary investigations, building a network to understand and to know the threats; moving threaten journalist to safer places through agreements between the local radio stations and newspapers; providing bullet proof vest, armored cars and easy communication with the protection police in some cases, and campaigning to convince the actors in conflict that they are going to need freedom of expression to build or sustain the country they are fighting for. International NGOs have complained to the government not just because of the lack of protection to journalists, or the ineffectiveness with which attacks have been investigated, but also because of the involvement of some congressmen and Army officers in these attacks. As result of these complaints the general attorney office appointed a special unit to investigate the crimes against journalists two years ago, and the presidency gave some money to support protection measures for journalist. In the case of Jineth Bedoya, who was kidnapped and tortured last year, the General Attorney office asked her to give a judiciary declaration, but three days latter she received a phone call from the right wing death squad's leader asking her specific questions about her declaration. In my case, three days after a failed kidnapping attempt by the same perpetrators of Jineth's attack the Police told me that I had to leave the country. In some cases FundaciÜn para la Libertad de Prensa (Press Freedom Foundation) and the Commission to Protect Threatened People (funded by international aid given to the Colombian government) can provide at least temporary protection to journalists and move them to safety inside the country. We are spread all around the world, mostly in developed countries, willing not just to preserve our lives but also our skills. We are still here - able to help the developed countries understand the complexity of, and the global responsibility for, the Colombian conflict. Ignacio Gomez is Nieman Fellow at Harvard University. He was editor of investigations for El Espectador, the Bogota-based national newspaper. He won the Amnesty International Media Award for journalism under threat (2000) and was also named Colombian Journalist of the Year in the same year.
