webTitle: The five words that baffle Oldham Asians

fields.headline: The five words that baffle Oldham Asians
fields.standfirst:
'Get out of our area' was the warning before the attack. But was it racially motivated?

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Walter Chamberlain's battered face, and the five words one of his attackers allegedly said to him, have become the emblem of all that is wrong with Oldham.
fields.body:
Walter Chamberlain's battered face, and the five words one of his attackers allegedly said to him, have become the emblem of all that is wrong with Oldham.

Here was a 75-year-old D-Day veteran, who served his country aboard a minesweeper, being told to 'get out of our area' by teenagers whose families had come here from a foreign land. Now it seemed they were threatening to make Oldham, this once-proud Lancashire mill town, into a foreign land for the white families.

The attack took place on Saturday, three days after Asian teenagers had told a radio reporter that no-go zones had been created for whites, and it crystallised all the fears that report invoked.

But the attack was not such a simple story. After the assault Mr Chamberlain was interviewed briefly by police officers and he told them he had been confronted by an Asian in his late teens, who demanded to know his address. The pensioner refused and was shoved.

In a carefully-worded press statement, police said they had not established whether his injuries were the result of him falling or being struck. It was thought two other Asian youths were present. Mr Chamberlain's wallet was not taken but his metal coffee flask was missing, possibly stolen. Police said the attack was being treated as racially motivated.

The headline on the front page of Monday's Manchester Evening News read Get Out Of Our Area, beside a picture of the battered grandfather. Those words were given to the paper by a senior detective, and though Mr Chamberlain did not say this in his initial statement, a force spokesman confirmed that police believe this was said to him.

Members of the local Asian communities were both horrified and baffled by the attack. It did not fit the profile of violence, in which the victims have largely been young males, both white and Asian.

Mr Chamberlain was attacked on an access road through an industrial estate towards the mainly white part of town where he lived. It was a no-mans' land unclaimed by any of the area's teenage gangs and therefore the words 'get out of our area' made little sense.

Then on Thursday night, Mr Chamberlain's son Steven denied there had been a racial motive. He told ITN's Tonight with Trevor McDonald: "It was a violent assault on an elderly man. As a family we don't think it was a race issue at all - it's an assault." The family are concerned that Mr Chamberlain may be a target when he returns home from hospital where he has had an operation on his fractured cheekbone. This fear may have governed what they told Tonight.

It may also be that they were seeking to pour some oil on troubled waters. It is certainly needed; the BNP's leader Nick Griffin is standing here at the general election, while the National Front is seeking to exploit tensions by applying for permission to march next Saturday. The police have applied for Home Office permission to ban the march.

Police, some of whom remain convinced Mr Chamberlain would not have been attacked were he an Asian grandfather, are continuing to treat this as a racist attack. Detectives stress that it is a very small number of Asian youths who are causing trouble; as few as 10 may have perpetrated up to 80 attacks.

Ordinary people say the reporting of the last 10 days has misrepresented their town. The reality, they say, is that Oldham is not a powder-keg. It is not, though a tiny handful of yobs might want it to be, a racial battleground.

"I live right in the middle of the problem,' said Rukhsana Sarwar, 17, a student at Oldham sixth-form college.'But the way the media has presented it has increased tension because they have made out that it is mainly Asian attacks on white people. They have angered the Asian community, stirred up racial trou ble and made it even worse."

Rukhsana, who is going to Oxford to read law in the autumn, spoke of attacks on both Asians and whites. "Asian people do not trust the police as much and don't report these incidents. But it's not just about race. It's about violence.''

Catherine Creamer, another 17-year-old A level student, said the reporting may have increased tensions but those tensions had been present for a long time."Perhaps the issues needed to be brought to crisis point before they can be solved," she suggested. "But our lives are not built on racial tensions. This does not reflect the Oldham I know."

What is happening here is based on ignorance in the literal sense of a lack of knowledge. Of Oldham's current population of 219,000, around 24,600 are Asian: 14,000 Pakistani, 9,000 Bangladeshi, and 1,600 Indians. But it is largely split between white, Pakistani and Bangladeshi areas. Primary schools are mostly dominated by one of these communities, so often the first time young people of different races mix is at secondary school.

The divides are historic. Oldham's Asian population came here in the post-war decades to work the unpopular night shift in the cotton mills. They were skilled workers, recruited from textile factories in the Sylhet area of Bangladesh, parts of Pakistan, and Gujarat in India. They settled in the cheapest parts of town, near people who spoke the same language.

When the cotton business began to suffer, the Asian night-workers were first to go. With no language or social skills because they had worked at nights, times were extremely hard in the tough economic climate of the late 1970s. White families were going through hard times too, and then as now the National Front swaggered through the town blaming these hardships on the immigrants.

A generation grew up watching their cowed parents being subjected to abuse. This history sometimes becomes an excuse for present-day attacks on whites, but is only one ingredient in the mix. Some of it is more about puberty than racism; teenage males staking out their turfs and picking on boys of a different colour in dim-witted acts of bravado. There is also a criminal element. Drug dealers sometimes employ teenagers as look-outs, briefed to scare off anyone who looks like a stranger.

The whole of this is overlaid by a cultural divide which can lead to trivial run-ins escalating out of control. Dogs are a good example of this. Fido is an Englishman's best friend, but many people from the subcontinent regard them as dirty and dangerous animals. While the Guardian's reporters were in Oldham they were given two separate accounts of arguments that started over dogs running off their leads and ended with blood-curdling threats.

Some white people, particularly young men, hold genuine fears about walking through Asian areas on their own. Asians feel the same about walking through some predominantly white areas. But there is no evidence that any part of Oldham is truly a no-go zone.

Tariq Rafique, chair of the Pakistani Youth Association, is frustrated that all Asians have been branded racist since the attack on Walter Chamberlain. "It's just two or three mindless idiots who have targeted this poor pensioner. They are cowards. The community needs to flush these people out. But it's just a handful of kids who are doing more harm to their own community than anyone else."

There has been a loss of pride among Asian elders, and a break-down of parental discipline. "Parents used to encourage their children to do well at school so they could brag about it," said Mr Rafique. "I think that's gone out of the window. With a lot of families, if their son hasn't done well, they say 'so what - so and so's son has done the same."

Millions of pounds have been channelled into the deprived areas of Oldham and the results are visible in the builders busy all over the Glodwick estate, and the new Tesco and B&Q on the mainly Bangladeshi Westwood estate.

But the parts of Oldham where many Asian families live remain among the poorest places in Britain. The smaller Indian community has been assimilated more successfully, but there is high unemployment within Pakistani and Bangladeshi quarters - 16% and 25% respectively.

There are fears among Asian leaders that some in the council believe they have had ''their turn'' and are diverting funding elsewhere. Chris Hilyer, deputy leader of the council, said there were areas of povery and deprivation across the whole borough. "Much of the investment coming in now is quite sensibly aimed at the whole community." But he is able to give an impressive list of the council's achievements in Asian areas; improving housing, bringing in business, and launching initiatives to reduce crime.

At the core of the regeneration work is improving children and teenager's educational prospects, and Oldham's sixth-form college is widely acknowledged as one of the town's biggest reasons to be cheerful.

Nick Brown, the principal, said: "The only way you regenerate poor communities is to have people who have knowledge, influence and power working effectively within those communities. We don't want Oldham to be typified by low levels of employment, bad housing and very low aspirations."

The principal sits in front of a table strewn with newspapers reporting the attack on Walter Chamberlain. Outside, some of the college's 2,000 students, a quarter of them Asian, mingle, chat, smoke and sometimes kiss.

Men of Mr Chamberlain's generation grew up in an Oldham which is gone now. The future is another country. What kind of place it will be depends on whether young people like these students can forge a new, shared identity.

webTitle: 'People look at Asians and see them all as Pakis'

fields.headline: 'People look at Asians and see them all as Pakis'
fields.standfirst:
What the neighbours think

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: What the neighbours think.
fields.body:
First man: 'I think the biggest racists today are the Asians. Your average Oldhamer isn't a racist.'

Second man: 'They are not all bad. But because of things like this, they all get tarred with the same brush. There are plenty of bad white people, aren't there?'

First man: 'Yeah but you're not in fear of white people. You wouldn't think of going in Werneth Park. The park that I go to is Westwood Park but you wouldn't dream of going in there now. If you were lucky, you'd get verbal abuse. Otherwise, stones.'

'Not everything has been reported and there have been many, many incidents of white people being attacked or property damaged.'

Second man: 'They eff at you and say, 'What you doing over here?' At one stage they wouldn't come near you if you had a dog. They saw dogs as rabid animals. But now if you've got a dog they start throwing things at you so that you'll disappear especially if they're having a game of football or cricket. It makes you want to come with your dog and stand there longer.

'It should take only five minutes to walk past them but they throw so much abuse at you it takes 20 minutes to walk past.'

First man: 'Even children are abusive and rude. If they are walking to school, they are intimidating and abusive.'

Second man: 'Three or four years ago I had a car and there was a group of Asians down Robinson Street. They all stepped into the road and obviously I had to stop. The next thing they just kicked my car in all the way round. No reason. I phoned the police and it took two hours for them to come. They said there was nothing they could do.'

'There's one Asian family in this street. They've only just moved in. But they are different again because they're Indian. People look at Asian people and see them all as Pakis. And that's how white children see them.'

First man: 'The average Oldhamer is very tolerant. A few years ago they would have said 'live and let live'. But I'm afraid that's not the case now. I've lived in this street for years but I'd love to move.'

Second man: 'If I move, it will be for my own reasons. I don't see why I should go because of them.'

First man: 'The future will be like Beirut or Israel today. You've got a total clash of cultures. I don't think there is a remedy, to be honest with you.'

Second man: 'I worry about my children's future. You don't know what's round the corner. It's frightening.'

webTitle: Black Tory peer puts Hague on the spot in race row

fields.headline: Black Tory peer puts Hague on the spot in race row
fields.standfirst:
Lord Taylor challenges party leader to withdraw the whip from MP who made `mongrel race' remark

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Lord Taylor challenges party leader to withdraw the whip from MP who made `mongrel race' remark.
fields.body:
The race row in the Tory party threatened to run out of control yesterday when a black Tory peer, Lord Taylor of Warwick, challenged William Hague to withdraw the whip from the Bridlington MP, John Townend, after he accused ministers of wanting to turn Britons into `a mongrel race'.

Lord Taylor, who endured racist attacks when he stood as a Conservative candidate in Cheltenham in 1992, said: `John Townend is clearly determined to continue spouting his racist rubbish. He is laying down the gauntlet to Mr Hague. The leader of the Conservative party prides himself on his judo and 14 pints a day macho image. Now is his chance to demonstrate real macho leadership by withdrawing the whip from Mr Townend and booting him out of the Conservative party.'

Yesterday morning John Townend renewed his attack on the commission for racial equality, whose anti-racist pact he had refused to sign. Mr Hague, whose fence-mending speech in Bradford was over shadowed by Mr Townend's outburst, repudiated the remarks, but said it was too late to move against Mr Townend, even though another Tory MP, Charles Wardle who is not standing again, had the whip withdrawn earlier this month.

`Taking the whip away from Mr Townend would just be a gesture when he's not even a candidate in the coming election. He's only got a few days left,' Mr Hague said. `I believe in substance, not gesture.'

Lord Taylor dismissed this as a cop-out. `He has caused a great deal of offence, not only to ethnic minorities around the country, but to decent people in England of whatever colour who believe in, and live in, a multiracial, multicultural society.' Mr Townend and others who have refused to sign the CRE pact on libertarian grounds, had claimed victory in the past few days because the argument had become one of free speech rather than racism. But some Tories fear that the defence - a concern raised by some Labour members too - is being used as cover by a small racist element.

Continuing his attack on Mr Hague, Lord Taylor said: `It might be that he is frightened of a certain rightwing element within the Tory party.' And in a scathing denunciation of Mr Hague's advisers, he said the leader was failing to send out a consistent message.

`When people feel uncertain, they tend to shy away, and certainly the ethnic minorities feel very uncertain about what he is really saying. If you feel that a party doesn't want you because of the colour of your skin, you're hardly likely to vote for that party,' he said.

Mr Hague was barracked by protesters wearing masks of the Tory leader as he tried to raise the issues of crime, education and transport in Pudsey, near Leeds.

Lord (Seb) Coe hauled three masked men away from the Tory entourage.

Mr Hague's solitary purchase in the marginal constituency, a £10 bunch of flowers, was greeted with a shout of: `Are those for Mr Townend?' Unruffled, he called back: `They are most definitely for my wife, Ffion.'

Bill Morris, of the Transport and General Workers' Union, last night used his speech to the TUC Black Workers' Conference in Perth to raise his own concerns about race.

Referring to the Hague speech, which last month triggered the race row by portraying a future where Britain was a `foreign land', Mr Morris said: `It is indeed a foreign land. A foreign land where ordinary black British families wake up almost every morning to listen on the radio to descriptions of themselves they do not recognise.'

John Edmonds of the GMB union, said: `We have to have the confidence to say clearly that, although William Hague personally may not be racist, his failure to discipline members of his party shows he is prepared to see the issue of race exploited.'

In further evidence of the critical role race is likely to play in the election, David Wilmot, chief constable of Greater Manchester, is seeking a Home Office prohibition order to ban a National Front march through Oldham next Saturday.

Mr Wilmot said the march had been given substantial consideration but added that the order was `essential for maintaining public order and to enable positive community dialogue''.

Mr Hague's solitary purchase in the marginal constituency, a £10 bunch of flowers, was greeted with a shout of: `Are those for Mr Townend?' Unruffled, he called back: `They are most definitely for my wife, Ffion.' Bill Morris, of the Transport and General Workers' Union, last night used his speech to the TUC Black Workers' Conference in Perth to raise his own concerns about race. Referring to the Hague speech, which last month triggered the race row by portraying a future where Britain was a `foreign land', Mr Morris said: `It is indeed a foreign land. A foreign land where ordinary black British families wake up almost every morning to listen on the radio to descriptions of themselves they do not recognise.' John Edmonds of the GMB union, said: `We have to have the confidence to say clearly that, although William Hague personally may not be racist, his failure to discipline members of his party shows he is prepared to see the issue of race exploited.' In further evidence of the critical role race is likely to play in the election, David Wilmot, chief constable of Greater Manchester, is seeking a Home Office prohibition order to ban a National Front march through Oldham next Saturday. Mr Wilmot said the march had been given substantial consideration but added that the order was `essential for maintaining public order and to enable positive community dialogue''. fields.headline: Michele Alboreto
fields.standfirst: The last Italian to win a grand prix in a Ferrari, he embodied the human spirit of motor racing
fields.trailText: The last Italian to win a grand prix in a Ferrari, he embodied the human spirit of motor racing.
fields.body:
At the Catalunya circuit in Barcelona this weekend, 22 Formula One cars will leave the starting grid under the control of their engineers rather than their drivers. Times are changing in grand-prix racing. As the technicians become the stars, the sport is losing some of its human spirit, represented in recent years by men such as Michele Alboreto, the last Italian to win a grand prix in a Ferrari, who has died in a racing accident, aged 44.

Although Enzo Ferrari grew reluctant to put drivers of his own nationality into the cockpits of his racing cars... fearing that the pressure of patriotic expectations might provoke accidents and the consequent bad publicity... he could not resist Alboreto. Intelligent, gracious and thoroughly simpatico, the Milanese driver came close to rewarding the old man's faith with the world championship.

Alboreto left the world of Formula One in 1994, aged 38, his fortunes having slumped after a 12-year career which yielded five victories. No longer wanted at the sport's highest level, but still passion ate about racing, he switched to saloons and sports cars. It was while testing an Audi, in preparation for this year's 24-hour race at Le Mans, that he died, after his car somersaulted over a barrier on the high-speed oval section of the Lausitzring, a new circuit south of Berlin.

His racing debut came in 1976, in a Formula Monza car built by friends. A year later, he finished third in the championship, and grad-uated to Formula Italia. In 1980, he won the European Formula Three champion- ship, with five race wins in the season. By this time, he was also a member of the Lancia team that competed in endurance sports car races, paired with his com-patriot Riccardo Patrese, already a fully-fledged grand driver, under the management of Cesare Fiorio.

Alboreto's first Formula One experience came when he tested a Williams in the winter of 1980-81. At the San Marino grand prix in 1981, Ken Tyrrell offered him a one-off drive. Impressed by his speed and competence, the Guildford timber merchant offered him a permanent seat in his team. His two grand prix victories with Tyrrell... around the Caesar's Palace car park in Las Vegas in 1982, and on the streets of downtown Detroit the following year... were the last the team ever achieved in Formula One, and, at the end of 1983 Alboreto received an offer no Italian could refuse.

It came, he later related, as a result of an interview he had given after his win in Detroit, in which he criticised Ferrari for failing to hire an Italian driver. He had been advancing the claims of Patrese and Elio De Angelis, but Enzo Ferrari responded by inviting him to visit the team's headquarters in Maranello. An offer was made and accepted, and, when the 1984 season began, Alboreto was a Ferrari driver.

"For any racing driver to drive a Ferrari, and to drive for Ferrari, represents the most profound moment of his career," he later wrote in the Gazzetta dello Sport. "So you can understand how much more important it is for an Italian driver." Quickly establishing his superiority over his team-mate, the fading French star Rene Arnoux, Alboreto won the Belgian grand prix in his first season. In 1985, he took the chequered flag in Canada and Germany, and installed himself as the favourite for the championship, ahead of the likes of Alain Prost, Nelson Piquet and Nigel Mansell, until a series of Ferrari engine failures allowed Prost to slip ahead and claim the title.

There were two more seasons with Ferrari, latterly with Gerhard Berger as his team-mate. Within days of the death of Enzo Ferrari in the autumn of 1988, the two drivers finished first and second in the Italian grand prix at Monza, unleashing a tidal wave of emotion among the fans. At the end of that season, however, he was replaced by Nigel Mansell. His wife, Nadia, had given birth to the first of their two daughters, and perhaps the late Enzo was looking down and noting an endorsement of his belief that marriage and fatherhood slowed a driver down.

Alboreto spent the 1989 season back with Tyrrell, but for the remainder of his time in Formula One he moved from team to team, slipping further and further down the grid as he switched from Footwork to Lola, and finally to Minardi, the little team from Faenza, in Emila-Romagna, with whom he enjoyed a respectable final year in the top flight.

Thereafter he concentrated on sports cars, competing in Ferraris, Porsches and, for the last three years, with the all-conquering Audi works team. Victory in the Le Mans 24-hour race in 1997, sharing the wheel of a Porsche, was the highlight of the final phase of his post-Formula One career, his dark close-curled locks now turned silver in the manner of an Italian ace of an earlier generation, Piero Taruffi.

At the San Marino grand prix two weeks ago, the paddock of the Autodromo Enzo e Dino Ferrari, just outside the small town of Imola, was as crowded as ever. There was no sign, however, of the gaggle of retired Ferrari drivers and mechanics who have traditionally used the occasion of the team's home grand prix as an excuse to gather and share their memories.

Grand Prix racing is losing a sense of the value of its own history. But there are plenty of people who will continue to remember Michele Alboreto as one of the warmest men to drive the red cars... as well as, on his day, one of the fastest.

 Michele Alboreto, racing driver, born December 23 1956; died April 25 2001

fields.headline: Ground control
fields.standfirst: Are you more interested in deck chairs than spadework? Well, take it easy - plant up a paradise for the lazy that will develop all by itself. Ann-Marie Powell on how to create a low-maintenance garden
fields.trailText: Are you more interested in deck chairs than spadework? Well, take it easy - plant up a paradise for the lazy that will develop all by itself. Ann-Marie Powell on how to create a low-maintenance garden.
fields.body:
How much time do you give to your garden each week (and I don't mean sitting in it, enjoying the view)? Most of us want to enjoy the outdoors, but have less and less time to do the work. We want plants that look good with the minimum of care, that cover ground quickly without cutting back on quality or quantity. We want restful, guilt-free places. Is that too much to ask for?

Work it out

To achieve this you'll need self-control, commitment, and you'll need to plan. Every plant you select should have a realistic purpose. But before you plant anything, take a long, hard look at what you've got. Check what soil type you have. Peeking at your neighbour's garden may give you some indication, but a soil-testing kit is far more reliable. What's the aspect of your garden? Split it into areas of shade and sun, and then consider how many plants you'll need to fill each area. Generally, shrubs take up a square metre, and herbaceous perennials swell into 60cm rounds. Leave space for things to grow. Cram things too tightly and you'll be constantly pruning, splitting and re-planting. Knowledge is everything in a garden. Know its limitations, and you'll easily find plants that will thrive.

Eager evergreens

No plant is perfect, but try to choose ones with the least flaws. Avoid, or get rid of, any high-maintenance plant: ones that catch diseases or need a lot of feeding. Give a wide berth to plants with messy fruits, pods or huge leaf drops. Damage limitation is the key with low-maintenance gardening. Aucuba is an obliging evergreen, and seems to grow almost anywhere. The leathery green, voluptuous A. 'Rozannie', with its light, reflecting foliage, is perfect for lifting dark patches. Other undemanding evergreen shrubs to structure your space include Mexican orange blossom (aromatic with clusters of orange-scented flowers), Photinia ¥ fraseri 'Red Robin' (brilliantly scarlet spring leaves), and Viburnum tinus 'Eve Price' (more compact than other varieties, with vibrantly pink flowerbuds). Yet the secret of any garden is variety through the year. For this you'll need some deciduous shrubs and herbaceous perennials.

Buoyantly deciduous

The smoke bush is the perfect undemanding deciduous shrub. Cotinus coggygria has grey-green young leaves that unfurl to a mid-green mass; but it comes into its own in autumn, with vivid orange-yellows and reds, and puffs of flowers that turn a smoky grey. You'll find more drama in the claret foliage and purple-pink blooms of C. coggygria 'Royal Purple', while C. coggygria 'Flame' morphs into a great fireball of red in autumn. This shrub will develop into a small tree, but cutting it to the ground in spring keeps it in check and encourages larger leaves. No garden is complete without at least one lilac. Syringa meyeri var. spontanea 'Palibin' grows in any soil; it is almost pest and disease free, and reaches a height and spread of about 1.5m. Lilac pink, scented blooms arrive in profusion in May, after which it can be cut back hard to save on space. Helpful herbaceous Bare soil is every gardener's enemy: brown, empty patches of earth are both unsightly and a portal for weeds. Weed-proof membranes and mulches help the fight, but nothing beats a smothering cloak of ground-covering plants. Send in weed-stomping troops of Geranium ¥ oxonianum 'Claridge Druce', a vigorous grey-green leaved plant with rose-pink flowers, which will hold its own among the most pernicious of weeds. Sturdy and semi-evergreen, G. macrorrhizum 'Album' not only colours up in autumn to shades of russet and red, but will glimmer with white blooms in the driest, shadiest spots. Other carpeting plants include Symphytum grandiflorum, Vinca minor (I hear Christopher Lloyd cuts his back every three years), Euphorbia amygdaloides var. robbiae and Lysimachia punctata.

Swelling numbers

Don't forget plants that will produce more of the same for free. Salix alba is an undemanding plant that'll blow you away come winter. S. alba 'Britzensis' has coral-red stems, while S. alba 'Vitellina' has strong limbs in glowing acid-yellow. Cut them back hard each spring for an abundance of young, coloured growths, then use castoffs to produce more plants for perking up your evergreens. Layer shrubs and climbers to stretch plants on walls and in borders without breaking the bank. Jasminum nudiflorum, Akebia quinata, hops, some honeysuckles and most passionflowers can easily be increased by bending flexible limbs to the ground and pegging them in place with a hairpin or wire; they'll root and spread to form dense, bushy masses.

Reap what you grow

Whatever you grow, make sure you plant things properly. I'm amazed how many plants are bunged in without concern for their health.

Dig planting holes shallow and wide (most new root growth is concentrated in the first 15cm of soil), mix compost and fertiliser, then firm the plant in at the same level as it was in its pot. Use at least 5cm of mulch around it to keep water in and weeds out (organic mulch rots into and improves the soil). With forward planning such as this, you'll have a full, easy-maintenance garden for years.

webTitle: Things my girlfriend and I argue about

fields.headline: Things my girlfriend and I argue about
fields.trailText: Just before the fire curtain came down last week, you'll recall that Margret and I were in the middle of exchanging opinions about various matters. To bring you up to speed, let me tell you that while you were away Margret and I have argued about:
fields.body:
Just before the fire curtain came down last week, you'll recall that Margret and I were in the middle of exchanging opinions about various matters. To bring you up to speed, let me tell you that while you were away Margret and I have argued about:

Which way - the distances were identical - to drive round a circular bypass (this resulted in her kicking me in the head from the back seat as I drove along).

The amount of time I spend on the internet. (A couple of minutes a week, it surely can't be more than that.)

First Born's name (Jonathan). Then, when that was settled . . .

How to pronounce First Born's name.

Our telephone number.

Which type of iron to buy (price wasn't an issue, it was the principle, dammit).

Where to sit in the cinema. On those occasions when we: a) manage to agree to go to the cinema together; and b) go to see the same film once we're there. (No, really.)

Whether her cutting our son's hair comes under 'money-saving skill' or 'therapy in the making'.

Immediately after every single time Margret touches my computer I have to spend 20 minutes fixing crashes, locked systems, data losses, jammed drives, bizarre re-configurations and things stuck in the keyboard.

There then follows a freeform discussion with, in my corner, 'It's your fault' and, in hers, 'It's a curious statistical anomaly.'

Until next week, then. When we may be asking you to take sides.

fields.headline: Takeover talks for nursing homes
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest owner of nursing homes, NHP, is believed to be in takeover talks with property investment firm Reit Asset Management.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest owner of nursing homes, NHP, is believed to be in takeover talks with property investment firm Reit Asset Management.

Reit emerged as the front-runner after NHP announced yesterday that it had received two bid approaches.

Industry sources suggested the second offer might be from a management buyout team, or from private equity firms Advent and UBS Capital.

Reit is controlled by north London property millionaire Leo Noe. It owns 29 care homes, bought three years ago from Ashbourne Nursing Homes.

NHP owns 400 homes, all of which are leased out to third-party operators. It ran into financial difficulties last year, when several tenants went bankrupt owing to increasing wages and a squeeze in public-sector funding.

A new management team led by chief executive Bill Colvin has been renegotiating rents and borrowing.

News of the approaches sent NHP's shares up 5p to 43.75p, valuing the company at £63m. The price reached 200p two years ago. The company has £550m of bonds outstanding and £100m of bank debt.

Mr Colvin has won praise from analysts. Nancy Davies of UBS Warburg said: 'The management has put the building blocks in place for a much higher price.'

NHP revealed it had turned down an offer for 25 homes from one of its directors, Jeremy Davies. Reit would not comment.

fields.headline: Scratch 'n' sniff
fields.standfirst: Glue finds Irvine Welsh stuck in a groove, says James Campbell
fields.trailText: Glue finds Irvine Welsh stuck in a groove, says James Campbell
fields.body:
Glue
Irvine Welsh
480pp, Cape, £12
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Irvine Welsh's Trainspotting was about a bunch of daft lads (or sub-psychopaths) whose violence and amorality were supposedly explained by their origins in the soulless Edinburgh housing schemes. They devoured drink, drugs and wee lassies by the ton. The one thing that inspired them was tribal loyalty: they stuck together like - well, like glue. Welsh's publishers call his new novel Glue "a return to form", which is something of a backhanded compliment. What they probably mean is a return to Trainspotting .

The old crew - Begbie, Sick Boy, Spud and Renton - make tantalising cameo appearances in Glue , and are known to its protagonists. Begbie is currently picking the pockets of gullible Americans in the bars of Leith, you'll be interested to learn. Renton was recently spotted on a Glasgow train. He's back from Amsterdam, and is thought to be working in the music business. His reputation goes before him, though: "He ripped off his mates." Who cares that they ripped off everybody else?

Trainspotting had a disjointed structure which suited its zonked-out state of mindlessness, and emphasised the characters' lack of connection to anything except each other. Glue, by contrast, is carefully crafted. It employs multiple perspective, and skilfully plays with a form of narrative rewind, whereby a fuzzy incident in chapter six, say, is replayed, gaining definition, in chapter nine. Welsh flits between standard English, in which he is not entirely comfortable ("Davie felt like a newly crowned emperor surveying his fiefdom", to cite but one peculiar phrase), and the more expressive but limited schemie demotic, in which he is fluent - is, in fact, the lad himself.

Glue has an epic scale: it charts the rites of passage from boyhood to ladhood (no Welsh character has progressed beyond the latter) of four friends: Terry, Carl, Billy and Gally. The most powerful element of Welsh's fiction is not the shock factor, which he has made common-place, but its forward momentum. There is a direct route between the imagination and the page, and the writing is highly reader-friendly. This was evident in Welsh's last novel, Filth , where the voice of the diabolical Detective Sergeant Robinson was so well conceived and sustained that participation in his horrific consciousness came to seem like fun. Glue is packed with witty lines and sharp insights into behaviour and landscape. In present-day Glasgow, for example, Carl senses "disconnected currents of harshness that the new shopping malls and designer boutiques seem to strangely accentuate rather than cover up".

Various plots are kept going from beginning to end, but the main interest is generated by the overlapping lives of the principal characters. Terry is a loveable rogue and a Casanova, apt to thieve from any house he enters, even as a guest; he has never got over being laid off from his early career selling bottles of juice from a van round the schemes. The job provided scope for his seduction technique, astonishingly successful despite a ridiculous hairdo, chronic flatulence and an ever-expanding beer belly.

Carl - aka the Milky Bar Kid, aka DJ N-Sign - values character in a girl more than Terry does, though he listens carefully when his mate says "ye cannae fuck a personality". He is something of an outsider, being a Hearts fan (the others support Hibs) and coming from a stable family. His skills at the turntable are his passport through life, until he almost surrenders to an overdose of ecstasy and cocaine. Gally is an oversensitive type, who attracts bad luck. He remains a virgin for a preposterously long time (the reluctant female being a rare breed here), and ends up catching Aids from dirty needles and committing suicide.

Billy is probably the most plausible stab at a three-dimensional character. Restrained and ambitious, he makes the grade as a professional boxer before retiring to run a profitable city-centre bar. Billy keeps his aptitude for violence under control. His squeamish side comes out when, in the course of a burglary, the ringleader breaks the legs of a couple of guard dogs, tapes their snouts, strings them over a tree and sets them on fire. "It wid be kinder for thum tae die," reasons Billy as he watches a madman called Doyle torture the dogs. "Ah jist shrugged. Thir wis nowt any cunt could dae tae stoap Doyle."

As the lads grow bigger, they naturally wish to broaden their minds by watching football in foreign cities, comparing German beer with McEwan's Export and checking out Australia's suitability for raves. Given Welsh's descriptive talent, there is curiously little feeling for life beyond the schemes (even they are sketchily described). He shares this lack with his characters, for whom other people barely exist. No matter how far afield they travel, Terry, Carl and Gally will never develop the faculty of recognising value in outsiders; others remain the Other. Nor will they ever get the hang of communal life, or - perish the thought - social responsibility. It's handy having public housing, food supplies, airborne transport and medical treatment when you need them, but when Carl's father is taken ill and rushed to hospital, we are hardly surprised to learn that "the doctors are fuckin wankers".

Central to the world described in Glue are Carl's dad's 10 rules, replacing the clapped-out Ten Commandments: always back up your mates, never cross a picket line, never grass a friend or foe, etc. Mates are everything ( Glue is dedicated to a football quorum of 11 mates). Your mates will back you up when there's a riot at a Hibs v Rangers match - in fact, your mates started it by infiltrating the visitors' end and head-butting every wanker in sight. There are frequent references to Festival tourists, studenty types, rich cunts and people from Glasgow - "Huns". No species is more exotic than women, however, who are so Other that they are never simply women. They are rides, cows, slags, hounds, hoors - or, at the upper end of the meat market, quality fanny, premium minge. The occasional glimmers of tenderness in Welsh's many sex scenes are quickly overwhelmed by, for example, a disquisition on a slag's dietary habits evidenced by a bout of anal sex.

Late in the novel, a girl gang enters the action, getting a minor storyline to itself. However, in their appetites and instincts, the girls are simply XX-chromosome versions of the lads. "Cocks oot fir the lassies!", one of them shouts at "two young studenty guys" on a train. The lassies are back from Ibiza, and too busy totting up the holiday cock-count to chase "wee fuckers" from the world of higher education. Lisa is the champion ride. "She's some machine," says her friend appreciatively. "Shaggin that boy fae Tranent in the bogs comin back oan the plane." Not surprisingly, Lisa will soon discover that "Terry was a brilliant shag".

The book contains one gesture in the direction of civility. When Billy helps an elderly neighbour with heavy shopping bags, offering to drive her home, the reader experiences a sense of relief, almost of gratitude. Here is a value which is not a load ay shite. To the readers of Glue , who will doubtless number hundreds of thousands, I say: don't miss Billy's charitable act. It occurs on page 174.

fields.headline: Look back at anger
fields.standfirst: When he was starting out as an actor, Nicolas Cage found his inspiration in James Dean: he wanted to be weird and powerful on-screen, a pain in the neck the rest of the time. At 37, and a serious star, he says he's putting away childish things. Well, up to a point
fields.trailText: When he was starting out as an actor, Nicolas Cage found his inspiration in James Dean: he wanted to be weird and powerful on-screen, a pain in the neck the rest of the time. At 37, and a serious star, he says he's putting away childish things. Well, up to a point
fields.body:
It's Saturday night at Los Angeles International Airport and the wan customs official wants to know business or pleasure, what business exactly and just who it is you're interviewing. At the mention of Nicolas Cage his face momentarily cracks into life. "Oh yeah, he's one of the biggest fish we got. Get me an autograph." I have the sense that he's only half joking.

Once upon a time it's unlikely that Cage's name would have excited much interest among LA's airport staff; those jaded gatekeepers used to seeing Hollywood's elite drift through immigration on an almost hourly basis. Back then the actor was embraced by fans as a turbulent cult icon and dismissed by phobes as a showboating brat. The past five years have changed all that. Cage's renaissance kicked off with an Academy Award for his bourbon-soaked performance in Leaving Las Vegas, then built through the runaway box-office of popcorn blockbusters like The Rock, Con Air and Face/Off. These days his image glowers down from a billboard atop Sunset Boulevard and the local TV network trails its celebrity news with a clip of the man brandishing his Oscar. In Hollywood terms Nicolas Cage has arrived. The 37 year-old currently resides in that rarefied $20m bracket inhabited only by the select few (Cruise, Hanks, Carrey, Roberts). But he reached the summit via the scenic route. His eccentric, freewheeling picaresque would have landed most other actors on the scrap-heap.

Our meeting is scheduled for 10am Sunday morning when Cage shows up, alert and ready to go, with 15 minutes to spare. In he comes, every inch your money movie star with his electric-blue suit, gym-slim torso and brisk pump of a handshake. And yet no amount of Beverly Hills grooming can quite plane down the man's rough edges. If your archetypal Hollywood player is compact and symmetrical in the flesh, Cage cuts a more outsize, Fauvist figure. The face is raw-boned, lugubrious; the hair perched high on a heavy forehead. "I feel like a modern actor, though some people have told me I look like I'm from medieval times," he remarks at one point. His voice is that of a stoner Elvis Presley.

But then Cage has always been a bit of a mongrel: part Italian-American primitive, part indulged Hollywood prince, with a well-connected uncle in Francis Ford Coppola. Fittingly his films provide a jumble of extremes. In the early years the dark stuff dominated. The young Cage set out his stall with angsty, oddball roles as a Vietnam casualty in Birdy, a goofy repeat offender in Raising Arizona and the volatile, chain-smoking Sailor Ripley in David Lynch's Wild at Heart. At that time the exotic stylings easily dwarfed his more palatable, mainstream choices (Moonstruck, Peggy Sue Got Married). Recently the balance has swung to a more even keel. So Cage will tackle the scuzzy noir thriller 8mm and Martin Scorsese's anguished Bringing Out the Dead and then compensate with the homespun feel-goodisms of Family Man and the sun-dappled sweep of his latest picture, Captain Corelli's Mandolin.

"I think I'm probably a little more comfortable playing the dark stuff," he admits. "But I know that if you don't do something light every now and then the dark will envelop everything and I'll be typecast as this dark, brooding, angry guy." Maybe he's mellowing. "When I started out I was really adamant about being a punk-rock kind of actor. I remember when I did Moonstruck I just hated myself for being in that movie because it was such a celebration of life. Now, of course, I look at Moonstruck and think: Oh, it's wonderful. What was I thinking? Why was I so angry? What was wrong with me?" These are questions he returns to, worrying at them, at various intervals throughout the interview.

Let's assume, then, that Captain Corelli's Mandolin is the sort of picture that the Cage of old would have run a mile from. An overhaul of the Louis De Bernieres best-seller, it's an epic, old-school wartime romance; an expert weave of glittering Greek scenery, tumbling rustic comedy and high-flown declarations of love. Off-screen matters were more fractious. During the shoot Cage's five year marriage to actress Patricia Arquette sputtered to a halt (divorce papers were submitted, withdrawn and then submitted again). Meantime the news wires hummed with rumours of an on-set affair with his Spanish co-star Penelope Cruz. The film's director, Britain's John Madden, now dismisses such talk as simple tabloid froth. "It's absolute bullshit," he tells me. "Penelope and Nic became very good friends but certainly not lovers on the film." Then comes an abrupt caveat: "But their private lives are their business."

For his part Cage is happier keeping off the personal issues. Artistically Captain Corelli's Mandolin was a stretch for him, he says. He normally feels more comfortable playing Americans, playing modern-day, and yet here he was as Corelli, a flamboyant Italian soldier (complete with sing-song Cornetto accent) adrift in 1940s Greece. On the other hand the role gave him the opportunity to connect with his ancestry, to feel his way into past generations. "If you allow me to be slightly metaphysical for a second I was trying to call upon the spirit of my dead grandfather, Carmine Coppola. I didn't spend that much time with my grandfather, but here I was in front of a 35mm camera and I would say: Come on Carmine. Get me through this." What was that like? "Wonderful," he says.

So alright then. Cage found the film a challenge, a move into uncharted acting territory. Others, though, might be more sceptical. There have been suggestions that the man runs the risk of selling himself short with such mainstream forays. A year or two back Sean Penn was acid in his criticism; taking Cage to task over the increasing number of action blockbusters that crop up on his CV. At the time there was some confusion over exactly what was said. For the record, Penn never directly dismissed his fellow actor as a "sell-out". What he said was that: "Nic Cage is no longer an actor. He's more like a performer." On another occasion he was generally assumed to be referring to Cage's action-laden Con Air when he remarked that: "If there's anything more disgusting in the movie business it's the whoredom of my peers. It's a guy's arm coming out of the screen [and] jerking you off. I prefer to do it myself at home than have some guy contriving wet dreams for me."

Cage would rather not get into a slanging match with Penn. After all, the pair were once firm friends. They acted together as youngsters, hung out off-set and their subsequent rise through the ranks shows them to be more similar than otherwise (two Hollywood kids with something of the roughneck about them). Still, the attack clearly rankles: "He's paying a little too much attention to my career, I think. I'm not thinking too much about what he's doing, you know. But he never said that I was a sell-out, so I don't know where that came from, OK? I had heard those words but not from him. But what he did say was that I wasn't an actor, and I can't agree with that. That's Sean's opinion and he's entitled to it. But for me acting has always been an expression, in any format. I happen to like action movies. For me that's a legitimate expression."

Perhaps it all comes down to a question of taste. Penn's comments, I say, were presumably based on the belief that you can be an actor or a movie star, but you can't be both. Until now Cage has kept his cool. With this he almost explodes out of his seat. "I think that's so absurd. It's just absurd. All of my favourite actors were movie stars. What makes a movie star is somebody who is inimitable, whose voices you can imitate. Humphrey Bogart. James Cagney. Marlon Brando. Clint Eastwood. They're fascinating to watch and listen to. That doesn't make them bad actors. That just makes them inimitable and idiosyncratic and unique." Of course it can also make them extremely wealthy into the bargain, if they choose the right projects (or wrong ones, depending on your position). Take Cage, who pocketed a reported $20m for his turn in last year's Gone in 60 Seconds, an airbrushed cannonball run of a movie that can hardly have dug deep at his reserves of talent. I wonder if money is important to him. "Well, money's always important," he shrugs. "It enables you to live a certain lifestyle that you want. And if I told you that money isn't important, like some actors will, then I would be full of shit."

Later on, still trying to pin down the man's motivations, I ask Cage to list what he reckons are his three most important movies. He names Wild at Heart, Mike Figgis's Leaving Las Vegas and Con Air, the film that so annoyed Penn. When I comment that this last one seems an unusual choice, Cage rolls his eyes skyward. "Why, because two are artistic and one is commercial? Why can't a commercial movie be artistic? They can be, you know. I hate those distinctions."

Some clues to Cage current state - this cocktail of action heroics and Methody madness, of insider gloss and rude native energy - can be found in his childhood. He was born Nicolas Kim Coppola to an artistic middle-class family (dad August a professor in comparative literature, mum Joy a dancer and choreographer) and raised in a household steeped in books and opera and philosophy. Even as a child August had been a prodigious scholar. Nicolas, by contrast, kicked against conventional education and struggled at school. Instead the boy was a discerning pop-culture junkie; a devourer of Marvel comics, Bond movies and the horror novels of Stephen King. He remembers being six, sitting in front of the TV and furiously conspiring a way to get inside, to make a break from the living-room carpet and slip inside that fuzzy, heightened landscape which flickered behind the glass. That, he says, was when he first decided to become an actor. For Cage this meant Hollywood. Theatre never entered the picture. "No. And I know it's shocking and how dare I say it. Typical American. But I've just always wanted to be a film actor."

He was a weird kid, "spooked". Most nights he had trouble sleeping. When he did eventually drop off he would be plagued by nightmares. A mannequin would come tapping at his window; a ventriloquist's dummy would swoop in over the bed. "Those things can be scary," he drawls, as though embarrassed at his own timidity. Meanwhile, downstairs, the Coppola home had troubles of its own. Joy suffered from schizophrenic episodes and was institutionalised for much of her son's childhood. The marriage eventually ended when Nic was 12, and he wound up going to live with his dad in San Francisco.

Cage's mother has since recovered. Yet you can't help wondering whether her illness had anything to do with his childhood traumas; maybe even with the "dark stuff" he's so keen to explore in his work. "I don't know," he says. "I don't know about that." Then he pauses for the longest time. "I'd hesitate to comment on that because, you know, I think she's been through enough. I mean, I know that people know about it and that she's talked about it. But I'd rather not go down that road, if that's all the same with you."

As a child Nic Cage would rip open his shirt and roar like the Incredible Hulk to ward off the playground bullies. Years later he would again look to Marvel Comics to kick-start his acting career. He was credited as Nicolas Coppola on his first movie, the 1982 teen romp Fast Times at Ridgemont High. After that he lifted his nom-de-plume from Luke Cage, a militant Afro-American superhero that Marvel developed as an early 70s response to Black Power. At the time he said that this was because he didn't want to be regarded as "some nepotistic asshole". Flushed with the success of The Godfather and Apocalypse Now, the Francis Coppola of the early 80s was still widely touted as America's most important film-maker. As a result, the name trailed a lot of baggage with it.

"It was difficult in that I would go into the casting office and I would have all my lines memorised," Cage remembers. "And when you audition for a movie it's an incredibly painful process. You feel so vulnerable and oh, it's dreadful. So I would go in and I would just want to do the scene that I had prepared and I would have to talk about Francis for an hour before I could do the scene, and by then I had lost my whole concept of what I wanted to do. It was like they were just trying to get information. That," he finishes dryly, "was a little hard for me."

That said, cynics could argue that the name change was merely cosmetic. Certainly the Coppola connection was crucial in sustaining him during that scrambling early dash. In fact, in his first four years in acting Cage made no fewer than three films with Coppola. He was the greaseball rival to Matt Dillon in Rumble Fish, a loutish "mad dog" enforcer in the jazz-era folly The Cotton Club and Kathleen Turner's high-school sweetheart turned obnoxious spouse in Peggy Sue Got Married. In this way, Uncle Francis effectively helped Cage get moving. He provided the stabiliser wheels as his young nephew pedalled precariously up the road to glory.

By all accounts, the ride was a rocky one. Scarcely out of his teens, Cage was green and gauche and chippy; a surge of unrefined ability. Richard Corliss, the film writer for Time magazine, refers to him as "a student of the crypto-eccentric school of modern acting", and reckons that "some of his early performances were mannerist bordering on the grotesque". Fired up by the Method school, he would hurl himself headlong at every role, badgering his director with off-the-wall suggestions and carrying the character with him wherever he went. When the part was a dark or violent one, this would cause problems. While making The Cotton Club, Cage would finish a take, then go back and smash up his trailer. There is a story that, one morning, on the way to the set, he suddenly suspected that he was not feeling quite angry enough. To work up the requisite red-cloud-before-the-eyes, he attacked a remote- control car that was being operated by an LA street vendor; broke the thing into little bits. Is this true? "Yeah," says Cage, faintly shame-faced at such brattish behaviour. "Yeah." What did the vendor think of that?

"He didn't like it. Nobody liked it. The whole street parted from one side to the next. People were screaming. Then I would go to work feeling ready to play the part. Conversely, if I was playing a really nice guy, I would have done really nice things." What, so you'd have bought the remote-control car? "Yeah," Cage agrees. "Well, actually, I did buy the car. I smashed it and then I gave him the money."

Known for staffing his productions with family and friends, Coppola was largely tolerant of his nephew's antics. Others took a dimmer view. Matters reached a head during the 1985 filming of Peggy Sue Got Married. "I almost got fired off Peggy Sue Got Married," Cage recalls, "which would have been enormously painful. But I didn't want to make that movie, and Francis knew that. I just thought that the character as written was boring, and I told him that I wanted to go pretty far-out with it, and he said okay." Cage's concept of "pretty far-out" was to hotwire his Joe-Schmo protagonist with an array of tics and twitches, and to deliver his lines in a strangulated whistle. Executives from Tri-Star took one look at the early rushes and flipped. "The studio came up to fire me. Francis cooked them spaghetti and they ate it and they went home and they didn't fire me. But . . ." - a gust of breathy laughter - "I never worked with him again." By this point, apparently, even Uncle Francis's patience was at an end.

Except that, all of a sudden, it didn't seem to matter any more. Even in such bull-in-a-china-shop mode, Cage had made a big impression. First Alan Parker hired him for Birdy ("That was the first time anybody really took me seriously as an actor"). Later, Cher demanded him as her co-star in Moonstruck, and the Coen brothers recruited him to play the baby-snatching hero of Raising Arizona, struggling to lock down his wilful idiosyncrasies yet still coming away with a brilliantly deadpan, disciplined performance. By the time of his extravagant, tour-de-force in 1990's Palme D'Or-winning Wild At Heart, there was a sense that Cage had at last grown into his talent. He was controlling it - as opposed to it controlling him.

"Acting has always been a medicine for me," he says. "It's a way to get this shit out of my system. But you have to learn to control it, or it just invades you. You end up making yourself impossible to live with, and life impossible to live. I look back on those early days and wonder what was the matter."

He does, however, suggest one culprit. "I was growing up watching James Dean, and I heard all the stories about him. How he was a pain in the ass as a person, but solid gold on screen. How he would come into a room going, 'Fuck you, fuck you, fuck you'." Cage gestures aggressively at invisible guests surrounding us. "And I thought, 'Is that what you have to do? Is that how you have to be?' And the answer, of course, is no. But tell that to a 17-year-old boy who wants to be an actor. So, yeah, I would trash the trailer, trash the hotel room, all that stuff. But that kind of behaviour at 37 would be really reprehensible."

David Lynch calls Nic Cage "the jazz musician of American acting". In the past, perhaps, his repertoire was mainly limited to variations on either dopey or menacing. But the last decade has seen him hone and expand his repertoire. He has added layers in between, and learnt to sprinkle telling moments of stillness in amid the storms. At times his natural extrovert exuberance can still leave him caught out (he looked ill at ease, for instance, playing the numbed ambulance-driving observer in Scorsese's Bringing Out the Dead). But now the bum notes are few and far between. Since coming of age in public, Cage has blossomed into one of his generation's most potent and compelling performers. Cast him in a mainstream, formula flick and he brings a bracing dose of madness to the role. Fit him inside a dark, quirky movie and he humanises it, keeps it rooted in reality. The wild energies of his formative years have now been harnessed. As a kid he used Hollywood as his playground. As a man he effectively runs the place.

The interview is over. In comes Cage's personal assistant to wrap it up, and the two retreat for a hurried conversation in an adjacent room. A moment later she's back again, buttonholing me as I pour a cup of coffee. The personal assistant just wants to make sure that we are crystal clear on the Sean Penn quote; that Penn never actually referred to Nic as a sell-out. No, that's fine, I say. I know that he didn't. I just want you to be absolutely sure, she says again. She cannot stress it enough.

By rights this should be Nic Cage's day off. He's currently a month into the filming of Adaptation with Spike Jonze, the maverick director of Being John Malkovich. Jonze is married to Sofia Coppola, the daughter of Francis who is now also a film-maker in her own right. The Coppola connection is still there, it seems. The difference is that now it is Cage who is its fulcrum. In terms of status and visibility, he is the Godfather now.

When today's round of interviews are over, a studio car will arrive to stretch-limo the actor back home. Cage's route will lead him up past Hollywood Boulevard, where he has a star on the Walk of Fame, and into the hills where he lives in a faux-Bavarian castle flanked by an army of vintage European sports cars. Tomorrow another limousine will squire him back down to the movie set where he will find his trailer, his entourage and the cameras prepared to catch his next burst of pyrotechnics. Because Hollywood looks after its own, nurtures them and lets them grow. Right now he's one of the biggest fish they've got.

 Captain Corelli's Mandolin is released on May 4.
