Back then the actor was embraced by fans as a turbulent cult icon and dismissed by phobes as a showboating brat. The past five years have changed all that. Cage's renaissance kicked off with an Academy Award for his bourbon-soaked performance in Leaving Las Vegas, then built through the runaway box-office of popcorn blockbusters like The Rock, Con Air and Face/Off. These days his image glowers down from a billboard atop Sunset Boulevard and the local TV network trails its celebrity news with a clip of the man brandishing his Oscar. In Hollywood terms Nicolas Cage has arrived. The 37 year-old currently resides in that rarefied $20m bracket inhabited only by the select few (Cruise, Hanks, Carrey, Roberts). But he reached the summit via the scenic route. His eccentric, freewheeling picaresque would have landed most other actors on the scrap-heap. Our meeting is scheduled for 10am Sunday morning when Cage shows up, alert and ready to go, with 15 minutes to spare. In he comes, every inch your money movie star with his electric-blue suit, gym-slim torso and brisk pump of a handshake. And yet no amount of Beverly Hills grooming can quite plane down the man's rough edges. If your archetypal Hollywood player is compact and symmetrical in the flesh, Cage cuts a more outsize, Fauvist figure. The face is raw-boned, lugubrious; the hair perched high on a heavy forehead. "I feel like a modern actor, though some people have told me I look like I'm from medieval times," he remarks at one point. His voice is that of a stoner Elvis Presley. But then Cage has always been a bit of a mongrel: part Italian-American primitive, part indulged Hollywood prince, with a well-connected uncle in Francis Ford Coppola. Fittingly his films provide a jumble of extremes. In the early years the dark stuff dominated. The young Cage set out his stall with angsty, oddball roles as a Vietnam casualty in Birdy, a goofy repeat offender in Raising Arizona and the volatile, chain-smoking Sailor Ripley in David Lynch's Wild at Heart. At that time the exotic stylings easily dwarfed his more palatable, mainstream choices (Moonstruck, Peggy Sue Got Married). Recently the balance has swung to a more even keel. So Cage will tackle the scuzzy noir thriller 8mm and Martin Scorsese's anguished Bringing Out the Dead and then compensate with the homespun feel-goodisms of Family Man and the sun-dappled sweep of his latest picture, Captain Corelli's Mandolin. "I think I'm probably a little more comfortable playing the dark stuff," he admits. "But I know that if you don't do something light every now and then the dark will envelop everything and I'll be typecast as this dark, brooding, angry guy." Maybe he's mellowing. "When I started out I was really adamant about being a punk-rock kind of actor. I remember when I did Moonstruck I just hated myself for being in that movie because it was such a celebration of life. Now, of course, I look at Moonstruck and think: Oh, it's wonderful. What was I thinking? Why was I so angry? What was wrong with me?" These are questions he returns to, worrying at them, at various intervals throughout the interview. Let's assume, then, that Captain Corelli's Mandolin is the sort of picture that the Cage of old would have run a mile from. An overhaul of the Louis De Bernieres best-seller, it's an epic, old-school wartime romance; an expert weave of glittering Greek scenery, tumbling rustic comedy and high-flown declarations of love. Off-screen matters were more fractious. During the shoot Cage's five year marriage to actress Patricia Arquette sputtered to a halt (divorce papers were submitted, withdrawn and then submitted again). Meantime the news wires hummed with rumours of an on-set affair with his Spanish co-star Penelope Cruz. The film's director, Britain's John Madden, now dismisses such talk as simple tabloid froth. "It's absolute bullshit," he tells me. "Penelope and Nic became very good friends but certainly not lovers on the film." Then comes an abrupt caveat: "But their private lives are their business." For his part Cage is happier keeping off the personal issues. Artistically Captain Corelli's Mandolin was a stretch for him, he says. He normally feels more comfortable playing Americans, playing modern-day, and yet here he was as Corelli, a flamboyant Italian soldier (complete with sing-song Cornetto accent) adrift in 1940s Greece. On the other hand the role gave him the opportunity to connect with his ancestry, to feel his way into past generations. "If you allow me to be slightly metaphysical for a second I was trying to call upon the spirit of my dead grandfather, Carmine Coppola. I didn't spend that much time with my grandfather, but here I was in front of a 35mm camera and I would say: Come on Carmine. Get me through this." What was that like? "Wonderful," he says. So alright then. Cage found the film a challenge, a move into uncharted acting territory. Others, though, might be more sceptical. There have been suggestions that the man runs the risk of selling himself short with such mainstream forays. A year or two back Sean Penn was acid in his criticism; taking Cage to task over the increasing number of action blockbusters that crop up on his CV. At the time there was some confusion over exactly what was said. For the record, Penn never directly dismissed his fellow actor as a "sell-out". What he said was that: "Nic Cage is no longer an actor. He's more like a performer." On another occasion he was generally assumed to be referring to Cage's action-laden Con Air when he remarked that: "If there's anything more disgusting in the movie business it's the whoredom of my peers. It's a guy's arm coming out of the screen [and] jerking you off. I prefer to do it myself at home than have some guy contriving wet dreams for me." Cage would rather not get into a slanging match with Penn. After all, the pair were once firm friends. They acted together as youngsters, hung out off-set and their subsequent rise through the ranks shows them to be more similar than otherwise (two Hollywood kids with something of the roughneck about them). Still, the attack clearly rankles: "He's paying a little too much attention to my career, I think. I'm not thinking too much about what he's doing, you know. But he never said that I was a sell-out, so I don't know where that came from, OK? I had heard those words but not from him. But what he did say was that I wasn't an actor, and I can't agree with that. That's Sean's opinion and he's entitled to it. But for me acting has always been an expression, in any format. I happen to like action movies. For me that's a legitimate expression." Perhaps it all comes down to a question of taste. Penn's comments, I say, were presumably based on the belief that you can be an actor or a movie star, but you can't be both. Until now Cage has kept his cool. With this he almost explodes out of his seat. "I think that's so absurd. It's just absurd. All of my favourite actors were movie stars. What makes a movie star is somebody who is inimitable, whose voices you can imitate. Humphrey Bogart. James Cagney. Marlon Brando. Clint Eastwood. They're fascinating to watch and listen to. That doesn't make them bad actors. That just makes them inimitable and idiosyncratic and unique." Of course it can also make them extremely wealthy into the bargain, if they choose the right projects (or wrong ones, depending on your position). Take Cage, who pocketed a reported $20m for his turn in last year's Gone in 60 Seconds, an airbrushed cannonball run of a movie that can hardly have dug deep at his reserves of talent. I wonder if money is important to him. "Well, money's always important," he shrugs. "It enables you to live a certain lifestyle that you want. And if I told you that money isn't important, like some actors will, then I would be full of shit." Later on, still trying to pin down the man's motivations, I ask Cage to list what he reckons are his three most important movies. He names Wild at Heart, Mike Figgis's Leaving Las Vegas and Con Air, the film that so annoyed Penn. When I comment that this last one seems an unusual choice, Cage rolls his eyes skyward. "Why, because two are artistic and one is commercial? Why can't a commercial movie be artistic? They can be, you know. I hate those distinctions." Some clues to Cage current state - this cocktail of action heroics and Methody madness, of insider gloss and rude native energy - can be found in his childhood. He was born Nicolas Kim Coppola to an artistic middle-class family (dad August a professor in comparative literature, mum Joy a dancer and choreographer) and raised in a household steeped in books and opera and philosophy. Even as a child August had been a prodigious scholar. Nicolas, by contrast, kicked against conventional education and struggled at school. Instead the boy was a discerning pop-culture junkie; a devourer of Marvel comics, Bond movies and the horror novels of Stephen King. He remembers being six, sitting in front of the TV and furiously conspiring a way to get inside, to make a break from the living-room carpet and slip inside that fuzzy, heightened landscape which flickered behind the glass. That, he says, was when he first decided to become an actor. For Cage this meant Hollywood. Theatre never entered the picture. "No. And I know it's shocking and how dare I say it. Typical American. But I've just always wanted to be a film actor." He was a weird kid, "spooked". Most nights he had trouble sleeping. When he did eventually drop off he would be plagued by nightmares. A mannequin would come tapping at his window; a ventriloquist's dummy would swoop in over the bed. "Those things can be scary," he drawls, as though embarrassed at his own timidity. Meanwhile, downstairs, the Coppola home had troubles of its own. Joy suffered from schizophrenic episodes and was institutionalised for much of her son's childhood. The marriage eventually ended when Nic was 12, and he wound up going to live with his dad in San Francisco. Cage's mother has since recovered. Yet you can't help wondering whether her illness had anything to do with his childhood traumas; maybe even with the "dark stuff" he's so keen to explore in his work. "I don't know," he says. "I don't know about that." Then he pauses for the longest time. "I'd hesitate to comment on that because, you know, I think she's been through enough. I mean, I know that people know about it and that she's talked about it. But I'd rather not go down that road, if that's all the same with you." As a child Nic Cage would rip open his shirt and roar like the Incredible Hulk to ward off the playground bullies. Years later he would again look to Marvel Comics to kick-start his acting career. He was credited as Nicolas Coppola on his first movie, the 1982 teen romp Fast Times at Ridgemont High. After that he lifted his nom-de-plume from Luke Cage, a militant Afro-American superhero that Marvel developed as an early 70s response to Black Power. At the time he said that this was because he didn't want to be regarded as "some nepotistic asshole". Flushed with the success of The Godfather and Apocalypse Now, the Francis Coppola of the early 80s was still widely touted as America's most important film-maker. As a result, the name trailed a lot of baggage with it. "It was difficult in that I would go into the casting office and I would have all my lines memorised," Cage remembers. "And when you audition for a movie it's an incredibly painful process. You feel so vulnerable and oh, it's dreadful. So I would go in and I would just want to do the scene that I had prepared and I would have to talk about Francis for an hour before I could do the scene, and by then I had lost my whole concept of what I wanted to do. It was like they were just trying to get information. That," he finishes dryly, "was a little hard for me." That said, cynics could argue that the name change was merely cosmetic. Certainly the Coppola connection was crucial in sustaining him during that scrambling early dash. In fact, in his first four years in acting Cage made no fewer than three films with Coppola. He was the greaseball rival to Matt Dillon in Rumble Fish, a loutish "mad dog" enforcer in the jazz-era folly The Cotton Club and Kathleen Turner's high-school sweetheart turned obnoxious spouse in Peggy Sue Got Married. In this way, Uncle Francis effectively helped Cage get moving. He provided the stabiliser wheels as his young nephew pedalled precariously up the road to glory. By all accounts, the ride was a rocky one. Scarcely out of his teens, Cage was green and gauche and chippy; a surge of unrefined ability. Richard Corliss, the film writer for Time magazine, refers to him as "a student of the crypto-eccentric school of modern acting", and reckons that "some of his early performances were mannerist bordering on the grotesque". Fired up by the Method school, he would hurl himself headlong at every role, badgering his director with off-the-wall suggestions and carrying the character with him wherever he went. When the part was a dark or violent one, this would cause problems. While making The Cotton Club, Cage would finish a take, then go back and smash up his trailer. There is a story that, one morning, on the way to the set, he suddenly suspected that he was not feeling quite angry enough. To work up the requisite red-cloud-before-the-eyes, he attacked a remote- control car that was being operated by an LA street vendor; broke the thing into little bits. Is this true? "Yeah," says Cage, faintly shame-faced at such brattish behaviour. "Yeah." What did the vendor think of that? "He didn't like it. Nobody liked it. The whole street parted from one side to the next. People were screaming. Then I would go to work feeling ready to play the part. Conversely, if I was playing a really nice guy, I would have done really nice things." What, so you'd have bought the remote-control car? "Yeah," Cage agrees. "Well, actually, I did buy the car. I smashed it and then I gave him the money." Known for staffing his productions with family and friends, Coppola was largely tolerant of his nephew's antics. Others took a dimmer view. Matters reached a head during the 1985 filming of Peggy Sue Got Married. "I almost got fired off Peggy Sue Got Married," Cage recalls, "which would have been enormously painful. But I didn't want to make that movie, and Francis knew that. I just thought that the character as written was boring, and I told him that I wanted to go pretty far-out with it, and he said okay." Cage's concept of "pretty far-out" was to hotwire his Joe-Schmo protagonist with an array of tics and twitches, and to deliver his lines in a strangulated whistle. Executives from Tri-Star took one look at the early rushes and flipped. "The studio came up to fire me. Francis cooked them spaghetti and they ate it and they went home and they didn't fire me. But . . ." - a gust of breathy laughter - "I never worked with him again." By this point, apparently, even Uncle Francis's patience was at an end. Except that, all of a sudden, it didn't seem to matter any more. Even in such bull-in-a-china-shop mode, Cage had made a big impression. First Alan Parker hired him for Birdy ("That was the first time anybody really took me seriously as an actor"). Later, Cher demanded him as her co-star in Moonstruck, and the Coen brothers recruited him to play the baby-snatching hero of Raising Arizona, struggling to lock down his wilful idiosyncrasies yet still coming away with a brilliantly deadpan, disciplined performance. By the time of his extravagant, tour-de-force in 1990's Palme D'Or-winning Wild At Heart, there was a sense that Cage had at last grown into his talent. He was controlling it - as opposed to it controlling him. "Acting has always been a medicine for me," he says. "It's a way to get this shit out of my system. But you have to learn to control it, or it just invades you. You end up making yourself impossible to live with, and life impossible to live. I look back on those early days and wonder what was the matter." He does, however, suggest one culprit. "I was growing up watching James Dean, and I heard all the stories about him. How he was a pain in the ass as a person, but solid gold on screen. How he would come into a room going, 'Fuck you, fuck you, fuck you'." Cage gestures aggressively at invisible guests surrounding us. "And I thought, 'Is that what you have to do? Is that how you have to be?' And the answer, of course, is no. But tell that to a 17-year-old boy who wants to be an actor. So, yeah, I would trash the trailer, trash the hotel room, all that stuff. But that kind of behaviour at 37 would be really reprehensible." David Lynch calls Nic Cage "the jazz musician of American acting". In the past, perhaps, his repertoire was mainly limited to variations on either dopey or menacing. But the last decade has seen him hone and expand his repertoire. He has added layers in between, and learnt to sprinkle telling moments of stillness in amid the storms. At times his natural extrovert exuberance can still leave him caught out (he looked ill at ease, for instance, playing the numbed ambulance-driving observer in Scorsese's Bringing Out the Dead). But now the bum notes are few and far between. Since coming of age in public, Cage has blossomed into one of his generation's most potent and compelling performers. Cast him in a mainstream, formula flick and he brings a bracing dose of madness to the role. Fit him inside a dark, quirky movie and he humanises it, keeps it rooted in reality. The wild energies of his formative years have now been harnessed. As a kid he used Hollywood as his playground. As a man he effectively runs the place. The interview is over. In comes Cage's personal assistant to wrap it up, and the two retreat for a hurried conversation in an adjacent room. A moment later she's back again, buttonholing me as I pour a cup of coffee. The personal assistant just wants to make sure that we are crystal clear on the Sean Penn quote; that Penn never actually referred to Nic as a sell-out. No, that's fine, I say. I know that he didn't. I just want you to be absolutely sure, she says again. She cannot stress it enough. By rights this should be Nic Cage's day off. He's currently a month into the filming of Adaptation with Spike Jonze, the maverick director of Being John Malkovich. Jonze is married to Sofia Coppola, the daughter of Francis who is now also a film-maker in her own right. The Coppola connection is still there, it seems. The difference is that now it is Cage who is its fulcrum. In terms of status and visibility, he is the Godfather now. When today's round of interviews are over, a studio car will arrive to stretch-limo the actor back home. Cage's route will lead him up past Hollywood Boulevard, where he has a star on the Walk of Fame, and into the hills where he lives in a faux-Bavarian castle flanked by an army of vintage European sports cars. Tomorrow another limousine will squire him back down to the movie set where he will find his trailer, his entourage and the cameras prepared to catch his next burst of pyrotechnics. Because Hollywood looks after its own, nurtures them and lets them grow. Right now he's one of the biggest fish they've got.  Captain Corelli's Mandolin is released on May 4.

fields.headline: Cecconi, London W1
fields.trailText:
Telephone: 020-7434 1500
Address: 5a Burlington Gardens, London W1
Rating: 17/20
fields.body:
Telephone: 020-7434 1500
Address: 5a Burlington Gardens, London W1
Rating: 17/20

Once upon a time, Cecconi was the kind of restaurant to which I would give a wide berth. Apart from the legendary inflated nature of its prices, it oozed literally and metaphorically that spurious oleaginous charm that certain Italian restaurants seemed to have delivered every morning along with the vats of cheap olive oil. This attracted the kind of clientele that seems to be made up entirely of passing dons of the non-academic variety, Mayfair toadies and assorted Eurotrash, whose discernment and aesthetic appeal was in inverse proportion to the size of their wallets. Now Cecconi has been revitalised, redesigned, and relaunched upon the world, and all has changed. Or has it?

Well, the food has, that's for sure. The man in charge of the kitchen is actually Nick Bell, but the man whose name has been drawing in the celebrity critics (not to mention the dons, toadies and Eurofolk) is Giorgio Locatelli, recently departed from Zafferano, who has been called in as executive chef or consultant, or some such arrangement.

Signor Locatelli, as readers of this column may well know by now, is one of the contemporary colossi of the London restaurant scene, a man whose charm is as great as his skill as a chef, and who was rightly named London chef of the year in the Mo¿t et Chandon London restaurant awards this year. It is slightly unfair, although understandable, that the excellence of Nick Bell should be overshadowed by Locatelli-mania. While the Locatelli inspiration is all over the menu, the daily delivery of the dishes depends on Bell, who worked at Zafferano for several years. Indeed, Locatelli was not on the premises on the day that Tetra and I went for a lunch so, while he may receive a good deal of praise for the excellencies of the menu, Bell should receive a round of applause for the beauty on the plate.

And there was plenty of it. Summer minestrone was subtle, soothing and herbal, evocative of sunlight filtered through green leaves, and quite at odds with the deluge engulfing Mayfair at that moment. Ravioli of oxtail managed to combine the ingratiating tenderness and sweetness of the long- cooked meat with a sauce of magisterial authority and pleasurable penetration. Saltimbocca of red mullet - that is, a brace of fillets of the said fish wrapped in prosciutto and fried to form a crisp carapace on the outside - was superbly executed, but I have nagging doubts about the basis of the dish because red mullet is such a strongly and distinctively flavoured fish that it needs a suitably robust treatment, and this was too refined to hold it in check.

That did for me, and Tetra did for a salad of chicory, gorgonzola and pear, an Italian variation of the classic French salad of endive, Roquefort and pear, which lost nothing in the comparison because the individual elements were so classy - they had her twittering like a songbird with delight. Then Tetra did for liver with onions, parsnip mash and spinach, which, while a combination that owed more to British tradition than to Italian, was completely Italian in its superb handling of the liver and the dulcet sweetness of the onion.

We had to pass on pudding with regret, but all in all this is Italian cooking by an Italian and English team of a very superior calibre. However, though many of the dishes have a pared-down quality that allows you to concentrate on the flavours produced by knowledgeable and skilful cooking, I wouldn't say that it was all as authentic as can be, what with the vegetables and sauce on the same plate, but when food tastes this good, authenticity can go hang.

I wish I could say the same about the redesign and the service. The former was altogether too dull, brown, linear and formal, and the latter too chirpy, intrusive and informal for comfort. Maybe the clientele, which does not appear to have changed since I last went 15 years ago, likes that kind of thing, and the price it comes at.

Our bill was £105.43, which represents something of a cut-price effort compared with former days, but is not exactly a snip by current standards, especially as we drank modestly by the glass. The mark reflects my feelings about the food, not the place. It seems unfair to tax such good food with the sins of conventional surroundings and service.

· Open Mon-Sat, 12 noon-3pm, 7-11pm. All major credit cards. Wheelchair access and WC for wheelchair users.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: 'One of the most exciting aspects of my trip to Argentina last month was the revelation that within five years La Agricola vineyards will ideally be wholly organic.'
fields.body:
One of the most exciting aspects of my trip to Argentina last month was not dancing at midnight with a beautiful young local winemaker, under a vivid half-moon in the middle of a Mendoza vineyard within sight of the snow-capped Andes, but the revelation, by Jos Alberto Zuccardi of La Agricola vineyards, that within five years he would like all his considerable acres of vines to be wholly organic. Indeed, I see nothing to prevent Argentina from becoming the leading organic wine producer in the world, if only more local producers would seize the initiative that La Agricola, and also Norton Vineyards, have begun by already obtaining organic accreditation for certain of their vines. When the wines that these vines produce are on sale,

I hope they are exemplary since, on the evidence of the organic grapes I tasted at both operations, the fruit is finely concentrated. We shall see if this juice produces outstanding wines; organically grown grapes are not a guarantee of a superior product in bottle.

Tesco's Picajuan Peak Chardonnay 2000, for example, is made by La Agricola from conventionally farmed grapes, and very charming it is, too. It has a lovely balance of elements that strike warmly yet refreshingly, showing melon, pear and lemon. There is real bargain quaffing here for £3.79. It rates 15.5 points out of 20.

Tesco has some other interesting white wines, two of which form part of this retailerÕs Australian wine promotion, which sees 20% off all Aussie bottles until May 8. Two of the most highly rated of these wines are Normans Unwooded Chardonnay 2000 (16.5 points, down to £3.99 from £4.99) and Tim Adams Semillon 1997 (17 points, down to £6.39 from £7.99). The Norman's wine offers quite superb richness, elegance and finesse, and is a remarkably complete wine for the money, demonstrating its purity of fruit in several ways. It may contain added natural acids, but it is finely balanced. The Adams, meanwhile, has striking lovely fruit of strident citricity, richness and layered tonality. It has hints of pear, apple and lip-smacking minerals, and is a superbly classy, complex specimen that is in limited distribution at those Tescos disposed to stock it (call 0800 505555 for details). More widely distributed at Tesco is Luis Felipe Edwards Chardonnay 1999, from Chile. This has beautiful subtlety with a controlled creamy richness that reveals gentle layers of melon, wood, lemon, pineapple and, again, that cream on the finish. This wine rates 16.5 points and costs £4.99.

Asda also has some entertaining wines from Chile and Argentina. Undurraga Gewürztraminer 2000 (16 points, £4.96), from Chile, is a wine from this producer that has some positive excitement. This is a really accomplished gewrz: spicy, balanced, rich and elegant, and it makes a terrific aperitif. From Argentina, Asda has Casa Latina Shiraz Tempranillo 1999 (16 points, £3.98), which has a vibrant buzz about its ripe, tannically-rich fruit. It has a plump texture that really sticks to the tastebuds and adheres nicely to spicy food. Also at Asda is Big Chilean Cabernet 2000 (15 points, £6.99 in the 1.5-litre bottle), which has piles of savoury plums, a hint of raspberry and a suggestion of herbs.

Two interesting Asda Cape reds are Graham Beck Coastal Shiraz 1999 (16 points, £6.96) and Neil Ellis Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16.5 points, £9.99).

Mr Beck offers brilliant softness and integrated tannins, ripe plums, and a hint of strawberry. Mr Ellis presents the delightful aroma of spicy blackcurrants, elegant layered fruit, delicious integrated acids and a lovely, lilting finish. This is a terrific cabernet in limited distribution.

Unlike so many British red-wine drinkers, Asda has not abandoned the pricey side of France. Château Haut Bernat Puisseguin-St Emilion 1995 (16.5 points, £10.97) has lovely, complex layers of fruit and rich, balancing tannins. This is a bright, serious claret in limited supply. As is Château Biston Brillette Moulis 1997 (16.5 points, £8.97), which flaunts the classic cheroot aroma of Oxbridge claret, superb tannins and a truly sumptuous texture. And last, from both France and Asda, there is Tramontane Sauvignon Blanc 2000 (14.5 points, £3.99), which offers a charming touch of ripe gooseberry to its minerals. If youÕve got a trout on the plate, or indeed a trout in the next dining chair, this is a companionable wine.

fields.bodyText: One of the most exciting aspects of my trip to Argentina last month was not dancing at midnight with a beautiful young local winemaker, under a vivid half-moon in the middle of a Mendoza vineyard within sight of the snow-capped Andes, but the revelation, by Jos Alberto Zuccardi of La Agricola vineyards, that within five years he would like all his considerable acres of vines to be wholly organic. Indeed, I see nothing to prevent Argentina from becoming the leading organic wine producer in the world, if only more local producers would seize the initiative that La Agricola, and also Norton Vineyards, have begun by already obtaining organic accreditation for certain of their vines. When the wines that these vines produce are on sale, I hope they are exemplary since, on the evidence of the organic grapes I tasted at both operations, the fruit is finely concentrated. We shall see if this juice produces outstanding wines; organically grown grapes are not a guarantee of a superior product in bottle. Tesco's Picajuan Peak Chardonnay 2000, for example, is made by La Agricola from conventionally farmed grapes, and very charming it is, too. It has a lovely balance of elements that strike warmly yet refreshingly, showing melon, pear and lemon. There is real bargain quaffing here for £3.79. It rates 15.5 points out of 20. Tesco has some other interesting white wines, two of which form part of this retailerÕs Australian wine promotion, which sees 20% off all Aussie bottles until May 8. Two of the most highly rated of these wines are Normans Unwooded Chardonnay 2000 (16.5 points, down to £3.99 from £4.99) and Tim Adams Semillon 1997 (17 points, down to £6.39 from £7.99). The Norman's wine offers quite superb richness, elegance and finesse, and is a remarkably complete wine for the money, demonstrating its purity of fruit in several ways. It may contain added natural acids, but it is finely balanced. The Adams, meanwhile, has striking lovely fruit of strident citricity, richness and layered tonality. More widely distributed at Tesco is Luis Felipe Edwards Chardonnay 1999, from Chile. fields.headline: Nineteen, Brighton
fields.trailText: This discreet hotel, really more of an upmarket B&B, is located up a sidestreet off the Brighton seafront.
fields.body:
Address: 19 Broad Street, Brighton BN2 1TJ.

Tel: 01273 675529.

Fax: 01273 675531.

Website: www.hotelnineteen.co.uk

First impressions: This discreet hotel, really more of an upmarket B&B, is located up a sidestreet off the Brighton seafront. A townhouse, it has been painted slate grey and the word nineteen, written in blue,gives the only indication that it is not a private house.

The rooms: The seven rooms vary in size but all are white, come with mirrored wardrobes and are filled with fragrant fresh flowers. Some have CD players but all have TV and video and the hotel stocks a great selection of films.

The bed test: Built on a platform of glass bricks that allows an oceanic blue light to filter through, they are vast and covered in crisp white cotton.

Bathroom: Mine was a small, white-tiled affair with just a shower but other rooms have baths. The toiletries were basic but owner Keith has just agreed a deal to stock the exclusive Espa range which, in the tiny form, will be worth pocketing.

Restaurant: There is no restaurant, just a breakfast room and a small outside eating area. Guests can nip into the kitchen and help themselves to tea and coffee at any time of the day or night.

What is there to see within walking distance? The seafront is just two minutes away and so is the Palace Pier with its dolphin derby and dodgem cars. The lovely Lanes shopping area is also nearby.

What is there to do in the evening? Nineteen is seconds away from some of the best clubs in Brighton, including the Escape and the Catfish.

How much a night: Rates vary from £95 for a double room with en-suite shower to £125 for kingsize room with bathroom.

webTitle: Troubled life of prostitute at centre of Archer libel trial

fields.headline: Troubled life of prostitute at centre of Archer libel trial
fields.standfirst: 'Loving mother' dragged through newspapers and courts for meagre financial reward
fields.trailText: Monica Coghlan was first trapped in the public eye on October 26 1986, when a grainy photograph of her was published in the News of the World. It had been taken two days previously on platform three at Victoria Station, and showed her accepting an envelope stuffed with £50 notes from Michael Stacpoole, a friend and colleague of Jeffrey Archer.
fields.body:
Monica Coghlan was first trapped in the public eye on October 26 1986, when a grainy photograph of her was published in the News of the World. It had been taken two days previously on platform three at Victoria Station, and showed her accepting an envelope stuffed with £50 notes from Michael Stacpoole, a friend and colleague of Jeffrey Archer.

It was the beginning of a chain of events that would see the prostitute, then 35, dragged into one of the most notorious libel trials in British legal history, and leave her name forever associated with that of the then Conservative vice-chairman.

Ms Coghlan went to that meeting wearing two microphones, and was shadowed by a team of six reporters, some armed with cameras. The article accompanying that first photograph alleged that Lord Archer had given Stacpoole the money and instructed him to give it to Ms Coghlan. Lord Archer understood she would use the money to leave the country.

For nearly two months, said the paper, Coghlan had been 'at the centre of politically sensational claims involving Archer which he strongly denies'.

Lord Archer acknowledged the payment, describing it as a 'lack of judgment', but maintained he paid the money to help Ms Coghlan escape the reporters hounding her by going abroad.

Six days later however the Daily Star ran a story alleging that Lord Archer had been a client of Coghlan's. Lord Archer denied the allegation, sued, and the following summer received £500,000, an unprecedented damages award.

During the sensational three week hearing at the high court in London Ms Coghlan was portrayed as a piteous character, in sharp contrast to Mary Archer, the loyal and famously fragrant wife; her reputation was never to recover.

Ms Coghlan, one of seven children, was born in Greater Manchester in 1951 and suffered a troubled childhood. She never settled into education, leaving school aged 15. After leaving home she was the victim of a violent sexual attack and forced to leave the flat in which she had been living.

Short of both money and opportunity she was working as a prostitute aged just 17. In the 18 years that followed before the incident at Victoria Station she was convicted of shop-lifting and possessing cannabis as well as prostitution, and served two prison terms.

In 1985 she had a son, Robin, and moved into a small bungalow in her home town of Rochdale where she lived a double life. During the week she cared for her son alone following the death of her partner, and at weekends he was left with neighbours or relatives as she travelled to London, where she would turn tricks.

She told relatives she was involved in the property trade. In fact she was based at the Albion Hotel in Shepherd's Market, a corner of Mayfair synonymous with the sex trade since Victorian times, where she met her clients and earned enough money to tide her over until the next week.

To family and friends alike her occupation came as a surprise when it was splashed across the papers, but all spoke of her devotion to her son. 'We have to accept that this was her profession but I am not going to condemn her,' her brother, Tommy, said following the first revelations.

'I am not making moral judgments about her. As far as I'm concerned I know her as a good sister to me and a great mother to her son. She adores her little boy and she is a good member of the family.'

During the libel trial Ms Coghlan was in the witness stand for 13 hours and was regularly in tears under cross examination by Lord Archer's counsel, Robert Alexander. Accused of lying she said: 'You're the liar... You're the one that's making vast amounts of money, not me. I'm penniless through all this... what's going to happen to me?'

In summing up, Mr Justice Caulfield, having told the jury that Mary was 'fragrant', said they may feel 'a great deal of pity' for Ms Coghlan. Her involvement with the News of the World did not provide a financial escape from the streets.

Reporters who worked with her on the Archer sting insist that she never asked for money or expenses during the six weeks she spent under the paper's wing, and in court she said she had been paid around £6,000. She later posed topless for photos, earning another £5,400. Even by the standards of the 1980s this was small beer for a story that resonates more than a decade on.

In recent years Ms Coghlan earned a living calling numbers at a bingo hall close to her terraced home in Rochdale and had settled into life away from the public eye, but that peace was not due to last.

The trial of Lord Archer and his former friend, Ted Francis, is due to start on May 15th, and will focus on the author's alibis for the night he was alleged to have spent with Ms Coghlan.

She was not expected to be called to give evidence. Now she has joined the list of those who were touched by the saga - Mr Justice Caulfield, Ted Baker who provided Archer's crucial alibi, and Lloyd Turner, then editor of the Daily Star - but did not live to see its conclusion.

webTitle: Review: On Green Dolphin Street by Sebastian Faulks

fields.headline: Tourist tale
fields.standfirst: Sebastian Faulks goes to the US in On Green Dolphin Street, but he can't do the lingo, says  Jay Parini
fields.trailText: Sebastian Faulks goes to the US in On Green Dolphin Street, but he can't do the lingo, says Jay Parini
fields.body:
On Green Dolphin Street
Sebastian Faulks
341pp, Hutchinson, £16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Sebastian Faulks has become an international sensation, attracting countless readers to his entertaining French trio, The Girl at the Lion d'Or , Birdsong and Charlotte Gray . The last - which details the adventures in France of Faulks's eponymous heroine, Miss Gray, during the second world war - will soon be a film, directed by Gillian Armstrong. This adaptation may propel the novel itself to the level of Birdsong , which can only be called a phenomenon. Now, with a surprising shift of novelistic scene, comes On Green Dolphin Street , set mostly in the United States in 1959.

It is not wonderful, though I found the story oddly compelling at certain points. Rather as you do with a decent television drama, I turned happily enough to the book every night for several days, wondering what would happen next. My hunch is that this is where the secret of Faulks's success with readers lies: he makes one interested in his characters and their fates, however stereotyped. He does this by dwelling on their vulnerabilities, while hinting at their secret strengths. There is a powerful tendency to "identify" with such characters, as all gifted storytellers know - especially those who focus on genre fiction.

On Green Dolphin Street rises several steps above the cheap romance novel. The plot, certainly, would be familiar to devotees of that genre: a bored housewife, married to a charming but neurotic drunk, with two lovely children, falls for a divorced newspaper reporter. She has a surreptitious affair with him, hiding her activities, more or less successfully, until the end. The husband cracks up from drink and depression. Out of pity more than love, she goes back to him, sacrificing her new-found happiness because, well, she must. It's the right thing to do.

There is more, of course, and that's where Faulks lays claim to being a genuinely interesting writer. As he showed rather triumphantly in Birdsong , he can summon a particular time and place with considerable skill, deftly relating individual stories to a broader historical scene. Although he often relies on period clichés -as when evoking life in the muddy trenches of the first world war - he understands their power and milks the drama in them for what it is worth. His flashes forward to the 1970s in Birdsong seemed pale and tedious by comparison, and one longed to get back to the trenches.

On Green Dolphin Street is another attempt to call forth a period in history, and a special place. As the novel opens, it is 1959 in Washington. Charlie van der Linden is a British diplomat, an expert in American politics with supposedly close ties to the Kennedy entourage. (The presidential primaries and the election campaign form a backdrop to the novel's progress, culminating in the famous television debate between the candidates.) The novel's heroine is Mary van der Linden, a model diplomatic wife who reluctantly packs off her children to boarding schools in Britain. Her husband is a high-flyer in the diplomatic corps who enjoys making up fake quotations from Wallace Stevens and Emily Dickinson; he also smokes and drinks with suicidal abandon. Frank Renzo, who becomes Mary's lover, is described as a "tall, lean man, his cropped hair showing the first dust of grey; his accent was from the urban midwest". I'm an American, married to a woman from the urban midwest, but I would not recognise such an accent.

Mary is nicely drawn, and the flashbacks to her first love affair during the war with a man later killed in action are memorable. Charlie, whose alcoholism is wrenchingly dramatised, lingers in the mind as a vivid character. Mary's dying mother and grieving father in London are movingly portrayed, too. The problem comes with the novelist's portrait of America and Americans. I found myself so distracted by minor errors that my involvement in the plot was frequently interrupted, and I began to doubt that any of the details were right. For example, Charlie is often seen gulping Tylenols to soothe a hangover, though anyone who lived through that era knows that Tylenols didn't exist then. Faulks appears to believe that John Kennedy went to law school (as did his brothers, Robert and Ted), and that the man who moderated the Nixon-Kennedy debate was called Howard Smith, when - as every American knows - this famous television presenter was always referred to as Howard K Smith. (I'm not being petty: to call him Howard Smith is like referring to FDR as FR.) I could multiply examples, but won't bother.

Faulks has an unfortunate tendency to rely on stereotypes to evoke an American scene. One example will suffice: Frank Renzo has supposedly been demoted at his newspaper for his coverage of a racist killing in Mississippi - the Emmett Till case, which is well known. In setting the scene, Faulks writes: "Frank noticed that almost all the local men seemed to be armed. Old boys in stray hats sitting on the verandah had shotguns across their knees; twin barrels poked from farm debris in the back of a pick-up truck; even in the grey brick courthouse, he saw more than one pearl handle sticking out from a straining waistband." What's wrong with this scene? For a start, it relies on every hackneyed image one could imagine. The "old boys" are not, as British readers might guess, Old Etonians. They are "good old boys". The pearl handles in the courthouse seem better suited to a Western than southern film.

Suffice it to say, no American reader will find this scene anything but parodic. Nor will they swallow many of the attempts at reproducing American vernacular, as when Charlie asks a couple of Americans what they are drinking and they reply "Martini", when they would say "Martinis". This is small stuff, but novels are made of small stuff like this. Faulks obviously needs to spend more time watching American television shows.

On the other hand, I frequently found myself writing "good!" in the margins, as when Mary's mother, Elizabeth, dies at home, and she and her father go into the sitting room to remember her. "They talked with a candour induced by the knowledge that there was nothing left to conceal; they remembered what Elizabeth had been like, what they had loved about her and what they had never understood, the mysterious motivations, the corrugations of her individual temperament. For long periods, they were quiet, exhausted, but with a sense that something had happened in its proper place; they were made silent by awe." It is in moments like this that Faulks does justice to his real talents, lifting the narrative into fresher, headier air.

Nobody will mistake On Green Dolphin Street for a work of art, but Mary's internal conflicts - in all their drab ordinariness - are tenderly embodied, while Charlie's existential despair, which alcohol amplifies more than soothes, is movingly rendered. Frank remains cardboard-thin beside the van der Lindens, and I never understood what Mary saw in him. Though entertained, I trolled these pages for those moments of extremely fine perception that make Faulks worth reading. Unfortunately, they were few and far between.

Jay Parini's sixth novel, The Apprentice Lover , will appear next year in the US from HarperCollins.

fields.headline: Be the loan ranger
fields.standfirst: Home loans costs are back to levels last seen when the Beatles ruled the hit parade. Now it's Emma Bunton and Hear'say topping the charts, writes Tony Levene.
fields.trailText: Home loans costs are back to levels last seen when the Beatles ruled the hit parade. Now it's Emma Bunton and Hear'say topping the charts.
fields.body:
Home loans costs are back to levels last seen when the Beatles ruled the hit parade. Now it's Emma Bunton and Hear'say topping the charts.

But it's not just the style of singles that's changed. Back in the mid-60s, home loans came in plain vanilla - and you had to grovel to get one.

Now the range has never been wider or more confusing, whether it's a first time purchase or a remortgage.

Home buyers need to find the best value. And the best way to do that is to always talk to at least three banks or building societies and three independent brokers.

But mortgage advice is unregulated. So borrowers also need to avoid being tied up in the small print that can turn an apparent bargain into a nightmare. They cannot turn to the financial services authority if they end up with a bad deal or suspect they have been "mis-sold".

Jobs and Money has teamed up with lender NewWorld to offer some pointers:

 Look at the APR

The headline-quoted rate on a mortgage states the rate of interest you pay. In contrast, the APR reflects the total cost of credit including the interest, charges, fees or compulsory insurance purchases that the borrower has to pay for. The bigger the gap between the two, the more likely it is that fees and other charges are involved.

 Come-on rates

Ask whether a cheap introductory rate reverts to an expensive standard variable rate, and how long any tie-in will be. You could find the low cost months are more than offset by expensive repayments later. It's not worth paying for one year of lower payments then 24 years of uncompetitive ones. Find out what you might be forced to pay when your short-term deal ends. These days it can often revert to a very high rate.

 Extra repayments

When inflation was high it made sense to delay paying as long as possible. But now you should make overpayments when you can afford them and pay off your mortgage ahead of schedule. Ask whether you will penalised.

If paying off debt saves you £200 in interest but your lender charges you £250 for this, there is no benefit. Always ask for specific examples - avoid banks which say penalties are tied to money market rates.

 Will I pay fees?

Some home loan deals add on substantial legal, valuation and other charges. Others say these are "free" or offer a cash amount to pay for them.

Ask for illustrations showing repayments on the loan with no extra charges - and compare that with the rival loan plus the costs.

 Can you extend the loan?

Find out whether you can increase the amount borrowed and how much this might cost. You need to know what will happen if you need an emergency loan.

 Ask what flexible features apply

The right to overpay is the most important flexible feature because the benefits of reducing the interest you pay can be substantial. Daily interest calculation is now commonplace.

Payment holidays can be useful for lifestyle changes such as having children - but they can be a trap leading to higher payments later.

 Fixed vs variable

There is some evidence that variable rates are cheaper over the longer term. But the real choice for homebuyers is not between one price level and another but between the security of monthly payments with the fixed loan and taking a chance on the variable rate. For those who can afford to live with the ups and downs of interest rates, the second option, which avoids the costs that monthly certainty bring, could be better.

Fixed interest loan buyers should also watch out for possible future shocks when their deal ends - if rates increase substantially, their monthly payments will leap.

 Length of deal

Almost everyone has some sort of deal - a fix, a discount, a cashback offer - when they start a new loan or remortgage an existing arrangement. Short-term deals often seem better value and offer greater flexibility. But each new loan involves new fees, so don't forget to factor these into the equation.

fields.headline: Brokers come second best to DIY research
fields.trailText: Teri Harman needed to remortgage to finance an extension, so Jobs & Money sent her out to test the deals offered by banks and brokers. She wasn't very impressed - particularly with the service from smaller brokers. Here's what she found:
fields.body:
Teri Harman needed to remortgage to finance an extension, so Jobs & Money sent her out to test the deals offered by banks and brokers. She wasn't very impressed - particularly with the service from smaller brokers. Here's what she found:

When I first applied for a mortgage 20 years ago the choice was between repayments and endowments. But when we decided to build an extension, and to remortgage our home to pay for it, we found it a whole new world, with a new vocabulary to match.

I set out to discover whether it was worth consulting a mortgage broker to cut through the complexity and find the best deal.

Top of my list was the much-advertised Charcol, whose representative Darren Wiltshire told me they had access to more than 4,000 products from more than 150 lenders. Some deals are exclusive to Charcol.

I told him we wanted to borrow £88,000. Mr Wiltshire sensibly suggested that first I should ask my existing lender what they would offer to avoid fees for switching.

But after 16 years Lloyds TSB did not want to know. They would increase my loan but only at the high rate I wanted to flee.

Mr Wiltshire said Charcol would charge up to 1% of the amount borrowed, payable on completion - in my case £880 - but he stressed this payment was for their advice, not for arranging the loan, which was free.

This may explain why advice from Charcol-online.com is free. You only get recommendations, although you can take advantage of exclusive deals, typically discounts of 2% to 3% for a limited period. If you buy these, there's a booking fee of £49.

Next I phoned Charcol's parent company, Bradford & Bingley, which also promises independent advice. Caroline Cooke from my nearest branch called back and suggested a meeting. She quoted a fee of £350 based on the amount I wanted to borrow and said there were "currently some fantastic deals where all legal and other fees would be included".

From Yellow Pages I tried a couple of smaller brokers. Andy Bradshaw of Bradshaw Associates in Ipswich took some details and quoted a flat £250 fee, payable on completion. What he did not explain on the phone - although it was in the small print of the advert - was that his company represented Legal & General for investment business. He called back within an hour and recommended the L&G base rate tracker mortgage.

Mandy Miller of E-zeemortgage, whom I contacted by email after failing to get a reply on the 0800 number, also failed to tell me that her company was a tied agent for Scottish Amicable (again, it was in the small print of the ad). But this applied only to investments; mortgage advice was unbiased.

The fee was £395, which could be added to the overall loan. I had to complete a questionnaire, and her response was the slowest. She came up with a couple of Abbey National loans - a discount mortgage (5% until April 2003, monthly repayment: £710.23, with an early redemption penalty only during the discount period) or 5.45% fixed rate until April 2003, monthly repayment: £733.95. There was a £195 booking fee on the latter, payable to Abbey.

In the end, we did our own research and came up with Woolwich Open Plan - an all-in-one scheme which offsets current account and savings cash against the loan.

There are a number of these plans - from Intelligent Finance, Britannic Money and Virgin among others - but none of the brokers I spoke to mentioned the idea. These plans are largely sold through the companies themselves.

Controversially, a mortgage is one of the few financial products where those offering advice still don't come under the control of a regulator. The Mortgage Code, which offers some degree of protection, is voluntary.

Brokers are also not allowed to charge a fee in connection with advice about mortgages conforming to the new Cat standards for investments, which means they are unlikely to recommend such loans.

There is a vast amount of information about mortgages, especially on the internet, which alerts you to deals offered by smaller building societies, such as Skipton, Loughborough, Scarborough, Hinckley & Rugby and West Bromwich - all of which are in the "best buy" lists.

You can find general information at moneyfacts.co.uk. If you don't have web access, Moneyfacts' faxback service on 0906 076 0701 offers a best mortgage selection which is updated daily.

Try kmc.co.uk if you have had problems getting a loan because you don't meet normal lending criteria. The Kensington Mortgage Company is a lender specialising in non-standard mortgages.

webTitle: Big switch can save you a fortune

fields.headline: Big switch can save you a fortune
fields.trailText: If you are one of the many people languishing on your lender's base mortgage or standard variable rate (SVR) because you think it would cost too much time or money to remortgage, then think again.
fields.body:
If you are one of the many people languishing on your lender's base mortgage or standard variable rate (SVR) because you think it would cost too much time or money to remortgage, then think again.

Just make a phone call, fill in a few forms, and you could be hundreds or even thousands a year better off.

In the past five years only 12% of consumers have switched lender, according to the Department of Trade and Industry. This compares to 53% of motorists who have swapped car insurance and 30% of consumers who have switched home insurance.

Remortgaging can be used to raise capital or even wipe out debts. And it's easy, according to advisers.

Lenders should be able to kit you out with your new mortgage within four to six weeks. Some, like Woolwich, even offer a rapid remortgaging service which keeps paperwork to a minimum.

Your first port of call should be your existing lender, as you may be able to negotiate a better rate without having to pay any fees. Also try rival banks and building societies and ring around the mortgage brokers.

But you must do your sums to see if a switch makes sense for you. A lower interest rate elsewhere may be enticing, but it will not be worth making the switch if you have to stump up a hefty redemption penalty to get out of your current deal.

You must also factor in all the charges involved in setting up a new mortgage. You can expect to pay fees of around £900 when you remortgage for £100,000 - £250 in valuation fees, £300 in solicitor's fees and £300 for the lender's arrangement fee. You may also be asked to pay the mortgage indemnity premium which protects the lender if you fall behind with your repayments, a deeds release fee of £50 and a funds transfer fee of £25.

A growing number of lenders are paying these costs themselves to attract more customers, but it is usually at the expense of the interest rate they offer. Again, do your sums before choosing a fees-free deal.

If a borrower with an interest-only loan of £50,000 were to remortgage an SVR of 7.24% with no redemption penalties to the Halifax's base rate tracker, which has a current pay rate of 5.45%, they would save about £1,790 in interest during the first two years.

If they had to pay all the remortgage fees mentioned above, the interest saving would fall to £865 during the first two years.

The impact of fees means you should go for a fees-free deal if you are remortgaging for less than £100,000.

Alliance & Leicester's two-year discount mortgage, which has a current payable rate of 5.24%, no arrangement fee and free valuation, as well as £250 cashback.

With another interest rate cut on the cards some time this year, perhaps you are waiting to see what happens - don't, say brokers.

If you sit tight you could be stuck on your lender's SVR for a further six months.

There already deals where future rate cuts have been factored in, such as GMAC's two-year fixed rate mortgage which has a payable rate of 4.99%. But this is only available to the cash rich - you have to stump up a deposit of 25%. The arrangement fee is £295 and there is a 5% redemption penalty in the fixed term.

London & Country recommends Britannic Money's 5.35% fixed-rate mortgage, which has no penalties at any time as well as a contribution towards valuation, free legal fees and no arrangement fee.

fields.headline: Pro-hunt alliance funded RSPCA infiltrator
fields.trailText: The pro-hunting Countryside Alliance covertly funded an attempted infiltration of the RSPCA led by a former Olympic showjumper, according to leaked documents seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
The pro-hunting Countryside Alliance covertly funded an attempted infiltration of the RSPCA led by a former Olympic showjumper, according to leaked documents seen by the Guardian.

The animal charity has accused Richard Meade, who won three Olympic medals in 1968 and 1972, of spearheading a campaign to encourage 600 hunt supporters to join the society to overturn the society's long-standing opposition to bloodsports.

Mr Meade faces possible expulsion by the RSPCA, which is planning to look at legal options to force him to leave the society at a future meeting of its ruling council.

His group, the Countryside Animal Welfare Group, set up five years ago, consists of 5,000 RSPCA members who want to make the charity support fox hunting.

The internal accounts of the Countryside Alliance, seen by the Guardian, show that in 1999, it gave Cawg at least £13,490 to fund a mailshot and the "fees and expenses'' of Mr Meade. The alliance admitted that this was part of a larger sum over a longer period but declined to disclose the full amount that had been given to the showjumper.

Nigel Henson, the alliance's director of communications, said the unpublicised funding was "entirely consistent'' with its support for Cawg's aims. He added: "This is yet another disingenuous attempt by the anti-hunting lobby to smear the reputation of the alliance, and we are fed up with it.'' Mr Meade said Cawg had "certainly'' received money from the alliance, but was "not part'' of the alliance. 'On the whole, we are separate, particularly now. Initially there was a bit of help,' he said.

Ben Stewart of the International Fund for Animal Welfare said: "This is blatant dirty tricks. You have to wonder just how low this lot will sink.'' In January, the RSPCA won the legal right to make people say why they wanted to join the society after an attempt by Mr Meade to recruit members of hunts.

fields.headline: The expert gardener
fields.standfirst: What to plant with a Michaelmas daisy
fields.trailText: What to plant with a Michaelmas daisy
fields.body:
One of the most supportive perennials in late summer and early autumn is Aster x frikartii 'Mönch' (0.8m). It is a Michaelmas daisy with a difference, having quite large mauve flowers on stems that branch only towards the top.

I have been discussing with a designer friend how best to use it effectively in the garden, and he suggests having a purple-leaved cotinus behind it, Cotinus coggygria 'Royal Purple'. Grown entirely for its foliage, which is paddle shaped and magnificently translucent when backlit by sunshine, this fast-growing shrub can (and should) be pruned back hard each winter, which both limits its size and produces the best leaves.

Now for a partner by the side or in front of the aster. My designer friend thought of Coreopsis verticillata (0.7m), which has a wiry, upright habit, elegant, finely divided leaves and lots of bright, slightly acid, yellow daisies. That would look fine at the start of the aster's flowering season, but would rather leave it in the lurch later on. The same with the crocosmias that we thought of. Whether these flower early or late, it is not for anything like as long a period as the aster's.

"How about Kniphofia 'Brimstone'?" offered my friend. It is a dwarf poker with very pretty pale-yellow flowers, and the upright habit would be in excellent contrast with the aster's. But really, it flowers too late - not till the end of September - and its lank foliage would hardly enliven the scene during the previous two months. But 'Little Maid', another kniphofia of dwarf habit, flowers over quite a long period - from mid-August - and has creamy-white colouring. As with many other perennials, its flowering season is greatly extended if it is rejuvenated, in this case by splitting and replanting in improved soil every two or three years. It is worth making the point that while many kniphofias make a terrific but short-lived display in one burst of blossom, there are others, like 'Little Maid', that offer continuity.

Another thought for a partner on the other side of the aster was Caryopteris x clandonensis 'Worcester Gold'. The main attraction in this shrub is its lime-green foliage, which lasts for a very long time. In August, the shrub carries its clusters of small, blue flowers all along the young shoots. I am generally not too keen on blue and mauve together, but the foliage would redeem that in this case.

Caryopteris belong to that group of summer- and autumn-flowering shrubs that you can prune hard all over each spring. In this case you would gauge the height you wanted and prune accordingly, keeping the shrub down to a maximum of one metre.

It is fun to work out possible plantings like this, even if you never put them into practice. Someone else can and they may improve on your ideas. I should like to get the rather late-flowering bulb, Nerine bowdenii (0.7m) near to this grouping. It has heads of bright-pink flowers, the petals with wavy margins making open trumpets, from September onwards. It remains more or less dormant in summer, returning to life by flowering when awakened by early autumn rains. If these fail to materialise, you can speed things up by applying a heavy dose of water yourself.

Readers can order Christopher Lloyd's Garden Flowers for £14.99 (rrp £18.99), The Well Tempered Garden for £21 (rrp £25, published May 3), or both for £33.99 (saving £10), by calling CultureShop on freephone 0800 316 6102.

It is fun to work out possible plantings like this, even if you never put them into practice. Someone else can and they may improve on your ideas. I should like to get the rather late-flowering bulb, Nerine bowdenii (0.7m) near to this grouping. It has heads of bright-pink flowers, the petals with wavy margins making open trumpets, from September onwards. It remains more or less dormant in summer, returning to life by flowering when awakened by early autumn rains. If these fail to materialise, you can speed things up by applying a heavy dose of water yourself. fields.headline: To die for
fields.standfirst: Hot furniture in Milan
fields.trailText: Hot furniture in Milan.
fields.body:
You have to be careful when you go to furniture fairs. It's the same with fashion shows. If you believed everything you saw in these less-than-real places then you would furnish your house entirely with outsized pieces upholstered in vermillion wool, and wear micro-minis so belt-like as to be almost illegal. These are the realms of extreme exaggeration, and it would be embarrassing not to read between the lines of such showmanship.

At this month's Milan Furniture Fair - the biggest annual event of its kind, a sort of Cannes for design, with endless parties and networking but sadly no starlets to speak of - the big red sofa was out in force. It was everywhere. It went round corners, it divided into sections, it was upholstered in wool, or neoprene, or textured linen, but it was definitely red. Some Italians and Germans really do live in the right kind of spaces for this kind of king-sized style statement.

No one but the luckiest British loft-dweller, however, would be able to give anything on this scale houseroom. Nonetheless, all this sofa nonsense did provide a sense of direction, even if you'll be buying yours from Ikea or Habitat. Look for something that's foam upholstered (in other words, not big and squashy, but harder and sleeker) probably perching on skinny, brushed-steel legs.

In evidence, too, was a shiny revival: lacquer is back. Sadly, it had never gone away in my incredible 70s hotel room, in which every surface gleamed with a different glossy shade of green. The floor was tiled in a bottle-green and jade dog-tooth check, the wall had been lovingly papered with pale-green suedette and there wasn't a neutral in sight. The 21st-century version of the hard reflective surface showed up all over the fair: from small stools-cum-occasional tables and folding chairs to bachelor-pad coffee tables and garden furniture. Equally shiny, and extremely desirable, was a new series of designs in clear-coloured plastic, created by Philippe Starck for the big Italian company, Kartell.

It included a bucket-style swivel chair and objects that looked like huge vases from a distance, but turned out to be little seats or tables close-up. Imagine these in clear purples, ambers and leaf greens, and expect to find them in an Ian Schrager hotel foyer near you, soon. They won't be in the shops until much later this year, but don't shell out on any more translucent or frosted plastics in the meantime - very last century.

This being Milan, fashion is never far away, even when it's furniture you're after. Visitors were treated to an exhibition of architects Herzog and de Meuron and Rem Koolhaas's plans for Prada, in its continuing bid for world domination, which include a three-storey shop in Tokyo housing the world's first electronic changing room, in which you are filmed and then "virtually" dressed in outfits of your choice. Herzog and de Meuron were the designers of London's Tate Modern, and Koolhaas counts the Rotterdam Kunsthal among his achievements. Surely it couldn't be that Miuccia Prada would like to elevate her own work to art by employing gallery architects to ensure it is correctly displayed? Just a thought.

Caroline Roux on design appears weekly.

webTitle: The secret of writing a novel

fields.headline: The secret of writing a novel
fields.standfirst: Well, you can hardly be expected to produce it at a bus stop, can you? The right setting is crucial, and contrary to popular belief, a bit of comfort will not kill off the muse. Novelist Liz Jensen finds a room of her own
fields.trailText: Well, you can hardly be expected to produce it at a bus stop, can you? The right setting is crucial, and contrary to popular belief, a bit of comfort will not kill off the muse. Novelist Liz Jensen finds a room of her own.
fields.body:
One day the young Virginia Woolf was greeted by two pieces of news. The first was that women were finally to get the vote. The second was that her aunt had died, leaving her £500 a year. "Of the two - the vote and the money - the money, I own, seemed infinitely more important," she recalled.

It meant no more kindergarten teaching, no more making artificial flowers, no more cadging odd jobs off newspapers, and the freedom to write.

Little has changed since Woolf commented that "a woman must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction". The reality for most writers, male and female, is that money - and the space and time it buys - is a constant, nagging preoccupation. Get any of us together in the bar and you'll find us talking not about who's tipped for the next Orange Prize, but plain old-fashioned dosh.

Money, space and time: of these three sacred "musts", most writers agree that the problem of space is the easiest to ignore. Want to be a writer? Easy: you can take a laptop, or a scrap of paper and a pen anywhere. You can write standing up, like Ernest Hemingway, or in the family sitting room, like Jane Austen. You can write at a bus stop, on the beach or in the loo. Hell, you can even write when you're meant to be producing Blue Peter: according to urban myth, when the computer system at the BBC was changed some years ago, 75 unfinished novels were found floating in the system.

Writing may be one of the most portable activities in the world, but it doesn't stop writers yearning for a private space in which to plumb the depths of their subconscious. The psychologist Martin Lloyd-Elliott, who works with many artists and writers, says that one reason the garret has become central to the mythology of the creative process is because outsiders imbue it with a kind of magic. Literary tourists, he points out, always flock to see The Desk where a great work was penned. Readers will often shyly confess to picturing writers tormented, scribbling in an ivory tower, or holed up in a windswept hotel with a bottle of Scotch.

"But it's also about the writer's preoccupation with the environment being 'just right' for the alchemy to work," says Lloyd-Elliott. "Some writers can only write upstairs. The journey may represent a passage from the ordinary place to this special elevated place in the clouds." According to Lorrie Mack, author of Calm Working Spaces, the garret myth springs from the idea that art should involve suffering, "that out of deprivation and pain is born artistry. So the garret is an attic that's uncomfortable and cold: if you're suffering, you're in a better position to produce great work. Not a view I subscribe to."

The modern-day work space is more about comfort, light, and the absence of distractions. You can set up a work space anywhere in the home, from a converted attic or garage, to a prefab at the bottom of the garden. But for anyone wanting to concentrate, the absence of mental clutter is the key. Start polluting your work space with other parts of your life and its mystique is shattered.

Even mundane disturbances can be galling. Jonathan Coe rents an office near his home in London, but admits to finding himself distracted by the constant demands of phone and fax: he escaped to a villa in Italy to write most of his new novel, The Rotters' Club. Julie Myerson wrote her last two novels, including the current paperback, Laura Blundy, in a flat she and her partner bought up the road, as an investment in lieu of a pension. She has made a point of not taking phone calls there. "Knowing the phone won't ring is extraordinarily concentrating and calm," she says. "Ten minutes from home is the perfect distance for me. The walk focuses me but never gets dull. Plus, I'm not so close that I'm tempted to pop home."

Determined to write my fourth novel more quickly than its predecessors, I decided to follow Julie's lead and have a go at garret life. Shelling out more than £156 rent a week until the book's done is a gamble, but it means I take my studio flat - and the work I do in it - very seriously. A bad day working at home doesn't really cost you, because you can kid yourself you were actually planning to spend the day planting bulbs. Renting a place, you become aware of the need to squeeze every ounce of work from it. It helps you feel more professional: as a writer, you're not a normal person, but sometimes you want to feel like one. Having an office to go to feeds that illusion.

Going to Paris may seem quite a schlep to achieve a state of creative nirvana, but novelist Douglas Kennedy has no regrets about buying a garret in St Germain-des-Près. He loves the city, and finds that the short, intensive bursts of work he does there - one week in every five - are highly productive. "Family life has a lot of pleasures, but it's intensely distracting," he says. "Writing is a disciplined sport, and the only way you can do it is by getting on with it. I wanted a bolt hole I could get to from London by train. I can get door-to-door in four hours. It's no further than a country cottage in Norfolk."

Thanks to the instant concentration the garret provides, he wrote and edited much of his new novel, The Pursuit Of Happiness, there. His day begins with coffee and 500 words. Then a shower, a 90-minute French lesson, lunch, a walk, then another burst of writing between four and seven. He works on a laptop, and emails chapters to London as backup, before heading off to one of the arrondissement's cinemas.

A friend spotted the garret in an estate agent's and alerted him to it. He didn't fall in love with it right away, but the price was compelling. Here was an apartment in the heart of the Parisian equivalent of Chelsea for the price of a studio in Croydon. It was designer David Bentheim (responsible for Kennedy's London home) who persuaded him of its potential, and turned the 7m x 3m room, plus small kitchen and bathroom, into a home. "It's a real writer's place," says Kennedy, "but it has comfort, too. I'm very conscious of my good fortune."

Kennedy is equally conscious of the thing that hits all of us garret-workers as we open the door and sit down to work: a Woolfian "room of one's own" might be magical, but it's not magic. It won't write the book for you. In that, you really are on your own

The right setting

Any romantic fantasies you harbour about producing the grand oeuvre will soon fade if you end up with headaches and stiffness rather than inspired prose. For a comfortable work space, and the optimum flow of creative juices, make sure the three basic elements are all taken care of.

The chair

If you sit at a desk for long periods, you need purpose-designed seating: a borrowed dining chair will not do. Look for one with all-over padding and fully adjustable bits, so you can change the seat height and angle. Arm rests should be adjustable, too; sit with your forearms straight and parallel to the floor. For stability, look for one with five legs that radiate from a central pedestal.

The desk

If you don't fancy a conventional desk, consider building a deep, wide shelf into an alcove (or even right across a small box room), or use a sturdy kitchen table. Make sure it's large enough for all your equipment, with plenty of room for work in progress; there are few things that hamper work as much as untidiness and overcrowding.

The lighting

Choose an adjustable work light, not a table lamp, to focus on your task; its bulb should be at least 60 watts. To avoid getting in the way of the light, place it at (or above) the opposite side of your work surface to your dominant hand (on the left if you're right-handed and vice versa). Don't let it reflect onto your computer screen. Have some subtle background light as well: working with a single source in a darkened room, tortured-poet style, brings on exceedingly unromantic headaches and eyestrain.

Lorrie Mack

Liz Jensen's novel, The Paper Eater, is published in paperback by Bloomsbury on June 4, priced £7.99. To reserve a copy for £6.99, including first-class p&p, free-phone Guardian CultureShop on 0800 316 6102. CultureShop is also offering Lorrie Mack's Calm Working Spaces for £15.99 (rrp£18.99), plus £1.99 p&p.

fields.headline: Snooping around for under £100,000
fields.trailText:
Lincoln Place, Hulme Street, Manchester

Here's swank status on a miser's budget. The ingredients? It must be a loft, darling, it must have lots of chrome and woodstrip (and a few twisted twigs in a hip-high vase) and it must be an olive's throw from good bars.
fields.body:
Lincoln Place, Hulme Street, Manchester

Here's swank status on a miser's budget. The ingredients? It must be a loft, darling, it must have lots of chrome and woodstrip (and a few twisted twigs in a hip-high vase) and it must be an olive's throw from good bars.

Pros: A pioneering warehouse development with a Japanese garden, in the emerging Little Ireland quarter. Generation X and other sultry hang-outs are a mere stumble away.

Cons: The garden is shared with your neighbours, and there's nowhere to leave your Beetle.

Price: £96,950. Available through Chesterton, 0161-835 9222.

Ommaney Road, London SE14

This is the best you'll get if you have to live in London. In Knightsbridge it would buy you little more than a parking space. But if you don't mind gritty New Cross (the socially self-conscious will probably want to call it Peckham) you can find a room in which to lay your weary head.

Pros: A private patio is thrown in, and escape is just five minutes away at New Cross Gate tube and rail station. Cons: The patio is minute. You get to it, rather intimately, through the bedroom; and the front door opens onto the lounge. It's a lower-ground floor flat, so do make sure windows lock.

Price: £99,995. Available through Kinleigh Folkard & Hayward, 020-7639 2029.

The Dell Farmhouse, Cullicudden, by Culbokie, Scotland

Flee north of the border and rejoice in three bedrooms, two sitting rooms with annexes and two acres of Highland landscape for the price of a London basement.

Pros: Views across the Cromarty Firth. Period features to console you in this land of pebbledash and plate glass.

Cons: There's a leaseholder already installed, with orders to evacuate within two months of a sale. Cosmetically, the interior is untouched by the new millennium.

Price: £95,000. Available through Scottish Highland Property Services, 01463 715175.

South View, Bovey Tracey, Devon

Cutesy, cosy and a trifle cramped. There's one bedroom, an attic with potential, outhouses for your washing machine and a large kitchen-diner.

Pros: Monday morning gloom will surely be brightened by views of Dartmoor through the bedroom curtains and a 13m garden in front. For metropolitan diversion the town centre is 200m away.

Cons: You reach your front door via a communal alley. The interior is, as the agent tactfully puts it, a little 'tired', but at least you'll have plenty of change left over from your £100,000 with which to reawaken it.

Price: £69,950. Available through Bradleys, 01626 834900.
