fields.headline: How to wear clothes
fields.trailText: I knew I was right. It was claimed recently that stilettos are less bad for you than court shoes. This is a little like finding out that Ben & Jerry's Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough ice cream is less fattening than low-fat yoghurt: sweet, jammy victory for those of us who have been indulging all along.
fields.body:
I knew I was right. It was claimed recently that stilettos are less bad for you than court shoes. This is a little like finding out that Ben & Jerry's Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough ice cream is less fattening than low-fat yoghurt: sweet, jammy victory for those of us who have been indulging all along.

Heels are not just back, they're back for good. Over the past few years, high shoes have enjoyed an impressive rehabilitation. Once associated with Essex girls and ladies of uncertain virtue, high heels have become socially acceptable footwear - even during the day, even with jeans. Even with ankle socks. "Fuck me shoes" now sounds as archaic a term as fob watch.

The shape du jour has a pointed toe, and is cut low at the front and sides. D&G, the cheaper diffusion line from Dolce & Gabbana, has some of the season's best, in plain or zebra-striped satin. The pointed toe is a slightly harsh shape, however, and looks wrong with floaty clothes: try butterfly-appliquéd sandals from Sergio Rossi or Dune, depending on your budget.

If you don't like showing bare toes, fishnets cover up without vile toe gusset. Some of the most fabulous shoes around shamelessly fetishise the heel. Jimmy Choo has sandals with heels of mother-of-pearl mosaic - not for amateurs, unless you don't mind throwing away £300 on a wobbly paving stone. High heels do wonders for your knees - don't even look at a short skirt without them, unless you have a tapeworm - but how high is high enough depends on whether you have a chauffeur. If you do, only the full 10cm will do. This summer's cone-shaped heel, narrowing to a square centimetre tip, feels more secure than a traditional stiletto (so less of the excruciating "overgrown foal with wobbly ankles" routine), but the tips still wear out in the time it takes to hail a taxi.

"Fuck me shoes" now sounds as archaic a term as fob watch. The shape du jour has a pointed toe, and is cut low at the front and sides. D&G, the cheaper diffusion line from Dolce & Gabbana, has some of the season's best, in plain or zebra-striped satin. The pointed toe is a slightly harsh shape, however, and looks wrong with floaty clothes: try butterfly-appliquéd sandals from Sergio Rossi or Dune, depending on your budget. If you don't like showing bare toes, fishnets cover up without vile toe gusset. Some of the most fabulous shoes around shamelessly fetishise the heel. Jimmy Choo has sandals with heels of mother-of-pearl mosaic - not for amateurs, unless you don't mind throwing away £300 on a wobbly paving stone. High heels do wonders for your knees - don't even look at a short skirt without them, unless you have a tapeworm - but how high is high enough depends on whether you have a chauffeur. If you do, only the full 10cm will do. This summer's cone-shaped heel, narrowing to a square centimetre tip, feels more secure than a traditional stiletto (so less of the excruciating "overgrown foal with wobbly ankles" routine), but the tips still wear out in the time it takes to hail a taxi.

fields.headline: The new black
fields.trailText: My skin goes darker in summer, so it's time to start looking for a new face powder.
fields.body:
My skin goes darker in summer, so it's time to start looking for a new face powder. I don't wear foundation, I just need a powder to take away the shine. I've been using Clinique's darkest shade, Stay Brandy, for the past couple of years. When I was growing up in Manchester it was impossible to find, and I had to rely on friends who were visiting London, or even the US, to bring me back a few compacts. Things are different now.

I'm at the make-up section of Selfridges. First stop, Bobbi Brown. The assistant helpfully tells me that their darkest powders, "look much lighter than they are". They do have darker foundations, but I don't want foundation, I want powder, so it's on to Prescriptives. Prescriptives' trademark is that they'll mix any shade to match your exact skin colour. They'd be happy to customise me a loose powder, but there is no tester, so once they start mixing, you are committed, and at £35 a pop I'm not ready to experiment. On to Chanel, where an apologetic mixed-race woman tells me to try Bobbi Brown, Iman or "somewhere like that". Ditto at Estée Lauder. Christian Dior try to flog me a bronzer, and YSL have a grand selection of two powders. The nice woman at Shiseido solves my problem by telling me I don't need anything at all. Flattery is certainly preferable to the blank looks I've got at the other counters, but it's no more useful.

Normal service is resumed at Elizabeth Arden. At Calvin Klein, I try a foundation that is supposed to dry as a powder. The colour is good but it's like wearing an oil slick. BeneFit tell me they're getting one in . . . next week. I try Mac, but the darkest is still too light. The assistant tells me I "wouldn't want to go any darker than that". Actually, I would. To Fashion Fair, the US brand for "women of color". Clearly not my colour, as I'm bang in between two shades. So, it's on to Iman, the brand set up by the supermodel wife of David Bowie. Success! I'm not even their darkest shade. I also buy a lip gloss. On the way home, I can't decide if I'm more pleased that Iman won or annoyed that the others were so disappointing.

Hannah Pool's column on black beauty appears weekly.

webTitle: Phone box ads for sex to be outlawed

fields.headline: Phone box ads for sex to be outlawed
fields.trailText: Ministers have decided to make it a criminal offence to plaster city centre phone boxes with cards advertising prostitutes after a six year battle between local councils and the 'tart-carders'.
fields.body:
Ministers have decided to make it a criminal offence to plaster city centre phone boxes with cards advertising prostitutes after a six year battle between local councils and the 'tart-carders'.

The carders will face fines of up to £5,000 and six months in prison after the House of Lords approves amendments to the government's criminal justice and police bill next week.

Peers are also to be asked to close a loophole in the law to strengthen the power of the police to close crack houses and prosecute the owners.

City centre councils, particularly in London, have unsuccessfully waged a long battle to tackle the problem of prostitutes' cards in phone boxes.

The only law that can be used against the carders is an obscure part of town and country planning legislation which makes it a civil offence to put up unauthorised adverts.

Repeated attempts have failed to persuade the telephone authorities to cut off the phone lines of numbers advertised on the cards. The new law will make it a criminal offence to place an advertisement for prostitutes' services in a phone box.

Ministers will have the power to extend the ban to bus shelters and other street furniture if necessary.

The trade has become increasingly violent with council cleaning teams being threatened. Last week Westminster council in London appealed to residents to "adopt a phone box'' and band together to tear down the cards.

Critics of the clampdown argue that the cards mean the prostitutes are not working on the streets, but indoors.

But the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, said the cards were explicit and offensive: "They can be seen by children. They create a bad impression for overseas visitors and are very much part of the increasingly organised business of prostitution, which exploits and degrades women and children.''

He said the cards often covered up important information such as adverts for the Samaritans and Childline.

The move against the owners of crack houses is to clarify the existing drug laws. The 1971 misuse of drugs act only allows specifically for the prosecution of owners or occupiers of houses where cannabis and opium is illicitly being consumed.

Police can act against dealers in crack houses, but the amendment to the law will ensure that the owners and occupiers of such places have to cooperate with the police in stopping such activity.

The police say that closing crack houses is a difficult challenge. They are often fortified and normally only small amounts of drugs are held on the premises.

The time it takes the police to force an entry is usually enough to ensure the drugs are disposed of which can make it difficult to prove the owner or occupier was knowingly concerned in permitting the drug to be supplied there. The new offence will carry a penalty of up to 14 years.

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Broadcasting
fields.standfirst: Barbara Slater, executive producer with BBC Sport, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Barbara Slater, executive producer with BBC Sport, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
Although I don't actually play golf myself, along with lots of British viewers I probably know the greens at the Augusta course as well as anyone. I've just returned from covering the US Masters and I spent last Sunday producing at the London Marathon.

Sports production is unlike most other areas of television in that the person producing it tends to be pushing the buttons themselves. Put simply, I am the person choosing the shot the viewer gets to see from the various cameras we have at an event and while it sounds simple, it isn't.

As the event is happening I am watching the shot from each camera. At the same time I might be directing the cameramen and asking them to change a shot - and simultaneously talking to the commentators. Golf is difficult because equally important passages of play may be happening at differing parts of the course. You might be waiting for one player to drive off before quickly cutting to a recording of a vital putt that may have just happened.

It's about juggling the various feeds and trying to stay one jump ahead of the events as they unfold. If you are producing tennis you have the added complications of slow-mo replays - viewers want to see if that shot was on the line or out, and it's up to you to show them. If you can't keep several balls in the air at once, this is not the job for you.

Although I tend to specialise in golf, tennis, horse jumping and rowing, I also cover other events. For example, at the marathon I produced the coverage at the finish, and had nine cameras at my disposal situated at various points, from the Mall through to the finish.

The thing that's exciting about sport is that it is so unpredictable. As the runner who won the woman's race was about to cross the finishing line, two spectators ran out and almost knocked her over - when things like that happen we try to ignore them and just carry on, although there was nothing we could do to stop the viewers seeing it.

When we are not actually covering an event we are planning the next. When the referee halted the last Boat Race it wasn't the catastrophe for us that it could have been, because we had talked about what we do in such an instance and we were able to cover the restart.

I joined the department in 1983 having been a gymnast, and worked my way up to my current role. It definitely helps to have done most of the other jobs on the way up. While it is often glamorous, the travelling can be a bit much. That said, I do realise I have what must be many people's dream job.

webTitle: First class strategies in the final countdown

fields.headline: First class strategies in the final countdown
fields.standfirst: Short bursts are the key to successful revision
fields.trailText: Short bursts are the key to successful revision
fields.body:
Finals, shminals. In a few months time all you final-year students out there will be done with exams. Finished. Over. Your fate, to some extent at least, will be sealed. You don't need us to point this out. You are all too aware of it. So, why then can't you focus on studying?

Here's the Rise guide to getting on with it.

First, get sorted. You need to be able to direct your whole attention to reading, revising and remembering. You can't afford to be distracted by the smaller things in life. So, stock up your cupboards and load up your fridge.

Blitz that pile of laundry. And have a general clean up. Once your domestic essentials are in order, focus on your working environment. In Organising From The Inside Out (Hodder & Stoughton), Julie Morgenstern says an orderly desk will help provide a "clear head", improving your ability to concentrate on your exams rather than on your "piles of stuff".

Of course, no matter how tidy your desk, you're never going to conquer that mountain of revision unless you plan your assault. "You've got to decide what it is you're aiming for," says Petra Cook from the Institute of Management. So figure out what needs to be done and when it needs to be done by.

Then set daily objectives. And make sure they're SMART - that is (with no apologies for repeating this well-known management mantra): Specific, Measurable, Achievable or Realistic, and to a Time-scale. This, says Petra, "will provide you with an effective work pattern which will help you to stay focused".

While putting together your to-do list, don't ignore your body clock. "If you are a morning person then study hard first thing and tail off towards the end of the day when less is going in," says Catherine Fleming from Career Psychology. "Vice versa if you are a night owl."

Even after all this preparation, it is still possible to veer off course. The culprit may be endless interruption. Phone calls, junk emails, friends popping in - these can all derail even your best efforts to work

towards your finals. The advice from the Industrial Society is that you just have to learn how to say no. Do this calmly and assertively and people will understand.

It's not just other people that you may have to be strict with. There will be times when you have to discipline yourself too. Especially when, inevitably, you start procrastinating. Procrastination isn't just the thief of time. In this situation it could cost you your 2:1 or your 2:2. (We are assuming those gifted souls in line for a first will be off swotting already.)

The solution lies in "breaking the task down into smaller, more manageable parts", says Mark Forster, a life coach and author of Get Everything Done and Still Have Time To Play (Help Yourself). "This way it won't seem so enormous or daunting. And your resistance to it will be reduced."

Another tip is to go at it in short bursts. "When I have a particularly large project to do, I work for 40 minutes and then have a 10-minute break where I can do whatever I want. It is free-time. There are no restrictions on it. But after that 10 minutes, and I set a timer, I go back to being focused."

Catherine Fleming, from Career Psychology, offers one last perspective on finals preparation: "In the scheme of things, this is a

very small chunk of your life you are giving up. It will be over before you know it and you don't want to be looking back in three months time saying 'if only I'd worked harder'. Keep your goal, whatever it is, in sight."

webTitle: Sun, sand ... and saving the planet

fields.headline: Sun, sand ... and saving the planet
fields.standfirst: The Volvo Environmental Scholarships - in association with The Guardian
fields.trailText: The Volvo Environmental Scholarships - in association with The Guardian
fields.body:
Three cattle-grids away from the highway was probably the strangest university in the world: brilliant glass domes, pyramids and towers set in miles-upon-miles of empty desert with a horizon of mountains as a jagged backdrop.

At least we wouldn't have too many complaints from the neighbours. Giant leaves pressed against the inside of the glass structure, and I pressed my nose against the outside, to sneak a look at the futuristic world where I would be studying for the next four months.

The most fitting way to get to Columbia University's Biosphere 2 Center would be to beam in from a spaceship. We arrived by bus where we got the full story from a friendly local with a country and western haircut. "Man, you should turn back now," he told me. "That place is dangerous - there is no way you're gonna survive being sealed in there."

This all sounded a bit ominous - had the nice people at Rise signed us up for some kind of psychological experiment?

It turned out that our friend's information was as out-of-date as his haircut. The Biosphere 2 Center started life as a bizarre cross between Star Trek and Big Brother, but is now in much safer hands. It was built in 1986 by a wacky group of scientists and actors who decided Tucson, Arizona was a good place to site their prototype for a Mars base.

By sealing a tropical rain forest, desert, savannah, mangrove swamp and coral reef inside a futuristic three-acre glasshouse, they hoped to create a stable atmosphere, regardless of what planet they were on. The project attracted the media spotlight when eight of the group decided to prove their point by spending two years sealed inside the structure.

When these 'biospherians' returned to the real world, the management team went their separate ways, and left the world under the glass to grow in peace.

But Columbia University, based in New York, spotted the potential lurking in the controlled atmosphere and diverse biomes of the Biosphere 2 Center. As a scientific research centre, it provides a living laboratory that can directly test the effects of a changing atmosphere on living ecosystems, and help predict the future of our changing climate.

It also provides an exciting atmosphere for 60 students who arrive twice a year from around the world to take part in a unique environmental science course known as "Earth Semester".

Thanks to last year's Volvo Environmental Scholarship, Antonia Williamson and I were the first UK students to graduate from Earth Semester. My memories of Biosphere 2 are still very fresh, and all bathed in hot desert sunshine (the rainy days almost forgotten). An incredible week studying the geology of the Grand Canyon melds into a week of marine biology (and margueritas) on the coast of Mexico's Sea of Cortez. Explorations of the tunnels and humid biomes of Biosphere 2 followed days surveying the prickly desert plants and hikes into the spectacular mountains around the campus.

However, we worked hard too. Where traditional courses focus on one particular discipline (biology, economics, social science), Earth Semester aims to blur the boundaries between disciplines to give a view of the big picture.

The teaching style of seminars, debates, and mock negotiations fits the progressive look of the campus (although the adjustment from a traditional British university did take a little time). My advice to anyone thinking of applying for this year's scholarship is to go for it - regardless of your degree subject.

If you go to Columbia University's Biosphere 2 Center with an open mind, it will soon be filled with ideas, visions and fresh perspectives on how we can preserve the natural environment for future generations to enjoy.

Ben graduated last year from Cambridge University with a degree in zoology. Following his return from the Biosphere 2, Ben has landed a job with the United Nations' Environment and Development Forum.

webTitle: How to... own up and keep your job

fields.headline: How to... own up and keep your job
fields.standfirst: Come clean, take the flak and move on
fields.trailText: Come clean, take the flak and move on
fields.body:
Heard the one about the bloke whose desire for a cup of tea cost him his job? The story goes that on a well-known quiz show there was a switch to flick if a contestant ever won the top prize. Lights would flash, music would play, ticker tape and balloons would cascade from the ceiling.

Months passed but no-one won the biggest prize. Finally, someone answered the last question correctly and the switch was pulled. Nothing happened. The director yelled, the assistant kept turning the switch on and off. Only when someone realised that the plug was out of the wall, replaced by a kettle, was an explanation found.

It's a fair bet that whoever was responsible waved a fairly swift goodbye to their career in television. But mistakes don't always have to be that costly. "Everyone makes mistakes - although not necessarily on that scale," says Corinne Mullhew, a TV producer.

"I've had assistants who have given people wrong scripts, sent cars to pick up the wrong actors, and even forgotten to book a studio when we were supposed to be shooting. I'd be lying if I said I don't get angry, but I do appreciate that everyone makes a mistake sometimes."

There are few feelings more unpleasant than the rising panic when you realise you've really fouled up. The obvious temptation is try to cover it up, to not mention it and simply hope it will go away - which is rarely the best plan. Think Nick Leeson, whose attempts to cover up his massive financial losses caused the collapse of Barings Bank. Owning up may seem a terrifying proposition, but it is rarely worse than trying to hide your mistake.

"The moment when I realised I'd given a hundred telephone interviewers the wrong questions still haunts me," says Kerry Packington, market research manager. "There were two big surveys going on, taking place in different areas of the UK, and I gave the wrong questions to the wrong interviewers. It wasn't until the results came back, and they were so totally different to what we had expected, that I realised what I had done."

Kerry admits that her first instinct was to try and avoid having to own up. "I tried to think of an explanation, tried to think of who else could be to blame. It sounds awful, but I just couldn't face telling my boss. For three days I worried obsessively about it. In the end, I decided the only thing to do was tell the truth. My boss went through the roof - he actually reduced me to tears. But I heard later that he'd said he appreciated my honesty in coming to him and admitting everything."

Often it is our own worst fears that make owning up so difficult. "If you've made a big mistake don't start thinking that you're an idiot, or that you'll probably get fired," says Avril Leimon of Plus Consulting. "Catastrophic thinking can be enough to put you off owning up, when in reality making a honest mistake rarely leads to serious repercussions. Your boss may well be angry but it's often just bluster. "Was it solely an error on your part or did the system let you down? Did you receive incorrect information or were you trying to cope in a situation where you were out of your depth?"

fields.headline: Work for the right madam
fields.standfirst: New lessons from oldest profession
fields.trailText: New lessons from oldest profession
fields.body:
Do you work in new media? Do you want better rewards, more autonomy and greater creative freedom? If so, you might find it satisfying to work in a brothel. A digital brothel, that is. There's nothing smutty about this idea which comes from Tom Campbell, the editor of online resource New Media Knowledge, who believes that working for a limited company is a hopelessly outdated concept and that digital brothels are the workplaces of the future.

Here's the logic: no-one expects a job for life any more, an increasing number of us, including fresh graduates are going freelance, and the digital economy means we're free to work anywhere we like with anyone we like.

Against this background, Tom reckons workers in the newest professions have a lot to learn from the oldest. "In the brothel model, updated for the digital economy, talented individuals are loosely and temporarily assigned to 'houses' that provide them with the clients, team, creative environment, tools and administrative framework they require to work," he says

"The 'house-madame' owns the brand and takes a healthy share of the revenues, but the bulk of decisions, profits and intellectual property reside with the individuals working on each project."

Wherever possible, workers choose which clients they work with. However, working this way doesn't mean prostituting yourself. Instead, you choose who will benefit from your knowledge and skills.

Tom adds: "It's about taking control of yourself, owning your intellectual property, and being rewarded for what you do rather than being exploited by a company."

This definition has similarities with the 'free workers' described by John Knell of the Industrial Society's Futures Division. In his report Most Wanted - The Quiet Birth of the Free Worker , he describes free workers as the "expert pollen of the new economy, moving quickly between jobs and assignments". Independent but not individualistic, they depend on networks and care more about the intrinsic interest of each project than who is employing them.

"The brothel model works best for those who are most in demand; whoever can add the most intellectual capital to a project," says Tom Campbell. He cites new economy workers like web designers, programmers and content providers as ideal candidates.

But what do new media workers think about working in a digital brothel? Ben Copsey develops internet software and is studying for an MA in electronic arts. He approves: "I think it's a great idea, as the biggest headaches for me in freelance work have been finding money for equipment and having a nice space to work. Working with lots of people would be great, as we could share equipment and help each other out."

William Myers, an interaction designer, says he would appreciate the creative freedom and holding intellectual copyright. He says: "Existing company models are often stifling and outdated. I would greatly welcome a level of autonomy which enabled me to be more in control of my creative output. And if individuals could retain property rights to creative solutions, as well as receiving payment, it would encourage them to produce a better quality of work."

For Mark McDowall, a freelance copywriter specialising in digital media, the networking element of the digital brothel is appealing. "It lets people do what they set out to do without having to worry about admin, job titles or 'being the brand'," he says. "Designers want to design. Writers want to write. Refreshingly, the brothel idea focuses on the work. It's an environment stripped of the meaningless gestures of the 'new' corporate world such as the unused pool table."

Some old economy industries are already working along the lines of the brothel model, though they probably wouldn't thank you for the comparison. "The film industry is the quintessential networking industry," says John Knell. "Producers and directors use their connections, reputations and networks to pull together groups of like-minded individuals to work on projects."

There are also similarities with barristers, where legal chambers own the brand and provide administration, but barristers charge their services out to clients. However, this is an ultra-hierarchical set-up with massive pay inequalities between partners and non-partners.

Then there are pioneering new economy companies who recognise you can't handcuff today's "expert pollen" to a desk. In the US, a company called Asynchrony is leading the way. It's a community of independent software developers who work in fluid teams over the web on different projects and negotiate shares for their contribution. The company carries out marketing, takes a percentage cut, and lets programmers get on with the job.

In his report, John Knell cites another example, bid4geeks.com, where teams of talented individuals working in IT put their details on a website and ask people to bid for their services.

In the UK, Runtime Collective in Brighton is a group of web engineers that loosely fits Campbell's brothel model. "We have a hyper-flat company structure and profit share," says Steve Crossan of the collective.

"Everyone's decisions about how they work and what they work on directly affect what they take home. The rewards are shared but also the risk. We provide the organisational structure and marketing as a shared resource, and work in motivated project teams with a shared, radically customer-focused project management style."

He says this approach is more rewarding for talented individuals than money alone. "Successful projects are very dependent on skilled, experienced programmers and project managers. But people are looking for more than just money. We can offer them work satisfaction, autonomy within a community of excellence and a sane balance between work and home life.

"If someone is ten times as productive as a staff member at a competitor company, it's crazy not to do whatever it takes to keep them happy, even if it means they want to spend three months a year snowboarding."

fields.headline: Ono? Oh, yes
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on the benefits of an ombudsman (or woman)
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on the benefits of an ombudsman (or woman).
fields.body:
I have spent most of this week in Paris at the annual conference of the Organisation of News Ombudsmen which I have just joined, a body with the wonderfully expressive acronym Ono. I imagined that its members would greet each other in salute with an open hand slapped to the forehead, as in "I don't believe it".

One of the main reasons I joined was to meet others of the same species, occupying the fretful and often lonely ground between readers and listeners or viewers and their newspapers or broadcasting organisations. It turned out that most of the others feel a similar need to huddle together now and again.

One session of the conference, in fact, was to address the isolation and stress of the job, a job that Ono itself defines like this: "A news ombudsman receives and investigates complaints from newspaper readers or listeners or viewers of radio and television stations about accuracy, fairness, balance and good taste in news coverage. He or she recommends appropriate remedies or responses to correct or clarify news reports."

Almost all the 35 ombudsmen who responded to a recent Ono survey said they felt isolated within their organisations. Many used the word "defensive" in describing the response of journalists to their approach. I quote from a summary of the findings: "All or almost all of the ombudsmen are aware of journalists' aversion to public criticism. Some journalists also consider themselves intellectually superior toward the public." These are symptoms of the culture that we have been trying to change at the Guardian.

Only a few ombudsmen thought they had no effect on the work of journalists. The majority thought that the feedback they provided from readers had increased respect for the individual and for privacy, and had increased sensitivity in other areas, for example in references to victims of violence.

Most of the ombudsmen (men and women), having expressed all their reservations, clearly loved the work and one or two, with distinguished and varied careers in journalism to their credit, said that it was the best and, in some ways, most rewarding job they had ever had.

Ombudsmen in journalism are a relatively new idea. The mass circulation Tokyo paper, Yomiuri Shimbun, has had a 28-member ombudsman committee to hear complaints and to liaise daily with editors since 1951. It is the largest newspaper in the world, with a circulation of more than 10m. One of its ombudsmen was at the conference in Paris.

The first newspaper ombudsman in the western hemisphere seems to have been appointed to serve the readers of the Courier-Journal and the Louisville Times in 1967.

Ono was founded in 1980. It has more than 70 members, almost 50 of whom attended the Paris meeting. Ono has so far been largely an American organisation but is now making active efforts to foster the appointment of ombudsmen in other parts of the world. It has three members in the United Kingdom: me and the ombudsmen from the Sun and the News of the World, soon to be joined, I hope, by the recently appointed readers' editors of the Observer and the Mirror.

Ono has been taking modest steps forward in Europe. The French newspaper Le Monde has had an ombudsman for a long time (by the way, its pages pass through five stages of proof reading before they are considered fit for publication). The host of the conference was France Télévision, which now has ombudsmen in place and broadcasts a regular programme to discuss issues raised by viewers. One of the sessions was addressed by the Palestinian cameraman who, while filming for France Télévision, took the controversial pictures of the Palestinian boy being shot as his father attempted to protect him.

Not every news organisation has an ombudsman. The New York Times, a most rigorous corrector of itself, does not. I have grown more rather than less convinced in the past three and a half years that it is a good idea to have one. I also believe that, if possible, the ombudsman should be placed in a position of declared and protected independence with a visible presence in his or her paper or broadcasting organisation. Newspapers, by admitting fallibility, increase trust.

It is worth having a look at the Ono website, where you will find out much more about the organisation and see representative articles by its members - www.infi.net/ono is the address.

webTitle: Chief's friend to edit Sunday Independent

fields.headline: Chief's friend to edit Sunday Independent
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Independent on Sunday has a new editor. As widely predicted, Janet Street-Porter's successor is Tristan Davies, currently executive editor at the Independent and a close friend of the editor-in-chief, Simon Kelner.
fields.body:
The Independent on Sunday has a new editor. As widely predicted, Janet Street-Porter's successor is Tristan Davies, currently executive editor at the Independent and a close friend of the editor-in-chief, Simon Kelner.

Kelner stressed yesterday that his appointment was based not on friendship but on his belief that "Tristan is the best possible choice for the post."

In an upbeat assessment of his new editor, Kelner said: "I think Tristan has genius for presentation, and that's not overstating it, but he's very good with words and, although this has just been announced to the staff, there's already a good mood around the office."

Davies said it was too early to reveal his plans for the Sindy, and he would be talking to his journalists in the coming weeks. "There would be no point in putting me in if I didn't have ideas about what to do," he said. "But the paper won't be veering off into another direction."

Davies, 39, started on free magazines after leaving Bristol University, notably on the Covent Garden Courier, which he helped to transform into Piazza. He joined the Independent soon after it was launched in 1986 and worked his way through listings, the arts and features.

He left to follow his mentor, Kelner, to the Mail on Sunday's magazine Night And Day, then returned to the Independent when Kelner became editor in May 1998. The two have been virtually inseparable for years, at work and in their social life.

Kelner admitted that the Sindy's deputy, Mike Williams, was "disappointed" to be passed over, but both he and Davies said he would be staying on.

They acknowledge that their task has become more difficult since the renaissance of the Sindy's rival, the Observer, edited by Roger Alton.

"What Roger has done is no secret," Kelner said. "He has applied his journalistic acumen. I expect Tristan to do that for us."

The Observer's sales have moved far ahead of the Sindy's in recent months. In the latest figures it recorded sales of 451,000 to the Sindy's 252,000.

webTitle: Farmworker tests negative for foot and mouth

fields.headline: Media catch cold from disease 'victim'
fields.standfirst:
Tests prove negative on farmworker who was contaminated when cow exploded in his face

Special report: foot and mouth
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Tests prove negative on farmworker who was contaminated when cow exploded in his face.
fields.body:
When a decomposing cow exploded in the face of Cumbrian farmworker Paul Stamper and he later developed blisters on his tongue and numbness in his feet, the media laid siege to his parents' house in Maryport.

Mr Stamper contacted his doctor, who said it was not possible to catch the disease, and then called his solicitor.

The Daily Mail and ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald emerged triumphant from long negotiations, offering a reported £30,000 between them for exclusive interviews with the first Briton in 34 years who appeared to have contracted foot and mouth. "I can't believe it. It doesn't seem real," Mr Stamper told the Mail reporter.

It was not real. Yesterday the newspaper and ITV were left wondering whether they had offered their money wisely when the story exploded in their face as Mr Stamper was declared by the public health laboratory to have tested negative.

The Mail was not responding to calls yesterday.

The scare story has consumed the tabloids for almost a week. But eight of the 13 people tested so far by the public health laboratory for foot and mouth have proved negative.

"It is very unlikely that any of the eight people we have tested are human cases of foot and mouth disease,'' said a spokesman for the laboratory. "But to exclude any possibility of infection, antibody tests need to be conducted on blood samples.''

Tests on saliva, blood and blister fluid samples from the five other cases are continuing. It was good news for tourism chiefs contemplating more negative publicty. The minister of agriculture, Nick Brown, said: "I am delighted he has been given the all-clear. Otherwise this could have had serious implications for his future employment.''

Mr Stamper could not be contacted yesterday, but was said by friends also to be delighted. Whether his all-clear means he can still be paid for his story remains to be seen, and may put a dampener on his celebrations.

Hundreds of people have contacted their doctors in the belief that they may have foot and mouth, and could earn a bit of extra cash. The public health laboratory would not say yesterday what the tests on the eight had shown, but it has said that people could be confusing an unrelated but common disease in children called hand foot and mouth with the animal version.

There has been only one confirmed case in Britain of a human infected with foot and mouth, during the outbreak in 1967. The Department of Health has said that it expects one or two cases this time.

As in sheep, which are thought barely to notice they have the disease, foot and mouth is very mild in humans. The main symptoms are tingling hands, a sore throat and blisters on the tongue or feet. People can theoretically be infected though skin wounds, by handling diseased stock or by drinking infected milk, but not by eating meat from infected animals.

fields.bodyText: When a decomposing cow exploded in the face of Cumbrian farmworker Paul Stamper and he later developed blisters on his tongue and numbness in his feet, the media laid siege to his parents' house in Maryport. Mr Stamper contacted his doctor, who said it was not possible to catch the disease, and then called his solicitor. The Daily Mail and ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald emerged triumphant from long negotiations, offering a reported £30,000 between them for exclusive interviews with the first Briton in 34 years who appeared to have contracted foot and mouth. "I can't believe it. It doesn't seem real," Mr Stamper told the Mail reporter. It was not real. Yesterday the newspaper and ITV were left wondering whether they had offered their money wisely when the story exploded in their face as Mr Stamper was declared by the public health laboratory to have tested negative. The Mail was not responding to calls yesterday. The scare story has consumed the tabloids for almost a week. But eight of the 13 people tested so far by the public health laboratory for foot and mouth have proved negative. "It is very unlikely that any of the eight people we have tested are human cases of foot and mouth disease,'' said a spokesman for the laboratory. "But to exclude any possibility of infection, antibody tests need to be conducted on blood samples.'' Tests on saliva, blood and blister fluid samples from the five other cases are continuing. It was good news for tourism chiefs contemplating more negative publicty. The minister of agriculture, Nick Brown, said: "I am delighted he has been given the all-clear. Otherwise this could have had serious implications for his future employment.'' Mr Stamper could not be contacted yesterday, but was said by friends also to be delighted. Whether his all-clear means he can still be paid for his story remains to be seen, and may put a dampener on his celebrations. Hundreds of people have contacted their doctors in the belief that they may have foot and mouth, and could earn a bit of extra cash. The public health laboratory would not say yesterday what the tests on the eight had shown, but it has said that people could be confusing an unrelated but common disease in children called hand foot and mouth with the animal version. There has been only one confirmed case in Britain of a human infected with foot and mouth, during the outbreak in 1967. The Department of Health has said that it expects one or two cases this time. As in sheep, which are thought barely to notice they have the disease, foot and mouth is very mild in humans. The main symptoms are tingling hands, a sore throat and blisters on the tongue or feet. People can theoretically be infected though skin wounds, by handling diseased stock or by drinking infected milk, but not by eating meat from infected animals. webTitle: MoD accused of paranoia over media injunctions

fields.headline: MoD accused of paranoia after a series of media injunctions
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The injunction against Ulster Television is the latest in a number of gagging orders and arrests under the Official Secrets Act acquired over the past few years by senior Ministry of Defence officials, enthusiastically backed by their secretary of state, Geoff Hoon.
fields.body:
The injunction against Ulster Television is the latest in a number of gagging orders and arrests under the Official Secrets Act acquired over the past few years by senior Ministry of Defence officials, enthusiastically backed by their secretary of state, Geoff Hoon.

Some have been obtained at night and sometimes newspapers have been told they cannot even report the fact they have been gagged.

Three out of the MoD's four live court actions - against the Sunday Times, Sunday People and UTV - are designed to prevent the media from reporting the activities of the army's covert force research unit (FRU) in Northern Ireland which is, in effect, being accused of indulging in state-sponsored murders.

The MoD says the injunctions are designed to prevent 'possible threats to life' rather than to protect national security.

The fourth court action is the continuing - and almost certainly forlorn - attempt by the MoD to prevent the publication in New Zealand of Soldier 5, a book by Mike Coburn, the pseudonym of an SAS soldier who was a member of the ill-fated Bravo Two Zero patrol in the Gulf war.

All these legal actions, and others recently dropped, have been sought by what Whitehall insiders describe as an increasing paranoid section in the MoD responsible for special forces. Senior officials and military officers in the section have led fierce opposition in Whitehall to the decision by Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5, to write her memoirs.

Also in the past three years the MoD police charged Tony Geraghty, author of The Irish War, and his alleged source, retired army colonel Nigel Wylde, under the secrets act. The charges were eventually dropped.

MoD attempts to gag the media flies in the face of a recent ruling by Lord Phillips, Master of the Rolls, according to Whitehall sources, who accuse the ministry of paranoia.

Lord Phillips roundly attacked the practice whereby government lawyers obtained broad injunctions preventing the media from publishing information without first getting clearance from the attorney general, Lord Williams.

'It subjects the press to the censorship of the attorney general,' he said. Such a practice, he added, 'results in the imposition of a restriction on the freedom of the press that is disproportionate to any public interest and thus in breach of article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights.'

webTitle: Comment: Global media giants attempting to privatise airwaves

fields.headline: Mayday, mayday
fields.standfirst:
Global media giants are lobbying for the most sinister privatisation of all: the airwaves

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Global media giants are lobbying for the most sinister privatisation of all: the airwaves.
fields.body:
Question: what is the single most valuable piece of property worth owning at the dawn of the information age? Answer: the radio frequencies - the electromagnetic spectrum - over which an increasing amount of communication and commercial activity will be broadcast in the era of wireless communications. Our PCs, palm pilots, wireless internet, cellular phones, pagers, radios and television all rely on the radio frequencies of the spectrum to send and receive messages, pictures, audio, data, etc.

Most of us never give the spectrum a passing thought. We regard it, more or less, like the oxygen we breathe, as a free good. In reality, the spectrum is treated as a 'commons' and is controlled and administered by governments who, in turn, license the various radio frequencies to commercial and other institutions for broadcast. In other words, in every country the electromagnetic system is owned by the government on behalf of the people.

But now powerful commercial media are seeking to gain total control over the airwaves. Imagine a world in which a handful of global media conglomerates like Vivendi, Sony, BskyB, Disney, and News Corporation own literally all the airwaves all over the planet and trade them back and forth as 'private electronic real estate'. A strategy is beginning to unfold in Washington DC to make that happen.

On February 7, 37 leading US economists signed a joint letter asking the federal communications commission (FCC) to allow broadcasters to lease spectrum they currently license from the government in secondary markets. The letter, which went virtually unnoticed by the general public, is the opening salvo in a radical plan to wrest control of the entire spectrum from governments around the world, and make the radio frequencies a private preserve of global media giants. If they succeed, the nation state will have lost one of its last remaining vestiges of real power - the ability to regulate access to broadcast communications within its own geographic borders.

This story starts several years ago, when the Progress and Freedom Foundation, a conservative thinktank in Washington with close ties to Newt Gingrich, former Speaker of the House of Representatives, published The Telecom Revolution: An American Opportunity. The report's authors called for the conversion of the electromagnetic spectrum to private property. Under the plan, broadcasters holding existing licences would be granted title to the spectrum they currently used and would be able to use, develop, sell and trade it as they saw fit. Remaining unused parts of the spectrum would subsequently be sold off to commercial enterprises and be reconstituted as private electronic real estate, while the FCC would be abolished.

The study argued that government control of the radio frequencies led to inefficiencies, and that if the spectrum were converted into private electronic real estate that could be exchanged in the marketplace, the invisible hand of supply and demand would dictate the most innovative uses of those frequencies. Congressional hearings were subsequently conducted on the proposal, quickening interest in the plan.

Still, the notion of selling off the US airwaves to private commercial interests seemed a bit too ambitious, even for the most experienced Washington corporate lobbyists. Then, less than one month after George Bush assumed the presidency, the letter from the 37 economists turned up on the FCC's doorstep.

The new thinking: first, secure a partial privatisation plan, allowing commercial licensees to sell and lease their leased spectrum in secondary markets. Once done, the commercial foundation would be laid for a final conversion from government licensing of the spectrum to a future sell-off to the private sector. Other nations would be encouraged to follow suit and sell off their spectrums to global media companies. If some baulked at the idea of relinquishing control over their airwaves, international trade sanctions could be imposed to force compliance.

In the industrial age, exchanging property in markets was the sine qua non of commerce. The role of national governments was to protect property and markets. But in the new commercial world being born, having access to the flow of information in telecommunications networks becomes at least as important as exchanging property in markets.

If the radio frequencies of the planet were owned and controlled by global media corporations, how would the billions who live on earth guarantee their most basic right to communicate with one another? In an era where more and more of our daily communications take place in cyberspace, access to the airwaves becomes critical. Of course, those who can pay will be connected. But what about the 62% of people who have never made a telephone call, and the 40% who have no electricity? How will they ever secure access to cyberspace in a world where the admission fee is controlled by a few global media giants?

If the flow of human communications is controlled by global media companies, how do we ensure that social and cultural points of view and political expressions that may differ from those of the companies who own the frequencies will be allowed to flow over the spectrum? We might face the prospect of a new form of repression as global media companies tighten their grip on the airwaves.

Equally ominous, when companies like AOL-Time Warner, Disney and Vivendi Universal own the channels of communication as well as much of the 'content' that flows through them, will the rich cultural diversity that has traditionally been created and nurtured in civil society dry up? Will we be left with only a few global media companies as the ultimate arbiters of human culture?

How do we prevent these companies from exerting undue influence over commercial life itself, because of their control over the channels of communications through which business is conducted? And finally, in the new era, when everyone is connected with everyone else in commercial information and telecommunications networks, how do we prevent corporate owners of the radio frequencies from exploiting the data on people's lives that flows through cyberspace? What safeguards will people have over their own privacy when every aspect of their life story is accessible as data bits travelling over corporate-owned and controlled communications channels?

At the dawn of the global media age more than 20 years ago, an American government official made the prescient remark that 'trade doesn't follow the flag anymore, it follows the communication systems'. When our very right to communicate with one another is no longer assured or secured by government but controlled by global media conglomerates, can basic freedoms and real democracy continue to exist?

 Jeremy Rifkin is the author of The Age of Access and president of The Foundation on Economic Trends in Washington DC

webTitle: Berlusconi to sue Economist for 'unfit' tag

fields.headline: Berlusconi to sue Economist for 'unfit' tag
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Italian opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi's media company says it will sue the Economist magazine for saying in yesterday's edition that he is unfit to lead a government.
fields.body:
The Italian opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi's media company says it will sue the Economist magazine for saying in yesterday's edition that he is unfit to lead a government.

Aides said that the media magnate was stunned that a magazine revered by Italy's business class could launch such an attack a fortnight before the general election in which his centre-right coalition expects to regain power.

Yesterday's front cover showed him looking pensive beneath the headline: "Why Silvio Berlusconi is unfit to lead Italy." An editorial and an article analysed his business empire, which includes three television networks, a publishing house, a football team, property, and financial services.

It added: "In any self-respecting democracy it would be unthinkable that the man assumed to be on the verge of being elected prime minister would recently have come under investigation for, among other things, money-laundering, complicity in murder, connections with the mafia, tax evasion and the bribing of politicians, judges and the tax police.'' Mr Berlusconi, 64, who briefly served as prime minister in 1994, has faced numerous trials connected to his holding company Fininvest. A conviction for false accounting was overturned on appeal.

Two convictions for bribing tax collectors and illegal payments to politicians were extinguished when the appeals ran out of time under the statute of limitations.

Accusations of false accounting, bribing judges, tax fraud and breaking anti-trust laws are being investigated.

The Economist also referred to the pending trial in Sicily of Mr Berlusconi's friend Marcello Dell' Ultri, who is accused of links to Cosa Nostra. Investigations into Mr Berlusconi's alleged mafia links were closed without any charges being brought.

Fininvest, which controls Mr Berlusconi's media interests, said in a statement faxed to Reuters that the article contained "a series of old accusations'' which were "an insult to truth and intelligence''.

"The Economist offers its readers an exact photocopy of the most infamous calumnies aimed at Fininvest and its founder Silvio Berlusconi in recent times.

"The answer to such a serious libellous action must be left to the courts in which the Economist will be obliged to deliver compensation matching the extent of the harm done." The statement did not say whether the case would be brought in the Italian or British courts.

The Economist declined to comment on the Fininvest statement except to say that it stood by its story.

Many of the allegations have been aired before in Italy, but the British magazine claims to have supporting evidence. The cumulative effect of six pages chronicling 40 years of unanswered questions has had an explosive impact in Italy.

Mr Berlusconi has always said the accusations were part of a leftwing conspiracy and the Economist, seen as right wing has not until now been counted among his enemies.

Its allegations were splashed across several national newspapers and brandished by the ruling centre-left coalition. "So even the Economist is communist?" said Arturo Parisi, leader of the Democrats.

Mr Berlusconi's aides dismissed the article as more pap from a biased foreign press.

Despite the fuss Mr Berlusconi is still expected to win on May 13. The Opinion polls suggested that the government has narrowed but failed to erase the gap in time to stop a remarkable comeback.

Mr Berlusconi's coalition would take 47.7% of the vote and the government 43.2% if the election was held immediately, a poll in yesterday's La Stampa found. Today is the last day polls can be published under election laws.

The key to the centre-right's advantage is the north, where an alliance with the anti-immigrant Northern League seems to have secured marginal seats.

An alliance with the post-fascist National Alliance is expected to win seats in the south.

Italian opinion polls tend to have wider margins of error because of the fractured parties and complex electoral system, a hybrid of first past the post and proportional representation.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: pollution levels high in Cumbria

fields.headline: Research shows high levels of pollutants over Cumbria
fields.standfirst:
Threat of civil disorder over health fears intensifies

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Renewed concern about the health hazards from foot and mouth burial sites and blazing pyres emerged yesterday with the first results from independent research showing higher than average levels of dangerous airborne pollutants from a big disposal area in Cumbria.
fields.body:
Renewed concern about the health hazards from foot and mouth burial sites and blazing pyres emerged yesterday with the first results from independent research showing higher than average levels of dangerous airborne pollutants from a big disposal area in Cumbria.

Consultants have told Allerdale council, which covers a swath of Lakeland and the surrounding area with the highest number of foot and mouth cases, that on occasions short-term levels of potentially deadly chemicals from one large pyre exceeded national air quality standards.

At the same time, the threat of civil disorder intensified in Devon as people demonstrated outside a waste tip at Deepford complaining they had been kept in the dark over plans to bury 50,000 carcasses. They say local streams and water supplies will be polluted if the burial goes ahead.

While the four-day pollution study at a farm pyre near Caldbeck, in north Cumbria, revealed average concentrations within accepted levels, the company that undertook the research said that a big question mark still remained over the wider atmospheric impact.

Dr Steve Bradley, of Whitehaven-based Westlakes Scientific Consulting, said a national survey was needed to investigate more distant airborne pollution from the pyres, which send thick, acrid smock high into the atmosphere. This was necessary 'to give people confidence'.

The study was undertaken from a mobile laboratory downwind of a pyre, which incinerated 500 cattle and needed 700 tonnes of coal, 3,800 railway sleepers, 900 wooden pallets, 60 tonnes of straw and 7,600 litres of diesel.

"People exposed to smoke at the locations monitored would clearly find it unpleasant and a nuisance," said Peter Daley, Allerdale's environmental health manager. "Whilst in these instances people should not have suffered any long-term health problems, the results do give sufficient grounds to strengthen the concerns that have been expressed about this type of burning."

With Cumbrians growing increasingly militant over the number of pyres in the county, people in Devon further raised the stakes in their battle with officialdom by demonstrating outside the Deepmoor pit.

"Feeling is running very high," said a resident, Pat Boulton. "We were given assurances that this tip would not be used and we have been lied to. It is totally unsuitable and we feel certain it will pollute streams. If there is any leakage it will be a catastrophe - people rely on water from wells and spring-fed water as their only supply."

But a spokesman for Devon Waste Management, which runs the site, said only sheep and pigs would be buried. "This is a crisis and things move very fast. We were served notice by the Ministry of Agriculture which required us to take the carcasses."

fields.headline: Cull or cuddle
fields.standfirst:
The new policy is straightforward enough: only pretty animals will be spared

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The new policy is straightforward enough: only pretty animals will be spared.
fields.body:
Labour this week denied that it had changed government policy just because of all the media attention given to one little white calf. The minister responsible insisted that it had always been the government's plan to extend the baby bond scheme to include calves. Newborn cows will receive £300 in their own junior savers account which will be theirs at 18 to spend on university courses, setting up small businesses or bribing their way out of the abattoir.

In terms of the actual foot and mouth cull, government policy is now that the slaughter must only proceed under strict new guidelines which grade animals according to how pretty they are. Calves are pretty so they will now be spared. Sheep and pigs are not that pretty, so they're still for it. Lobsters, toads and stag beetles might as well all just commit suicide now. But if it's suddenly discovered that labrador puppies and koala bears are the worst carriers of foot and mouth then the government is really in trouble.

What's amazing about this whole episode is that it has taken the media so long to find a cuddly calf to move us all to tears. We've had a surfeit of farm animal pictures, but somehow the creatures don't look so endearing when they are the wrong way up and on fire. It's not been the sort of animal footage that had you expecting to hear Johnny Morris coming in with a funny voice-over.

Of course you would have to be a complete cynic to think this calf's miraculous survival was some sort of set-up. It's just a coincidence that the creature that's risen from the ashes of the slaughter policy is called Phoenix, that she's purest white and was discovered at a time when farmers believed that the culling of healthy cows might possibly be suspended. Suddenly she's all over every front page and the British are besides themselves with emotion. If the same photos of a calf appeared on the other side of the Channel the French would just think `Mmm, delicious!' In Spain, they'd probably say `Let's kill it by getting the fattest man in the village to ride it through the main square!'

The whole episode proves once again that the British care more about animals than they do about people. Nothing upsets us more than man's inhumanity to beast. If pensioners have to wait years for a hip operation then we accept it with a defeated shrug, but show some footage of a gannet with a broken wing, and get-well cards will pour in from around the country; police will set up roadblocks to ensure the creature gets to the seabird rescue centre as quickly as possible, where a candle-lit gannet vigil is already under way.

In Britain we donate more money to animal charities than we give to children's charities. Last year a new record was set when an old lady left $7m to the National Canine Defence League. I suppose this is better than giving it to a cats' home - at least the dogs might wag their tails a bit and look vaguely grateful; cats would just look at you as if to say `Yeah, £7m? So what?' One animal refuge specialising in hamsters has funds of nearly £10m. What use is £10m to a few hamsters? You could shred the banknotes for their bedding, I suppose, and maybe employ some domestic staff to spin the little wheel for them at weekends. A rest home for horses in Buckinghamshire has a stockmarket portfolio of £14m, which is more than the combined funds of Unicef UK, Shelter and Care International UK. Either these retired horses are geniuses at investing on the stock market, or someone has been giving them more than they really need.

But just as animals win the beauty contest of deserving causes, so our news agenda is set by emotional rather than rational criteria. Thousands of steel workers have lost their jobs during the foot and mouth crisis; mass redundancies were announced in West Lothian this week, but these workers have already been forgotten because they made the mistake of not being wide-eyed cuddly animals.

In the meantime Phoenix herself continues to enjoy the overnight celebrity status that only the tabloids can bestow. Tonight she's going to a film premier with Angus Deayton; OK! Magazine are currently doing a photo shoot of Phoenix relaxing in her barn and she's already being tipped as the next host of Gladiators. But of course the tabloids that currently love little Phoenix won't be so kind to her forever. They are building her up to knock her down... soon it will be `Phoenix denies udder implants'; `Moo-er! Fatty Phoenix has turned into an old cow!' and the rather harder to believe `Drug crazed Phoenix in pub brawl with EastEnders star'. By the time she has come through the experience of being a tabloid celebrity, the prospect of culling might not seem so grim after all.

 John O' Farrell is prospective Labour parliamentary candidate for Maidenhead

webTitle: Leader: ministers should face an audit

fields.headline: A rational reshuffle
fields.standfirst: Maybe ministers should face an audit
fields.trailText: Maybe ministers should face an audit.
fields.body:
It is one of the great summer games and even a general election cannot stop it. In the salons and watering holes it has replaced "guess-the-majority" as the conversational ice-breaker of choice. The cry among Westminster insiders is uniform: let's play reshuffle! The game is played in two parts. First, you talk people: who should be up, who should be out? Some players like to warm up with a quickfire round on the Conservatives. The Tory papers had a go yesterday, suggesting William Hague would pre-empt a leadership challenge after the inevitable election defeat by sacking the chief plotters against him, Michael Portillo and Francis Maude, and by booting out party chairman Michael Ancram. He would then bring in fresh blood, which poses a problem for reshuffle fans: few can name Conservatives who are not already in the shadow cabinet (it's hard enough to remember the ones who are).

As that exercise runs dry... it is hard to get excited by the career prospects of Gary Streeter... attention soon turns to the main event: the Labour cabinet. Here there is more than mere speculation to go on: the pre-reshuffle positioning has been under way for months. David Blunkett is so confident that he's moving up from Education and Employment that he's already had his leaving do. The smart money says he will become home secretary... and a more rightwing one than the incumbent, Jack Straw. The latter could then become foreign secretary, which would have a perverse logic. Perceived as a eurosceptic, he could reassure the hostile press and then have credibility in any future campaign for the single currency. "I had my doubts," he could say, "but now I realise the euro is best..."

That would leave Robin Cook out of a job. Perhaps he could go to a new ministry of constitutional affairs, replacing the old Wales and Scotland offices and advancing the government's programme of regionalisation. That would strip the regions bit from John Prescott's superministry, leaving just environment and transport. He would not care, because he'd have become Cabinet Office minister, the "enforcer" charged with joining-up government. That job has not worked until now, possibly because it has lacked a `big beast' with the clout to knock heads. Mr Prescott could be the answer. The environment chunk of his previous department could combine with rural affairs to form a new body, replacing the hapless agriculture ministry. Nick Brown would be unlikely to make a Phoenix-like escape from the cull.

You get the idea. But notice the sudden slide from the first phase of the game... people... into the second, structures. In an ideal world these two would be discussed separately. First, ministers would be subjected to a performance audit, much as other public sector professionals are expected to. The good ones would hold on or be promoted, the incompetents would be sacked. Next, the prime minister would take a cold, hard look at Whitehall itself... deciding which areas now overlapped, which no longer belonged together and which ministries were simply out of date. DfEE, Maff and DETR might all be deemed for the chop; a ministry of justice would be a gap to fill.

But no such rationalism prevails. Unwieldly megaministries are kept because to downsize them would be to demote their ministers. Of course you can never drain the politics from cabinet appointments. But this annual round of jockeying hardly produces good government. What is worse, it remains the secret talk of Westminster insiders. It is our government that is being determined here; the public should at least get a look-in.

fields.headline: Celebratory census
fields.standfirst: Fill it in with pride
fields.trailText: Fill it in with pride.
fields.body:
A big bang decennial census is not strictly necessary. Other countries do well enough in utilising the mass of information about households collected in the normal course of tax gathering, schooling, health and town hall registration. Some worry about government transferring personal data across the firewalls which keep the state's various banks apart. But e-technology both makes this easier and helps anonymise personal data. When asked about alternative kinds of census in a Cabinet Office review a little while ago, the information commissioner was relaxed. It is a fair bet that the census to be taken tomorrow will be the last of its kind.

Maybe the fact that national statistics will soon review the census's future gives all the more reason to celebrate the richness of social knowledge gleaned from this survey. This year's form gives households a chance to identify themselves in terms of their ethnic (and UK-national) provenance... though not including a Welsh identifier was stupid. It opens up the domestic economy to provide insight into who does the looking after when relatives are dependent. To combat the know-nothings who seem to find society's self-knowledge frightening, national statistics has perhaps exaggerated the significance of a mere head count. Of course grants and health planning depend on it. This census will be especially pertinent in charting neighbourhoods and local communities: detailed knowledge of who lives where is a precondition of targeting money for regeneration and renewal. In order to care about neighbours... or at least to use taxes, benefits and grants to try to help the disadvantaged... means, first of all, knowing where they live. Though the census does not directly record people's incomes and once-in-a-decade enumerations rapidly date, it should fill in the social map and so add to mutual understanding in a fissiparous society. For that reason Sunday's form should be filled in with pride.

It is a fair bet that the census to be taken tomorrow will be the last of its kind. Maybe the fact that national statistics will soon review the census's future gives all the more reason to celebrate the richness of social knowledge gleaned from this survey. This year's form gives households a chance to identify themselves in terms of their ethnic (and UK-national) provenance... though not including a Welsh identifier was stupid. It opens up the domestic economy to provide insight into who does the looking after when relatives are dependent. To combat the know-nothings who seem to find society's self-knowledge frightening, national statistics has perhaps exaggerated the significance of a mere head count. Of course grants and health planning depend on it. This census will be especially pertinent in charting neighbourhoods and local communities: detailed knowledge of who lives where is a precondition of targeting money for regeneration and renewal. In order to care about neighbours... or at least to use taxes, benefits and grants to try to help the disadvantaged... means, first of all, knowing where they live. Though the census does not directly record people's incomes and once-in-a-decade enumerations rapidly date, it should fill in the social map and so add to mutual understanding in a fissiparous society. For that reason Sunday's form should be filled in with pride.

webTitle: Suspected armed robber hits car during getaway

fields.headline: Suspected armed robber hits car during getaway
fields.standfirst: Archer case witness, Monica Coghlan, killed
fields.trailText: Monica Coghlan, the former prostitute at the centre of the Jeffrey Archer libel case in 1987, has been killed after a car allegedly hijacked by a suspected armed robber collided with her Ford Fiesta in Scammonden, near Huddersfield, west Yorkshire.
fields.body:
Monica Coghlan, the former prostitute at the centre of the Jeffrey Archer libel case in 1987, has been killed after a car allegedly hijacked by a suspected armed robber collided with her Ford Fiesta in Scammonden, near Huddersfield, west Yorkshire.

Ms Coghlan, 50, died in the early hours of yesterday morning at Leeds general infirmary after being cut from the wreckage of her car and taken to hospital by air ambulance.

The driver of the Jaguar, a 32-year-old man, was seriously injured and was last night under police guard in Huddersfield royal infirmary.

Ms Coghlan, who leaves a teenage son, Robin, was killed after a chain of events that began when a man apparently armed with a handgun raided a chemist in Birkby, near Huddersfield.

After stealing valium, temazepam and DF118, a compound used by drug addicts, the man demanded another customer's car keys before driving off in a white Peugeot.

Shortly afterwards, the Peugeot collided with a Land Rover on New Hey Road, and the man stopped a passing white Jaguar. The Jaguar then crashed into Ms Coghlan's blue Fiesta, which was thrown through a wall into a field.

Ms Coghlan became synonymous with Lord Archer in 1986 when allegations that she had slept with the then Tory vice-chairman were published in the Daily Star.

The allegations, which Lord Archer denied, followed a sting operation by the News of the World in which Ms Coghlan was photographed accepting money from Michael Stacpoole, a friend of Lord Archer's, on platform three at Victoria station.

Lord Archer acknowledged offering Ms Coghlan £2,000 to leave the country to escape hounding by reporters, describing it as 'an error of judgment', but he vigorously denied having slept with her. In 1987, after a sensational libel trial, he was awarded a record £500,000 in damages.

Ms Coghlan's death comes two weeks before Lord Archer and his former friend Ted Francis are due to stand trial at the Old Bailey on charges of perjury and attempting to pervert the course of justice in relation to the 1987 trial.

It is alleged that Lord Archer asked Francis to provide a false alibi for him in advance of the libel trial, and falsified diary entries. Both men have pleaded not guilty.

Last night the crown prosecution service said the trial would go ahead. Ms Coghlan, who lived in Rochdale, Greater Manchester, where she worked as a bingo caller, had not been due to give evidence.

Ms Coghlan's nephew Kevin, 20, said: 'We just can't believe what has happened. Everyone is really upset. I don't know how my cousin is coping with it because I have not seen him.'

webTitle: Rush-hour bus lanes planned to beat motorway jams

fields.headline: Rush-hour bus lanes planned to beat motorway jams
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government yesterday tried to persuade disgruntled motorists that its 10 year transport plan will bring short term relief when it promised speedy introduction of new in-car information on traffic jams.
fields.body:
The government yesterday tried to persuade disgruntled motorists that its 10 year transport plan will bring short term relief when it promised speedy introduction of new in-car information on traffic jams.

Ministers also promised removable bus lanes operating during the rush-hour on some of the most congested sections of English motorways. The bus-and-lorry-only lanes scheme is part of a highways agency project which received £40m of government funding.

The proposal was part of a wide ranging speech by Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, designed to show ministers will not be budged from their support for public-private partnerships. The traffic information system, aimed at tackling congestion and improving safety, is to be tested on either the northern part of London's orbital M25 or on the motorway area around Birmingham.

He said: `Our motorways and trunk roads are getting busier. New technology and new systems will enable the highways agency to provide more reliable journey times, improve safety and control traffic flows.''

Similar bus and taxi routes have been tried successfully on the M4 from Heathrow.

The new routes would not be permanent. The highways agency said: `We could, during peak hours, reserve lanes for buses and lorries by operating each lane individually through electronic signs.''

The traffic control centre will collect information, passing it on to commercial organisations and the public through satellite transmissions or via the installation of message signs on roadsides.

The centre will operate through cameras at strategic locations, a network of roadside detectors and variable message signs at key decision points allowing the network to inform motorists of imminent delays. The system would also vary speed limits to improve the evenness of traffic flow.

The scheme also involves lightweight gantries to carry message and warning signs.
