webTitle: 'Regrets for 30 years' if Prescott presses ahead with tube contracts

fields.headline: 'Regrets for 30 years' if Prescott presses ahead with tube contracts
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Underground services will get worse and taxpayers and passengers will have to pay more if, as expected, John Prescott announces "preferred bidders'' next week for the part privatisation of the tube, the London transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Underground services will get worse and taxpayers and passengers will have to pay more if, as expected, John Prescott announces "preferred bidders'' next week for the part privatisation of the tube, the London transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, warned yesterday.

In an indictment of the bids for the 30-year contracts to run track, stations and signalling - which Mr Kiley and his staff have had access to - the former New York subway chief said the government's decision to press ahead with an "unworkable and dangerous'' scheme was irresponsible and against the public interest.

Mr Kiley, who has full authority from the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, to negotiate with the government, set out his reaction to the public-private partnership bids by consortiums in a letter to the London Transport chairman, Sir Malcolm Bates. Using London Underground's forecasting model, the figures showed tube services would deteriorate, Mr Kiley said, and "none of the four bids offers value for money''.

Figures had been "crudely manipulated'' to favour the government's plan, he claimed, and its insistence on pushing ahead before Mr Livingstone's legal challenge came to court in June would remove the leverage to make improvements.

Ministers reject Mr Kiley's criticism as 'spin' and appear determined to pick the favoured consortiums before the election, partly to make it more difficult for the courts to stop part privatisaton.

His appeal to the government to draw back from locking in its sell-off plans came as talks were announced to try to avert next week's planned tube strike over safety and jobs. The TUC general secretary, John Monks, is to join the negotiations at the conciliation service Acas on Monday.

On Thursday Mr Kiley unveiled his own £13bn public sector scheme for transforming the tube, appealing to London business to make its voice heard before next week's "fateful decision'' over the partnership, which Londoners would "regret for the next 30 years''. Under his plan - financed with £8.2bn from revenues, £4.4bn from bonds and £225m from equity - 85% of the tube's 4,000 carriages would be refurbished or renewed in seven years, and investment would be focused on the track and signalling equipment causing the worst delays.

He said the private partnership bidders for the deep lines had still not worked out detailed plans, budgets and timetables for the urgent work and were not obliged to do so until six months after a deal.

 Labour's former communications chief, Joy Johnson, was appointed head of media relations at the Greater London assembly yesterday, answering directly to Mr Livingstone.

webTitle: War on crime is just an illusion

fields.headline: War on crime is just an illusion
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The police are sometimes accused of being invisible when you really need them, but Scotland Yard is set to take the maxim to new heights after hiring a magician to perform two 'magic shows' for senior officers.
fields.body:
The police are sometimes accused of being invisible when you really need them, but Scotland Yard is set to take the maxim to new heights after hiring a magician to perform two 'magic shows' for senior officers.

Michael Vincent, a former postman who has appeared on Jim'll Fix It and the Paul Daniels Magic Show, will perform a range of card tricks and illusions in front of an audience of chief superintendents in an effort to boost confidence and encourage leadership skills.

The two five-hour courses will cost £3,000 and are intended to help officers build better relations with members of the public.

Mr Vincent, a former magician of the year, said he will use illusions as a metaphor for real life situations when he performs for the officers at the London Chamber of Commerce on May 17 and 24.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: 'This trial event uses the communication skills learned by a professional magician to encourage delegates to develop their own abilities to communicate and develop rapport.'

But not everybody appears so convinced. Dave Rodgers, vice-chairman of the Metropolitan Police Federation, said: 'We all love a magic trick, but will bobbies be pulling rabbits out of helmets or making poodles out of balloons? The Met needs to get value for money and should think carefully about where it is spent.'

Norman Brennan, a police officer and spokesman for the pressure group Protect the Protectors, said: 'Perhaps he could make several thousand more police officers appear on the streets of the capital to help combat the number of burglaries and robberies and help us to protect the public.'

The training course, entitled the Magic of Networking, was suggested by a Met worker who watched the show and recommended it to superiors.

Mr Vincent, 37, who has performed for, among others, Muhammad Ali, will demonstrate a number of illusions, including one involving mixing oil with water and a trick in which rope is cut in half and then put back together again.

webTitle: News soon for relatives in child organ scandal

fields.headline: News soon for relatives in child organ scandal
fields.trailText: Some of the 20,000 people who fear their relatives' organs may have been kept by doctors after death will shortly find out the truth from the first 100 hospitals to complete the cataloguing of all stored human tissue.
fields.body:
Some of the 20,000 people who fear their relatives' organs may have been kept by doctors after death will shortly find out the truth from the first 100 hospitals to complete the cataloguing of all stored human tissue.

The Retained Organs Commission, set up in the aftermath of the Alder Hey scandal, yesterday said that 6,000 of the 20,000 people who have contacted hospitals since the scale of tissue retention was revealed in January, will now be contacted. If a hospital does hold the organs or tissue of someone close to them, they will either be visited at home, invited to the hospital, or receive a phone call, according to their stated preference.

Margaret Brazier, professor of law at Manchester University and chairwoman of the commission, expressed sympathy for those who may have been waiting for information for the last three months, and who could have to go on waiting until the end of June.

'Delay must be agonising. But getting things wrong must be even worse,' she said yesterday. 'The very distressing and emotional nature of the subject means we just can't make mistakes.'

The commission was set up by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to prevent any repeat of the tragic farce played out at Alder Hey in Liverpool. The teaching hospital and the university between them held 2,300 children's organs, many of them collected by the pathologist Dick Van Velzen in the late 80s and early 90s. He was severely criticised by the Redfern report into Alder Hey and has since been suspended from the medical register by the General Medical Council.

When it emerged two years ago that hospitals had collections of hearts and brains and Alder Hey began to be asked for their return, it gradually became clear that the hospital and the University of Liverpool had no idea of the extent of the collection, or the whereabouts of the organs. Body parts were handed back piecemeal to the intense distress of parents who had buried organs only to be told the hospital had found more.

'We do not want to repeat the spectre of multiple funerals,' said Professor Brazier. 'I'd like to thank all the families across the UK for their patience.'

The length of time the searches and cataloguing is taking is further evidence that hospitals' records of retained organs are far from adequate. The physical search of one hospital took a team of three people two weeks to carry out.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, reported in January that 54,300 retained organs, body parts, still-births and foetuses had been identified in England and Wales. Professor Brazier said the cataloguing and physical searches - including cupboards and disused rooms - had turned up more, although she did not have figures for how many.

In response to public pressure the chief medical officer has broadened his investigation to include organs retained as far back as 1948. Professor Brazier said they had decided to go back to records from the beginning of the NHS, to try to give people answers. The commission has also instructed hospitals to give relatives details of any tissue blocks and slides held, however small the samples of human tissue.

Of the 100 hospitals that are now ready to give out information to relatives, just 30 were on the chief medical officer's census list as acknowledging that they held organs. Some of the 70 others may have found some since.

People who are told that the hospital does have organs taken from their relatives will be given the option to have them returned or to leave them for research purposes. The commission is to make recommendations about the disposal by hospitals of organs that neither they nor the relatives want once the cataloguing is finished.

fields.headline: Pro-hunt alliance funded RSPCA infiltrator
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: The pro-hunting Countryside Alliance covertly funded an attempted infiltration of the RSPCA led by a former Olympic showjumper, according to leaked documents seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
The pro-hunting Countryside Alliance covertly funded an attempted infiltration of the RSPCA led by a former Olympic showjumper, according to leaked documents seen by the Guardian.

The animal charity has accused Richard Meade, who won three Olympic medals in 1968 and 1972, of spearheading a campaign to encourage 600 hunt supporters to join the society to overturn the society's long-standing opposition to bloodsports.

Mr Meade faces possible expulsion by the RSPCA, which is planning to look at legal options to force him to leave the society at a future meeting of its ruling council.

His group, the Countryside Animal Welfare Group, set up five years ago, consists of 5,000 RSPCA members who want to make the charity support fox hunting.

The internal accounts of the Countryside Alliance, seen by the Guardian, show that in 1999, it gave Cawg at least £13,490 to fund a mailshot and the `fees and expenses'' of Mr Meade. The alliance admitted that this was part of a larger sum over a longer period but declined to disclose the full amount that had been given to the showjumper.

Nigel Henson, the alliance's director of communications, said the unpublicised funding was `entirely consistent'' with its support for Cawg's aims. He added: `This is yet another disingenuous attempt by the anti-hunting lobby to smear the reputation of the alliance, and we are fed up with it.''

Mr Meade said Cawg had `certainly'' received money from the alliance, but was `not part'' of the alliance. `On the whole, we are separate, particularly now. Initially there was a bit of help,' he said.

Ben Stewart of the International Fund for Animal Welfare said: `This is blatant dirty tricks. You have to wonder just how low this lot will sink.''

In January, the RSPCA won the legal right to make people say why they wanted to join the society after an attempt by Mr Meade to recruit members of hunts.

webTitle: Phone box ads for sex to be outlawed

fields.headline: Phone box ads for sex to be outlawed
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Ministers have decided to make it a criminal offence to plaster city centre phone boxes with cards advertising prostitutes after a six year battle between local councils and the 'tart-carders'.
fields.body:
Ministers have decided to make it a criminal offence to plaster city centre phone boxes with cards advertising prostitutes after a six year battle between local councils and the 'tart-carders'.

The carders will face fines of up to £5,000 and six months in prison after the House of Lords approves amendments to the government's criminal justice and police bill next week.

Peers are also to be asked to close a loophole in the law to strengthen the power of the police to close crack houses and prosecute the owners.

City centre councils, particularly in London, have unsuccessfully waged a long battle to tackle the problem of prostitutes' cards in phone boxes.

The only law that can be used against the carders is an obscure part of town and country planning legislation which makes it a civil offence to put up unauthorised adverts.

Repeated attempts have failed to persuade the telephone authorities to cut off the phone lines of numbers advertised on the cards. The new law will make it a criminal offence to place an advertisement for prostitutes' services in a phone box.

Ministers will have the power to extend the ban to bus shelters and other street furniture if necessary.

The trade has become increasingly violent with council cleaning teams being threatened. Last week Westminster council in London appealed to residents to "adopt a phone box'' and band together to tear down the cards.

Critics of the clampdown argue that the cards mean the prostitutes are not working on the streets, but indoors.

But the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, said the cards were explicit and offensive: "They can be seen by children. They create a bad impression for overseas visitors and are very much part of the increasingly organised business of prostitution, which exploits and degrades women and children.''

He said the cards often covered up important information such as adverts for the Samaritans and Childline.

The move against the owners of crack houses is to clarify the existing drug laws. The 1971 misuse of drugs act only allows specifically for the prosecution of owners or occupiers of houses where cannabis and opium is illicitly being consumed.

Police can act against dealers in crack houses, but the amendment to the law will ensure that the owners and occupiers of such places have to cooperate with the police in stopping such activity.

The police say that closing crack houses is a difficult challenge. They are often fortified and normally only small amounts of drugs are held on the premises.

The time it takes the police to force an entry is usually enough to ensure the drugs are disposed of which can make it difficult to prove the owner or occupier was knowingly concerned in permitting the drug to be supplied there. The new offence will carry a penalty of up to 14 years.
fields.bodyText: Ministers have decided to make it a criminal offence to plaster city centre phone boxes with cards advertising prostitutes after a six year battle between local councils and the 'tart-carders'. The carders will face fines of up to £5,000 and six months in prison after the House of Lords approves amendments to the government's criminal justice and police bill next week. Peers are also to be asked to close a loophole in the law to strengthen the power of the police to close crack houses and prosecute the owners. City centre councils, particularly in London, have unsuccessfully waged a long battle to tackle the problem of prostitutes' cards in phone boxes. The only law that can be used against the carders is an obscure part of town and country planning legislation which makes it a civil offence to put up unauthorised adverts. Repeated attempts have failed to persuade the telephone authorities to cut off the phone lines of numbers advertised on the cards. The new law will make it a criminal offence to place an advertisement for prostitutes' services in a phone box. Ministers will have the power to extend the ban to bus shelters and other street furniture if necessary. The trade has become increasingly violent with council cleaning teams being threatened. Last week Westminster council in London appealed to residents to "adopt a phone box'' and band together to tear down the cards. Critics of the clampdown argue that the cards mean the prostitutes are not working on the streets, but indoors. But the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, said the cards were explicit and offensive: "They can be seen by children. They create a bad impression for overseas visitors and are very much part of the increasingly organised business of prostitution, which exploits and degrades women and children.'' He said the cards often covered up important information such as adverts for the Samaritans and Childline. The move against the owners of crack houses is to clarify the existing drug laws. webTitle: Shayler case: QC says let jury decide secrets issue

fields.headline: Let jury decide secrets issue, says QC
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Blanket bans preventing former MI5 officers from disclosing anything about the work of the security and intelligence services cannot be justified, the chief defence lawyer in the David Shayler case told the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
Blanket bans preventing former MI5 officers from disclosing anything about the work of the security and intelligence services cannot be justified, the chief defence lawyer in the David Shayler case told the high court yesterday.

They would lead to silence about unlawful activities outside a 'magic circle', Edward Fitzgerald QC told Judge Alan Moses. There must be circumstances where, having exhausted all other remedies, someone was absolved from the duty of confidentiality.

Mr Fitzgerald was opening the case for the defence in a pre-trial hearing arguing that the Official Secrets Act is incompatible with the Human Rights Act, which guarantees the right to a fair trial and enshrines the principle of freedom of speech.

The prosecution insists that the secrets act does not allow for any public interest defence and that if an MI5 officer had evidence of unlawful activities, he or she should report it to superiors or the police.

Mr Fitzgerald argued that it was not always realistic to expect someone to go to the police with his concerns which might, for instance, involve misconduct by the police in conjunction with the security services.

Mr Fitzgerald said Mr Shayler would be robbed of a fair trial on secrets charges if he was barred from arguing that what he did was in the public interest. Mr Shayler should be allowed to put that defence to the jurors and let them decide.

A trial in which a defendant was barred from running such a defence could result in a conviction which was incompatible with the Human Rights Act, Mr Fitzgerald said.

Mr Shayler, 35, faces trial at the Old Bailey on three charges relating to the disclosure of information and MI5 documents to the Mail on Sunday in 1997.

The hearing continues on Monday.

fields.headline: IRA moles plead for protection
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: British soldiers were recruited by the army's secret intelligence wing to infiltrate the Provisional IRA and were cleared to carry out terrorist operations, including bomb-making and the shootings of RUC officers, as part of their undercover work.
fields.byline: Nick Hopkins, Rosie Cowan and Richard Norton Taylor
fields.body:
British soldiers were recruited by the army's secret intelligence wing to infiltrate the Provisional IRA and were cleared to carry out terrorist operations, including bomb-making and the shootings of RUC officers, as part of their undercover work.

But after the signing of the Good Friday agreement the men, who grew up in Northern Ireland, claim they were suddenly cut adrift from the army.

They have described being unable to contact their handlers or seek the protection which, they say, was promised to them when they agreed to act as double-agents.

Ten soldiers who say they were sent back to their home communities in the early 1980s to infiltrate the republican movement have begun to lobby the Ministry of Defence, fearing that without help they will be hunted down and assassinated by republicans.

They want the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, to recognise what they did at the behest of the security forces and have them 'brought in from the cold'.

Specifically, the men, who regard themselves as soldiers even though they were discharged from the military, want to be given new identities and relocated. They also want an army pension.

The MoD has so far refused to accept the existence of the double agents. Sensitivity on the subject, however, is high.

The ministry has repeatedly tried to thwart reporting of details of intelligence operations in Northern Ireland, especially since the Metropolitan police launched a third inquiry into long-standing claims that the army and RUC special branch colluded with terrorists.

Earlier this week the MoD won a high court order stopping Ulster Television from broadcasting a documentary in which one of the alleged double agents gave a detailed account of how he informed on the IRA for more than 10 years. UTV is contesting the injunction.

One of the double-agents has told the Guardian that another, a 40-year-old, claimed that his army handlers knew he had helped to murder members of the security forces and had been responsible for making a bomb which was fired at an RUC patrol in Newry, Co Down, on March 27 1992, killing a female officer, Colleen McMurray.

Her colleague, Constable Paul Slaine, who lost both legs in the attack, received the George Cross from the Queen on behalf of the RUC at Hillsborough Castle in April 2000.

Another former soldier involved in the campaign told the Guardian that he and the other double agents were recruited from the Ist and 2nd Battalion, Royal Irish Rangers and the Queens Royal Irish Hussars, between 1979 and 1984.

The soldiers, then aged 18 and 19, were approached individually at an early stage in their careers - one after just a few weeks service - by members of the army's intelligence corps. Although they were never told who they were working for, it is believed they were recruited and handled by the army's Force Research Unit.

The FRU, which was led by Brigadier Gordon Kerr - known as Colonel J - is at the heart of claims that the army was involved in state-sponsored assassinations of republicans.The FRU is now the subject of an inquiry overseen by Sir John Stevens, the Met commissioner.

The recruiting routine was the same for all of them. At first they were asked if they recognised photographs of potential republican sympathisers. Secret meetings with senior officers 'over tea and biscuits' continued for several months until the soldiers were finally asked if they would be prepared to go back home to take part in what was called 'The Programme' - infiltrating the IRA.

'We were groomed to do a special job,' said the former soldier. 'We were given surveillance and anti-surveillance training over several weeks to help us prepare. We had to be demilitarised before we could go home to Ireland.

'We were officially discharged from the army so as not to raise suspicion, but we were told by the army we would be taken care of financially. At every meeting with a handler, I was given cash. We were told that if we needed to be pulled out, we would be pulled out.'

The former soldier claims that senior officers told him it could take years before he won the trust of republicans and was accepted into the movement.

According to Willie Carlin, who is acting as a spokesman for the group, one of the soldiers had a five-year apprenticeship before being officially sworn into the IRA - 'greenbooked' as it is known. All 10 of the former soldiers who are seeking MoD help were 'greenbooked', and nine continued to provide intelligence on the IRA until the Good Friday agreement three years ago.

'We were the eyes and ears of the army,' the former soldier said. 'We provided everything from low level intelligence, like gossip in the community and sightings of suspects, to high grade intelligence. Details of planned bombings and shootings, things like that.

'It was extremely stressful. If you're in the army and you break the Official Secrets Act, you go to jail. If you break the rules and regulations of the IRA, they shoot you and put you in a hole.'

Mr Carlin, an ex-Sinn Fein press officer from Derry who spent more than a decade working undercover for the intelligence services, says that all 10 of the agents he represents were put in a position where they had to shoot at other soldiers or RUC officers.

Three of the men were IRA bombmakers; two were convicted of being members of the IRA and one has a conviction for perverting the course of justice.

'They saved more lives than they cost,' Mr Carlin said. 'Because of these men, bombs went wrong and didn't go off. Or the army was tipped off long enough in advance to make sure the area was evacuated.'

The Good Friday agreement, though, heralded a new era.

'You'd phone the number given to you by a handler and nobody would be there, or the number wouldn't work,' Mr Carlin said.

'I tried numerous times to phone my regiment, but couldn't get through to anyone. They didn't want to know. As far as they were concerned, the records show I was discharged from the army and became a member of the IRA.'

Mr Carlin wrote to Mr Hoon on behalf of the former soldiers, but the MoD was dismissive. 'He advised these men to go to the RUC if they felt they were under threat,' said Mr Carlin. 'How could they do that? The RUC knows them as IRA men.'

The MoD has argued that the injunctions are designed to prevent 'possible threats to life', rather than to protect national security. However, Whitehall insiders say the section of the MoD responsible for special forces has become too paranoid. They argue that the activities of undercover army units in Northern Ireland will come out sooner or later.

'We didn't want to have to go public, because that puts us in even greater danger,' said the former soldier. But we have no choice. We became victims of the ceasefire.'

webTitle: Ulster: Sinister role of secret army unit

fields.headline: Sinister role of secret army unit
fields.standfirst:
Police investigate claims of collusion with paramilitaries

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commissioner, is examining claims of an astonishing collusion between the military and the paramilitaries in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The methods and practices of the army's once secret Force Research Unit have become the focus of an investigation led by Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commissioner, which is examining claims of astonishing collusion between the military and the paramilitaries in Northern Ireland.

Although the investigation was set up two years ago specifically to look into the murder of the Belfast solicitor Patrick Finucane in 1989, the Stevens team has been drawn into allegations that the FRU, which the MoD will not admit ever existed, was directly involved in this and numerous other killings.

Deputy Assistant Commissioner Hugh Orde, the officer in day-to-day charge of the inquiry, has also investigated claims that the army has a high-ranking informer in the IRA, codenamed Stakeknife, who is said to have been paid £75,000 a year through an account in Gibraltar.

Although it is unlikely that Stakeknife, the army's primary source spy within the movement, will feature in Mr Orde's report - a draft copy is likely to be sent to ministers in the autumn - he has admitted that he believes Stakeknife exists, and is not a figment of the imagination, as claimed by some republicans.

The evidence of an army whistleblower, who used the pseudonymn Martin Ingram, also helped Mr Orde to shed light on aspects of covert military activity in Northern Ireland that had never been known before.

Ingram has now withdrawn a detailed statement he gave the Stevens team because he believes he has not been offered proper security and assurances of confidentiality. He has been threatened and his house burgled.

The FRU was one of three army-sponsored undercover intelligence squads in Northern Ireland. The others were 22 Squadron SAS, and 14 Company. The FRU, which was set up in Northern Ireland in 1980, dealt with recruiting and handling agents in paramilitary organisations.

14 Company specialised in surveillance while 22 SAS undertook 'executive actions'. 'That means they killed people,' said an army source.

FRU was divided into detachments - north, south, east and west. Headquarters FRU dealt only with material supplied by Stakeknife. Overall, the unit had a complement of about 100 soldiers.

One of its biggest successes was the infiltration of the loyalist paramilitary group the Ulster Defence Association, using an agent, Brian Nelson. Nelson was the UDA's senior intelligence officer at the time Finucane, who had represented republicans, was shot dead in front of his wife and children at home in 1989.

Although Nelson has never been charged with being involved in Finucane's shooting, he was jailed in 1992 for 10 years for a series of other offences, including conspiracy to murder and having information useful to terrorists. He lives at a secret address in England.

Earlier this year he was questioned by the Stevens team over his work with the FRU. He was, apparently, given an assurance that he would not be prosecuted over Finucane's death. The news infuriated the Finucane family, which is campaigning for a public inquiry into the murder and has chosen not to cooperate with the Stevens team.

Nelson was one of up to 20 Northern Ireland-born soldiers who were asked by the army to become agents inside terrorist groups.

The Stevens team has already questioned a number of former members of the FRU, and will eventually speak to Brigadier Gordon Kerr - known as Colonel J - who was in overall charge of the unit. He is now a military attache in Beijing. Another potentially key witness for the Stevens team is Nelson's handler, an officer known as Captain M.

One man has been charged with aiding and abetting in the Finucane murder, and is due to stand trial later this year. He is William Stobie from Belfast, an ex-UDA man and self-confessed former RUC special branch agent.

It is expected that Stevens will use the phrase 'institutionalised collusion' to describe some aspects of army intelligence gathering.

But in an interview with the Guardian last year, Martin Ingram said the FRU did not operate in a maverick fashion, and that the unit could not be blamed in isolation for the extent of the collusion. 'To blame FRU for breaking the rules would be nonsense, because there were no rules,' he said.

webTitle: Silence speaks volumes for Brown's doubts on Europe

fields.headline: Silence speaks volumes for Brown's doubts on Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is not a man spontaneously to be cross, and he never sounds cross when he is cross. Rather, he spins rage, lets it be known that he is angry. And sometimes, as he did this week, he goes on the Today programme and thwacks the object of his ire to one side as though he is irritated even to have it mentioned.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is not a man spontaneously to be cross, and he never sounds cross when he is cross. Rather, he spins rage, lets it be known that he is angry. And sometimes, as he did this week, he goes on the Today programme and thwacks the object of his ire to one side as though he is irritated even to have it mentioned.

The problem this week was the intervention of the European commission in his area of responsibility, the British economy.

Mr Brown told Brussels not to interfere in British economic policy after the commission ordered him to put a cap on public spending, reported the Daily Telegraph, going on to talk of the government's outrage at the supposed intervention.

It was seen by Mr Brown as a deliberate attempt to meddle in domestic affairs, in particular tax and spending decisions, even though Britain is not a member of the single currency. The Financial Times said the government "had reacted angrily".

In his radio interview Mr Brown adopted the "I am not going to be told by Brussels..." tone so welcome to Euro-sceptic ears. It's all about tone, and the noise that the chancellor consistently puts across is to speak out when Europe goes over the line and to remain silent, as he has over the euro, at other times. Were you simply to collect what he has said, as opposed to collecting his volume of silences, you could easily draw the conclusion that Gordon is a Eurosceptic.

That presumably is the point, and is what the committed Europeans, including the prime minister, find so irritating. Mr Brown smiles and keeps his counsel, as he does in so many matters controversial or difficult for the government. As Donald Macintyre said in his Independent column this week: "There are times when it almost looks as if these problems [Kosovo, fuel prices, foot and mouth] belong to a different government from the one Mr Brown is involved in running." And that, said Macintyre, could have consequences after the election.

A looming problem is the question of how far Mr Brown will seek to keep the assessment of the famous EMU tests (the euro entry criteria) closeted within the Treasury. But the euro is not something Mr Brown mentions. Not so the Sun. As the non-election campaign gathers momentum, Labour's other red-top declared supporter (the Mirror is always there) misses no opportunity to remind the government, more than its readers, that it may be voting Labour but it is certainly not voting euro. In a leader headed On a Loser, the Sun declared that the message about the euro finally seemed to be getting through.'It appears the government realises it can't win a referendum on scrapping the pound during its second term of office. We like the sound of this, Tony. If you can't do it before 2006, why do it at all?' The Sun regularly drips in little paragraphs of little consequence quoting people of little influence, running stories which do not appear elsewhere. So this week we had "French face euro chaos", which amounted to some quotes from former French interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, warning that the new euro notes and coins would confuse shoppers and deter them from buying anything.

If Britain's 12m or so tabloid readers are not offered a choice of which party to vote for in the election, they are certainly given one in terms of attitude to Europe. Consistently the Mirror is doing the government's work for it, championing Europe when ministers think it safer to keep quiet.

Europe is strongest link for UK, read the headline on a Mirror leader this week. Praising the chancellor for his stewardship of the economy, and pointing out the widening trade gap with the American and Asian economies, the paper said: "But trade with our European partners has been doing all right. Which just shows what nonsense is talked by the anti-Europeans.

"For long term prosperity and security there must be long term vision. That means keeping a tight rein on public finances, spending only what the nation can afford and strengthening our links with Europe." Gordon Brown would certainly agree with the first half of that last sentence.

Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University.

A looming problem is the question of how far Mr Brown will seek to keep the assessment of the famous EMU tests (the euro entry criteria) closeted within the Treasury. But the euro is not something Mr Brown mentions. Not so the Sun. As the non-election campaign gathers momentum, Labour's other red-top declared supporter (the Mirror is always there) misses no opportunity to remind the government, more than its readers, that it may be voting Labour but it is certainly not voting euro. In a leader headed On a Loser, the Sun declared that the message about the euro finally seemed to be getting through.'It appears the government realises it can't win a referendum on scrapping the pound during its second term of office. We like the sound of this, Tony. If you can't do it before 2006, why do it at all?' The Sun regularly drips in little paragraphs of little consequence quoting people of little influence, running stories which do not appear elsewhere. So this week we had "French face euro chaos", which amounted to some quotes from former French interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, warning that the new euro notes and coins would confuse shoppers and deter them from buying anything. If Britain's 12m or so tabloid readers are not offered a choice of which party to vote for in the election, they are certainly given one in terms of attitude to Europe. Consistently the Mirror is doing the government's work for it, championing Europe when ministers think it safer to keep quiet. Europe is strongest link for UK, read the headline on a Mirror leader this week. Praising the chancellor for his stewardship of the economy, and pointing out the widening trade gap with the American and Asian economies, the paper said: "But trade with our European partners has been doing all right. Which just shows what nonsense is talked by the anti-Europeans. "For long term prosperity and security there must be long term vision. That means keeping a tight rein on public finances, spending only what the nation can afford and strengthening our links with Europe." Gordon Brown would certainly agree with the first half of that last sentence. Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University.

fields.headline: Why I hate the countryside
fields.trailText: The British, against all logic and evidence, still believe we're a nation of jolly gentleman farmers.
fields.body:
This was always the dislike that dare not speak its name. If, as a city dweller, you professed an antipathy to the countryside, said that you don't much like it out there, don't particularly want to visit and certainly don't ever want to live in it, you were deemed some kind of crackpot, a disturbed and probably unpatriotic pariah. I was once pilloried on the public stocks of the Terry Wogan show for saying just that. Ridiculed for suggesting that it might be more rewarding to reside in London, Manchester or Glasgow than in some twee village where a tractor show is high culture and Asda is a shopping experience. Diss the cities and the millions who live in them, however, and you'll be lauded for talking obvious commonsense. During a phone-in on Radio 5, some charming chap from the West Country insisted that I must be "educationally subnormal" because I preferred the challenges and chances proffered by a big, noisy, dirty, city.

Yet this was the first country to turn its back on country life in favour of mass industrialisation and urbanisation, and is now the nation with one of the lowest percentages of its people working the soil, the most intensively mechanised farming practices, the least well-preserved rural culture and the most cosmopolitan metropolitan one. But we don't acknowledge all that, instead indulging in a bizarre form of collective self-loathing. We're urban and suburban souls in denial and Barbours. We have such a romantic, roses-round-the-door-tinted perception of our supposedly green and pleasant land, of warm beer and long shadows, of John Bull's stout and hearty yeomen, that "city bad, country good" is the almost universally accepted wisdom.

In fact, so keen are we on owning a little piece of the sacred soil that we even buy up vast tracts of rural France. Around 400,000 British people have bought homes in the Dordogne, Normandy and Provence, amazed that the French want to sell their ruined out-houses and draughty barns to the old enemy. But, as Paul Rambali, an Anglo-French writer who lives in Paris, points out, "The French don't want to live out there in the wasteland, that's for peasants and pigs as far as they're concerned." Like most Europeans, in fact like most everybody else, the French are resolutely urban. By 2020, the World Resource Report suggests, 75% of the world's population will live in cities.

The British, however, against all logic and evidence, still believe they're a nation of jolly gentlemen farmers. Professor Maxwell Hutchinson, former president of the Royal Institute of British Architects, is convinced that this warped and uniquely British idea has damaged both town and countryside: "It was a reaction against the genuine squalor of Victorian cities, and a soppy watercolour idealisation of the countryside which is simply not substantiated by reality. It means that our priorities are skewed, cities are denigrated and rural areas are overpopulated. I fell for it and tried the country house bit, but came back to live in London, which I have to say I much prefer. The city is man's greatest invention." Most British men and women, however, would not agree with that, cherishing some Good Life fantasy image of Albion.

But today, as military snipers stalk the charred and diseased fields, all that might finally be changing. The Wellington boot is finally on the other foot. Suddenly, the countryside is a dangerous place, out of bounds and out of favour, synonymous with contagion and corruption, dark practices, huge subsidies and red-faced men in dubious alliances bleating like the sheep they fed to cows and blaming everybody but themselves when people got sick. Foot and mouth hasn't led to a massive wave of support for the poor sons of the soil among the urban masses, but it may well have brought about a sea change in our attitude to rural Britain.

People in towns are saying enough is enough. We've given you one job to do, huge subsidies to do it, and you've given us mad cow disease, E. coli, salmonella and now this. There's a sense here in the dark satanic cities that what's happening out there is a clear case of "as you sow, so shall you reap". Which farmers, of all people, really ought to understand. (I would add something about chickens coming home to roost, if they weren't all crammed into batteries so small that they can't possibly go anywhere.)

I'm sure that many agricultural souls are genuinely suffering, but for years too many cried wolf while hunting foxes, driving Range Rovers and sending their kids to private schools on the proceeds of turning fields into featureless factories. But do you ever hear a single one of them say sorry, we were wrong?

No, instead they blame foreigners, the EU, the government or city types "demanding cheap food". How many times have we heard that ludicrous mantra in this current crisis? I don't recall going on the cheap chop demonstrations of the 90s or marching to Trafalgar Square insisting that our food producers save us a few pennies by cannibalising herbivores. Surely the huge swing towards organic produce among us townies, the queues at overpriced health-food shops, the fetish for free-range, corn-fed, extra-virgin, born-free, lived-wild-and-hopefully-died-naturally food is a sign that we're demanding anything but the chemically-saturated, factory-farmed, lowest- common-denominator produce that farmers have foisted upon us. But do they listen?

A photographer friend, sent to Devon to cover foot and mouth for his paper, said to me, when he came back, "The arrogance of those people was amazing. All they did was blame me as a representative of the media." Certainly, the farmers who've had any contact with newspapers or television during recent crises haven't done themselves too many favours. Few seem prepared to accept that there could be anything intrinsically wrong with the way they go about managing the countryside, and producing our foodstuffs, and that perhaps it has to change. Most seem intent on whingeing until they get yet more hand-outs to preserve the putrid status quo. But these were not people noted for their support of miners, steelworkers or printers when their industries were being decimated by the Margaret Thatcher they all voted for. Farmers will happily hold the country to ransom over the tax on petrol they don't even have to pay, and then hold us responsible when things go horribly wrong. The man whose pig-processing plant first succumbed to foot and mouth blamed it not on allegedly dubious hygiene practices, but on someone eating foreign meat in a sandwich and throwing it on the ground. That's not exactly grace under pressure.

Now is a time for us ignorant townies to apply pressure to rethink the way we allow farmers to go about their business. And perhaps we will also start to reassess our views of what life is really like out there. Countryfolk have always said that we don't understand them; well, perhaps, we are finally beginning to, and it doesn't look particularly pretty. But then, to me, it never has. Apart from the sensory deprivation of nothing to do, whenever I've ventured into the rural wonderland. I always seem to land up in some small-minded little England. A bad-taste, intolerant, prying land that time forgot, where everybody looks and thinks and dresses and moans and eats the same. How come, whenever you dine in one of our famed country pubs, everything is served in a basket and comes complete with frozen chips and sachets of ketchup or ersatz Thai spices? In rural Italy, France or Spain, you really can find great fresh, indigenous, truly local peasant cuisine in the most humble surroundings, whereas here you get served the same bland, uniform, processed rubbish. While the posh restaurant will inevitably be a bastion of snotty pretension with dress codes and French menus. If the countryside is where food comes from, how come they don't know how to cook and serve it?

Jonathan Meades, a leading food writer, puts it like this: "We lost our national cuisine after the war when we chose to go down the path of industrial farming, basically an animal feed business, the biggest amount of the least choice. And that is absolutely reflected in the standard of food, which is appalling. It's all cooking by numbers and pre-prepared boil-in-a-bag exoticism. We have to be honest with ourselves: most of the British countryside is breeze-block bungalows and light industrial estates with cuisine to match. It's no better now than it was when I was growing up there and desperate to leave."

Yet we're force-fed the idea that the countryside is the ideal place for kids. And typically, this faintly soppy predilection for watching sprogs gambol in fields like so many lambs has been turned into an anti-urban prejudice, suggesting that it's akin to child abuse to allow young ones to be brought up in big towns. As a result, I've known otherwise sane urban couples anguish about giving up the metropolitan existence they so enjoy to do the right thing by their little ones. Country Life, a bizarrely British title if ever there was one, recently ran a shock-horror survey suggesting that civilisation was about end because deprived inner-city kids didn't know that milk came from cows or that cows came from Gloucestershire, or some such insulting nonsense. Well, if they watch the news, they'll know that British cows can't go anywhere right now.

My three (well, more the older two - Maude has a good excuse, being only 20 months) are fairly aware that the organic milk left on our doorstep every day began life as bovine baby juice, and they also know a few other things. Among them the contents of the British Museum and Tate Modern, the Portuguese for "please" and "thank you" (the bloke in the corner shop is Portuguese), the menu at our local Japanese restaurant, the date of Diwali, the capital of Eritrea (the babysitter's Eritrean), most of the words to Pretty Vacant, the underlying reasons for the Balkan crises (the neighbour's Kosovan), the layout of Lord's cricket ground, Loftus Road and the Tricycle Theatre, and how best to get a couple of bob out of Grandma Ying if she's had a win at mah jong (Grandma's Chinese). If you really think rural life - with its limited horizons, few diversions and endless hours hanging out at the bus stop drinking cider - is better for kids, then try asking some of them. The minute they get anywhere near old enough to have minds of their own, they want to get on the first bus to the dreaded city.

When I occasionally take my family in the other direction, that's when I really notice one of the major differences. A rumbustious bunch of mixed-raced kids with an Anglo-Chinese mum and a ginger dad don't cause much of a stir in London NW1. But the stares and the whispered comments the minute we arrive in Straw Dogs territory are immediately noticeable. When I said this on Radio 4 recently, Miles Kington wrote a supposedly funny column in the Independent saying that my family get stared at in the country not because of our racial make up, but because the locals might think we're burglars or Jehovah's Witnesses. I don't know how funny Mr Kington would find it if his wife and children were racially insulted in the street. It's only ever happened twice, both times in small English market towns by respectable middle-aged women of the shires.

It isn't only my family who get that sort of treatment. I've known numerous black friends who simply refuse to leave their cities. For them, it's too much like travelling back in time, to that sorry England where a racist joke served up in the pub along with your pewter tankard is just a bit of fun, where strange "outsiders" are still a source of amusement or fear. Claire Gorham, an Anglo-African TV presenter living in London, puts it like this: "I feel very uncomfortable in the country because the atmosphere and the attitude is very different. Suddenly, you're made aware again that your race is an issue. It isn't always hostile, but occasionally it can be."

Certainly, the fact that everybody looks the same because everybody is pretty much the same is one of the reasons why I find the countryside dreary and rather depressing. But I also fear that it's one of the reasons some people are attracted to it. Those who sing the praises of rural over urban life always point out that there is an annual exodus from cities to towns, as if all those people upping sticks to move to the sticks can't be wrong. Well, some of those people may well be moving for what I would definitely consider to be the wrong reasons. They used to call it "white flight" in the US during the 70s and 80s, when cities such as Detroit and Chicago were being stripped of their affluent, Caucasian middle classes, who were fleeing to gated communities in the deep suburbs. A retreat into the uniform monoculture of old England because of an inability to accept the challenges and pleasures of genuinely multicultural cities, is, I'm sure, one of the reasons why some people choose to relocate in the laager of the shires.

But perhaps now that the harsh and sometimes ugly realities of true rural life are being shown on our television screens every day, our preposterous romanticism of all things green and supposedly bucolic will end. And the attendant defamation of all things urban will give way to a more realistic and balanced attitude. Perhaps, also, we will finally see a change in the priorities and practices of those who manage our agriculture, better to reflect the true demands of the urban population who crave more varied, more healthy, more natural food.

It's hard to imagine anything good coming out of all this disease and destruction, but, if it does, then maybe even I could learn to love the countryside just a little.

fields.headline: US bounce raises hopes
fields.standfirst:
Surprise doubling of growth rate creates 10-year record but UK expansion weakens

Special report: Global recession
fields.trailText: Signs of a bounce back in the US dispelled some of the gathering gloom about the global economy yesterday when stronger than expected figures raised hopes that a recession would be averted.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott and Jane Martinson in Washington
fields.body:
Signs of a bounce back in the US dispelled some of the gathering gloom about the global economy yesterday when stronger than expected figures raised hopes that a recession would be averted.

America's growth rate doubled to an annualised 2% in the first three months of the year after the bursting of the hi-tech bubble and sharp downturn in spending last year.

The surprise momentum, led by increased consumer demand, meant the US completed a record 10th year of unbroken expansion.

There was less good news from Britain where GDP expanded at 0.3% in the first quarter, with the weakness of industrial production acting as a brake on the economy.

Although the annual rate of growth fell only slightly, by 0.1 percentage points, the slowdown raised speculation that the Bank of England would cut interest rates next week for the third time this year.

Foot and mouth disease had little impact on the economy in the first quarter but is expected to depress agriculture and tourism in the second.

Paul O'Neill, the US treasury secretary, described the 2% growth rate as 'nothing but good news'. In contrast Horst Köhler, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, warned against being overly optimistic. 'The world economy is going through a very difficult phase. We are still not in a very nice world. We recognise that in the US and other regions' growth is slowing down and there is no region taking up the slack.'

The IMF will this weekend give details of a $10bn (£7bn) support package to help Turkey clean up the bad debts in its banking system follow ing the crisis this year. It is also anxiously monitoring the situation in Argentina, suffering from a debt-induced crisis.

As the multilateral institutions grapple with such problems in the developing world during their annual spring meetings this weekend, Wim Duisenberg, the president of European Central Bank, is expected to come under heavy pressure today to cut euroland interest rates. Several leading economists and politicians have criticised the ECB in the past few days for its reluctance to ease policy.

Mr Köhler yesterday appeared to step back from com ments in which the IMF's chief economist, Michael Mussa, gave the ECB a public dressing down. Mr Köhler said that Mr Mussa was 'a brilliant and serious economist', but he indicated that his presentation might have been inappropriate.

The head of the IMF made it clear that he would like the central bank to act amid signs of a sharp global slowdown. 'I would like to underline that I think an interest rate cut in Europe would be helpful,' he said, adding that it was up to the ECB to set its own course.

Comments made by Mr O'Neill this week have also indicated US frustration at the ECB's failure to act. Yesterday, he said that it would be inappropriate for him to give monetary policy advice to the European bank, but: 'It seems to me that it is the obligation of leaders around the world, especially in the developed countries, to aspire to and hopefully achieve a rate of growth consistent with our potential.'

US stock markets rallied on the signs of an upturn yesterday morning. Some US economists suggested that the 3.3% increase in inflation also reported yesterday could prevent the US central bank from cutting rates for the fifth time at its next meeting in May.

Mr Köhler yesterday appeared to step back from com ments in which the IMF's chief economist, Michael Mussa, gave the ECB a public dressing down. Mr Köhler said that Mr Mussa was 'a brilliant and serious economist', but he indicated that his presentation might have been inappropriate. The head of the IMF made it clear that he would like the central bank to act amid signs of a sharp global slowdown. 'I would like to underline that I think an interest rate cut in Europe would be helpful,' he said, adding that it was up to the ECB to set its own course. Comments made by Mr O'Neill this week have also indicated US frustration at the ECB's failure to act. Yesterday, he said that it would be inappropriate for him to give monetary policy advice to the European bank, but: 'It seems to me that it is the obligation of leaders around the world, especially in the developed countries, to aspire to and hopefully achieve a rate of growth consistent with our potential.' US stock markets rallied on the signs of an upturn yesterday morning. Some US economists suggested that the 3.3% increase in inflation also reported yesterday could prevent the US central bank from cutting rates for the fifth time at its next meeting in May.

fields.headline: Rioter was 'time bomb'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: A 'stop the City' rioter who became a 'timebomb' of pent-up violence after witnessing the axe murder of his mother as a 10-year-old boy walked free from court yesterday.
fields.body:
A 'stop the City' rioter who became a 'timebomb' of pent-up violence after witnessing the axe murder of his mother as a 10-year-old boy walked free from court yesterday.

Andrew Saunders, 22, was spotted in the vanguard of the anti-capitalist demonstrations that left a multimillion pound trial of damage through the City of London two years ago.

He repeatedly hurled missiles at police lines protecting the Liffe building, including a piece of breeze block that smashed against an officer's riot shield.

Saunders of Woking, Surrey, who admitted two charges of violent disorder, was put on probation for a year after Southwark crown court heard that his role in the violence had been triggered by the sight of a woman being knocked over by a police van and another being restrained by police.

Evan Nuttall, defending, said his client had twice attempted suicide. At the root of his mental problems lay his mother's appalling death and the years of untreated post-traumatic stress disorder he suffered as a result.

Judge George Bathurst-Norman said: 'Obviously if any violence is directed towards a woman in front of him then he is a timebomb. His background is as disturbing as anyone could possibly imagine.'

webTitle: Tough job ahead for Japan's new PM

fields.headline: Falling prices and pay confront Japan's new PM
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The new Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, was given no honeymoon period yesterday as sobering economy data underscored the challenges he faces in rebuilding the world's second biggest economy.
fields.body:
The new Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, was given no honeymoon period yesterday as sobering economy data underscored the challenges he faces in rebuilding the world's second biggest economy.

Worse than expected statistics on consumption and earnings heightened concerns about deflation, while a sharp fall in industrial production suggested Japan could be lurching back towards recession.

The premier may also have to find a new governor of the Bank of Japan, after reports that Masaru Hayami is about to resign, citing 'ill health' as the reason.

Yesterday's dismal economic figures seemed in line with an IMF forecast that Japan's growth would slow to a meagre 0.6% this fiscal year compared to 1.7% last year.

Even that modest prediction may prove too optimistic if Mr Koizumi pushes through the painful reforms that he considers necessary to restore Japan to health after 10 years of stagnation.

The prime minister, who inaugurated his cabinet on Thursday, has made reform of the banking system his priority even if it means two years of recession, unemployment and bankruptcy.

Yesterday's data gave ammunition to his opponents, who say that the economy is too weak for such surgery. Consumer prices slipped by a record 0.5% in the year to March 31 as sluggish demand and deregulation forced down prices for everything from hamburgers to clothing.

With unemployment hovering close to a record 4.7% and expected to rise, wage earners cut back their spending by 0.4% last year to save more for an uncertain future.

Incomes also slipped for the fourth month in a row fuelling fears that Japan may be on the edge of a deflationary spiral.

'There is a very persistent downward move in prices,' said Heizo Takenaka, the new economics minister. 'We need to determine how much of the decline is due to lack of demand.'

Yesterday, Sony posted its first group operating profit in three years despite glitches affecting the PlayStation2 console. Hitachi and Mitsubishi Electric more than quadrupled pretax profits, and Toshiba returned to the black due to strong computer and household appliance sales.

Honda saw net profits slide by 11.5% and Matsushita Electrical Industrial, maker of the National and Panasonic brands, suffered a 58.4% fall due to restructuring costs.

Mr Koizumi is adamant. 'I feel that I have to push forward by summoning up my fighting spirit,' he said. 'There is strong resistance, but I must not be intimidated.'

webTitle: Islanders fail to stop US bombs

fields.headline: Islanders fail to stop US bombs
fields.standfirst:
Navy ships and jets reopen target practice despite objections from Puerto Rico's government

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Navy ships and jets reopen target practice despite objections from Puerto Rico's government.
fields.body:
The United States navy resumed its controversial bombing practice on a small Puerto Rican island yesterday, ignoring protesters and a new law against noise pollution passed by the territory's government to try to curtail the bombing.

About 200 demonstrators gathered outside the entrance to the shelling range on Vieques, 52 square miles of beaches and green hills off the east coast of Puerto Rico. The navy owns two-thirds of the island, and uses a 900-acre piece at the eastern end as a range for bombing by ships and jets.

While the bombs and shells used are dummies, the protesters believe that the loud noise is harming residents' health. A security guard was killed by stray shells in 1999.

In the past two days 14 people have been arrested and accused of trespass after breaching security to enter the range.

A court ruling in Washington on Thursday cleared the way for the exercises to resume, though the judge noted that the navy had implied to residents that it would hold off bombing until studies were finished into claims that the noise caused heart troubles.

'This is a sad day for Vieques,' said Nelson Lopez Aponte, a priest on the island. But, he said, 'If the Berlin Wall fell, so can the navy ... The rule of God is peace. You can never get peace by bombing.'

Protesters say that the navy has damaged the health of the island's 9,300 people - the cancer rate is 27% above that on the Puerto Rican mainland - depleted fish life, stunted tourism and diminished the islanders' self-respect.

The US claims that the range is essential. 'Vieques is a superb training range, the best in the entire Atlantic for the uses that the navy and marines put it toward,' said Rear Admiral Craig Quigley.

Vieques has been taken up as a cause by celebrity dissidents such as Jesse Jackson and Robert Kennedy Jr. The governor of New York, George Pataki - who has millions of Hispanic voters - was on the island recently to show sympathy. Benicio del Toro, an Oscar-winning Puerto Rican actor, is among the protesters.

Puerto Rico's new anti-navy governor, Sila Calderon, also persuaded 11 stars - boxers, baseball players, and singers Ricky Martin and Marc Anthony - to take out full-page ads in prominent US newspapers asking President Bush to stop the bombing.

'It's really the first time that Puerto Rico is standing up to the US,' said Dario Moreno, a political scientist at Florida International University.

Puerto Rico exists under the US umbrella as a commonwealth: its people are US citizens who so far have shied away from asking either for independence, or to become a US state (meaning they would have to pay federal taxes). As non-taxpayers they cannot vote in presidential elections, but are largely self-governing.

The governor has been accused of breaking a deal her predecessor made with the Clinton presidency, under which the island will vote in November on whether the Navy should stay or go by 2003. The result is not in doubt.

Puerto Rico's legislature has denounced the agreement as offering too little, too slowly and some Republicans in Congress are trying to block part of it, the return on May 1 of 8,000 acres to the island and $40m in aid. The Vieques government is broke, unemployment rampant, education poor and health care minimal.

webTitle: Hidden powerhouse of the US presidency

fields.headline: Hidden powerhouse of the US presidency
fields.standfirst:
While George Bush takes the public eye, Vice-President Dick Cheney pulls the Washington strings

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: While George Bush takes the public eye, Vice-President Dick Cheney pulls the Washington strings.
fields.body:
George Bush had an uncompromising message for the Washington cynics who claim that he is nothing more than Dick Cheney's front man. 'To these people, I say this,' the president began a speech last month. Then he looked at the man sitting further down the table and asked: `Well, Dick, what do I say?'

Self-deprecating humour is one of the favourite weapons of America's new president, who completes his first hundred days in office tomorrow. But the jokes cannot entirely conceal the truth. Mr Bush may have got the office and the title, but time and again it is Mr Cheney who does the work, who calls the shots and who sets the administration on its conservative course.

Having picked many members of the administration in December and January, he has now surrounded himself with a heavyweight staff of his own, installed himself at all the vital junctions of decision-making in the White House, and taken charge of key policy areas, including the federal budget and the energy policy review.

No important meeting on foreign policy takes place without his being present, and he is the administration's principal ambassador to Capitol Hill, where as vice-president he holds the casting vote in the evenly divided Senate. It is an unprecedented workload for a US vice-president, let alone one who has had four heart attacks and quadruple bypass surgery.

The job has come a long way since Vice-President John Nance Garner in the 1930s said it was 'not worth a bucket of warm spit'. It is a mark of Mr Cheney's importance that he has four separate Washington offices: one in the Senate, another in the House of Representatives, a third in the Old Executive Office Building, where most of his staff work, and one in the west wing of the White House, just down the corridor from the Oval Office.

None of this is obvious from the outside. Mr Bush's daily schedule is full of activities which keep him constantly in the public eye. Mr Cheney, by contrast, has few public engagements, makes virtually no speeches, gives only rare interviews (including one to Larry King last night), and keeps out of the limelight, 'never showing more surface than necessary' as the secretary of state, Colin Powell, describes it in his 1995 memoirs.

And this secret revolution has stunned friend and foe alike. Ronald Reagan's former chief of staff Ken Duberstein says it is 'the first time in our history we've had a president and a prime minister'. The Democratic congressman Robert Wexler just says: 'Dick Cheney is running the government'.

'To compare him to other vice-presidents is to diminish his real influence,' says Paul Light, the author of a book on the vice-presidency. 'He's really a chief of staff, the senior cabinet secretary, the chairman of the kitchen cabinet, the president's best friend and mentor, all rolled into one.'

No one ever doubted that Mr Cheney would be a huge asset to the inexperienced Mr Bush. His time as Gerald Ford's chief of staff and George Bush Sr's defence secretary, plus his 10 years as an influential Republican congressman in the 1980s and his experience as chief executive of the Halliburton oil company from 1995, gave him an exceptional background.

It also helped that he had given up any thought of running for the presidency himself. In the past 50 years Spiro Agnew was the only elected vice-president who did not have a shot at the top job.

'You can play a very different role if you aren't running for president,' Mr Cheney's longstanding colleague Bob Teeter says. 'It means the president can entrust you with big things'.

The first proof of Mr Cheney's true importance came when Mr Bush sublet the entire presidential transition process to him in December. Mr Cheney's hand was soon seen in cabinet nominations, such as his old patron Donald Rumsfeld for defence secretary and his old colleague Paul O'Neill at the treasury.

Even so, few people would have been able to predict how central Mr Cheney has already become on policy issues. 'He's a lot stronger today than anybody anticipated when Bush picked him,' the Republican lobbyist Chuck Greener says.

For instance, no previous vice-president had such power over the government budget. Mr Cheney chaired the budget review board this spring, settling spending disputes between departments without ever referring them to Mr Bush.

No previous vice-president has had such a central role in national security policy either. Mr Cheney attends every 'principals' meeting' of the national security council and is one of the inner group, along with Mr Bush, the national security adviser Condoleezza Rice and the White House chief of staff Andy Card, which takes the final political decisions. And while Mr Cheney gets every security briefing that goes to his colleagues, he has also installed his own private national security team, headed by his chief of staff Lewis 'Scooter' Libby, which briefs him alone.

Mr Cheney was the key proponent of the two big policy reviews set in motion as soon as the administration took office. The first, on US defence needs, was entrusted to Mr Rumsfeld. The second, on US energy strategy, he has taken charge of himself.

When it is published in a few weeks time, the energy review may prove to be the defining document of the Bush years. It aims to establish policy on everything from nuclear power to oil drilling in protected lands and the future of international oil sanctions. It will set the stage for crucial battles between the energy industry and environmentalists.

It will recommend drilling in Alaska, a project Mr Cheney championed as a congressman 20 years ago, exploratory drilling to be allowed in more than 7.6m hectares (17m acres) of the Rocky Mountains, including the Lewis and Clark national forest in Montana, and an easing of air pollution controls.

It will raise the possibility of lifting US sanctions against Iran, Libya and possibly even Iraq. It will call on America to build dozens of power plants and reinvest in nuclear power. It will be a bonanza for an industry which gave more than $25m to the Republicans for last year's elections.

Everything about the energy review is classic Cheney. Like the president, Mr Cheney is an oil industry man. Before returning to politics he was chief executive of Halliburton, the biggest oil service company in the world, which itself has given $1.5m to the Republican party in the past10 years. Wherever there is oil - Iraq, China, Alaska - Halliburton has interests. Every decision that Mr Cheney's team takes about access to new energy supplies will have a bearing on the company, which provided him with an income of $36.1m last year alone.

Mastermind

But Mr Cheney is more than just the architect of the administration and the mastermind of its policy direction. He is a fixture at the Senate Republican caucus's weekly strategy meetings, and when arms need to be twisted in the Senate and the House, he is the administration's chief negotiator and dealer.

'Any time there's a strategy session on scheduling and lobbying, he is in the middle of all that,' says Mike Frank of the conservative Heritage Foundation. 'He is a really key player at a substantive level, and not just because of the title he holds.'

Conservatives are now preparing for him to play this role in what many see as the greatest battles of the next two years: the right wing's attempt to place its supporters in hundreds of judicial positions at all levels of the federal court system and, above all, to take firm control of the supreme court.

Or at least he will if his health holds out. Just over 10 years ago his wife Lynne wrote a novel called Body Politic, in which a 59-year-old vice-president dies of a heart attack while in bed with a television anchorwoman. Today, the health of the 60-year-old Mr Cheney's heart is a constant concern at every level of government.

Mr Bush, meanwhile, sticks to the jokes. 'Here are some of the headlines I'd like to see in the future,' he told the American Society of Newspaper Editors on April 5. 'Cheney cloned: president has nothing to do at all now.'

fields.headline: Future Network axes Business 2.0
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Magazine publisher Future Network announced yesterday the closure of all the European editions of its new economy title, Business 2.0.
fields.body:
Magazine publisher Future Network announced yesterday the closure of all the European editions of its new economy title, Business 2.0.

The news comes barely two weeks after the demise of the internet business magazine Industry Standard.

Business 2.0 was launched last May at the height of the dot.com boom as a spin-off from its US version. German and Italian editions followed in August and October, before the dot.com bubble burst.

"Since late last autumn advertising revenue on the European editions has fallen by more than half,'' said Greg Ingham, chief executive of Future Network. "We could not see a way forward for these titles. Unfortunately, all the staff will be made redundant."

In contrast to the US edition, which turned a profit shortly after launch, the European editions never made money.

Future estimates the costs of closing the Italian and British editions will be £1m, and the company will lay off 20 members of staff, 17 in Britain.

The firm also announced the closure of its entire, loss-making, German operation, Future Verlag, with the sale of the German edition of its games magazine PCPlayer to publisher IDG and a loss of 55 jobs.

By the end of last year Future Verlag had lost £6.4m and is expected to lose £2.9m more for the current financial year.

The closure of the Business 2.0 in Europe comes at the height of nine weeks of speculation over the possible sale of the US edition, which some estimate to be valued at $50m (£35m).

The firm also announced the closure of its entire, loss-making, German operation, Future Verlag, with the sale of the German edition of its games magazine PCPlayer to publisher IDG and a loss of 55 jobs. By the end of last year Future Verlag had lost £6.4m and is expected to lose £2.9m more for the current financial year. The closure of the Business 2.0 in Europe comes at the height of nine weeks of speculation over the possible sale of the US edition, which some estimate to be valued at $50m (£35m).

fields.headline: Scoot dismisses £100m Vivendi bid
fields.standfirst:
Troubled directory service says French offer is 'wholly inadequate'

More internet news
fields.trailText: Troubled internet directory service Scoot.com last night turned down a possible £100m offer from French media company Vivendi Universal as 'wholly inadequate'.
fields.body:
Troubled internet directory service Scoot.com last night turned down a possible £100m offer from French media company Vivendi Universal as 'wholly inadequate'.

The rejection of a potential 15p per share offer came at the end of another extraordinary days trading in Scoot stock.

Shares rose 60% to 18.5p in early trading after the British company said it was in 'preliminary' talks that might lead to a takeover offer.

An hour before the market closed, Vivendi put out a statement identifying itself as the mystery bidder, emphasising that there was 'no certainty' any offer would come and that if one is eventually made, it would be not more than 15p per share. Shares in Scoot then fell sharply, closing at 12.75p, reflecting concern that any offer may not even reach 15p. Ninety minutes after the market shut the offer was rejected.

Vivendi owns 22% of Scoot and has long been linked with a takeover. Periodic reports that a deal is imminent have prompted wild swings in the Scoot share price before they were denied. At one stage the loss-making firm was valued at £2.5bn in anticipation of a bid from the French company, which had bought shares for as much as 325p each.

Based on the closing price of its shares last night Scoot, which last June bought free newspapers group Loot for £190m, is now worth just £86m.

Vivendi's carefully worded statement noted that the potential offer price of up to 15p was based on 'the existing position and future prospects of Scoot' and could be altered 'in circumstances of material new information coming to light as a result of due diligence'.

Last month Scoot said it had appointed Merrill Lynch to conduct a strategic review of the business. Scoot has experienced problems with its technology and its subscriber numbers. Several interested parties including free newspaper firm Trader.com and mobile phone firm Vodafone are also understood to have approached Merrill.
