fields.headline: Minister's signal lifts Railtrack
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, yesterday delivered the strongest endorsement yet by the government of Railtrack's radical plans to restructure its operations.
fields.body:
Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, yesterday delivered the strongest endorsement yet by the government of Railtrack's radical plans to restructure its operations.

In a speech which prompted the rail network operator's share price to rise by 9.6% at one point yesterday, he said: 'We have rejected calls to renationalise Railtrack ... Our new approach to major rail enhancements will allow third parties to be deployed, enabling Railtrack to give more attention to management of the core network.

'We expect Railtrack to be a major partner in the development projects, along with train operating companies, construction consortia and financial institutions.'

The City interpreted Lord Macdonald's remarks - made to the Birmingham Chamber of Commerce - as firm government backing for Railtrack's plans to split into two divisions: one focusing on track maintenance and renewal; the other to consider one-off greenfield development projects. The company's shares closed up 20.5p at 475p.

A spokesman for Railtrack said that the company had no plans to demerge the two proposed divisions.

One City analyst said: 'The current structure of the company hasn't delivered what it should have. A reorganisation to provide more clarity in the management is good news.'

Railtrack announced the radical overhaul at the beginning of this month when it accepted the need for development projects to be opened up to competitive bids.

Sebastian Bull, acting finance director, was promoted this week to business development director to drive the strategy through and work with outsiders such as Bechtel to enhance the network.

The proposals were greeted with reticence by investors after John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, insisted the company appoint a non-executive director to 'provide a powerful public and consumer interest voice'.

While Lord Macdonald's remarks marked a softer tone and proved a fillip to Railtrack's share price, his speech underlined how politically sensitive the network operator was. 'Railtrack is the ultimate political stock,' a spokesman for the company said.

fields.headline: Pro-hunt alliance funded RSPCA infiltrator
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The pro-hunting Countryside Alliance covertly funded an attempted infiltration of the RSPCA led by a former Olympic showjumper, according to leaked documents seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
The pro-hunting Countryside Alliance covertly funded an attempted infiltration of the RSPCA led by a former Olympic showjumper, according to leaked documents seen by the Guardian.

The animal charity has accused Richard Meade, who won three Olympic medals in 1968 and 1972, of spearheading a campaign to encourage 600 hunt supporters to join the society to overturn the society's long-standing opposition to bloodsports.

Mr Meade faces possible expulsion by the RSPCA, which is planning to look at legal options to force him to leave the society at a future meeting of its ruling council.

His group, the Countryside Animal Welfare Group, set up five years ago, consists of 5,000 RSPCA members who want to make the charity support fox hunting.

The internal accounts of the Countryside Alliance, seen by the Guardian, show that in 1999, it gave Cawg at least £13,490 to fund a mailshot and the "fees and expenses'' of Mr Meade. The alliance admitted that this was part of a larger sum over a longer period but declined to disclose the full amount that had been given to the showjumper.

Nigel Henson, the alliance's director of communications, said the unpublicised funding was "entirely consistent'' with its support for Cawg's aims. He added: "This is yet another disingenuous attempt by the anti-hunting lobby to smear the reputation of the alliance, and we are fed up with it.'' Mr Meade said Cawg had "certainly'' received money from the alliance, but was "not part'' of the alliance. `On the whole, we are separate, particularly now. Initially there was a bit of help,' he said.

Ben Stewart of the International Fund for Animal Welfare said: "This is blatant dirty tricks. You have to wonder just how low this lot will sink.'' In January, the RSPCA won the legal right to make people say why they wanted to join the society after an attempt by Mr Meade to recruit members of hunts.

fields.headline: Cheerfully doing something useless
fields.trailText: A lot of email is junk, and plenty of emails bring the kind of message that nobody would bother to pick up the phone or scribble a postcard to send. But the net has magically transformed the gap year. Anxious parents who would have no idea if their offspring were being mugged in Sao Paolo or being held hostage in the jungles of Borneo can now get a stream of jovial, heartening and deeply relieving news.
fields.body:
A lot of email is junk, and plenty of emails bring the kind of message that nobody would bother to pick up the phone or scribble a postcard to send. But the net has magically transformed the gap year. Anxious parents who would have no idea if their offspring were being mugged in Sao Paolo or being held hostage in the jungles of Borneo can now get a stream of jovial, heartening and deeply relieving news.

My nephew Will has emailed us all this week from China, where he has compiled a list of the Top Five Useless Jobs that the system uses to keep everyone in employment. They are, he says, in reverse order: (5) the six people needed to mow a medium-sized lawn; (4) the women paid to sit at the entrance of filling stations to tempt drivers in by waving at them; (3) the people who stand at pedestrian crossings with a big red flag in a vain attempt to stop cyclists from jumping the lights; (2) the clappers who stand outside clothes shops and clap... in the faint hope that you'll come in; and finally (1) the people in supermarkets who are paid to drop pieces of paper at random, so that other people can be paid to pick them up.

I was slightly reminded of our own privatised rail system, where you can bump into six ticket inspectors at one barrier, checking people who are about to board a train which isn't going anywhere because there is a shortage of crew.

I spent last week in the countryside... in south Berkshire to be precise. It didn't look too bad, though foot and mouth had come close to the place where we stay, and all footpaths were closed. However, the towpath by the canal was open, offering miles of less than strenuous walking, and our favourite pub was more crowded than ever. The car park was full by 12.20 on Sat urday, the place was serving the usual fine food and excellent ale, and everyone seemed perfectly merry.

But the handling of foot and mouth... using a 19th- century technique that is the equivalent of amputating a leg to cure an ingrowing toenail... is just another example of the monumental British incompetence that has transformed our national life. Recently it gave us the great rail disaster, but it also works at a micro level. There is a roundabout at the eastern end of Westminster bridge in London. One side is being pedestrianised, so that it is now perhaps the only roundabout where traffic moves simultaneously clockwise and anti-clockwise, while having to turn right and left in the face of oncoming vehicles. Now there is a permanent traffic jam between Waterloo and Lambeth bridge, meaning that a two-minute journey can take 20. Will anyone change this ludicrous arrangement? Don't be silly.

Here's another example. A few days before the disastrous Lennox Lewis fight in South Africa, he and his entourage gave a press conference. One reporter, Steve Bunce, asked, no doubt sarcastically: "At what point, exactly, did you realise that Johannesburg sits at 7,000 feet above sea level?'' He was blasted by one of Lewis's tip-top training team: "How many cars do you own? How many rooms do you have in your house? How many people do you employ? And you think you somehow have the God-given right to ask a question like that?'' Not Lewis's fault; he's clearly fantastically incompetent, but no more so than everyone else in this benighted land.

The British Flying Saucer Bureau has closed down. It appears that nobody is sighting UFOs any more. No doubt the people who assured us that the government was covering up the evidence have moved on to some other paranormal lunacy. What always amazed me was that these folk... by comparison with whom Flat Earth Society members are rational and scientific... actually thought that intelligent races would make the unimagineable effort to come here and would then abduct an illiterate logger, or mutilate a few cattle. Suppose it was the other way round, and it was we who had found another civilisation light years away.

"Congratulations, Astronaut Figgis, on your safe return from the inhabited Planet Tharrgh, thanks to time-warp relativity transpondence. Tell us, what did you do when you got there?'' "Actually we just trampled a few of their crops, but in really neat patterns. You should have seen their faces next morning! Well, they don't really have faces, but it was a good laugh. Then we come home, like.''

I bought the News of the World the other day and still, to my astonishment, just under the masthead, are printed the simple words: "For Sarah''. It refers to Sarah Payne, the little girl who was murdered last year. This is a newspaper that makes a speciality of destroying people's lives. It stood by as its list of alleged paedophiles caused mob vengeance all round the country, much of it directed against innocent people, and including one paediatrician. It tore apart the family of a woman who had tried to make ends meet by working as a prostitute, on the grounds that she had dared to appear on The Weakest Link. It odiously swindled Sophie Rhys-Jones, blackmailed her into giving an even more damaging interview, then reneged on the deal anyway. In a smaller way it has stomped in its hobnailed boots all over people who may have behaved foolishly or venially, but who not not deserve to see their lives wrecked and the parts strewn all over the nation's living rooms. (All, one might add, under one of the very few female editors in Fleet Street.)

Yet the News of the World still persists in the grotesque pretence that it is published ("For Sarah'', for goodness sake) as a memorial to a little girl who died in terror and agony, and who deserves much, much better. No doubt they will point out that Sarah's parents are in full support, but that doesn't change my point at all.

fields.headline: World Bank 'can't afford' debt write-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, yesterday adopted a tough stance on forgiving the remaining debts of the poorest nations when he warned that the cost could bankrupt his organisation.
fields.body:
James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, yesterday adopted a tough stance on forgiving the remaining debts of the poorest nations when he warned that the cost could bankrupt his organisation.

Drop the Debt, the successor organisation to Jubilee 2000, yesterday urged the bank and the IMF to write off the debts crippling countries in Africa and Latin America.

Mr Wolfensohn said a total write-off for 63 developing countries would cost $29bn. It could not be afforded unless donor nations doubled their contributions. 'I can't forgive the debt unless I have the capital to do it - ultimately it is up to the shareholders.'

Mr Wolfensohn said that, so far, the heavily-indebted poor country initiative had reduced the debts of the poorest countries by 65%, releasing $1.7bn a year for social programmes.

Gordon Brown said he would put the issue of debt sustainability high on the agenda at this weekend's meetings. 'There can be no complacency. We must ensure that this relief provides countries with a lasting and sustainable exit from the burden of debt and releases adequate resources for poverty alleviation.'

The correct title is When The Sky Falls In a jazz review, Delightful Precipice. page 16, April 2, we said that the Vortex jazz club was moving to the new Ocean club in Hackney, east London. The negotiations had, by then, failed and the Vortex is staying in Stoke Newington.

The 40th anniversary tour of Beyond the Fringe (Tobacco money clouds revue tour, page 5, April 25), means that the original tour which brought together Jonathan Miller, Dudley Moore, Peter Cook, and Alan Bennett could not have taken place in 1964, as was stated in the panel which accompanied the piece. fields.headline: Unilever to cut another 8,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Unilever is to cut 8,000 jobs and close about 30 factories to integrate Bestfoods, the American company bought last year.
fields.body:
Unilever is to cut 8,000 jobs and close about 30 factories to integrate Bestfoods, the American company bought last year.

This is in addition to 25,000 job cuts announced last year and will save the Anglo-Dutch consumer products group 395m euros (£237m) in 2001 and 830m euros by 2003.

'With the purchase of Bestfoods last year there is obviously going to be overlap, given the size of the two companies, and shortly after the purchase we said we would be able to make synergies,' a company spokesman said.

Unilever will decide where the jobs will be lost by the third quarter of this year, but posts will go at both Unilever and Bestfoods, the maker of Hellmann's mayonnaise.

The cuts are on top of plans to shed 25,000 employees and 100 factories worldwide over the next four years, in a 'path to growth' strategy. Restructuring and disposals will allow the company to concentrate on 400 leading brands out of the original 1,600.

The news came as Unilever unveiled first quarter results ahead of forecasts, bolstered by such products as Dove Soap, Magnum ice-cream and Close-up toothpaste.

Unilever said a 38% fall in profits to 628m euros was caused by reorganisation costs and increased interest charges. Sales of the top brands rose by 5.4% - meeting targets - and trading had been strong in March. Last year £28bn was spent on acquisitions such as SlimFast and Ben & Jerry's but the company disposed of brands including Oxo and the Elizabeth Arden cosmetics range.

Turnover rose more than 20% to 12.74bn euros including acquisitions, and underlying earnings per share were 4% down, rather than the 18% Unilever predicted last month. The shares rose 19.5p to 527p.

Restructuring and disposals will allow the company to concentrate on 400 leading brands out of the original 1,600. The news came as Unilever unveiled first quarter results ahead of forecasts, bolstered by such products as Dove Soap, Magnum ice-cream and Close-up toothpaste. Unilever said a 38% fall in profits to 628m euros was caused by reorganisation costs and increased interest charges. Sales of the top brands rose by 5.4% - meeting targets - and trading had been strong in March. Last year £28bn was spent on acquisitions such as SlimFast and Ben & Jerry's but the company disposed of brands including Oxo and the Elizabeth Arden cosmetics range. Turnover rose more than 20% to 12.74bn euros including acquisitions, and underlying earnings per share were 4% down, rather than the 18% Unilever predicted last month. The shares rose 19.5p to 527p.

fields.headline: TalkSport changes tune
fields.trailText: By luring younger men to tune in and encouraging older women to switch off, Kelvin MacKenzie's TalkSport radio group narrowed its losses by £1.6m last year.
fields.body:
By luring younger men to tune in and encouraging older women to switch off, Kelvin MacKenzie's TalkSport radio group narrowed its losses by £1.6m last year.

The Wireless Group still reported a £12.3m loss for the year but former Sun editor Mr MacKenzie yesterday said the group was on track to breakeven towards the end of 2002. But, if the cost of investing in digital technology and other one-off items are included, the loss for the financial year widened to £34.2m from £27.5m the year before.

TalkSport, rebranded from Talk Radio last year, now has 2.2m listeners, 76% of which are men - attractive to the advertisers.

'Our listeners used to be 52-year-old women who are hard to sell to, but now it's 36-year-old up-market men,' Mr MacKenzie said.

This attractive customer profile should allow Wireless Group to weather any further deterioration in the economy which might deter advertisers, he added. Revenues rose by 15% last year to £10.6m for the station.

The company is currently in talks with its bankers, Barclays, over the renewal of a £40m loan, which is due to expire next April. Wireless Group is confident that the talks will be successful.

In addition to TalkSport, its flagship station, Wireless Group also owns a number of regional and local radio stations, including Wade 105 FM in Southampton, which it bought last year. The company said that a 'significant' factor contributing to the £12.3m loss was the investment in market and sports rights.

From August, TalkSport will broadcast live commentary to the London area of Chelsea, Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur matches.

The group's turnover rose 95% to £29.4m, while operating costs rose 4%. The shares fell 2.5p to 122.5p yesterday.

fields.headline: BoS and Halifax rush talks
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland and Halifax are racing towards completion of their £27bn merger this weekend, hoping to announce details early next week.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland and Halifax are racing towards completion of their £27bn merger this weekend, hoping to announce details early next week.

The two sides are anxious to seal the deal as quickly as possible to deter a spoiling bid which could leave BoS - for the third time - with a failed attempted merger.

As negotiations continued in the City yesterday, it was understood that the banks were prepared to convene board meetings this weekend, if necessary, to ratify the terms of the merger.

Annual results are due from BoS on Wednesday, which is now thought to be the target date for the 'nil premium' merger.

Discussions yesterday were thought to have led to agreement that Lord Stevenson, chairman of Halifax, would continue that role in the combined group. Peter Burt, BoS chief executive, would be offered the same role for 18 months - to be succeeded by his Halifax counterpart, James Crosby.

Mr Crosby, who initiated the talks, is expected to receive a special role in the interim period. Mr Crosby and Mr Burt were locked in talks in London yesterday to work out a three-year integration plan to save £300m a year.

The thorny issue of head office location is expected to be resolved in favour of Edinburgh. However, Halifax's base in the Yorkshire town will retain an important role; retail operations, in particular, are to be based there.

It is not yet clear what the combined entity will call itself, but it may use an acronym derived from the names of both banks. The individual names will be kept on the high street.

Job cuts for the combined workforce of 57,000 are expected to be kept to a minimum with careful steps taken to ensure the axe does not fall too unevenly on Halifax or Edinburgh, which both employ some 4,000 staff.

fields.headline: Vandevelde gives in gracelessly
fields.standfirst: Chief's smugness is misplaced
fields.trailText: Ed Warner, our regular City columnist, reckons it is a cyclical thing: institutional investors, fretting about their shrinking portfolios during a bear market, turn shareholder activists, and along the way force Marks & Spencer chairman Luc Vandevelde to drop his repugnant non-profit related bonus; smugness all round.
fields.body:
Ed Warner, our regular City columnist, reckons it is a cyclical thing: institutional investors, fretting about their shrinking portfolios during a bear market, turn shareholder activists, and along the way force Marks & Spencer chairman Luc Vandevelde to drop his repugnant non-profit related bonus; smugness all round.

This is no doubt true. Setting aside the odd extravagant lunch or tickets to Cheltenham perhaps, the massed ranks of City fund managers are (and always will be) primarily motivated by stock performance. But on a narrow, short-term view an intellectual gap between the owners of certain household corporate names and the managers paid to run these businesses has become all too visible. There is a dangerous mis-match between expectation and action.

We had the BT example on Thursday, with Sir Iain Vallance being given the long, luxurious kiss-off, complete with his car and driver in London, another car in Scotland, a terminal bonus and a final 14-month consultancy gig with a fancy title. Think how much the man might have got if he had exhibited some real competence in his job.

Now we have Mr Vandevelde who, six weeks after it emerged in these pages that he was in line for a bonus of more than £700,000 simply for meeting unspecified 'strategic targets' (which clearly didn't include raising profitability or sales), has finally decided to waive his entitlement. And, 'to underline his confidence in the future prospects of the company', our super-responsive M&S chairman has reduced his notice period entitlement from 12 to nine months.

Thanks Luc. What yesterday's statement failed to mention was that Mr Vandevelde only had his attack of conscience after the company's broker, Cazenove, presented him with the results of an institutional straw poll, and the Association of British Insurers demanded a full dress meeting to discuss how the chairman's intransigence had provoked civil unrest among M&S's senior management. In short, he was given no option but to respond to the clamour and it is extraordinary that it took six weeks for him to realise as much.

What is more, half Mr Vandevelde's bonus is not in fact being waived. It is simply being deferred and will be handed over in the form of free shares in 12 months' time, regardless of the commercial performance of the businesses between now and then.

It is too little, too late. The job spec has already changed. Suspect affair It is about time the Department of Trade and Industry took a look at events surrounding the sorry collapse of EuroTelecom.

The fibre-optic specialist raised £17m through an AIM flotation and despite investors receiving assurances that it was not a cash-burn business it went bust, running out of money in just 11 months.

Since PriceWaterhouseCoopers were called in as administrators in February, the flow of information on the suspect way in which this South Yorkshire firm was run has become alarming. Numerous allegations have been made, but it still remains unclear quite how EuroTelecom managed to rattle through so much money so quickly.

An internal report from accountants BDO Stoy Hayward has revealed a series of payments made to companies related to directors, and also unusual bonuses paid to directors - although those involved claimed they were cleared by the board as a whole.

The report also claims that EuroTelecom, advised by stockbroker Beeson Gregory, came to the stock market owing the inland revenue £280,000 in unpaid PAYE and national insurance. The debt was paid almost as soon as the new money had been raised.

One former non-executive director, no doubt embarrassed by the whole affair which raises questions about the responsibility of directors, has commissioned corporate sleuths to investigate the collapse.

The completed report is known to contain a litany of further allegations.

Curious share dealings by persons close to the company, a lack of full disclosure in the flotation prospectus and suggestions of undeclared links between executive directors and firms that EuroTelecom was doing business with, are among a number of items known to be included in the dossier. On Thursday, the company's chief executive followed the example of his close friend, the former finance director, by quitting the board even though both insist they have done nothing wrong.

Shareholders in the company have conceded that they are very unlikely to see any of their money again. The FSA has interviewed the key players in the affair but the watchdog's powers remain limited until the autumn, when the new regulatory regime comes on stream. But investors should not have to wait to be told exactly where their cash went.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Bland backs BT with own £1m
fields.body:
Bland backs BT with own £1m

Sir Christopher Bland, the incoming chairman of BT, plans to invest £1m of his own money in the company's shares, BT said.

The timing of the purchase was undecided, and could not take place before BT's results scheduled for May 17.

BT shares were down 2.7% at 535p.

Corus adamant on closure

Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group sacking 6,000 British workers, expects steel prices to show some recovery in the second half of this year, chairman Sir Brian Moffat told the company's annual meeting. But he brushed aside pleas by Eddie Lynch, national organiser for the ISTC steel union, for a rethink of plans to end steel-making at Llanwern.

Bayer turns cautious

German chemical and pharmaceutical group Bayer yesterday posted worse than expected first-quarter results and delivered a cautious outlook. Bayer said first-quarter operating profit on continuing operations before exceptionals fell 6.9% to 936m euros (£581m), just below a consensus forecast.

Alcatel seek Lucent unit

French communications company Alcatel has offered $5bn (£3.5bn) to buy Lucent's fibre optic unit after talks for a complete merger with its US rival recently fell through, industry sources said.

They said the parties had been in talks that could have led to a merger of equals, with the initiative taken by Alcatel which wants to break into the carrier market.

Downturn for Telemetrix

Telemetrix , the computer-related hardware company, lost more than a quarter of its value yesterday after it warned of a lower operating profit this year. Chairman Colin Gaskell said a pronounced slowdown in activity in the semiconductor industry would hurt sales and earnings of specialist semiconductor manufacturing unit Zetex for longer than first anticipated.

BAE Systems in joint venture

BAE Systems yesterday safeguarded hundreds of UK jobs by confirming it is folding its missile-making business into an expanded European joint venture. Existing partners BAE and Matra Aérospatiale of France, parent of the EADS group, will join forces with Italy's Finmeccanica to create the world's second largest missile-maker. The new missile group, to be called MBDA, will have sales of more than 2bn euros (£1.26bn) and six years of orders, worth 13bn euros. MBDA will involve BAE's subsidiary Matra BAE Dynamics, which employs about 3,500 people at Stevenage, Bristol and Bolton.

fields.headline: MP in brewery rescue bid
fields.trailText: A rescue plan is under way to save the 151-year-old Mansfield Brewery, which Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries intends to shut by the end of this year.
fields.body:
A rescue plan is under way to save the 151-year-old Mansfield Brewery, which Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries intends to shut by the end of this year.

Local Labour MP Alan Meale has teamed up with former managing director Ron Kirk to work on a bid for the brewery and about 150 pubs, which together are likely to be worth at least £40m.

Mr Meale says the bid has backing from heavyweight institutional investors. He has been working on the plan since the end of last year and has presented his proposal to Wolves' financial adviser NM Rothschild.

'The finances are in place. This is a real bid - it's not back-of-a-matchbox stuff,' Mr Meale said. The buyout team has been to see Pubmaster and leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare, who are mounting takeover bids for Wolves & Dudley.

Brands could be a sticking point - Wolves is keen to keep the rights to Mansfield Bitter. Mr Kirk, who ran the brewery in the early 1990s, is a Midlands leisure entrepreneur whose interests have included Harry Ramsden restaurant franchises and Alldays convenience stores. Richard Meadows, a former Mansfield brewing director, is also involved.

Wolves & Dudley bought the Mansfield Brewery for £250m in December 1999, with an estate of 520 pubs. At the time, it had 1,000 staff and was turning out 750,000 barrels a year.

Wolves pledged to keep the site open for at least two years. This week, the company confirmed it intended to close the brewery and move beer production to its sites in Wolverhampton and Burton-on-Trent.

Mr Meale attacked Wolves' deputy chairman David Thompson over the decision: 'I'm angry and disappointed. He's persistently and consistently changed his mind and direction.'

webTitle: Matalan dives as front man walks out

fields.headline: Matalan dives as front man walks out
fields.standfirst: Store success sours 'Go now' founder tells chief executive who asked to retire in 3 years
fields.trailText: Store success sours 'Go now' founder tells chief executive who asked to retire in 3 years.
fields.body:
Multi-millionaire Angus Monro, the front man for the trail-blazing Matalan discount fashion chain, yesterday walked out on the company he helped to build into a multi-billion pound empire and one of the City's favourite stocks.

Shares in the company tumbled more than 14%, wiping £500m off the value of Matalan, as details of the chief executive's unexpected departure emerged.

Mr Monro, whose 0.5% stake in the company is worth more than £10m, quit after telling the store chain's billionaire founder, John Hargreaves, that he wanted to retire in two or three years - just when the company plans to expand into Europe.

For the workaholic Mr Hargreaves, a former market trader who oversees the buying operation at Matalan, a two-year commitment was no commitment at all - and he told his colleague of 10 years that he should leave straight away.

Mr Hargreaves, who is taking on the chief executive's role as well as his chairman's job until a replacement is found, paid tribute to Mr Monro's 'outstanding contribution,' but added: 'It is more appropriate that he leaves at this time.'

Mr Monro was credited with being the professional retailing brains behind Matalan, which symbolises the label crazy, cost conscious revolution that fashion retailing has undergone in the past 10 years.

Last night analysts were bemused. One said: 'The party line is that he was leaving anyway and they wanted one person for a longer-term strategy, but it seems odd that he should want to leave.

'It is not as if he had done all he could. Matalan is an immature company with a lot of growth ahead it. There are some politics in this somewhere.' Another said: 'He was a key figure in the development of Matalan. His departure will leave the boardroom looking really light.'

Immediately there were suggestions that all may not be well within the business. Traders speculated about black holes and fiery boardroom rows, which the company quickly moved to deny.

'There are no black holes and there have been no rows', said a spokeswoman. 'John and Angus have not fallen out.' She suggested Mr Munro might want to spend more time with his young family. 'He has worked hard and wants to do the sort of thing families like to do.'

That does not sound like the Angus Monro of only a few days ago. At the opening of the group's largest store to date - 55,000 sq feet in Killingworth, outside Newcastle upon Tyne.

He told the Guardian 'work is my hobby' and described weekends spent trailing around Matalan stores with his wife. The magazine Management Today asked him to write about his favourite book, and it was left to his secretary to explain that he didn't read any.

Matalan is the chain that sells shirts for a fiver and top brands at half high street prices and has become such a thorn in the side of established chains like Marks & Spencer and Littlewoods.

It was the brainchild of the Liverpudlian Mr Hargreaves, who came up with the idea after a trip to America. The first opened in Preston in 1985 and Killingworth is the 130th. Over the past decade it has piled up sales and profits at an almost incredible rate and it has made Mr Hargreaves a very seriously rich man - 12th richest in Britain, according to the latest Sunday Times Rich List, with a fortune of more than £1.3bn.

Good team

The founder is an intensely private man and the public face of the group has always been Mr Monro, a smooth talking Geordie career retailer, who has spent almost his entire working life in womenswear.

On Wednesday, at the Killingworth opening, Mr Monro said they were a good team: 'I came on board to add professional retail management. We are close, mates even. John does the product and I manage all other aspects of the business.'

All expense is spared at Matalan. Behind the shiny new frontage at Killingworth, previously a Morrisons supermarket, the dingy old offices remain. There are no window displays and no mannequins.

'Mannequins cost money,' said Mr Monro. 'Then you have to pay someone to change them.'

The group's head offices are in Skelmersdale, a world away from the London W1 head offices of rivals such as Arcadia and Marks & Spencer.

'It's cheap', said Mr Monro. 'It's a good place to have an office.' It helps Matalan keep its costs razor sharp. Central costs were 25%, compared to 40% at Arcadia, he said.

He lives in Prestbury, the epicentre of the Cheshire set, 'a good place to live and to educate your kids'.

He built a lean organisation and said on Wednesday: 'We have no projects, no working parties and no committees. And we have no politics. People know if they are succeeding or failing.'

He banned internal emails, regarding them as insidious. 'People have got to talk to each other.' It has been said that he was a tad aggressive behind closed doors. 'You don't build a business by being nice. You've got to be hard,' he said, then added: 'Well, hard but fair.'

The stores are utilitarian, with the clothes laid out on endless rails and racks. In the Killingworth store there is a fixture 20 metres long and six metres wide which displays only men's polo shirts. There is a full 50 metres of women's cotton tops.

It is an approach which City analysts and other assorted retail experts believe is killing Marks & Spencer and is one of the main drivers of M&S's new 'lifestyle' approach, which groups co-ordinating clothes alongside each other.

'Pah!' said Monro. 'People know what they want. They know if they want a skirt or a jumper. And if they want a skirt they prefer to see them all in one place.'

He was constantly fingering the merchandise, selling the benefits of each item in a style not unlike that employed by Del Boy Trotter. 'Look at this embroidery - feel the quality of this - if this was in black [a £40 blue lounge suit] you'd think it was Armani.'

The patter was endless and indicative of his enthusiasm for the store he is now putting behind him: 'Look at this [an £8 cotton nightie with a teddy bear motif], if I were a woman I'd wear it - this is really very good [a £20 garden chair], it's made from hardwood from sustainable forests.'

Matalan buys grey-market branded products and also produces its own brand goods, under a series of labels such as Copperstone, Armando, US Athletic and Isabelle. The stock is sold through every eight weeks, so customers, who are called members because they pay £1 for a lifetime's privilege of shopping there and who average five or six visits a year, always find new product.

There are 6m Matalan members in Britain about one in seven of the shopping population, and Mr Monro said there were plans to open up to 240 British stores.

Mr Monro is a one-off, and a very rich one. Born in Gateshead in 1949, he joined Marks & Spencer as a graduate trainee and spent 13 years with the Baker Street brigade before quitting 'in search of a more results-driven culture', as his Matalan-issued resumÀe put it. He joined Ralph Halpern's Burton group, working first for Dorothy Perkins and then for Debenhams.

A spell at Kingfisher followed and in 1992 he joined Matalan as a non-executive director. Four years later he became chief executive to steer the company to its 1998 flotation.

Awesome growth

The Matalan chain has been an astonishing success with awesome sales growth in recent years - and the shares were seemingly rocket-fuelled until this year when City analysts interpreted news of a minor drama as a full-on crisis.

In its post-Christmas trading statement the company which could do no wrong admitted a couple of November store openings were delayed, planned marketing campaigns were pulled for fear of running short of stock and margins had suffered. Like-for-like sales were up a huge 16.3%, but that was down on the 22% recorded the previous year and the shares plunged by 33% in one day, wiping £1bn off the value of the company.

Shares in the company tumbled more than 14%, wiping £500m off the value of Matalan, as details of the chief executive's unexpected departure emerged. Mr Monro, whose 0.5% stake in the company is worth more than £10m, quit after telling the store chain's billionaire founder, John Hargreaves, that he wanted to retire in two or three years - just when the company plans to expand into Europe. For the workaholic Mr Hargreaves, a former market trader who oversees the buying operation at Matalan, a two-year commitment was no commitment at all - and he told his colleague of 10 years that he should leave straight away. Mr Hargreaves, who is taking on the chief executive's role as well as his chairman's job until a replacement is found, paid tribute to Mr Monro's 'outstanding contribution,' but added: 'It is more appropriate that he leaves at this time.' Mr Monro was credited with being the professional retailing brains behind Matalan, which symbolises the label crazy, cost conscious revolution that fashion retailing has undergone in the past 10 years. Last night analysts were bemused. One said: 'The party line is that he was leaving anyway and they wanted one person for a longer-term strategy, but it seems odd that he should want to leave. 'It is not as if he had done all he could. Matalan is an immature company with a lot of growth ahead it. There are some politics in this somewhere.' Another said: 'He was a key figure in the development of Matalan. His departure will leave the boardroom looking really light.' Immediately there were suggestions that all may not be well within the business. Traders speculated about black holes and fiery boardroom rows, which the company quickly moved to deny. 'There are no black holes and there have been no rows', said a spokeswoman. 'John and Angus have not fallen out.' She suggested Mr Munro might want to spend more time with his young family. 'He has worked hard and wants to do the sort of thing families like to do.' That does not sound like the Angus Monro of only a few days ago. At the opening of the group's largest store to date - 55,000 sq feet in Killingworth, outside Newcastle upon Tyne. Matalan is the chain that sells shirts for a fiver and top brands at half high street prices and has become such a thorn in the side of established chains like Marks & Spencer and Littlewoods. 'Pah!' said Monro. 'People know what they want. They know if they want a skirt or a jumper. And if they want a skirt they prefer to see them all in one place.' He was constantly fingering the merchandise, selling the benefits of each item in a style not unlike that employed by Del Boy Trotter. 'Look at this embroidery - feel the quality of this - if this was in black [a £40 blue lounge suit] you'd think it was Armani.' The patter was endless and indicative of his enthusiasm for the store he is now putting behind him: 'Look at this [an £8 cotton nightie with a teddy bear motif], if I were a woman I'd wear it - this is really very good [a £20 garden chair], it's made from hardwood from sustainable forests.' Matalan buys grey-market branded products and also produces its own brand goods, under a series of labels such as Copperstone, Armando, US Athletic and Isabelle. The stock is sold through every eight weeks, so customers, who are called members because they pay £1 for a lifetime's privilege of shopping there and who average five or six visits a year, always find new product. There are 6m Matalan members in Britain about one in seven of the shopping population, and Mr Monro said there were plans to open up to 240 British stores. Mr Monro is a one-off, and a very rich one. Born in Gateshead in 1949, he joined Marks & Spencer as a graduate trainee and spent 13 years with the Baker Street brigade before quitting 'in search of a more results-driven culture', as his Matalan-issued resumÀe put it. He joined Ralph Halpern's Burton group, working first for Dorothy Perkins and then for Debenhams. A spell at Kingfisher followed and in 1992 he joined Matalan as a non-executive director. Four years later he became chief executive to steer the company to its 1998 flotation. fields.headline: Marks & Spencer chief waives £816,000 bonus
fields.trailText: Luc Vandevelde, chairman of troubled Marks & Spencer, yesterday caved in to pressure and waived his entitlement to an £816,000 bonus payout.
fields.body:
Luc Vandevelde, chairman of troubled Marks & Spencer, yesterday caved in to pressure and waived his entitlement to an £816,000 bonus payout.

Mr Vandevelde has been under attack from unions and shareholders since it emerged last month that he was still in line for the bonus - despite the continuing plunge in M&S sales and profits.

The payout is also known to have been causing serious dissent at the highest executive levels within the store group, as all other staff and directors' bonuses have been scrapped.

A spokeswoman for Marks & Spencer insisted it had been Mr Vandevelde's decision to waive the bonus, which the GMB union had described as 'obscene' and 'a slap in the face to British workers'.

She said the chairman had asked for a meeting of the company's remuneration committee, which ratifies directors' pay packages, to be brought forward to put an end to the mounting controversy. They met on Thursday and hammered out a new deal.

Dame Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5 who is a non-executive director of M&S and chairman of the remuneration committee, described Mr Vandevelde's move as 'a very significant gesture'. She said the chairman had no obligation to give up his bonus and that his decision to do so had demonstrated 'real leadership'.

Under the old pay deal Mr Vandevelde was in line for a £704,000 bonus, half in shares and half in cash, payable next month. He was then in line for a futher £112,000 in five years. The payout was for meeting 'strategic and qualitative' targets which Mr Vandevelde helped frame when he joined the company last year and which have never been made public.

He is also paid an annual salary of £650,000, was given a £2.2m golden hello payment when he joined the company and has a £10m share option package.

Under the new deal he will receive £352,000 in shares next May. A further £352,000 will be paid at the same time, so long as certain financial targets are met. Those targets have not yet been set. Mr Vandevelde will forfeit the £112,000 due in five years' time, but the rest of his multi-million package is unaffected, although he is also reducing his notice period from 12 months to nine.

Shareholders and unions had become incensed by the payout as Mr Vandevelde's first year at the helm has been judged a failure. Sales are still plunging, new store layouts have backfired and the company has been accused of mishandling the decision to close down its European operations.

M&S said: 'Luc is aware of his leadership role. He wanted to show his colleagues that he is confident in the future of the company and he didn't want to be the only one to get a bonus this year.'

However, he is certain to have been persuaded by mounting pressure from shareholders.

Quiz?
Could you be a chairman?

fields.headline: Daring escape of the Karmapa
fields.standfirst: Sixteen months after he arrived in Nepal, the Buddhist leader, 15, breaks his silence on the night he fled China in a jeep
fields.trailText: Sixteen months after he arrived in Nepal, the Buddhist leader, 15, breaks his silence on the night he fled China in a jeep.
fields.body:
The 15-year-old Karmapa, one of Tibetan Buddhism's most senior leaders, yesterday gave the first account of his dramatic escape from China across the Himalayas, and revealed that he fled his monastery by jumping off the roof into a waiting jeep because he was refused permission to go abroad.

The Karmapa said Chinese officials had `persistently and repeatedly' turned down his requests to travel to India, where several of his teachers live in exile. After a year's consideration, he decided to leave.

Under cover of darkness he drove out of the monastery with a handful of followers and slipped across the border into Nepal three days later.

The escape, almost 16 months ago, was a massive embarrassment for the Chinese government, which had recognised the Karmapa in an attempt to woo support away from the exiled Dalai Lama. After learning of his flight, Chinese officials claimed the teenager had gone to India merely to collect a sacred black hat and musical instruments belonging to his order , hinting that he would be back soon.

The Karmapa yesterday dismissed the claim as absurd. `Why would I want to bring the hat back from India? All that would accomplish would be to place the hat on Jiang Zemin's head.'

The Chinese had groomed him in an attempt to consolidate their rule in Tibet, he admitted. `I came to suspect that there might have been a plan to use me to separate the people within Tibet from His Holiness the Dalai Lama,' he said he had been given `very special treatment' by the communist regime, and had even been whisked to Beijing to meet the Chinese leader.

The Karmapa is the head of Tibetan Buddhism's influential and wealthy Kagyu sect, which dates back to the 12th century. Uniquely, both the Dalai Lama and the Chinese authorities recognised him at the age of seven as a reincarnate lama. As the 17th Karmapa, Urgyen Trinley Dorje is now the third most important spiritual leader in Tibetan Buddhism. Only the Dalai Lama and the Panchen Lama are more senior.

The Panchen Lama has not been seen since the age of six , when he was arrested by Chinese officials. The Chinese have replaced him with their own Panchen Lama.

Since his escape, the Karmapa has been a virtual prisoner in Gyuto monastery near Dharamsala, the hill station in northern India where the Dalai Lama has his residence. The Karmapa yesterday said he now wanted to travel outside India. He had no plans to return to Tibet, unless the Dalai Lama was allowed to accompany him. `I will only go back with His Holiness,' he declared.

He said the decision to leave Tsurphu monastery, 30 miles from Lhasa, was entirely his own.

At 10.30pm on the night of the escape, December 28, 1999, he slowly climbed down from his room and jumped on to the roof of a nearby shrine room. He then leapt to the ground where a jeep was waiting, together with another lama and a driver.

`Driving day and night, we stopped only to change drivers. By taking back roads through the hills and valleys, we avoided check posts and two army camps,' the Karmapa said. The party - which included the Karmapa's 25-year-old sister - arrived undetected in Mustang, Nepal. They then trekked across dangerously crumbling paths in freezing conditions.

The Karmapa finally arrived in Dharamsala eight days later, having travelled the rest of the journey by horse, helicopter, train and rented car. He then went straight to the Dalai Lama, who had made a similar escape across the snow-bound Himalayas in 1959 following China's invasion of Tibet. `He received me with his great love and affection. My joy knew no bounds,' he said.

The Karmapa, speaking from Gyuto monastery, seated on a throne in front of a giant Buddha statue, yesterday denied that the Chinese had colluded in his escape. He has been accused by at least one dissident regent within his sect of being a Chinese stooge. He also faces competition from a rival Karmapa, who maintains he is the true reincarnation of the 16th Karmapa who died in 1981.

`The identity of the Karmapa is not decided by popular vote or by a debate between groups. He is decided by the prediction of the previous Karmapa,' he declared, as the monastery at the foothill of the Himalayas resounded with thunder.

He said he now intends to devote himself to the study and practice of Buddhism.

fields.headline: Vanished Briton leaves family baffled
fields.standfirst: Relatives continue search for tourist who disappeared at Australian world heritage site five weeks ago after pausing for a smoke
fields.trailText: Relatives continue search for tourist who disappeared at Australian world heritage site five weeks ago after pausing for a smoke.
fields.byline: Audrey Gillan and Patrick Barkham in Sydney
fields.body:
The clock radio clicks on in the morning and at night in David Eason's house in Battersea, London. The lights are set on a regular timer too. Everything is neat and ordered - just as the 46-year-old left it before he set off for a four week adventure in Australia.

The advertising executive flew in to Melbourne where he visited friends, then travelled up to Sydney where, after a few days, he joined a group heading out on a 14 day, 1,700 mile trip up the east coast to the Great Barrier Reef and on to Cairns.

Four days later, Mr Eason disappeared. Nothing has been seen of him since. Five weeks on, his family are desperately awaiting news. On the morning of March 28, Mr Eason boarded a four-wheel drive minibus with a group of international travellers and headed for Fraser Island, the largest sand island in the world, a world heritage site where dingoes roam along white beaches.

The group spent the morning making their way across the island. At 1pm they were dropped off at the vast white surfing beach at One Tree Rocks where they had the choice of walking up a clearly marked track to nearby Lake Wabby or staying on the bus. Mr Eason and four others chose to walk, agreeing to rendezvous at the car park at 3pm.

A smoker on a non-smoking bus, Mr Eason took the opportunity to smoke when he disembarked. He sat on the beach and told his fellow travellers that he would catch them up. Police are convinced he has not left the island, but there have been no sightings. Two helicopter searches, one with heat seeking infra-red equipment, have found nothing. Quentin Davidson, the tour leader, said: `It's just strange, nobody knows. There were no signs that anything like this was going to happen.'

The weather that day was changeable and, according to Mr Davidson, the sea was terrible. "It wasn't a day when you would've taken all your clothes off and gone frolicking in the surf, but he [Mr Eason] wanted a bit of peaceful space."

The beach is regarded as treacherous and there are signs warning people not to swim due to undertows and sharks. Mr Eason, a good sailor who had a healthy respect for the sea and a great fear of sharks, is unlikely to have gone swimming.

Activities

Mr Eason, creative director of VB Communications in Beaconsfield, Buckinghamshire, gave no indication to his fellow tourists that he would up and leave. Mr Davidson said: "David said he was a part owner of an agency that specialised in doing campaigns for the health industry. He said he was looking for a change of direction in his life. He wanted time out.

"He was a person very well at ease with his own company but when he wanted to be involved in a conversation he would. He was very much looking forward to the activities that were coming up on the second week."

After looking for Mr Eason, Mr Davidson alerted police and local rangers but because it was dark, no proper search got under way until daybreak. By then, Mr Eason's family in Bromley, south-east London, had been told of his disappearance.

Less than two days later, his sister Janice was in nearby Hervey Bay persuading police that her brother was not the type of man to go 'walkabout', asking why he would have booked an escorted tour if he wanted to roam around on his own and why would he leave his passport and tickets in the hotel?

Afterwards, she travelled to Fraser Island where she joined a search and when that was called off, kept searching on her own. Now back in Bromley, Ms Eason is distraught and dumbfounded at her elder brother's disappearance.

She said: "I kept going over the area where he had been - looking for clues. The trail David was supposed to take, it's a gentle walk. There's nothing difficult about it. I walked the trails and it's just baffling to try and work out what happened. Personally I don't think it was an option that he got lost.

"Initially they thought he would have gone into the ocean but there's no trace of his backpack. The police have assured me that if he had gone into the sea there would have been a trace of that by now.

"We don't think he ever reached the lake. Why can no one find him? Personally, I am not convinced they have actually searched the area enough."

Police told the family they are certain Mr Eason is still on the island. The tour guide recalls that police said if he was alive and wanted to be found they would have found him by now. He remembers another strange disappearance. "Further up the coast there is a little place called Flaggy Rock. A couple of years ago a guy disappeared from a campsite there, with a car and a tent, and they never saw another thing of him nor did they find anything he was wearing."

Sinister

Ms Eason, her brother Peter and husband Mike Eames are angry that there is no continuing search. There will be a further search on May 5, but only as part of previously planned state-emergency exercise.

The two men believe they are "looking at a more sinister scenario." They feel Mr Eason may have been the victim of a robbery, that he may be lying buried in the sand. Every possible scenario has gone through their minds, including being swallowed up by a sand dune, or being the victim of a hit and run by the four wheel drive vehicles that roar up the beach.

Ms Eason said: "We have had to face the prospect that David may well not have survived what's happened. At the same time we are not going to be able to come to terms with that unless we know what's happened."

Her brother Peter, who will head out to Australia tomorrow to search for his brother, says: "Our ultimate goal is having the search resumed. We are looking for some intervention from the British government. The police there will do no more unless they are instructed to by a higher authority. We don't feel as if the Foreign Office is doing enough."

Last night a Foreign Office spokesman said: "Both the consular general in Brisbane and our consular staff in London have done everything possible to help resolve this situation. We have liaised directly with those in charge of the Australian investigation.

"We have kept the family informed at every stage. We have also initiated contact with various other government departments including Interpol and the UK police. We are determined to resolve this matter and have not given up."

He was very much looking forward to the activities that were coming up on the second week." After looking for Mr Eason, Mr Davidson alerted police and local rangers but because it was dark, no proper search got under way until daybreak. By then, Mr Eason's family in Bromley, south-east London, had been told of his disappearance. Less than two days later, his sister Janice was in nearby Hervey Bay persuading police that her brother was not the type of man to go 'walkabout', asking why he would have booked an escorted tour if he wanted to roam around on his own and why would he leave his passport and tickets in the hotel? Afterwards, she travelled to Fraser Island where she joined a search and when that was called off, kept searching on her own. Now back in Bromley, Ms Eason is distraught and dumbfounded at her elder brother's disappearance. She said: "I kept going over the area where he had been - looking for clues. The trail David was supposed to take, it's a gentle walk. There's nothing difficult about it. I walked the trails and it's just baffling to try and work out what happened. Personally I don't think it was an option that he got lost. "Initially they thought he would have gone into the ocean but there's no trace of his backpack. The police have assured me that if he had gone into the sea there would have been a trace of that by now. "We don't think he ever reached the lake. Why can no one find him? Personally, I am not convinced they have actually searched the area enough." Police told the family they are certain Mr Eason is still on the island. The tour guide recalls that police said if he was alive and wanted to be found they would have found him by now. He remembers another strange disappearance. "Further up the coast there is a little place called Flaggy Rock. A couple of years ago a guy disappeared from a campsite there, with a car and a tent, and they never saw another thing of him nor did they find anything he was wearing." Sinister Ms Eason, her brother Peter and husband Mike Eames are angry that there is no continuing search. There will be a further search on May 5, but only as part of previously planned state-emergency exercise. The two men believe they are "looking at a more sinister scenario." They feel Mr Eason may have been the victim of a robbery, that he may be lying buried in the sand. Every possible scenario has gone through their minds, including being swallowed up by a sand dune, or being the victim of a hit and run by the four wheel drive vehicles that roar up the beach. Ms Eason said: "We have had to face the prospect that David may well not have survived what's happened. At the same time we are not going to be able to come to terms with that unless we know what's happened." Her brother Peter, who will head out to Australia tomorrow to search for his brother, says: "Our ultimate goal is having the search resumed. We are looking for some intervention from the British government. The police there will do no more unless they are instructed to by a higher authority. We don't feel as if the Foreign Office is doing enough." Last night a Foreign Office spokesman said: "Both the consular general in Brisbane and our consular staff in London have done everything possible to help resolve this situation. We have liaised directly with those in charge of the Australian investigation. "We have kept the family informed at every stage. We have also initiated contact with various other government departments including Interpol and the UK police. We are determined to resolve this matter and have not given up."

webTitle: TV jester crashes the election party

fields.headline: TV jester crashes the election party
fields.trailText: Gabriele Paolini bounds down a sunlit Via Barberini with a grin, a mobile phone, and three bags containing his ticket to stardom. He has the same flowing hair, dark suit and spectacles as at our last meeting 11 months ago.
fields.body:
Gabriele Paolini bounds down a sunlit Via Barberini with a grin, a mobile phone, and three bags containing his ticket to stardom. He has the same flowing hair, dark suit and spectacles as at our last meeting 11 months ago.

"Can't dawdle, I've got a show tonight. A television show." His life's ambition to get on TV realised... he is to be a chat-show guest on a cable channel... he says, "I'm going to auction myself." From the bags he fishes little containers. The contents, "Faeces, hair, skin, urine and semen." All his.

"It'll be live. The first such auction in the history of Italy," he says, raising a trouser leg to show a shorn shin. "I've also shaved my arms." And other bits.

He adjusts a necklace of coloured condoms. "My schedule is very hectic, what with the election." Paolini, 26, is eccentric and slightly famous; he lives in a Rome suburb with his mother and his father, a retired army general, and plots to become very famous.

For the past seven years he has been a full-time media gatecrasher, appearing wherever cameras roll: Nato bases, strikes, Mafia trials, papal audiences, political crises.

He positions himself behind reporters filing their stories and stares into the camera. Italy stares back.

The Condom Prophet, as he prefers to be called, makes it on-screen several times a week. Journalists hate, insult, and sometimes beat him. That suits him fine, as long as they do it on air.

What started as an Aids-awareness stunt... he slipped a condom to Mother Theresa and, allegedly, to the Pope... mutated into self-promotion.

He enjoys some success: a book, fan clubs, acolytes who join his ambushes. At the midnight auction he dominated other guests, selling a sachet of his hair for £4.80 to two male viewers.

Now Italy's general election campaign is offering endless events for Paolini to exploit.

In any society he would stand out, but especially so in Rome. Codes for appearance and behaviour are slavishly followed here. Individualism invites mockery.

Few people break ranks as spectacularly as Paolini. Yet he mostly gets away with it. Strolling through town he is greeted as a celebrity.

For this he can thank television. For decades, dancers, models and actors made it in Italy thanks to chat shows.

But for sheer bludgeoning frequency not even the Condom Prophet can match the performance of the opposition leader, Silvio Berlusconi.

A recent survey showed that Mr Berlusconi received 11 times more coverage on three private networks than the coalition government's candidate for prime minister, Francesco Rutelli.

Mr Berlusconi has no need to gatecrash since he is ahead in the polls and owns the networks: a different method of ensuring air-time. But in this election it gives him one thing in common with Paolini... television looks likely to make winners of them both.

fields.headline: Slave warning for chocolate firms
fields.trailText: Britain's sweet manufacturers may face `fair trade' labelling laws unless they set up a foolproof scheme to ensure that their cocoa is not farmed by child labour.
fields.body:
Britain's sweet manufacturers may face `fair trade' labelling laws unless they set up a foolproof scheme to ensure that their cocoa is not farmed by child labour.

Sources at the ministry of trade and industry have said they are prepared to require the manufacturers to certify that their products have been produced fairly, unless they provide clear signs that they are cleaning up their practices.

The Foreign Office minister Brian Wilson is to meet British chocolate manufacturers next Friday, after reports that as many as 15,000 slave children along the Ivory Coast, west Africa, are working for cocoa producers.

He told the Guardian yesterday: `I am not greatly impressed with their claims that they only became aware that this was happening six months ago.

'Cadburys a century ago freed the slaves from cocoa plantations. If it could be done for slaves a century ago, it can be done for child labour today. It is quite possible for these issues to be investigated and the abuses removed.'

The industry does not rule out labelling, but prefers to minimise the risk of abuse by spreading cooperative production along the Ivory Coast.

The Biscuit, Cake, Chocolate and Confectionery Alliance said: `What we urgently need to do is establish commercial relationships with cooperatives so that contract terms can stamp out abuses.

'At present there are 1m farms with one or two hectares each, selling to travelling dealers who then sell it on in turn. It is difficult to monitor such an uncontrolled structure.'

But Mr Wilson said the companies could also face consumer boycotts if they did not act. `The companies will be extremely sensitive to the views of consumers,' he said.

`We will act in partnership with the companies, but Britain is a signatory to ILO conventions on child labour and we have act to implement those conventions. I am not going to let this story go away.'

The UK chocolate market was worth £3.7bn in 1998, with the average person spending £1.20 a week. The Ivory Coast produces 42% of the world crop and nearly 15% of British cocoa imports. Of British manufacturers, Mars would be most vulnerable to a boycott, since it buys 75% of its cocoa from the Ivory Coast.

Many supermarkets already stock fair trade chocolate lines, alongside other chocolates.

webTitle: Singapore takes slow step towards democracy

fields.headline: One small step for Singapore
fields.trailText: Singapore's slow transition to genuine democracy will take a step forward today with the first legal political rally by a non-party organisation.
fields.body:
Singapore's slow transition to genuine democracy will take a step forward today with the first legal political rally by a non-party organisation.

Its organiser, James Gomez, hopes several thousand people will turn up to support Joshua 'JBJ' Jeyaretnam, one of the island's three opposition MPs, who is fighting to overturn a defamation conviction that will leave him bankrupt and banned from politics.

But he says that even if only a handful show up it will still be a success.

The authorities were completely flummoxed by the fact that Mr Gomez's organisation, the Think Centre, followed the strict rules in its application to hold the rally.

'The licensing office were not even sure what the regulations were or what criteria we had to meet, because they'd never encountered this situation before, so the decision ended up going all the way to the top of government,' Mr Gomez said.

No one in the government was willing to comment on the rally, and the police were only prepared to send a couple of bland press releases.

It is a sign that there is still a long way to go before Singapore is truly democratic that at least one of the organising committee lost his job for his involvement.

Yaw Shin Leong was sacked by a government community centre when his name appeared in the press in connection with the rally.

'The directors claimed they were afraid I would make use of the welfare organisation's statistics for political gain,' Mr Leong said. 'But the reality is that the political oppression ... is still very implicit.'

Singaporeans thought there had been a breakthrough last year when the government opened a Speaker's Corner, but it has proved a flop, because speakers have to register with the police and are severely restricted in what they can say, and because it quickly became apparent that the authorities were taping some speeches.

Kevin Tan, a constitutional lawyer, said the government was 'afraid that the multi-ethnic fabric of Singapore might crumble if the country became too open'.

webTitle: Red Cross workers killed in Congo attack

fields.headline: Six Red Cross workers killed in Congo attack
fields.trailText: Six relief workers with the International Committee of the Red Cross have been killed in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in one of the worst attacks on the aid community in recent years.
fields.body:
Six relief workers with the International Committee of the Red Cross have been killed in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in one of the worst attacks on the aid community in recent years.

The circumstances of the attack were unclear, but it appears the group was deliberately targeted.

'The members of the ICRC team, who were travelling in two vehicles marked with the Red Cross emblem, were on an assignment to bring assistance to the region when they were killed by unidentified assailants', the Red Cross said in a statement yesterday.

Troops in the Ugandan-controlled area found the bodies of the two women and four men by their cars on Thursday afternoon, about 40 miles from the Red Cross base in Bunia, in the north-east of the country. The dead were identified as a Colombian relief specialist, a Swiss and a Congolese nurse, a local family-tracing expert and two drivers.

Yesterday, Antonella Notari, of the ICRC, said radio contact with the aid workers had been lost a few hours earlier after they set out to help displaced people along the road to Djegu village. 'This really was absolutely out of the blue, there was no indication of any hostility towards us,' she added.

More than 220 Red Cross staff are active in eastern Congo, an area torn apart by rival factions backed by Congolese, Rwandan and Ugandan troops, as well as by local ethnic conflicts. The incident has plunged the close-knit Red Cross community into mourning and highlights the growing dangers faced by aid workers in conflict zones.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Child-killer to get Paris parole
fields.body:
Child-killer to get Paris parole

A child-murderer whose trial 24 years ago led to the abolition of the guillotine in France could be freed from jail within days.

Patrick Henry, now 47, was dubbed `France's most hated man' after strangling an eight-year-old boy in Troyes, north-west France, in 1977. Judges are unlikely to stop his parole.
Jon Henley, Paris

Didgeri don't kill off the trees!

Didgeridoo makers are endangering the rare eucalyptus phoenicea tree by cutting them down to make and sell the Aboriginal wind instruments to tourists, a researcher said yesterday.

Authorities in Northern Territory want a tagging system to curb the black market.
AP, Darwin

Oldest city in Americas found

US archaeologists have unearthed the oldest city in the Americas, dating as far back as 2600BC.

Experts say the find in Caral, 120 miles north of the Peruvian capital, Lima, involves huge, stone monuments that predate the oldest settlement by 1,000 years.
AFP, Lima

Israeli's Tel Aviv shooting spree

An Israeli reservist shot three Arabs on a crime spree after refusing to queue behind a Palestinian for hospital treatment.

David Amouyal, 29, admits charges including attempted murder but says he needs psychological help.
AP, Jerusalem

webTitle: Son of the Big Boss gets into the rhythm

fields.headline: Son of the Big Boss gets into the rhythm
fields.standfirst: Dancing prince delights Canadians on royal tour
fields.trailText: Dancing prince delights Canadians on royal tour.
fields.body:
For the man christened by the Inuit tribe Son of the Big Boss it was always going to be a tricky hunting dance - but even with his highly polished leather shoes he managed it with a little shuffle of the feet and a puzzled smile.

With a gleeful world's press focused on him Prince Charles, who seems rarely to turn down a potentially embarrassing photocall, got into the rhythm of the crowds in Ottawa during a walkabout on his Canadian tour.

Officials and local dignitaries had laid on an open horse-drawn landau for the prince and the local newspaper had issued instructions to the locals on how to behave if they met him: `Practise basic good manners. Don't shout in order to get his attention. Don't grab or touch him. Remember that he is officially the Prince of Wales and not Prince Charles or Charles.' Indeed the crowd was well behaved and enthusiastic.Two ageing first nation Canadians complete with their feathered war bonnets were dragged forward to have their pictures taken with the prince. They had been meaning to raise the issue of improved pensions for war veterans from the Canadian tribes but did not get round to it.

Grand Chief Howard Anderson, 77, is waging a campaign to get more money. A Cree, he rode a motorcycle for the Royal Canadian Army Service Corps in England and Europe during the second world war and has a chest full of brightly polished service medals to prove it. `They put us on a reservation when we came back and we've never got off it.'

But he was charmed by the prince: `I knew he'd been given a war bonnet and I told him why didn't you bring it? He said it's too windy,' the grand chief explained through toothless gums. The prince has been wary about putting on silly hats since the Daily Mail took him to task last year for donning a Rastafarian woolly bonnet with attached dreadlocks during a trip to the Caribbean.

This time he has so far contented himself with some genial rhythmic swaying alongside a group of first nation dancers outside Regina City Hall.

The Canadian government has been full of praise, sensing that if there is no wild enthusiasm for this distant monarchy, there is no appetite to sever the link either. `May your every appearance in Canada be met with warm applause and every exit bring the promise of a rapid return,' Jean Chretien, the prime minister, told a state banquet.

It is a country in which the Monarchist League can get steamed up about the absence of portraits of the Queen in every civic building - a cause long abandoned in Britain.

In Ottawa's museum of civilisation another first nation Canadian waited to see the prince. Lloyd King, an 85-year-old elder of the Ojibway tribe was being given an award for recording weather observations for the federal government at his reservation for the past 53 years.

He mused about whether he could be bothered about the monarchy, telling a local reporter: `I should say shove it, but I don't. Off-hand I'd say what do I care about a foreigner in our land? You'll find a lot of cynicism among natives. We were here first.'

fields.headline: In the wake of Mandela
fields.standfirst: Mbeki needs to focus and relax
fields.trailText: South Africa's president Thabo Mbeki has doomed himself to live in his predecessor's shadow.
fields.body:
Lucky to succeed Nelson Mandela, South Africa's president Thabo Mbeki has doomed himself to live in his predecessor's shadow. One Mbeki gaffe after another has been implicitly corrected by Mandela. First came his unwise assertions that poverty is the main cause of Aids, which he insisted on repeating in the international spotlight of last year's UN conference in Durban. Mandela rescued South Africa by taking the majority view that while poverty makes things worse it is not the decisive factor.

Now comes Mbeki's reaction to the extraordinary announcement by his security minister, Steve Tshwete, this week that three prominent African National Congress stalwarts are under police investigation for plotting against him. Mbeki could have distanced himself. Instead, he supported the minister by appealing to anyone with information to come forward. It was Mandela who took the right line by praising the accused men. "Until there is evidence to substantiate the allegations I will always regard them in high esteem," he said.

South Africa's first democratically elected president was always going to be a difficult act to follow. His relaxed personality, his dignity, his good looks, plus the cult which built up around him when he remained, unphotographed and invisible, in Robben Island for over two decades, were bound to make him an icon. The leitmotif of his rule, the concept of racial reconciliation, was also guaranteed a sympathetic response from white South Africans and the western world which could have expected more reprisals for their long years of supporting apartheid.

Mbeki had to forge a different agenda. He needed to turn the spotlight on the economy, do something to redistribute resources and wealth, and try to reduce the country's colossal incomes gap without undermining growth. There was no obvious leader who could have done this hard task better, including the three alleged ANC plotters who have each benefited from so-called black "empowerment" to become super-rich tycoons. But Mbeki has been clumsy, too thin-skinned and opaque in his dealings. The rapturous reception which Mandela will get in London's Trafalgar Square this weekend will contrast sadly with the subdued response that Mbeki can expect during his state visit to Britain in June. It is not all Mbeki's fault, but his style and substance must take some of the blame.

He needed to turn the spotlight on the economy, do something to redistribute resources and wealth, and try to reduce the country's colossal incomes gap without undermining growth. There was no obvious leader who could have done this hard task better, including the three alleged ANC plotters who have each benefited from so-called black "empowerment" to become super-rich tycoons. But Mbeki has been clumsy, too thin-skinned and opaque in his dealings. The rapturous reception which Mandela will get in London's Trafalgar Square this weekend will contrast sadly with the subdued response that Mbeki can expect during his state visit to Britain in June. It is not all Mbeki's fault, but his style and substance must take some of the blame.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: West Yorkshire
fields.trailText: West Yorkshire
fields.body:
Squelching through the mud, peering carefully beneath the hanging branches of rush, searching for signs of water vole, I was reminded of William Boot's line "Feather-footed through the plashy fens passes the questing vole . . ." in Evelyn Waugh's Scoop. This probably wasn't fen, but it was definitely plashy - marshy pools all over the place. So were signs of vole, although in this case they were bank voles. There were little piles of cut vegetation, chopped off by sharp incisor teeth, and bundles of white pith, the inside of soft rush stems, the green outer cuticle neatly stripped and eaten. Here and there were latrines and surface tunnels through the vegetation where these particular questing voles had passed.

Close by a drystone wall, a rustle of movement beneath a bramble patch caught my attention. Two bank voles, flanks a rich red brown in the sunlight, were chasing round the barbed strands of blackberry, before disappearing into a gap between the stones of the wall.

Down by the water's edge, I looked in vain for water-vole clues. Each collection of feeding remains turned out to be those of bank voles and not their larger relatives. There were no territory-marking latrines, scent-marked by a feather-footed female paddling secretions rubbed from her flanks. Wading knee-deep through the water, I parted fresh shoots of meadowsweet and greater willowherb, looking for the telltale signs of water vole occupation. Each stand of branched burr-reed and flag iris was searched, but to no avail.

Turning to the adjacent wetland, I hopped over the stile, and two startled young rabbits burst from beneath the overhanging refuge of soft rush. Once again I rummaged around, finding only bank-vole runs and molehills.

My survey is the second phase of work commissioned by West Yorkshire Ecology, based in Leeds and covering the former metropolitan county council area. To get a clear picture of where water voles are and are not, all watercourses and other potential sites need to be surveyed, which will mean a lot of nil returns. Such is, however, the lot of the vole-questing naturalist.
