fields.headline: Smallweed
fields.trailText: Knaptoft: an apology. It has been drawn to Smallweed's attention that this column recently referred to the delightful village of Knaptoft, Leicestershire, as Knapcroft.
fields.body:
Knaptoft: an apology. It has been drawn to Smallweed's attention that this column recently referred to the delightful village of Knaptoft, Leicestershire, as Knapcroft. I would like to offer an unreserved apology to the people, institutions and livestock of Knaptoft, to their friends and relations, their ostlers within and without, their helots, understrappers, retainers and tracklements, for this undeserved slur on their reputation. I have arrayed myself in sackcloth and ashes, and intend to parade along the A50, which passes this delectable spot, wearing sandwich boards bearing the slogan: "Woe is Smallweed. In his dotage, he can no longer distinguish between a toft and a croft."

I would like also to take this opportunity to apologise to the people of Knapcroft in case the above apology should in any way be taken to imply that the village of Knapcroft is in any way less estimable than the village of Knaptoft. True, I can find no Knapcroft on the map, but one can't be too careful nowadays, with so many lawyers about.

A lawyer writes: Would it not also be wise for Smallweed to extend his apology to cover such communities as Knapdale, Argyllshire, Knapthorpe in Nottinghamshire, and Knapwell, Cambridgeshire, not to mention a number of Knaptons, lest the value of local homes and hereditaments is taken to have been reduced by his failure to mention them in the aforesaid? Thank you. That will be 50 guineas.

There seems to be no end nowadays of people writing biographies claiming to prove that saints were sinners, and vice versa. But I never expected to see a campaign mounted to redeem the name of the rector of Stiffkey, Harold Davidson. On April 17, the Daily Telegraph (of which Charles Moore is still editor) published a letter from Lord Walsingham, who had got wind of this enterprise. "My godfather," he wrote, "a distinguished veteran of the South African war . . . once kicked the Rev Harold Davidson down the steps of his house when he called. The man was a fantasist and an exhibitionist, whose sexual practices remained suspect . . . Incidentally, I took his record from him for living at the top of a pole in 1956, when I spent longer up the canal station mast at El Cap during the Suez campaign. I was able to plot the minefield laid by the Egyptians at El Kantera by counting their steps as they paced it out through my telescope . . ." Well, once up the pole, up the pole for ever, as the Marquis of Vauvenargues once remarked in a different context, but this outburst did provoke two instructive replies, printed on Tuesday. These disputed the usual accounts of Davidson's fall from grace, which describe how he was defrocked by the Church of England for bad behaviour (especially with young women), found a job in a circus, and was eaten alive by a censorious lion in 1937. His granddaughter, Karilyn Collier of London N7, insists that his fall resulted from the Norfolk establishment's desperation to get rid of a radical socialist priest.

"According to local people," wrote JB Shrive of Holt, Norfolk, "the rector was the victim of a conspiracy by members of the local squirearchy, to whom he had been bold enough to comment on the moral deficiencies of their own lives." I may well find myself moved to array myself in sackcloth and ashes and parade along the A149, which passes close to this delectable village, wearing sandwich boards bearing the slogan: "Woe is Smallweed. All these years he has been ignorantly traducing the memory of a great Christian socialist gentleman."

I am a big devotee of the weekend programmes on Radio 3 hosted by Edward Seckerson. I sometimes feel guilty at having serious music playing at such an hour, but over the years it has introduced me to all sorts of work I did not know and was able to study later, as well as filling my head with instructive anecdotes. Last weekend, for instance, he told us that Francis Poulenc had said that Fauré's Requiem was one of the few things in music he could not stand. It may have been just as well that Fauré took the precaution of dying in 1924, thus sparing himself the experience of hearing Poulenc's Gloria, written in 1959.

Later, Seckerson treated us to a work by the almost unheard-of English composer Harold Truscott - his Elegy for String Orchestra, a work of real anguish written in 1943 as a long relationship with one of his students was breaking up. Truscott, he said, had been banned from the airwaves by William Glock in the mid-50s, and only one recital, by John Ogdon in 1969, got through. As it happened, though, I heard what I think was the Elegy, then recently recorded on the Marco Polo label, on Radio 3 in 1995 and wrote about it in this column, recounting how his father discovered the teenage Truscott copying Bach note by note on to manuscript staves, and promptly had him committed to an asylum.

Guy Rickards, whom Seckerson credited with discovering the elegy among Truscott's papers, wrote an affectionate tribute in this newspaper in 1992, commemorating him as composer and teacher. "Who else outside Switzerland," Rickards wrote, "even knew the name of Fritz Brun, let alone that his fourth symphony was in E major?" Fritz Brun, however, makes it into the new Grove Musical Dictionary. Truscott, unjustly I think, does not. I may well array myself in sackcloth and ashes and parade along the A616, close to Huddersfield, where he taught for 22 years, wearing sandwich boards bearing the slogan: "Posthumous justice NOW for Harold Truscott".

And so again to lampreys, a surfeit of which, I alleged last week, did for Henry I. A reader asks if I am sure that it wasn't Henry II. I shall stick to Henry I if I may, and not just to save space.The Dictionary of National Biography says HI fell sick while hunting in the forest of Lyon, "his illness, it is said, being brought on by eating lampreys contrary to the orders of his physician"; while HII died of a fever at Chinon after a war with Philip II of France and his own son Richard. My thanks to the culinary readers who have written recommending delicious things you can do with lamprey. But I shan't, if you don't mind, since I'll be too busy next week parading along the D42, close to Lyon, wearing sandwich boards bearing the slogan: "French lampreys: hands off our monarchs!"

An editor writes: That's enough lampreys, thank you. We don't want a surfeit.

webTitle: 'There was a thrill of discovery about every concert . . .'

fields.headline: 'There was a thrill of discovery about every concert . . .'
fields.trailText: For the first 30 years of its half century, the Royal Festival Hall really was what its planners had intended: the centre of London's musical life.
fields.body:
For the first 30 years of its half century, the Royal Festival Hall really was what its planners had intended: the centre of London's musical life. There was the Albert Hall, of course, which came into its own every summer for the Proms, as it still does. The Wigmore Hall retained its special position for song recitals and chamber music and, in those days, as the place where young performers would hope to make their London debuts. When the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Purcell Room were added to the South Bank complex in the late 1960s there really was a space for everything, from the most intimate to the grandest occasion.

So when I began going regularly to concerts in London in the early 1970s, the RFH was the place to be. I was lucky in my timing too; it was an era when the London orchestras were vying with each other for supremacy, and still able to attract the world's greatest conductors and soloists. With Bernard Haitink in charge of the London Philharmonic, Riccardo Muti at the Philharmonia, André Previn with the London Symphony, and the likes of Georg Solti, Carlo Maria Giulini, Eugen Jochum and Karl Böhm regular guests with these orchestras, the standard repertory was presented in a thrilling and diverse way. Pierre Boulez was beginning to make his presence really felt with the BBC Symphony Orchestra, too.

It is Boulez's concerts from that period that stick in the mind most of all - especially performances of Schoenberg's two great unfinished masterpieces, Jakobsleiter (which I've never heard live since) and Moses und Aron, but also the works by Webern, Berg, Debussy and Ravel that were then the core of his repertory. There was also new music, including his own. There seemed to be a thrill of discovery about every concert, a real sense of adventure; audiences went along with it, and were rewarded with imperishable memories.

There were piano recitals by Serkin, Curzon, Richter, Arrau, Rubinstein, Gilels and Michelangeli - an astonishing line-up in just a couple of seasons - and Jacqueline du Pré playing the Elgar Cello Concerto for the last time (though, of course, no one knew it then) on a Sunday afternoon with the Philharmonia and Zubin Mehta. The 20-year-old Simon Rattle made his London debut with the premiere of Peter Maxwell Davies's First Symphony, and even the elusive Carlos Kleiber, still the most thrilling conductor I've ever heard, was tempted to the RFH for the occasional incandescent appearance.

Perhaps it was the end of a golden age, but there is no doubt that the public for classical music in those days was more focused, and its appetite seemed insatiable. Any chance to hear the world's top stars was eagerly seized. When Herbert von Karajan came to London with the Berlin Philharmonic for two concerts of Brahms symphonies (one of which, amazingly, clashed with a recital by Sviatoslav Richter next door in the Queen Elizabeth Hall), tickets were priced astronomically, but there was a queue at the box office before dawn on the day booking opened.

This isn't just dewy-eyed nostalgia, I think, or even my being more appreciative of what was on offer in the days when I had to pay for my tickets. There really was more high-quality, innovative concert-giving in London then, and the RFH naturally got the lion's share of it. Events such as the British premiere of Stockhausen's evening-long Momente, directed by the composer, with the singers and players erupting on to the stage from all corners of the auditorium, just don't happen any more. There isn't the money for them, nor, one suspects, the artistic will.

Like Britain itself, it all began to change in the 1980s. In 1982 the RFH lost its monopoly on orchestral concerts when the Barbican Centre opened. The new hall became home to the LSO, now with Claudio Abbado at the helm, and was generously supported by the City of London, so that financial equality between the capital's orchestras was undermined. The situation was exacerbated as the stringencies of Thatcherism began to bite. No longer able to rely on its exclusivity, the RFH had to reinvent itself, and it did so with a fair degree of success through that decade. But there was still plenty to hear, and still a sprinkling, though a smaller proportion, of important events. It was only in the 1990s that the strain really began to show.

Though an important and rightly celebrated anniversary like this may not be the most tactful time to say so, the RFH now is a pale shadow of its former self, artistically as well as physically, and shows absolutely no signs of getting itself back on track. Of course it had to change; one of the most important innovations that occurred during Nicholas Snowman's tenure as chief executive was the opening up of the foyers to non-ticket holders during the daytime, with cafes, book and record shops providing somewhere to while away the odd half-hour, even when there were no concerts going on.

Snowman at least maintained quality control over the programming; he introduced the idea of resident orchestras and ensembles on the South Bank and mounted some important retrospectives - those devoted to Berio and Birtwistle particularly lodge in the memory. But even he was losing his enthusiasm by the time he left in 1998, driven to distraction by the constant postponements of the long-mooted redevelopment. Since then the place has seemed to be in freefall: the programming has acquired an increasing air of desperation as it falls over itself to try to be all things to all punters, and fails to satisfy any part of its constituency in the process.

At least the resident orchestras, the Philharmonia and the London Philharmonic, who have finally put the years of duelling over favoured status well behind them, still maintain high standards. (Though across the river the LSO does consistently manage to offer more alluring programmes.) The regular visits from the Concertgebouw Orchestra from Amsterdam and the Vienna Philharmonic add a frisson of international excitement to the season, and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment and the London Sinfonietta in their own specialist fields add another strand of excellence. But there is nothing like the regular diet of top-quality concerts in the RFH there was just 10 years ago; it is much more uneven, and often simply meretricious.

At the beginning of this season the BBC Symphony Orchestra, which had given its winter concerts at the RFH ever since the hall opened, transferred its allegiance to the Barbican. That said it all really. The Barbican is just a nicer, more inspiring place to hear orchestral music nowadays, and much more likely to offer something that is genuinely adventurous and worthwhile.

The faded, tattered fabric of the place doesn't help, and long-term planning has been compromised by the uncertainty over the redevelopment that has been proposed for so long, but still shows barely any sign of coming to fruition. (With far less fuss, the Barbican starts on the first phase of its refurbishment next month.) Funding for any major initiatives, too, is tighter than it has ever been. But none of that is any excuse for the complacency that seems to cast a pall over so much of the programme nowadays, or for a lack of real flair in what is presented. Hoping that a properly renovated RFH, if it ever comes to pass, will automatically bring back all the enthusiasm and the boldness that have drained away over the last five years is, I'm afraid, a fond delusion.

fields.headline: Miracles in maximum security
fields.standfirst: Brutal gangs rule South Africa's prisons. But in a remarkable experiment, some of the world's most violent men are starting to rediscover their humanity.  Allan Little investigates
fields.trailText: Brutal gangs rule South Africa's prisons. But in a remarkable experiment, some of the world's most violent men are starting to rediscover their humanity. Allan Little investigates.
fields.body:
Mogamat Benjamin has been in prison for 34 years and has killed more people - mostly fellow inmates - than he can remember. He has beheaded and mutilated their corpses. He has - along with other members of his gang - cut out his victims' hearts and eaten them in a grim, semi-mystical ritual in which the life-force of the victim passes into the bodies of the killers. Mogamat holds the rank of general in the gang known as the 28s.

"Their power grows and grows," says Barry Coetzee, a prison warder. "It feels as if they are taking over. It's not the warders who have control of the prison any more. The Numbers control the prison. They make the decisions."

Coetzee has reason to feel afraid. He has been warned that he has been selected by the gang leaders as a future target. Someone in the gang structure - he doesn't know who - has been ordered to stab him as a test of courage and loyalty to the gang. This is known as "calling a number".

"A number has been called on me," says Coetzee. "I will be stabbed or cut with a blade. My blood has to flow. There's no way to defend yourself. You never know when, you never know where. It's terrifying. It's a psychological war."

Erefaan Jacobs is Mogamat's second-in-command. He holds the rank of judge. It is his job to "try" gang members who break gang law and to decide on appropriate punishment. He, too, has ordered that disloyal and mistrusted members be killed. He also punishes any sign of fear in new recruits.

"When you join the gang, I will not allow any fear from you," he says. "We develop you in such a way that you will become fearless. You can only come into the camp [of the 28s] by spilling blood. We do not have scared people in our camp. If you're scared, you will betray us. If we see you're scared, we'll kill you. It has happened. Many people's heads were cut off in cells where I was present. I see that tonight we will kill this man. The whole day I know it. I will talk with you, laugh with you. But I know that tonight we will kill you."

Erefaan's face is covered in tattoos. "Spit on my Grave" is tattooed across his forehead; "I hate you, Mum" etched into his left cheek. The tattoos are an expression of loyalty. The men cut the emblems of their allegiance into their skin. The Number demands not only that you pledge your oath verbally but that you be marked, indelibly, for life. Facial tattoos are the ultimate abandonment of all hope of a life outside.

The Numbers gangs have their origin in the violence of white rule. The 28s are the oldest gang. They were founded in 1906 as a revolt by 28 black prisoners. The gang quickly became a way for its members to defy - and protect themselves against - the atrocities of the white prison regime. It developed its own military-style hierarchy, its own elaborate codes of punishment and reward, and its own sexual mores. For what distinguishes the men of the 28s is sex. They are known as the men who have sex with each other in the night. An intricate protocol determines which new recruits will serve as sexual partners for which established gang members. The gang officers take regular sexual partners, known as "wyfies", who win membership of the gang - and with it the gang's protection - in return for sexual obedience.

It was as a revolt against sodomy that the second main gang was formed - the 27s. They are known in prison as the men of blood. Their loyalty to their officers is tested by stabbing warders and other inmates. In Pollsmoor Maximum, almost half the warders have been stabbed or cut at least once.

The gang known as the 26 also repudiate sex between men. They prove their loyalty by robbing warders and fellow inmates of whatever material possessions can be smuggled in.

In cell 191, the men of the 26 sleep on the west side of the room, where the sun comes up, because their principal activity takes place during the hours of day light. The men of the 28 sleep on the east side, where the sun sets, because they are men of the night. It is a pattern repeated across South Africa, for the Numbers gangs operate in all South Africa's prisons, and inmates transferred from one prison to another must demonstrate a knowledge of gang culture, beliefs and practices in order to be accepted into the camp in the new prison.

But Pollsmoor is pioneering a new approach to the prison gang culture. Jonny Jansen is the first black man to head the maximum-security wing. He recognises that the origins of the system - and the hierarchy of violence that sustains it - lie in apartheid. So he has persuaded leading gang members - including Mogamat and Erefaan - to join a programme known as Change is Possible. The South African film-makers Cliff Bestall and Pearlie Joubert got exclusive access to film a series of remarkable and - at times - breathtaking workshops in which the country's most hardened killers are forced to confront themselves - to examine who they are and the evil that has so blighted them - for the first time in their lives. It is an astonishing experiment in human nature, an attempt to reach into the souls of mass murderers and multiple rapists to see whether they can be changed. As a BBC journalist I visited the prison and narrated the film. The workshops are run by Joanna Thomas from Cape Town's Centre for Conflict Resolution. She is a striking feminine presence in the masculine, emotion-free zone of Pollsmoor Maximum.

She leads them into an isolated cell on the roof of the prison. It is the cell where Nelson Mandela was held for six years after being moved from Robben Island. It is the room where he began his dialogue with the old apartheid regime - the room where South Africa began to change. Change is its purpose again.

It takes her 10 days to break down their resistance. At first they see her as a threat to the Numbers system. Some threaten to stab her. Eventually she wins the cooperation of a small group who see in her a chance for change. But they in turn must endure the taunts and threats of their fellow inmates.

Suspicion spreads about what Thomas is up to in her rooftop workshops. One member of the 27s issues an explicit threat: "You who give the Number away - you must be killed. That's how the Number is."

On the last day, they face the toughest test. Thomas forces them to talk about their families - their wives, their children. But, tellingly, it is when they talk about their fathers that the floodgates open. There is not a single man in the room who can recall an affectionate male presence in his childhood. "I, too, lacked fatherly love," says one. "That's why I'm glad I met all of you, in prison. You gave me that."

It is a powerful and extraordinary moment to witness - a fleeting instant when the humanity seems to seep back into these most dehumanised of human beings. It is what motivates Thomas to come back into this place day after day. "I am not so naive as to believe that one series of workshops can change a man who has been in the heart of the gang system for most of his life. But I see a struggle, and as long as I see it, I am prepared to engage with it."

South Africa's prisons department took a risk letting our camera in on this. They had a lot to lose. We have shown them a copy of our film. They are copying it and showing it in South Africa's jails, using it to recruit other inmates to the Change is Possible programme. The effect on many of the prisoners, they tell us, is immediate and overwhelming. At the end of one screening, one prisoner - the 27 gang member who appears in the film threatening to kill those who are "giving away the Number" - saw for the first time what the workshops were about. He rose to his feet at the end of the screening, asked for his fellow inmates' forgiveness, and declared himself ready to seek Thomas's help.

Like Thomas, none of us who worked on this chilling and inspiring film is naive enough to believe that a few workshops can change a man's life. But the South African prisons department has turned its back on more than a century of brutality and has taken a brave and radical step to try to overcome the enduring legacies of what this country used to be.

webTitle: An every day tale of country folk

fields.headline: An every day tale of country folk
fields.trailText: There is nothing about the countryside that could be called natural, from the artfully placed copses and carefully tended stone walls to the church spires dominating the villages.
fields.body:
I drove down to Gloucestershire to stay with friends before the Cheltenham literary festival. I saw signs saying "Foot and Mouth Area" and I saw some large organic objects burning in a field. But the Cotswold village where my friends live was perfect, every stone, every blade of grass and and every field just so.

We have come to understand that landscape is entirely artificial. Those parts of the landscape free of garden centres and Little Chefs - the parts that seem most natural - are that way because people made them that way. There is nothing about the countryside that could be called natural, from the artfully placed copses and carefully tended stone walls to the church spires dominating the villages.

In a book edited by Michael Sissons (my agent), A Countryside for All, one of the contributors, Simon Jenkins, says that there should be an absolute stop on rural land development. He also says that there is plenty of derelict land in the cities to be used before we suburbanise the countryside. It is a theme of the book that neglect of the cities leads to suburban sprawl. It seems to me that the advocates of the countryside, as opposed to its inhabitants, are engaged in an aesthetic struggle, a struggle superficially about the countryside but really about a set of values. They see the countryside as a last stand against baseball caps and rap and fast food and motorways and cultural relativism and lifestyle television and multiple-choice education. Roger Scruton is so daring as to mention the desirability of religion.

It is a characteristic of Britain today that these kinds of battle are fought by proxy. Fox hunting is surely not about the welfare of foxes; foot and mouth is not about the treatment of a cattle virus. Although there is no advocacy of fox hunting in this excellent book, it is clear that it is going to be difficult for Labour, having mythologised the countryside, to abolish fox hunting in the next parliament, now that a million and a half innocent ruminants have been slaughtered. The wretched little fox has replaced the lion in the heraldic bestiary.

Sliding through the sleeping countryside on the way to Cheltenham, I pass some houses of staggering beauty, set above small streams crossed by stone bridges, looking across to hillsides of daffodils. I see a few genuine old country folk in flat caps (the men) and stout worsted skirts (the women); the pleasure of the drive is mitigated only slightly by the knowledge that the beautiful houses are inhabited by people who made their money elsewhere and came to the country to give expression to their good taste and good fortune.

As we chat about politics in the town hall, I reflect that we are all a mass of contradictions; we are all pedestrians and motorists; we would all like the countryside to remain untouched, but don't want to sit in traffic for hours getting there; we all use supermarkets, but would like to have Farmer Giles's wife delivering a basket of speckled duck eggs to our door; we have all considered riding a bike when it wasn't raining; we all approve of Prince Charles on the one hand while thinking he's a bit loopy on the other.

Many years ago I used to go out with a girl who was at the Webber Douglas drama school. One day she told me they had spent the day doing movement. What did that entail? She said she had been asked to imitate an egg. I pointed out that eggs don't move. A short intake of breath and pitying look: movement is part of acting. That may be, but it brings to mind school productions where girls attached to floaty garments run about the stage standing proxy for important ideas.

The much-heralded Mill on the Floss at the New Ambassadors in London is big on movement, as though George Eliot has been hijacked by a ballet company. It is also very long, nearly three hours of unflagging energy. It is an extraordinary production, with three versions of Maggie Tulliver at war with their natures. The overwhelmingly female audience was rapt, almost ecstatic; it was clear that they were able to see, across the 140 years since the book was written, the message that women still have difficult decisions to make and obstacles to overcome. I pondered what the theatrical equivalent of a chick-pic might be.

The Shared Experience company has been quite faithful to the story, but they have given it a spin by suggesting that Maggie Tulliver was seen as a witch - something the book suggests only obliquely - because of her independence of mind. So the great flood at the end of the book doubles as a witch-ducking. Helen Edmundson, the adapter, describes this in her note as "a dramatic central idea".

The truth about Maggie Tulliver is that she represented Eliot, but without the option of escaping rural ignorance and prejudice. Eliot left Warwickshire for London, lived with a married man until his death, and inhabited literary society. She was herself a contradiction, an independent woman who believed in traditional moral order. It's easy to see her as a modern figure, her beliefs at war with the way she lived. Incidentally, it was a reminder of how often rural life has been portrayed in literature as a kind of rigid boredom.

Feelgood, at the Garrick Theatre, is very funny. It is, consciously or not, based on Orwell's premise that political speeches and speechwriting are the defence of the indefensible. When the Blairesque leader made a speech near the end of the play, defending the indefensible, I felt the pull of meaningless demagogy; it was a moment when the play transcended farce. Perhaps the key moment in Neil Kinnock's career was when he trusted his image to Hugh Hudson and made the superficially brilliant but ultimately vacuous party political broadcast, the one known as "The first Kinnock in a thousand years . . ."

At the same time I was responsible for a party political on a different scale of notoriety, referred to as "Rosie Barnes and the Rabbit" among those who care about such things. Rosie Barnes, SDP MP for Greenwich, was filmed in her garden with her children and a large rabbit. It was intended as a small section of a broadcast, but two florid and emotional leaders of the Alliance decided, against my advice, that it should run for the full 10 minutes. One of them was in tears as he viewed the film: middle England, plus rabbit. I once started writing a play about party politicals, starring this rabbit. Having seen Feelgood, I wish I had finished it.

Apologies all round, a personal phone call from the minister of education and a severe reprimand for some naive person in the Johannesburg area education department. The Nadine Gordimer brouhaha has ended - for the moment - with a whimper, as I thought it would.

Her book, July's People, is restored to the educational canon. But Gordimer herself has come in for criticism, in particular from the commentator RW Johnson, for her equivocation on ANC lapses. History shows that it is inviting disappointment to mistake a political party for a movement. In South Africa the "struggle" is over. The high ground is - like the Mill on the Floss - inundated, in this case by mere politics.

webTitle: Royal Festival Hall: Thanks for the memories

fields.headline: Thanks for the memories
fields.standfirst: I could smell the waves of ganja wafting towards me and I thought: I've done all this. It was my moment of vanity, if you like  - John Peel on the Royal Festival Hall
fields.trailText: I could smell the waves of ganja wafting towards me and I thought: I've done all this. It was my moment of vanity, if you like - John Peel on the Royal Festival Hall
fields.body:
Tasmin Little, violinist

I first performed at the Royal Festival Hall in 1989. I like the hall very much indeed; it was probably quite trendy at the time it was built, and now it looks slightly old-fashioned - but I rather like that.

It makes me feel nostalgic. The outside belies what goes on inside. It looks rather daunting - bit of a concrete block - but in fact it's very warm and welcoming and they've done a lot to it. It's now quite diverse inside, what with the CD shop and bookshop and cafeterias.

I enjoy the atmosphere of the hall and walking out on to the stage there, and I like the layout of the auditorium from the audience point of view. With the boxes and the seats at the sides and behind you in the choir, you get the feeling that your audience is all around you. It feels genuinely intimate.

Last year I performed the Ligeti concerto in the final concert of the Towards the Millennium festival with Sir Simon Rattle, which was a 10-year-long event celebrating all the music of the 20th century. It felt like a really momentous occasion because it completely sold out, and we had the most fantastic audience. It was a real night to remember.

Keith Miller, RFH employee for 40 years

My involvement with the hall started as a hobby. First I was a steward for about 18 months, and then I was transferred backstage, where I was responsible for looking after the artists, keeping the programme running to time.

I have looked after the Princess of Wales and Prince Charles, Princess Margaret and the Queen Mother. When the Queen Mother comes we always have to remember to put a little cushion on her seat so that she can see over the balcony because she's so tiny. Princess Anne always sits in the auditorium rather than in the royal box, and even though we always book the row in front and behind, people have no idea that she is there.

I once had to have words with Spike Milligan; he was chatting with friends after one of the concerts. When I asked him if he would leave the auditorium, he said he had no intention of taking it with him.

One of the most poignant moments I can remember was the day after the Aberfan mining disaster in 1966 when about 3,000 schoolchildren attended a concert. Most of them were unaware of what had happened. They were all chattering away making a terrific noise, but backstage there was hardly a dry eye in the house.

John Peel, broadcaster and curator of the RFH's 1998 Meltdown festival

I wasn't very keen on organising the festival at first because it clashed with the World Cup, but David Sefton asked me to do it and he's basically a nice chap. So we set up the hall with screens so that people could watch the football if they wanted to. That's why I changed my mind.

My main memory would have to be one balmy evening when I was standing on the riverside with my back to the balcony: on one side I could hear Culture playing and on the other Extreme Noise Terror in the Queen Elizabeth Hall - they're good Ipswich lads, probably the best at what they do.

I could smell the waves of ganja wafting towards me and I thought, "I've done all this." It was my moment of vanity, if you like. What really mattered was that I could have people that I wanted to see - and the venue has a certain cache about it because it is the RFH.

The wonderful thing about the hall is that the people who work there have a really relaxed attitude. Extreme Noise Terror probably aren't everyone's cup of tea, but you don't get staff telling people not to dance and enjoy themselves.

Valerie Solti, patron of the Friends of the London Philharmonic Orchestra

My acquaintance with the RFH goes right back to the beginning. As a child, during the Festival of Britain I was taken there by my mother to see a 3D film, which was the first time I had ever seen anything like that. Much later, when I worked for the BBC on an arts programme, I used to go there to interview people.

There were some wonderful concerts - one of the best ones I can remember was going to see the pianist Vladimir Horowitz on a Sunday afternoon about 20 years ago. He always played at the same time of day. There were lots of musicians in the audience and it was a very exciting atmosphere.

When my husband was music director of the LPO I remember we were always rushing to get to the RFH at the last minute. I remember the excitement of going through the stage door, and up to level three. I discovered my own special route so I could get to my seat quickly as soon as the performance started.

The RFH has a particular smell, a mixture of floor polish and resin from the bows. If I was blindfolded and taken there I'd always know exactly where I was.

At the end of the concerts I always had to rush down the back stairs to get to the side of the stage before everyone else, so I could be there to meet my husband as he came offstage.

Karsten Witt, chief executive of the South Bank Centre

At the moment we are in the middle of transforming the building completely. I imagine how wonderful it must have been in 1951. The impression must have been overwhelming, with the light coming into the building from all sides and the astonishing views.

I am at the RFH probably every other night. One of the most impressive performances I remember was Claudio Abbado and the Berlin Philharmonic. Abbado told us to raise the stage 30cm to improve the acoustics - the difference was amazing. Among the things I like most is the diversity of the programming. Last year we had Placido Domingo and then the next night Radiohead.

For the future, I want to restore the original features of the hall, including the rooftop cafe and the river terrace, to fulfil the vision of the original architects. They wanted the RFH to be one of the best halls in the world.

webTitle: Comment:  Irish play sets new records for grossness

fields.headline: Sick-buckets needed in the stalls
fields.standfirst:
An Irish play sets new records for grossness. But don't let it put you off

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An Irish play sets new records for grossness. But don't let it put you off.
fields.body:
The late Sarah Kane's 1995 play Blasted, which has just been revived in London, is generally described as the most violent and shocking piece of modern British theatre. For those who have not seen it - or attended but been forced to look away - it contains scenes of cannibalism, rape and murder.

Next week, however, the Royal Shakespeare finally premieres a drama which makes Blasted look like the Teletubbies. At the preview performance I attended, some members of the audience appeared to be vomiting or retching during the most savage moments of the last act.

The Lieutenant of Inishmore is the latest work by Martin McDonagh, a young Irish writer previously known for The Beauty Queen of Leenane and a subsequent, lavishly praised trilogy of dramas set in rural Ireland. The latter felt as though JM Synge had been able to watch Quentin Tarantino videos before sitting down to write The Playboy of the Western World.

The Lieutenant of Inishmore was rejected by both the Royal Court and the Royal National Theatre. The theatres hint that this was quality control; McDonagh regards it as political caution or censorship. Having seen the play performed, I'd bet on the second of these explanations. It's a brave move for anyone to stage this play but more so for a theatre with the royal imprimatur in its name. You can understand why the Court and National said no. The RSC may be gambling that its own company is not only royal but Shakespearean, named for the man who wrote Titus Andronicus, another sick-bag piece.

The theatre wrote to all ticket-holders warning that the play was potentially disturbing. At the performance I attended, this caution was repeated at the door of the auditorium. Specific reference was made to loud gunshots (there are dozens) but, as it turns out, bangs are the least of it.

Mad Padraic, the central character, is a terrorist so excessive that the IRA turned him down, leading him to join the INLA. Hearing from the home farm that his beloved cat has been decapitated by a driver, Mad Padraic comes back to take revenge. One of theatre's most unlikely love scenes takes place between two people each of whom is clutching a headless cat (the latter played by models). After a shoot-out, three corpses are sawn into small pieces on a stage awash with blood. Finally, a genuine cat walks into this slippery melee. The published text (Methuen) offers alternative stage directions depending on whether or not the feline eats some proffered Frosties.

Publicists and critics routinely describe plays as controversial, but this one is truly unusual in giving potentially triple offence. Moralists will object to the scenes of brutality; terrorists and their sympathisers to the mockery of Irish freedom-fighters; and animal rights campaigners will fret about the simulation of dead cats and the participation of a real one. With the now traditional bonkers priorities begun by Hollywood, a programme note reassures us that no animals have been harmed in the production.

There have been rumours that the sudden cancellation of the first press night (scheduled for March 18) resulted from restaging to prevent action by lawyers or protesters. The RSC denies this, blaming a hand injury to a leading actor, although that performer continued to appear during what would have been the opening week and it is admitted that some changes have been made.

Modern Irish plays have usually proved contentious because of allegations that they defend terrorism. Ronan Bennett's TV series Rebel Hearts has recently suffered from the Daily Telegraph in this regard. Critics, though, will find it hard to aim that grenade against The Lieutenant of Inishmore, which is a very rare example of a play liberal in content but conservative in politics. A final comic twist - involving the live cat - leads to the realisation that the sickening killings have been entirely pointless and based on a misunderstanding. 'So all this terror has been for absolutely nothing?', asks one of the few living characters. 'It has', his fellow survivor replies.

This could, I suppose, be interpreted as supporting the position of Republican breakaway groups towards the peace process - all that killing was for this - but it seems to me more likely that McDonagh is offering an Ulster twist on the Borges put-down about the Falklands war: 'Two bald men fighting over a comb.'

It's true that the playwright has been careful in dramatising the INLA - who even IRA killers have described as 'wild men' - but his depiction of terrorists as sentimental psychopaths is unusual and brave in Irish drama. McDonagh has also, I think, deliberately set a trap for English audiences and reviewers, which is to make us worry more about the cats than the humans killed. Soppiness about creatures is our national vice, as this week's tabloid scramble to save Phoenix the calf again proved.

With critical armour well in place - having read American Psycho, seen Blasted, and sat through Reservoir Dogs - I regarded myself as unshockable. But The Lieutenant of Inishmore made me shade my eyes and worry about seeing my lunch again. It's theatrically gross but also thrillingly written and politically challenging. It would be a pity if its reception finally comes down to controversy over the treatment of moggies.

fields.headline: Al Hibbler
fields.standfirst: American singer who bridged the worlds of jazz and pop
fields.trailText: American singer who bridged the worlds of jazz and pop.
fields.body:
The blind singer Al Hibbler, who has died aged 85, was once described by Duke Ellington as "our major asset". The great bandleader was referring to Hibbler's deep-toned, dramatic vocal style, with its heavy vibrato... "You could drive a truck through that vibrato," said one musician... which brought Hibbler and the band considerable popular acclaim. He achieved national prominence in the United States with the Ellington orchestra in the mid-1940s, and went on to build a substantial career, which included continuing involvement with jazz musicians.

But Hibbler's historic place in popular music was achieved by being the artist who originally recorded the hit, Unchained Melody, in the mid-1950s. Numerous singers, including the Righteous Brothers, have recorded the number since, many obviously influenced by Hibbler's recording .

Hibbler was born in Tyro, Mississippi, but spent his formative years in Little Rock, where he attended the Ark- ansas school for the blind. He joined the school choir as a soprano, but, once his voice deepened, found opportunities to sing the blues in juke joints and bars around Texas and Arkansas.

Influenced by Pha Terrel, the ballad singer with the Andy Kirk band, Hibbler won amateur contests in Memphis, formed his own group and went on the road. In the pre-civil rights atmosphere of the 1930s, times were tough for black artists in the southern states... doubly so in Hibbler's case... but he prospered, learning his trade with a succession of southwestern territory bands, including those of Dub Jenkins and Boots and his Buddies.

Kansas City bandleader Jay McShann was the next to hire him. "I could tell Hibbler had it, so I wired him to join us in Kansas City," he said. By the time the band, including bebop pioneer Charlie Parker, arrived in New York, Hibbler had displaced McShann's other vocalists, and was to tour with him for the next two years.

It was in New York in 1943 that Ellington got wind of the singer's talent, when his musicians began to sing Hibbler's praises. Ellington was dubious about adding another man to his payroll but, once persuaded, never ceased to marvel at Hibbler's contorted style, describing it as `tonal pantomime.' He was also impressed by Hibbler's ability to learn endless new songs, and by his extraordinary range of vocal devices, as shown, for example, on Do Nothing Until You Hear From Me, and in a memorable section of Ellington's six-part Liberian Suite.

While some critics found Hibbler's style hard to take, his fans were sufficient in number to bring him the Esquire New Star Award as best male singer in 1947, and the Downbeat award as best band singer in 1948-49. He toured with Ellington for eight years, majoring latterly on lachrymose ballads such as Trees and Danny Boy, until 1951, when leader and singer fell out over money.

Once away from Ellington, Hibbler became busy on the club circuit, recording frequently, sometimes with Ellington's colleagues, such as the Duke's son Mercer (with whose band he toured) and alto-saxophonist Johnny Hodges. He was signed to the Verve label, but had little success until 1955, when he recorded Unchained Melody for Decca. Originally a film theme, Hibbler's version went to No 3 in the US charts, and was followed a year later by another hit, After The Lights Go Down Low.

Hibbler's involvement with the civil rights movement of the 1960s... he was arrested twice on protest marches... curtailed his career. It was not until Frank Sinatra championed his cause by giving him a Reprise contract, that he worked again.

In more recent years, less was heard of Hibbler, though he sang at Louis Armstrong's funeral in 1971, and, a year later, recorded with the blind multi-instrumentalist Rashaan Roland Kirk. His last public appearance was at the Lincoln Center, New York, in January 1999, with a group of old Ellington alumni, his vibrato as stunning as ever as he sang Time After Time.

Hibbler settled in Chicago, where he died. He is survived by a sister and a brother.

 Albert "Al" Hibbler, singer, born August 16 1915; died April 24 2001

fields.headline: Michael Northen
fields.trailText: Michael Northen, who has died aged 79, was the first person in Britain to be credited as a theatre lighting designer.
fields.body:
Michael Northen, who has died aged 79, was the first person in Britain to be credited as a theatre lighting designer. In 1952, he worked on John Gielgud's production of King Lear, at Stratford. The painted scenery of the time required his sensitive approach, and he knew how to make that scenery look beautiful... he literally painted with light and understood the way it could connect directly with an audience's emotions.

He collaborated with some of the most remarkable designers and directors of his day, including Peter Brook, Sophie Fedorovitch, John Gielgud, Tyrone Guthrie, Robert Helpmann, Tanya Moiseiwitsch and John Piper.

He worked on the world premiers of Benjamin Britten's Billy Budd, Gloriana, and The Turn Of The Screw, numerous Stratford and Glyndebourne seasons, countless West End plays and musicals, a son et lumiere following the investiture of the Prince of Wales, and Noel Coward's 70th birthday gala.

Northen was born in London and educated at Canford school, Dorset. In 1938, the stage-struck youngster was apprenticed as stage manager to the Q-Theatre, at Kew Bridge, for £100... a sizeable investment on the part of his parents, but one that reaped great returns.

He developed a model theatre in his studio at Cheyne Row, Chelsea, where he was able to mock up productions, from the smallest stage to that of the Royal Opera House, and could even light them with an astonishing degree of accuracy.

Michael was that wonderful mix of a charming man, an innocent enthusiast and a pioneer. He helped to create the role of the modern lighting designer, and his influence is still felt in the profession. When he, and a handful of others, decided to meet for lunch at Rules restuarant once a month... telling their stories of veteran switchboards, recalcitrant lighting equipment and elderly chief electricians... it was the begining of the Association of Lighting Designers and the Society of British Theatre Designers.

Northen was chairman and president of the 500-strong association until his death, and earlier this year, when he was awarded an MBE for services to the theatre, it was typical of his generosity that he chose to mark the occasion by funding a scholarship for a young trainee lighting designer. His 1997 autobiography is called Northen Lights.

He is survived by his partner of 52 years, Robert Camac.

 Michael Northen, lighting designer, born May 12 1921; died March 18 2001

fields.headline: Just stick to it
fields.standfirst: We've all heard about royal jelly, but now we've got bees to thank for a whole variety of health-giving products. Suzannah Olivier reveals the latest buzz words
fields.trailText: We've all heard about royal jelly, but now we've got bees to thank for a whole variety of health-giving products. Suzannah Olivier reveals the latest buzz words.
fields.body:
Did you know that a good way to inoculate yourself against hay fever is to eat locally produced honey? Or that enriched honey, when dabbed on cold sores, reduces their severity?

Better for you than sugar - bee enzymes break nectar down into fructose (fruit sugar) and glucose (blood sugar) - honey and other bee products offer a whole medicine chest of alternative remedies.

Royal jelly has long been thought to have nutritional qualities, but now other bee substances, most notably propolis and pollen, are appearing on the shelves of health-food stores. Bee pollen is a complete food, with protein-building amino acids and twice as much calcium as milk, weight for weight, says nutrition consultant Susan Fletcher.

Propolis is the brown, resinous "glue" that bees use to seal the cells in the hive. The bees collect it from the sap of trees, and when these trees have strong antibiotic properties - as the poplar, willow and birch do - the propolis transfers these antibiotic benefits to the hive, and thus to the honey itself. And propolis-enriched honey, mixed with a little warm water, can be dripped into the ear to help combat bacterial ear infections.

It is the antiviral properties of propolis that make it good for cold sores, but it also has anti-fungal benefits, so honey with added propolis makes a great remedy for athlete's foot. Propolis has even been found to inhibit the antibiotic-resistant superbug Staphylococcus aureus.

But you can't use just any old honey. It is important to buy organic honey that has not been heat-treated above hive temperature, as this kills the active compounds. And not all honey is equally effective. Single-source honey, such as pine, lavender or thyme, are recommended; the most potent of all, however, is New Zealand manuka honey. The bees gather pollen from the manuka, or tea tree, which is renowned for its healing properties. When applied to wounds, surgical scars or burns, the honey clears up bacteria, keeps the wound supple and clean and reduces scarring. It also helps prevent the wound smelling.

While there is a lot of manuka honey produced, the most effective is thought to be the honey that is certified as containing "active manuka". Because of its antibacterial action, manuka honey is a powerful ally against gastritis (usually felt as indigestion) caused by the bacteria Helicobacter pylori, which invades the stomach lining, acting as an irritant and causing inflammation. However, a teaspoon of manuka, three times a day, slowly kills the H. pylori. Fletcher, whose husband is a bee-keeper, has had plenty of success with local honey. "We use our UK-made honey for dressing wounds to avoid scarring," she says. "I had one client who was treated for gastro-enteritis for several years, and within three months of taking this honey he was fine."

Honey is no slouch in the beauty stakes, either - it's a great moisturiser. You can make your own face mask by mixing a tablespoon of honey with a teaspoon of olive oil and an egg yolk. Apply the mixture to your face (avoiding your eyes) and lie down for 20 minutes before washing it off. Your skin will be silky smooth, even if your pillow is a little sticky.

One word of warning: honey should not be given to babies younger than one year old, because there is a very slight risk of botulism. And if you suffer from a very severe pollen allergy, it's best to steer clear of honey.

fields.headline: In your face
fields.trailText: I have experienced the zeitgeist of beauty treatments this week. All modern, high-maintenance ladies are fans of Eve Lom, that grande dame of skincare, and every jet-setting fashionista is resting her kitten-heeled feet at the über-trendy central London hotel, The Sanderson. Brilliantly, the two experiences are now combined at the newly opened Sanderson spa, Agua. All the treatments on offer, including Eve Lom's, are said to be garnering a bit of a cult following from the hotel's famous guests. Who could resist?
fields.body:
I have experienced the zeitgeist of beauty treatments this week. All modern, high-maintenance ladies are fans of Eve Lom, that grande dame of skincare, and every jet-setting fashionista is resting her kitten-heeled feet at the über-trendy central London hotel, The Sanderson. Brilliantly, the two experiences are now combined at the newly opened Sanderson spa, Agua. All the treatments on offer, including Eve Lom's, are said to be garnering a bit of a cult following from the hotel's famous guests. Who could resist?

Entering Agua you would be forgiven for thinking you had wandered into a dream sequence in a David Lynch film, or perhaps stumbled onto the set of a video for a dodgy boy band. Billowing white drapes line the many walkways, and the waiting room is filled with an unending supply of almost unnaturally red strawberries.

My therapist, Celeste, delightfully informed and of gentle nature, removes the ridiculously short robe provided and swaddles me like a baby on to a state-of-the-art massage bed. She introduces me to Eve Lom's "philosophy" and asks those questions we all hate to answer: how much water do you drink, do you exercise, and so on. I explain that I'm a new mum, hoping that this will excuse my not exactly glowing-with-radiant-health appearance.

Then for the famous Eve Lom facial. First, cleanser is applied with a mixture of acupressure and reiki (the Japanese healing practice) to encourage lymphatic drainage, then removed with a warm muslin cloth. My facial muscles are relaxed with a beeswax mask.

A cold camphor mask, followed by Celeste's icy hands, close my squeaky clean pores. Finally, compresses dipped in camomile tea are applied. I have to admit, on critical inspection in the mirror, I do look years younger and feel alive and invigorated again -a true miracle for a new mother. She knows a thing or two, that Eve Lom.

After all that cleansing and purifying, it was time for something sweeter: Agua's milk and honey Ayurvedic treatment. Laid out naked on a bed, I was scrubbed with a hard brush and then massaged with a blend of honey and sesame oil. I did smell like a marinated chicken for a while but then warm milk was poured over me to wash away the oil. All you needed was a eunuch playing a lute and for Russell Crowe to walk by in battle fatigues, and I swear you could have been in Roman times.

Thoroughly recommended, but please, Agua, turn off the never-ceasing water fountain. It may be there to calm the soul and drown out the whale Muzak, but it just left me gagging for the loo.

Zoe Ball's beauty column appears weekly.

fields.headline: The grape divide
fields.trailText: I actually dislike people who bang on about the glories of France much more than I hate the French themselves.
fields.body:
I was really pleased to see this week that that horrible swill Le Piat D'Or - which, I blush to say, my first husband often impressed me with when I was a green young teen - is to be re-launched and re-branded, so dire have its sales been recently; down by £10m since the 80s. Out go those annoying ads of the silly, chic French couple getting dressed while the rude, early guests wait at the door bearing a bottle of it, as if that was the answer to everything!

Out goes the line "Les Français adorent le Piat D'Or." The reason? "France and the French are no longer aspirational," says Emma Chamberlain, the drink's marketing manager. Apparently your average winey would rather have a beaker of the warm Antipodes, and I'm not surprised. With wine, as with no other drink, the aspirational and lifestyle sway is high, and it seems quite understandable that a modern, friendly, sunny country like Oz would be more on our mind when we kicked back with a glass of the grape on yet another freezing spring evening than the thought of crumbly, snooty old Paree, where there's just as much rain and twice as much dog muck.

Hopefully we've seen the back of what that Czech intellectual refugee - dazzled by the liberty and culture of postwar Britain, amazed that our chattering classes were so in thrall to the French - named in the 50s as "French flu". Because it's certainly been with us until extremely recently. Ah, the French! Never mind that they collaborated with the Nazis, that their legal system has you guilty until proven innocent, that their National Front is thriving, that you have to choose your child's name from a state-approved list, that door-to-door political campaigning is illegal, that their bloody fingers had to be prised off their empire a good two decades after we'd given up ours with a wistful smile, that their spooks blow up unarmed Greenpeace ships and then get a hero's welcome, and that women didn't get the vote until 1945 and still rarely make it in politics unless they've slept with the president. Ah, but they had a revolution a zillion trillion years ago, so they must be really sound!

But the French can't help the way they are, of course - and it occurs to me that I actually dislike English people who bang on about the glories of France much more than I hate the French themselves. It's like boxing - it's the brainless trash in the front row baying for blood who are objectionable, not the poor lunks themselves. And the same with fox-hunting - hunters, like naughty Mr Fox, are vermin and born to kill for fun, but those people who can do joined-up writing and use it to send letters of support for their more cranially-challenged brothers are the real danger.

I think that the only British people left who like the French tend to be men between the ages of 45 and 65 - the Rancid Years - and I bet you any money that a good many of them like the idea of it so much because they've grown up with the old line that every married Frenchman has a "mistress" and the wife just puts up with it. (For some reason this is meant to be "liberated", though curiously it ties in exactly with the Victorian English way of looking at sex.) I've never been able to work out how exactly this would be physically possible, unless there were literally twice as many women as men in France, which seems unlikely considering their, ahem, war record - I mean, it wasn't exactly the Eastern Front down the Bois de Boulogne. Unless all the "mistresses", of course, are someone else's wives - ooohh, doesn't sound quite such a good set-up to you suddenly, does it?

And I would bet you any money that a good number of these fading Francophiles read a magazine called the Erotic Review, and buy dirty pictures from its sister set-up, the Erotic Print Society. I have for a long time been intrigued by the sheer, off-the-scale naffness of these organs, an annoyance that was admittedly piqued when they asked me to write for them and I was forced to admit to myself that 20 years of me banging on in public about how much I hated the word "erotic" above all others had been as naught.

Erotic; go on, isn't that the naffest, weasliest, most Hyacinth Bucketish word of all time? And so up itself! You are a tourist - I am a traveller. You are a sad wanker who buys Big And Busty off the top shelf; I am an erotic gourmand who gets sent prints of strangers' tits in a plain brown wrapper. And might just accidentally knock one off before breakfast, but hey, that's not the point.

So I've always examined their ads - always in "classy" publications such as the Sunday Times - with some fascination, wondering how it could ever get worse. Well, the current one could never be surpassed, believe me; "This month, you'll find out, if you're not completely sure already, what women want, from Karen Krizanovich, Lizzie Speller and harems of other fun-loving females. Then you can decide whether to provide for them or not. TAKE CONTROL OF YOUR LIFE NOW with the Erotic Print Society catalogue and your free Review."

I honestly believe I've never read such a sad, stunted, bleak view of human sexuality anywhere, including toilet walls. Harems of fun-loving females! Hacks who've been paid to make fools of themselves. You can decide whether to provide for them or not! Hello? And excuse me, but exactly how is it "taking control" to furtively masturbate over a photo of a woman who wouldn't look twice on you while your wife - who gave up shagging you three years ago because it was so boring - slumbers on in the sleep of the just?

Hmm . . . I don't know who the average Erotic Review reader is, but I bet he drinks Le Piat D'Or.

webTitle: Alexander Chancellor: The prince is right

fields.headline: The prince is right
fields.trailText: Poor Tony Blair may have to forego his holiday in Tuscany this summer, even if he doesn't want to.
fields.body:
Poor Tony Blair may have to forego his holiday in Tuscany this summer, even if he doesn't want to. After months of anxiety about foot and mouth, followed by a gruelling election campaign, what could be more appealing to an exhausted prime minister than the prospect of a couple of weeks in the splendid, sun-drenched villa near San Gimignano of Prince Girolamo Guicciardini Strozzi. Prince Strozzi, host to the Blairs for the past three years, would gladly have them to stay again. He said in a newspaper interview last week that he likes Blair very much, but he also seemed to want to put him off by pointing out the political disadvantages of him taking another foreign holiday this year.

"It would seem strange, as foot and mouth disease lays waste to the British tourism industry, for the prime minister to be seen going off with his family to Tuscany again," he said. "I wouldn't do it. That's for sure." But then the prince may have misjudged his man. It may seem obvious to a rich, hereditary Italian nobleman, unanswerable to any electorate and planning to support the right in next month's Italian general election, that a British Labour prime minister should holiday in Blackpool this year, but it may not seem so obvious to the prime minister himself. For while Blair dithers about lots of things and allows focus groups to determine many of his decisions, he is a man of steel on the question of holidays.

I admire him for it. When it comes to his private life - where he spends his holidays, where he sends his children to school - Blair is indifferent to public opinion. These matters are nobody's business but his own and his family's, he insists. He would never sink, like Bill and Hillary Clinton, to going on a miserable camping holiday in the Rocky Mountains just because an opinion poll said that this was what a majority of the electorate wanted them to do.

So it is just conceivable that the Blairs could still be hanging out with the Strozzis in Tuscany this summer. The prince will be surprised to see them there, for he knows the British electorate won't approve. But he is familiar with the prime minister's sturdy independence of mind about such things, which is possibly why he expressed the view in his interview that Blair is "in many ways, a bit of a Thatcherite".

Personally, I will not be diverted from going to Tuscany this August. I don't like it much in Britain at the moment, especially with the animal holocaust going on. I am not one of those optimists, who, according to new RAC findings, wilfully misinterpret road signs to mean something nice. I don't think that a sign displaying a wind-sock means "kite-flying area", or that one of a toad means there is a French restaurant ahead. I see things in a gloomier perspective.

Another good reason for going to Tuscany is the food. I want to get away for a bit from our new national dish, chicken tikka masala, which Robin Cook says perfectly illustrates "the way Britain absorbs and adapts external influences". Marmalade does that, too, being composed almost entirely of non-indigenous ingredients, but the importance of chicken tikka masala as a symbol of multiculturalism is that its origins are Asian. This makes it a handy weapon for using against "racists". You might just as well say that spaghetti or pizza are British national dishes.

In this sterile, dishonest argument about racism between Labour and the Tories, we should recognise and accept a few of the obvious facts. One is that, while Robin Cook is right in saying that the British never have been a "race" but have always constituted an amalgam of races, our sense of nationhood until recently was built principally around a shared belief in our cultural superiority over other peoples (Italians being one of them). Now that we can no longer get away with such claims, we have to base our national identity on something else. The logical step would be to follow the example of the world's most successful immigrant nation, the United States, and base it on loyalty to the constitution and to the flag.

So why does a Labour MP like Peter Bradley contemptuously accuse the Tories of "wrapping themselves in the flag", as if it were a racist thing to do? Isn't that what Labour should be doing, too? We have to have some sort of glue to hold our immigrant nation together.

fields.headline: We love each other
fields.standfirst: Jo Ralling & Geoff Guy
fields.trailText: Jo Ralling & Geoff Guy
fields.body:
Geoff: We first met at a bar in Bondi at around 6pm. After a while, our friends just got up and left. In England, Jo was used to bars closing at 11, but we stayed until the sun came up, talked through the night, and got drunker and drunker. Next morning, when we all went for breakfast, Jo disappeared. She'd gone to lie under a bush, so I regularly went to check she was all right.

Jo: The thing I remember about first seeing Geoff was his back. I hadn't even seen his face, but I thought, 'Oh, I could be in trouble here.' It was hard living around the world from each other. What really brought us together was when I did some undercover documentary film work in Burma. fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Your article, Bloody Bequest (April 21), was very partial. ETA is not glamorous, the young abertzales are not naughty guys, they are killers and accomplices; they are not martyrs but beasts.
fields.body:
Your article, Bloody Bequest (April 21), was very partial. ETA is not glamorous, the young abertzales are not naughty guys, they are killers and accomplices; they are not martyrs but beasts. The society these people want in Pais Vasco is only for nationalists. In fact, they are immersed in the dirty job of ethnic cleansing: no one who is not a nationalist can live there peacefully. Another thing I missed in your report was the opinion of ETA's victims.
anahernando@yahoo.com

At last, Julie Burchill has the home she deserves - the new Weekend is poorly written, badly structured and without substance. Even the "serious" article ( your deplorable attempt to make ETA seem fashionable) was misleading, celebrating a quasi-fascist group with minuscule support among the very people they claim to represent. I hope this regurgitated, moronic attempt to boost circulation backfires.
Ronnie MacPherson
London

PR Rowland wrote a letter (Dear Weekend, April 21) about religion, telling us in his/her signature that they are the proud possessor of an MSc, a PhD, a CChem and is an FRSC. None of this was relevant to the letter, so I only assume that PR thinks that listing initials makes an impression. It does.
Ross Bradshaw
Nottingham

Did you consider, before deciding to go glossy, how difficult it is to read print on glossy paper in direct light?
Alan Alexander
Glasgow

Congratulations for your pastiche of the Cosmo/Loaded mag culture. Who thought of those great articles? What are we like?, We love each other, Things my girlfriend and I argue about? Give them a raise. And pass on our appreciation to the design team. The shiny form matched the content. But if the Guardian is now producing Q-type magazines, whither Marie Claire?
Dermot Carney
Moseley, Birmingham

Marcel Berlins' Quiz restored to its rightful place in Weekend - justice! And in a print size I can read - joy!
John Dean Headington, Oxford

101 Things We Don't Miss? No 102 is surely cheap, humourless magazines that smell unpleasant, and are as tacky to the touch as they are to the intellect.
Bob Woodward
Winchester

Well done for the new look. I don't usually read much in supplements, but there was plenty to interest me in this one. Pity about the crab recipe, though.
Ruth King
Cardiff

It was nice to have a bit of gloss first thing on a Saturday - what a treat! And can you even begin to know the greater pleasure I experienced when I turned to The New Black, a column dedicated to black beauty? I didn't even realise that I felt neglected by you, and then I felt all loved and cared for!
Christiana Ebohon
London SE1

I thoroughly enjoyed your feature 101 Things We Don't Miss. But there was an error in No 89, "Actors who pretended to sound like Gerry Adams." There was no law banning the voices of Irish Republicans from being broadcast in news bulletins, documentaries and the like. It was mere policy - one introduced by the evil Thatch and eagerly swallowed, like mother's milk, by the nation's broadcasters.
David Northmore
London N4

Julie darling! Please switch off the autotext, we know you were married to Tony Parsons.
Mike Mitchell
Manchester

webTitle: Prada Wellingtons and a tweed suit

fields.headline: Prada Wellingtons and a tweed suit
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole  aged 34
fields.trailText: I was once besotted with Lady Penelope. She was the subject of my first sexual fantasy. I still like women who are a bit on the wooden side
fields.body:
Sunday, April 22, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

Last Sunday, I forced the boys to sit and listen to Go4it, the new Radio 4 children's programme. I was annoyed when, after only five minutes, Glenn complained, "It's for posh kids, innit?" William fell asleep during the Sir Steve Redgrave interview. I woke him and said, "Sir Steve has won five gold medals for this country. The least you can do is stay awake while he's talking."

This evening, we again sat down to listen. I was enthralled by the interview with Thunderbirds creator Gerry Anderson. I was once besotted with Lady Penelope. She was the subject of my first sexual fantasy. I still like women who are a bit on the wooden side. Pandora Braithwaite MP, the love of my life, has a carved look about her. Though it is the Labour party who are now pulling her strings. Ha ha!

She was on the news tonight, wearing Prada Wellingtons and a tweed suit, trying to assure angry country folk why a massive hole containing hundreds of thousands of noxious, decomposing cows and sheep, would not become a health hazard. A reporter shouted, "Have you signed the compact, Pandora?" She snapped, "The only compact I have any use for has the name Chanel embossed on the lid."

Monday, April 23

Pandora's remark has landed her in trouble with the CRE. She's been ordered to have her photo taken with a black or brown person. She rang to ask if William was available. I said, "The child's skin is not for hire." She asked me for Mohammed's mobile number and then rang off.

Tuesday, April 24

When I went to the BP garage for a box of Coco Pops, Mohammed was bursting with the news that Pandora had rung him and had invited herself and a Newsnight crew to dinner last night. She had requested chicken tikka masala. Mohammed said, "Me missus were a bit put out, coz she usually gets fish and chips on Tuesdays, but you can't deny Pandora owt when she orders you about in that posh voice, can you?" He asked me what side Newsnight was on.

Naturellement, I viewed the programme with great interest. Pandora was wearing her Alexander McQueen-designed Punjabi suit she'd last worn to the inaugural meeting of Ashby's Anglo-Asian women's rugby team.

fields.headline: How to... get dressed
fields.trailText: Getting dressed is a tricky business, and the worst time to attempt it is first thing in the morning. The brighter and more colourful clothes you wear, the earlier you get up.
fields.body:
Getting dressed is a tricky business, and the worst time to attempt it is first thing in the morning. The brighter and more colourful clothes you wear, the earlier you get up. Most evening people wear black because they are completely incapable of making colour-matching decisions before midday. On the other hand, people who wear fantastically bright colours get up too early, have to get dressed in the dark and can only pick out lime-green tops.

As if getting dressed weren't difficult enough, you have to take your jimjams off first, so you're not only befuddled with sleep but also numb with cold. There is a huge temptation to throw on the nearest corduroy skirt, which is why it's vital not to leave any corduroy skirts lying around when you go to bed.

Once you've got yourself suitably naked, you have to think about underwear. For many men, this is simply a question of stepping into the ones they dropped the night before, because until their pants are crawling into the laundry basket of their own accord, they are still perfectly okay for use.

Younger people often dress to be undressed, which leads them to wear all sorts of dangerous and impractical undergarments. Older people also dress to be undressed, but by a healthcare professional, which means they can relax in big, comfy pants.

The next big issue is whether to tuck your vest into your pants. This is made a lot easier if you're the absurdly macho type who doesn't wear a vest or, heaven forefend, pants. You can, of course, let your vest hang outside your pants, but this then leaves a VVL, or visible vest line, which men absolutely dread.

There are two types of men: those who put their pants on the radiator in winter and those who don't. Those who don't probably wear their pants in bed. You can, of course, pile your radiator with every single item of clothing you're going to wear the following day, which means your clothes will be as warm as toast, but you'll probably die of cold, because the radiator is completed lagged up.

Women often fling open their wardrobe first thing in the morning, look at serried racks of clothing and then panic that they've got nothing to wear. That's because women dress to suit their mood, and they don't know their mood until they're dressed. By then, it's too late.

Men dress to suit their suit. As a fall-back, everyone has one set of clothes in which they feel entirely comfortable. But it's worth remembering, before you start looking for them, that the natural home of that set of clothes is in the wash.

fields.headline: Words that should be banned
fields.standfirst: 2: Real
fields.trailText: 2: Real
fields.body:
Think not of the word, which is innocuous at worst, but of its context. Real orange juice (citric mush). Real IRA (not that I'd ever contest the importance of a violent, unrepenting rump wherever there's an imperialist oppressor, but come on: real IRAs blow up proper buildings, not post offices in Hendon). Realpolitik (grown up and sensible, rather than name-calling? Call that politiks?). Real Madrid (not a place at all, awash with streetside caffs and superior bar foods - no! A football team!). These Are My Real Breasts (trans: these are my real breasts, but only in so far as they are the ones I chose out of a catalogue and they inhabit my breast space, therefore they are real. But only until such time as they start to leak, whereupon they shall be removed, leaving only the real real ones). That's A Real Bummer (simple example of American excess, where a straightforward 'bummer' would do).

It's not the fact that it's a non-word that makes it so pernicious, it's that its modern usage is almost entirely concerned with lying, cheating, scheming, obfuscating and generally making things seem as they aren't. Without it, people would have to use the longer but more transparent 'Orange juice - and when I say orange juice, I mean that in its truest sense.' Then where would they be? They'd be having to utilise real fruit, that's where.

fields.headline: To DiY for
fields.standfirst: How to use gloss paint
fields.trailText: How to use gloss paint.
fields.body:
Some people think gloss paint is difficult to apply and smelly. Others find it boring. I was shown how to use it by an artist with an obsessive compulsive disorder, so for me gloss is all about incredible patience, delayed gratification and adrenaline.

To the usual shopping list of white spirit, primer, sandpaper, undercoat and gloss paint, the artist added gaffer tape, industrial plastic sheeting, more white spirit and surgical gloves (theoretically for hygiene, but really because he liked us wearing them). Before we were allowed anywhere near the wet stuff, there was preparation to be done. We filled and sanded, sanded and filled, and sanded and sanded to a finish of porcelain, and we hoovered the room with a soft-brush attachment. Then we wiped every surface with white spirit, and sealed the room with plastic sheeting and gaffer tape - with us on the inside. 'This is now a Dust-Free Zone,' the artist declared, using up valuable oxygen. 'Nothing comes in or out.' If you're planning to put aside a weekend for glossing, put aside two.

Try to get close to our dust-free, porcelain state during the first two days, then spend all week dreaming of dolloping on the paint. We used a separate primer and undercoat (you can buy them combined), then an extra undercoat and two coats of gloss. Between each coat we sanded, vacuumed the room and wiped with white spirit. Finally, it was time for the last coat of gloss, and trust me, there's a lot riding on this. Use a good brush to get rid of streaks. You don't have much time to correct mistakes on gloss before it dries, so keep edges 'live' by going over them repeatedly. Although eccentric, the artist was right about one thing: dust is the enemy of gloss. Prepare well. But don't go mad. You can probably do without the surgical gloves.
