webTitle: All the people I've ever slept with

fields.headline: All the people I've ever slept with
fields.standfirst: Number 2: The Teacher
fields.trailText: Number 2: The Teacher
fields.body:
I was 16. I wanted to be a famous actress. I'd never been in a play or anything, but I liked the idea of it, getting to be someone else as a job. A new English teacher started that term. He was tall, dark and not like other teachers. He said he'd help me prepare for my audition for the next production, The Three Sisters. The best way to do that, he said, was to go round his house after school and talk about Chekhov.

Brahms was hissing out of the tiny cassette recorder on the floor of his sitting room, and it felt grown up to be discussing literature, even though I was still wearing my uniform. He let me smoke his Marlboro Lights. The tape squeezed to the end of its run and I bent down to turn it over. He was standing over me.

'Do you mind if I . . . ?' he kissed me and took my hand.

'I haven't been able to sleep because I've wanted you to lie on my bed.' I lay on the mattress and he climbed on top of me. His face moved in and out of the shadows cast by the streetlights. I imagined myself in a movie where things like this happened.

Next week: the best friend.

fields.headline: Your personal trainer
fields.standfirst:
Got a fitness problem? 
We have the answers . . .
fields.trailText:
Got a fitness problem? 
We have the answers . . .
fields.body:
Will spinning make my legs bulky?
This is a question women often ask, and also a common misconception. The answer is no. Spinning - high-energy classes on static bikes - will not make your legs look bigger. In order to provoke the human growth hormone, you must work against high resistance measured roughly by the performance of 8-12 repetitions. In an endurance-based exercise such as spinning, or indeed long-distance running, when you are carrying out numerous repetitions, your legs will not increase in muscle size or bulk. Hence the difference in build between a sprinter and a long-distance runner. The sprinter is muscle bound (power-based training), the long-distance athlete is slim (endurance-based training).

I get cramp very easily: what is the cause and what can I do to avoid it?
Cramp can be caused by either dehydration, lack of body salt (sodium), or both. Sodium is required for nerve and muscle action and is also required to ingest water. Water, however, is lost during prolonged exercise (as sweat) and takes with it sodium. To avoid cramp, aim to remain hydrated at all times. To relieve it, try light stretching and manipulation of the affected muscle.

Chris St George is fitness director of The Third Space in London, 020-7439 7333. Send your questions to: Your Personal Trainer, Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Down in one
fields.standfirst: Lillet
fields.trailText: Lillet
fields.body:
Or 'lil-lay', as you should carefully pronounce it in order to avoid any unfortunate confusion with a well-known feminine hygiene product. This old-fashioned, wine-based aperitif is apparently creeping back into fashion.

Made in the Graves region of Bordeaux since 1887, there are white and red versions, both of them based on the local grape varieties. The rather sexier Lillet Blanc - which has an appealingly sweet, fragrant, Mary Archerish quality - is made from sauvignon blanc and semillon blended with liqueurs from 10 different fruits and fruit peels. It should be drunk chilled or (better still) on the rocks, and is, so the French say, frightfully good with foie gras. A rather more appetising partner than human brains, which is how Hannibal Lecter prefers it, apparently. James Bond is another fan - Lillet is the base for the famous Vesper Martini in Casino Royale: three parts gin to one part vodka and a half part Lillet Blanc - shaken, of course, not stirred.

So who else drinks it? New Yorkers are nuts for it, apparently, consuming more than a million glasses a year. Here, you can buy it from Berry Bros & Rudd (0870 900 4300) for £10.50 a bottle.

So who else drinks it? New Yorkers are nuts for it, apparently, consuming more than a million glasses a year. Here, you can buy it from Berry Bros & Rudd (0870 900 4300) for £10.50 a bottle.

fields.headline: Feed me
fields.standfirst: Dig in organic matter to feed the soil, allow in air, improve drainage and loosen the ground for roots
fields.trailText: Dig in organic matter to feed the soil, allow in air, improve drainage and loosen the ground for roots.
fields.body:
Garden compost: Make your own - build a compost bin, and chuck in grass clippings, kitchen scraps (but not meat), plant prunings (shred anything woody) and young, annual weeds that have not yet produced seed. Leave it until it's dark and crumbly.

Manufactured compost: Sold by the bag, with a range of specialist uses that are easy to deduce: seed, potting, ericaceous (for acid-loving plants), etc.

Animal manures: Encourages good bacteria and fungi in the soil. Horse manure is the easiest to find, but make sure it is well rotted, or it will use up nitrogen in the soil.

Leaf mould: Made from decomposed leaves; encourages useful bacterial action in the soil.

Peat: Avoid, as it is often harvested from endangered habitats.

Mushroom compost: Alkaline in nature, so great for clay, not acid, soils.

Seaweed: Composted before use. Rich in trace elements. Available in liquid form.

Green manures: A crop grown to keep the soil covered and weed-free, then dug into the soil to improve it without composting (eg, mustard or clover).

Mulch: Anything spread over the soil to suppress weeds, keep the soil warm, promote root growth and conserve moisture. Use composts that will feed the soil, too: landscape fabric (weed-proof membrane spread around plants), gravel, old carpet or bark chips.

Fertiliser: To keep plants fit and healthy. Don't go mad with it, or your plants may overdose. There are two types: inorganic (chemically derived) and organic (eg, fish, blood and bone), which is pretty well-balanced and takes six to 10 weeks to disappear from the soil.

fields.headline: The green-eyed monster
fields.standfirst: We're warned to beware of jealousy, the fiend 'which doth mock the meat it feeds on', yet we still tangle with it regularly. And when sex is involved, things get really complicated. Virginia Mallin confronts the beast.
fields.trailText: We're warned to beware of jealousy, the fiend 'which doth mock the meat it feeds on', yet we still tangle with it regularly. And when sex is involved, things get really complicated. Virginia Mallin confronts the beast.
fields.body:
It's not many of us who can say we haven't experienced jealousy about someone to whom we are emotionally or sexually attached. Most adult relationships will have known - to a greater or lesser degree - the angst of jealousy at some time or another, and probably all of us can remember those intensely jealous feelings in the school playground when our best friend went off, or even when there was only the threat of them going off, with a rival playmate.

Jealousy exists from early childhood, when we, as infants, first have unconsciously to negotiate the difficulties of sharing our primary love object.

If we can successfully come to terms with the fact that mother is sexually bonded to father and is not our sole possession, then we move on to finding our own sexual and emotional partnerships as we enter adulthood. But growing up doesn't mean we necessarily put away childish feelings of insecurity, and quite intense rivalry can, and does, reappear when future relationships in which we have invested emotionally are, or seem to be, threatened with infidelity or betrayal. And, as adults, betrayal involving sexual intimacy seems to affect us the most.

Jealousy is a universal phenomenon for men and women, girls and boys, and children and their parents. But it is interesting to ponder the nature of sexual jealousy, and whether everyone feels the same sort of jealousy. Is it different, depending on how much we view the betrayal as a real threat to our security? Is it gender-based? Is one type of betrayal worse than another?

Most of us recognise that, when it comes to jealousy, there is a "sliding scale" of strength of reaction. Conventional thinking has it that a woman is more likely to be forgiving of a "one-night stand" if she feels that her partner is not going to repeat it; that it was purely a sexual fling.

But she would feel terribly hurt, furious and threatened if her partner seems to have fallen in love with another woman, because that represents a real threat to him staying emotionally connected to her. It is generally thought that a man might not worry so much about his partner's emotional liking for another male, but once sex enters the equation that same man will "hit the roof".

Freud's explanation for this was that, biologically, a man's instinctive drive is to protect his chances of impregnating his partner, while a woman needs to ensure that her progeny are raised in optimum security, so she needs emotional commitment from her partner.

But dividing this discussion into the male/female split is far too simplistic. As with everything, how we view life is always a matter of individual perception, based on our personalities, our upbringing, our emotional maturity, our circumstances and our emotional "pain threshold". The "truth" of a situation is as variable as there are individuals.

For boys and girls, the first love object is mother - and is, therefore, incestuous. To achieve heterosexual maturity, boys then have to struggle for identification with the father and become rivals for the original love object. Girls, initially experiencing gender identification with the mother, then have to transfer their sexual attachment to the father.

However, other complications exist, because the boy is jealous of, but also attracted to, the father in his attempts to identify with him, and the girl also is both attracted to her mother and in competition with her for the attentions of father and, later, men in general. That all this goes on unconsciously does not impede the power of these ambivalent emotions; on the contrary, unconscious feelings can often direct us more forcefully from within than can conscious ones, and they always play an influential part in our thoughts, actions and relationships.

But while sex can, and does, happen without emotional attachment, and emotional attachment can, and does, exist without sex, to imply that men have only a superficial view of sex as something divorced from emotional content and that women can deny sexuality, and its importance and connectedness with emotion, is to create a split between two inextricably linked fundamentals of our existence. While defences are originally put in place for a reason, to protect from pain - and jealousy could be viewed as a defence against loss and a spur to preventative or vengeful action - the psyche aims for balance and wholeness: defences can become a negative influence when they are out of balance, as they distort and magnify one aspect of our inner psychological world at the expense of another, and feelings can be split off from one another when, actually, they need to be integrated so that each is useful to us in informing our actions and reactions.

Virginia Mallin is a psychodynamic counsellor and a member of the Foundation for Psychotherapy and Counselling. Referral service, 020-7721 7661.

fields.headline: Let's move to...
fields.standfirst: Leigh-on-Sea, Essex
fields.trailText: Leigh-on-Sea, Essex
fields.body:
Where do you want to be an hour after work: eating a plate of cockles, toes dangling in the sea, or stuck on a bus for Streatham? No disrespect to Streatham, but I'll plump for Leigh-on-Sea. London house prices are criminal. Don't moan: commute from Leigh, with cheap homes and sea air to cheer you up after work.

Ups: London's nearest seaside. Glorious sea views. Cheap and quaint houses.

Downs: Tiny beach. Chemical works add spice to the sunsets. Only good for London if you work in/near the City.

Getting around: Fenchurch or Liverpool Street 45 minutes away (every 10-20 minutes; annual season ticket £2,220). Locally there's buses (Southend 15-20 mins) or the train (Southend 10 mins).

Schools: Primaries: Heycroft and West Leigh. Secondaries: Southend High School for Girls, and Boys, and Westcliff High School for Girls, and Boys. For independents, St Hilda's (for girls) and St Michael's prep.

Property: Old Leigh, the cobbled fishing village, has pretty clapboard or brick houses. More on the hill to the new town, where there's Victorian homes in ice-cream colours. Chalkwell has great Edwardian detached homes. One-bedroom flats £50,000-£75,000; two-bedroom houses £130,000-£170,000. Estate agents line the Broadway: Castle Estates (01702 710610), Abbotts (01702 715262) and many more.

fields.headline: A touch of the herbals
fields.standfirst:
If we can reap the benefits of alternative treatments, might they not also work
on our pets? Janet Wright weighs up the evidence
fields.trailText:
If we can reap the benefits of alternative treatments, might they not also work
on our pets? Janet Wright weighs up the evidence.
fields.body:
When the actor David Arquette was recently reported to have consulted a hypnotherapist to stop his dog snoring, it was hard not to snigger. But this was not the behaviour of some self-obsessed Hollywood celeb that it at first seemed, for we are now embracing alternative therapies for our pets as eagerly as for ourselves. Herbal remedies for rabbits, Bach flower remedies for dogs, therapeutic touch for cats, Ayurvedic medicine for horses: someone out there is offering it.

They're not all new-age practitioners, either. Many vets are taking a fresh look at ways of healing, too. At his Oxfordshire clinic, Christopher Day uses a range of alternative treatments as a first measure, reserving drugs and surgery only for what, he says, are those rare occasions when they're really needed. Susan and Martyn Bittleston went to him after their usual vet suggested putting down their Ridgeback dog, Millie. "She lost the use of her back legs suddenly for no apparent reason," says Susan. "After examining her, Day gave her acupuncture: 11 needles down her spine and one in her forehead. He used a laser to stimulate points on her feet. It didn't cause her any distress. She just lay there, very relaxed. After the second session, a week later, she could stand. And after the next, she started walking for the first time in six weeks."

For much the same reasons as Day, London vet David Boersma added homeopathy to his repertoire last year. "I was no longer happy using conventional medicine alone - there were cases I just couldn't treat. I saw animals with cancer deteriorating more rapidly after chemotherapy and surgery than after alternative therapies. Now I give clients the option of trying a homeopathic remedy."

The British Veterinary Association now considers alternative medicine as "another weapon in the veterinary surgeon's armoury", says a spokeswoman, while Tory MP David Tredinnick went so far as to suggest adopting alternative tactics in the battle against foot and mouth: "If homeopathy is good for humans," he told parliament earlier this month, "it is good for animals." With such rousing endorsements, it is hardly surprising that alternative therapies for pets now mirror developments in mainstream human medicine. NHS consultant dermatologist Dr Nick Mann thought of using evening primrose oil to treat his cat's eczema only because "it's something doctors use as an adjunct in treating eczema in humans", he says. "The cat certainly benefited from it, too."

Critics of alternative medicine often argue that any positive effects on human patients are all in the mind, but when it comes to animals the results are harder to explain away - unless, of course, our pets are reacting favourably to these treatments because we are soothed by the expectation of success. Animal psychologist Dr Deborah Wells of Belfast University says that animals can pick up an "amazing" amount from their owners, but adds that the physical improvements from alternative treatment can also be measured in real terms. "I don't think it's just a question of owners being soothed. A lot of vets treat physical problems such as arthritis with acupuncture, for example, and some vets and animal behaviour therapists recommend herbal remedies, too."

There is still very little research in this field, however, and much of what does exist was carried out on farm animals, which are unlikely to have developed any great emotional bond with their owners. Even so, sceptics will find it hard to explain why some of the most esoteric remedies are being sought by hard-headed business folk. "It's a big thing now," says Roy Hutcheson of the National Federation of Spiritual Healers. "We're often called on to heal working animals, especially at the start of the racing season."

If spiritual healing can keep racehorses fit, could hypnotherapy really cure Arquette's snoring dog? Perhaps, although hypnotherapist Jean Credland thinks this may be an alternative too far: "You could probably hypnotise a dog, but how would you communicate the command to stop snoring? Telepathy? Better leave the jury out on that one."

For a practitioner in your area, call the British Association of Homeopathic Veterinary Surgeons, 01367 718115; or the Association of British Veterinary Acupuncturists, 020-7937 8215.

fields.headline: Under the weather
fields.standfirst: Fantasising about summer in a new conservatory? Then it pays to think ahead. Charlotte Abrahams has answers to the 10 crucial questions you'll need to ask before starting out
fields.trailText: Fantasising about summer in a new conservatory? Then it pays to think ahead. Charlotte Abrahams has answers to the 10 crucial questions you'll need to ask before starting out.
fields.body:
Do I need planning permission?

That depends upon what kind of conservatory you're after. Building regulations state that conservatories are exempt if built onto domestic dwellings, separated by a door (so that's your open-plan space out, I'm afraid) and if they increase the building's floor space by no more than 30 sq metres (which is big enough to sit and enjoy the garden, but not big enough for that eight-seater glass dining table you've been dreaming of). If you've already had an extension the council may decide you've done enough. You may also run into trouble if you live in a conservation area. The good news is that if you're having your conservatory built for you, then sorting all the red tape is the builder's responsibility.

What should my conservatory be made of?

There are three main materials: timber, aluminium or uPVC (that's plastic to you and me). Timber and aluminium are the most expensive, and which you choose comes down to personal taste. Timber is flexible, so if you want mouldings and twiddley bits to fit in with your period house it's probably the best choice, although you'll have to look after the paintwork if you want it to last. Aluminium is light on maintenance (other than an annual wash) but it is uncompromisingly modern, so you - or your council - may not think it suits your house. uPVC is cheap and low maintenance, but it is noisy and can yellow with age.

What are the building options?

Again, you have three choices: the cheapest is a self-assembly kit available from most DIY stores, but you do need to be fairly competent - are you really up to dealing with foundations and brick laying? If not, then you can buy a conservatory from a stock design built to order, or, if you have a large enough budget, you can commission a bespoke number. Always check that the site you have chosen is suitable (and check sun and wind directions). A level, damp-proof and insulated base is essential.

What about the glass?

What you choose depends on your priorities. Toughened glass is quiet, but it shatters if anything - or anyone - crashes into it. Laminated glass provides more soundproofing and is safer because it breaks in one piece. If you plan to use your conservatory all year round, you will need double glazing.

What about the roof?

Choose between glass, which is translucent but heavy, so is unsuitable for some structures, or polycarbonate, which is light and strong but only semi-translucent.

How much will it cost?

How much have you got? You can set your budget and find a conservatory to fit. But as a guide, a 4m x 4m bespoke timber conservatory will set you back around £30,000 (including building costs), while a home-constructed uPVC one can be bought for less than £3,000.

How do I regulate the temperature?

If you're freezing in the winter and frying in the summer, then you've got something wrong. Double glazing and central heating (which must be able to be switched off if the conservatory is attached to the house) will deal with winter chills, and manual or automatic roof vents will keep the heat down in the summer. Light-reflecting, bronzed glass or blinds will also help to keep the sun out.

What about lighting?

Lighting is very important (natural light is fabulous, of course, but a bit limited at night), and you need to think about it at the start of the building process rather than the end. If you're planning to fix lights to the rafters, then the channels for the wires need to be cut at the factory. Also, think about lighting the garden: at night, a lit conservatory will just reflect the blackness outside, but a well-lit garden will add depth and interest to your new room.

And what if I want the look but I don't have any space to spare?

No problem. That light, indoor/outdoor thing can easily be achieved by replacing a flat roof with a pitched glass one and installing a pair of French windows.

Who do I call?

Bartholomew Conservatories, for modern and traditional stock and bespoke timber designs (01428 658771). Amdega, for all shapes and sizes of stock and bespoke timber conservatories (0800 591523). Machin, for stock and bespoke aluminium conservatories (01325 360776). Lloyd Christie Garden Architecture, for modern and traditional bespoke timber designs (020-7243 6466). Wickes, for timber and uPVC conservatories in a kit (0500 300328 for your nearest branch; technical advice is available on 0870 601 1030). The Conservatory Association, for advice and a list of over 200 members (020-7207 5873).

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Richard Ehrlich on a new venture from Iqbal Wahhab, the reissued Pan Cooks series and M&S's new ready meal line, Steam Cuisine.
fields.body:
The ready meal

If I had my way, everyone would buy good ingredients and cook them from scratch every day. But since no porcine aviators have been spotted lately, I acknowledge the demand for quick, pre-packaged foods. And since they've gotta exist, they've gotta new standard to beat: M&S's Steam Cuisine. These are not foods for reheating in the microwave, but for cooking. They incorporate a 'widget' in the top, so you don't have to pierce any plastic, and the flavours are almost astonishingly clean and vivid. Prices aren't scary, either: from £2.49 for a pasta with summer vegetables, to £3.49 for haddock, new potatoes, fresh veg and cheese sauce. Complaint: the pasta ends up a bit squidgy. Apart from that, these tubs are tops.

The books

Intelligent cookery publishing doesn't always mean spotting the next trend or hot new chef. It often involves reissuing books that the original publishers were dumb enough to allow to go out of print. By this measure, the new Pan Cooks series has an IQ of 185. That's the high number. The low number is the price, £6.99, made possible by a no-frills, no-pics approach to texts of high quality.

The first quartet comprises Jeremy Round's The Independent Cook, Annie Bell's Evergreen, Simon Hopkinson's Gammon And Spinach, and Darina Allen's Simply Delicious Suppers. Good books all, but I'm particularly pleased to see The Independent Cook, by a gifted writer who died just over a decade ago at a heartbreakingly young age. You should make his acquaintance, courtesy of Pan.

The restaurant

Iqbal Wahhab was canned as editor of Tandoori magazine for daring to suggest that service in Indian restaurants sometimes falls a bit short. So he turned his hand to running restaurants, and his debut at Tabla, Canary Wharf, bodes well for this swish sequel. The Cinnamon Club, a 180-seater plus bar and (hiss!) members' bar, has several distinctive features. It's grandly housed in the Grade II-listed Old Westminster Library. Its makeover has been trebly overseen by an interior designer, graphic designer and ïIndian stylist'. And the cooking is doubly overseen by head chef Vivek Singh and consultant chef Eric Chavot, of the doubly Michelin-starred Capital Hotel. Spices: air-freighted monthly from India. Cuisine: Indian-meets-haute. Service: early reports suggest it can take an remarkably long time to get such inessential items as food, drink and wine list. You might want to take a book along, or maybe a recent issue of Tandoori. The Cinnamon Club, The Old Westminster Library, Great Smith Street, London SW1, 020-7222 2555.

The blender

Expensive kitchen hardware has to justify itself with maximum utility and durability. KitchenAid blenders, those retro-chic electrical kings, deliver the goods in both categories. Latest recruit: the Ultra Power Plus. Technical details: 500-watt motor, 10 speeds, pulse button, dishwasher-safe stainless-steel jar, a ïstep start' feature that begins at low speed to beat splatters, and an ïauto shut-off' mechanism that protects against overheating. All that, plus blades by Sabatier. If you want a blender that'll do everything, this could be your man: KitchenAid Ultra Power Plus Blender, £149, from John Lewis, and good department stores and kitchen shops nationwide.

fields.headline: Do I have to?
fields.trailText: ''You know what? We are going to get you thin," Roly whispers conspiratorially as I huff and puff up the treadmill that he has rashly set on an incline today.'
fields.body:
'You know what? We are going to get you thin," Roly whispers conspiratorially as I huff and puff up the treadmill that he has rashly set on an incline today. He wants to increase my workload but, come on, 1%, thatÕs going it a bit, isnÕt it? "I donÕt want to get thin," I insist. "The aim was to get fit, and even thatÕs debatable now if itÕs going to prove this torturous, but thin was never in my sights."

"No, we are going to get you thin, trust me," Roly beams back, clearly not able to compute a sentence containing the words not, want and thin.

"Sorry, Roly," and I do feel sorry because by now, week two, I worship him and really wish I could be what he wants me to want to be. In a swift seven days IÕve gone from stroppy teenager to prefect straight out of Swot High. IÕm thinking of bringing him an apple next week (WhatÕs that, about 80 calories if itÕs a big one? And itÕd have to be for my Roly). But my defiant nature prevails Ñ I do not want to be thin. There is no "real" me inside, struggling to squeeze out past all that flesh. This body, saddle bags, stomach rolls and all, is the "real" me. And the "real" me just wants to be able to open a jar of macadamia nuts without breaking into a sweat, okay?

But as I limp along, I find myself brooding on my mentorÕs words Ñ "We are going to get you thin!" If there was any hope of a "we" getting me thin, then I might give it a whirl. If a "we" could come round my house, cook me low-fat, high-fibre, nutritious meals every day, then come on you "we-s". But, of course, there is no "we". Roly can "we" all he likes. He can afford to "we" until heÕs blue in the face because thereÕs only a "me" hoicking myself up the treadmill as far as I can see. ThereÕs only one "I" shuddering through 40 sit-ups with a huge ball jammed strategically under my thighs to make the exercise harder.

For slim-is-a-way-of-life-Roly, it is inconceivable that I donÕt hanker after the state of thin. Naturally, IÕd welcome the idea of a little less reverberation in the underarm region when flagging down a taxi. But if "thin" is the only way I get there, forget it; IÕll just leave sleeveless to the babes. "Thin" means changing my life. It means thinking about every single little thing that goes into my mouth, and itÕs a long time since IÕve done that. Oh dear, Roly and I are going to have to take some time out. "WeÕve" got some talking to do.

 Arabella Weir is the author of Does My Bum Look Big In This? Her get-fit diary appears weekly. She trains at the Laboratory health club, London, 020-8482 3000.

fields.headline: The perfect duck breast
fields.trailText: Crisp-skinned, rosy-pink duck breasts are delicious, and only slightly tricky to cook. Restaurants usually brown them savagely on both sides, then finish off the cooking in a furnace-hot oven. At home, you can do it all on the hob.
fields.body:
Crisp-skinned, rosy-pink duck breasts are delicious, and only slightly tricky to cook. Restaurants usually brown them savagely on both sides, then finish off the cooking in a furnace-hot oven. At home, you can do it all on the hob.

The prep: get a heavy-based frying pan medium-hot, and prick the skin all over.

The cooking: skin down, gentle sizzle, spoon out the fat (thereÕll be lots of it) to save for frying potatoes.

Within 10-20 minutes, depending on subcutaneous fat levels (which, in turn, depend on breed and rearing conditions), the skin will be mahogany brown. Salt, turn, and cook at a slightly higher heat for five to 10 minutes more. They should now feel barely springy to the touch. Transfer to heated plates and rest for a minute.

A&E measure: if the meat is too pink once sliced, return to the hot pan for a few seconds.

Restaurant method: do unto the skin as above, then brown the flesh briefly. Finish in an oven turned all the way up for 10 minutes. One trick you shouldnÕt try at home - the version I ate in the restaurant of a so-called celebrity chef: skin: inedibly under-cooked; flesh: inedibly overcooked. A miracle.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Peer would be a cut above
General union GMB is to put forward the name of Maria Hicks, a 27-year-old hairdresser from Sheffield, to become a people's peer after discovering that the first 15 successful candidates announced on Thursday did not include any such workers.
fields.body:
Peer would be a cut above
General union GMB is to put forward the name of Maria Hicks, a 27-year-old hairdresser from Sheffield, to become a people's peer after discovering that the first 15 successful candidates announced on Thursday did not include any such workers.

`I talk to people of all ages and different backgrounds every day and I think it is prejudiced to say only certain types should become a peer,' Ms Hicks said.

Stars save rehab clinic
Rock stars have stumped up £60,000 to keep open a treatment centre in west London after pleas from Pete Townsend of the Who, a reformed alcoholic.

Cheques sent by Eric Clapton, Mick Jagger, Phil Collins, Paul Simon and Roger Waters will keep the Chaucer Clinic, which treats homeless addicts free alongside fee-paying celebrities, in business for the next six months.

Firm fined for trench death
A judge fined a leisure company £30,000 after an employee suffered an `agonising' death when a trench caved in.

Cardiff crown court heard that Andrew Newberry, 31, was laying drainage pipes in a trench in May 1997 at a caravan park near Newport when the walls collapsed. The park's owner, Berkeley Leisure Group, pleaded guilty last year to breaching health and safety laws.

Peace activists acquitted
Veteran peace campaigners Lindis Percy and Anni Rainbow were found not guilty of obstruction outside the US eavesdropping base at Menwith Hill, North Yorkshire. District judge Peter Nuttall ruled at Harrogate magistrates court that they had a right to peaceful protest.

Secombe statue
Council chiefs are to erect a bronze statue of comedian Sir Harry Secombe in Swansea, close to the house where he was born in 1921. Secombe died of cancer this month aged 79.

fields.headline: Saturday matinees make cinema comeback
fields.standfirst:
Film company set up 50 years ago aims to woo young audiences with the best of British fiction

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Film company set up 50 years ago aims to woo young audiences with the best of British fiction
fields.body:
The great British tradition of Saturday morning cinema enjoyed by millions of children in the 1950s and 60s is set for a modest revival, as part of a drive to bring a regular diet of quality British fiction to the big screen for the under-12s.

The company set up 50 years ago today to make children's films... and which also helped launch the careers of many TV and film stars... is hoping to wrench youngsters away from their PlayStations, videos and computers with a new series of movies for special Saturday matinees.

Launched in 1951 by Lord Rank of the Rank Organisation, the Children's Film Foundation had a specific remit to make films for children to be screened at Saturday morning matinees to build up the cinema audiences of the future. In the early and middle 1950s, an estimated 1m children packed into Saturday matinees in nearly 2,000 ABC, Odeon, Gaumont, Granada and independent cinemas.

Typically two or three short films and a cartoon were shown to the eager audiences, at a special ticket price.

But the foundation's work was curtailed by the arrival of television, which led to a dramatic slump in the number of film goers, while the growth in children's Saturday morning television, weekend school-related activities and the popularity of hi-tech entertainment through computers and Playstations eventually killed off the regular films for youngsters.

Over the past 10 years the foundation has been under threat because of funding difficulties, and recently has concentrated mainly on script development for children's television and films.

Yesterday Anna Home, chief executive of the renamed Children's Film and Television Foundation, said the organisation's future lay in making films. It was in "active talks" with the film council and prospective private sector partners with a view to commissioning and producing films based on new British fiction.

"We are certainly talking about a revival of the films that would be suitable for Saturday morning cinema", she said. "There is clearly a need for quality fiction on the screen for the under-12 age group... whether there is a market for it is another matter but we clearly hope so." Youngsters and their parents might appreciate the value of good quality films commissioned from the best of British writers and based on new or existing work, Ms Home added.

One of the books being developed as a film, for example, was Junk by Melvyn Burgess. "Fiction has to have a future," she said, "and there is more to films for this age-group than just blockbusters. But it is not a matter of replacing what children do on computers and PlayStations, but creating a mixed diet." She pointed out that some independent cinemas such as the Everyman in Hampstead, north London, had already started a revival by launching a Saturday morning cinema club.

In its heyday in the 50s and 60s the foundation made up to six low budget films a year. These helped to launch the acting careers of stars such as Jean Simmons, Michael Crawford, Francesca Annis, Dennis Waterman, Susan George (soon to join EastEnders), Pauline Quirke and Linda Robson... all then still children.

Significantly, the films were able to use child actors for the first time following a ground-breaking relaxation in government rules which had for 20 years banned youngsters from films by a law which sought "to protect them". But despite such a promising start, the foundation's funding became increasingly precarious, particularly after the scrapping of the Eady levy... a tax on cinema seats... in 1981.

The company then struck deals with TV companies for the right to screen selected features.

In 1987 it was renamed the Children's Film and Television Foundation, and has since generated most of its income from its `assets', the films on its back catalogue, on TV.

Its focus on script development has led to projects such as the recent TV children's series The Borrowers and The Magician's House and collaboration with Portobello Pictures on Danny the Champion of the World (made in 1989) featuring Jeremy Irons and his son Sam as Danny.

It is among the films being shown this morning at a special anniversary screening, hosted by the British Film Institute, at the Odeon in Leicester Square, London, attended by the stars whose careers were launched by the films and, appropriately, shown to their seats by usherettes in 50s' period dress.

Young stars who shone

Children's films which launched the stars

Francesca Annis The Cat Gang (1958)
Michael Crawford Blow Your Own Trumpet (1958)
Sadie Frost A Horse called Jester (1980)
Susan George Cup Fever (1965)
Pauline Quirke The Trouble with 2B (1972)
Sally Thomsett Seven Deadly Pills (1964)
Dennis Waterman Go Kart Go (1964)

fields.headline: Prostitute beaten to death
fields.trailText: Bradford detectives are hunting the killer of a young prostitute who suffered what they described as a 'sustained, vicious and brutal beating'.
fields.body:
Bradford detectives are hunting the killer of a young prostitute who suffered what they described as a 'sustained, vicious and brutal beating'.

The naked body of Rebecca Hall, 19, mother of a four-month-old son, was found in an alley in the city's red light district on Thursday. She may have lain there for three days.

Ms Hall, known to friends as Goofy because of her protruding front teeth, died as a result of severe head injuries.

She was last seen on the night of Good Friday when she left her home in the Little Horton area to go to work.

'Her body was exposed to the elements and there were items of clothing nearby,' said Detective Chief Superintendent Max McLean.

'We are anxious to know what happened to her in the days before her body was found. It is important that people who know her, or have seen her since Easter, get in touch.'

Detectives have been unable to establish a motive for the killing.

Ms Hall, one of five sisters, was described as 5ft 5in tall and of a slim build. Her dyed red hair was cut in a bob style. When last seen she was wearing black leggings and a purple see-through top.

Her son Jordan is being cared for by his grandmother.

fields.headline: Representing the nation
fields.trailText: Lord Stevenson's extraordinary revelation that "one criterion is that the human being will be comfortable in the House of Lords" (Sketch, April 27) may explain the shameful fact that the list of 15 new top people's peers only includes four women.
fields.body:
Lord Stevenson's extraordinary revelation that "one criterion is that the human being will be comfortable in the House of Lords" (Sketch, April 27) may explain the shameful fact that the list of 15 new top people's peers only includes four women.

As a long-legged six-foot male I can report that the red leather benches are extremely comfortable. But my shorter-legged female colleagues don't agree, since their feet don't reach the ground and they cannot get their bottoms in the back of the seat without their feet sticking out in front of them.

But do we go to either house to be 'comfortable'? It's almost a year since I turned up as a "working peer", a polite term for a party hack with the job of working for my party, speaking up for liberal principles and doing my small bit to help hold an arrogant government with a huge majority in the Commons to some kind of account.

So do I feel comfortable there? Do I heck as like! I can live with the flummery, with the extravagance of the building, with being called 'My Lord' by the staff, and with being addressed as 'the noble Lord' in debate. The titles are archaic but it's really no different from the formal courtesies of being called 'Councillor Greaves' for the last quarter of a century.

What is really uncomfortable is being able to exercise the privileges of being a member of parliament without having had to seek a single vote. In a democracy all 700 of us should be booted out... aristocrats, top people's peers and street-level politicians like me... and our replacements elected by PR. But first those of you who are not debarred from voting in the coming election need to vote Liberal Democrat, since no other party will dare to do it!
Tony Greaves
House of Lords
tonygreaves@cix.co.uk

You are wrong to say that elections are the 'only way' to produce a more representative upper house (Leaders, April 27). This would merely produce a different political class to that which currently occupies the House of Lords, and similar in most respects to the Commons... neither of which are "representative" in the sense you mean. The principle of (s)election should be a biannual lottery for which all voters would be eligible. Not only would this produce hairdressers and hod-carriers, it would also enliven the political landscape immeasurably. Imagine the biannual national excitement at the prospect of trousering those fat expense claims that go with membership of the House of Lords.
Prof Andrew Dobson
Keele University

You claim that election is the only way to get an upper house which is representative of the wider nation and free of patronage. There is an alternative: the upper house could be chosen by lot. This would achieve freedom from patronage far more effectively than election, while avoiding the objection that an elected upper house would become a rival of the Commons.
Nick Gotts
Aberdeen
nickgotts@hotmail.com

You no longer have to be a toff to join the Lords, but you do need an independent income or an employer rich and generous enough to give you lots of time off on full pay. The prime minister is said to be thinking about salaried peerages, but until then the initiative remains an empty gesture. Haircut, my Lord?

Nursing Director, Emap Healthcare
jane.salvage@emap.com

London
liamshort@hotmail.com

fields.headline: The house that we built
fields.standfirst: As the Royal Festival Hall prepares to turn 50,  Jonathan Glancey  celebrates this idealistic, grandiose, shabby, mucked-around palace of the people
fields.trailText: As the Royal Festival Hall prepares to turn 50, Jonathan Glancey celebrates this idealistic, grandiose, shabby, mucked-around palace of the people.
fields.body:
King George VI declared the Royal Festival Hall open on May 3, 1951. Sadly, a number of VIPs attending the event - including Gerald Barry, director general of the Festival of Britain, and the Lord Mayor of London - missed His Majesty's declaration: they were stuck in a lift inside Britain's first major post-war public building. Embarrassing that; yet in the 50 years since, the Royal Festival Hall - the "people's palace" - has been one of the most trouble-free and best-liked modern buildings in Britain.

Intellectually rigorous, elegant, impeccably built and open to all comers, the hall was and remains a triumph of democratic public design. It introduced the British public to a form of modern architecture that had been brewing since soon after the first world war, in Germany, France and the Soviet Union, but arrived here late and generally unappreciated. Although in many ways original, the RFH owed its pedigree to the radical architecture of early Soviet architects as much as it did to the less strident Scandinavian modernism that must have seemed so attractive to the hall's young British architects.

Those architects included Robert Matthew, Leslie Martin, Peter Moro and Edwin Williams. When the new concert hall was commissioned from the London County Council architects' department in September 1948, most of the design team, led by Matthew, were under 40. They produced what Wagner would have called a Gesamkunstwerk - a complete artwork. Although not quite completed when opened as the heart of the Festival of Britain, the building brought together the very best talents the nation had to offer.

Its foyers were light and generous, reflections of the Thames rippling from its whiter-than-white ceilings on sunny days. (It rained and rained throughout the Festival of Britain.) The 3,165-seat auditorium was raised on stilts inside the generous volume of the stone-clad structure, so that it sat, as Martin said, like an "egg in a box". This was a stroke of genius - and it still surprises. Because you can see from one side of the RFH to the other, through big windows, the auditorium appears to have done a runner. In fact, it's up above you, a surprise of warm wood, swallow-nest boxes and plush seats. It has a magnificent organ designed by Ralph Downes . . . all 10,000 tons of it. Lined in double concrete walls to keep the noise of trains crossing Hungerford Bridge at bay, it is as "rich and as sensual", according to its architects, "as 1951 would allow an interior".

The reason for placing the auditorium above the foyers was not to show how clever the architects were but to solve a very basic problem: although situated on a magnificent bend on the River Thames, the site itself was tight, hemmed in on one side by Hungerford railway bridge and on the other by what was scheduled to become the Royal National Theatre. The solution? Build upwards so as to maximise public circulation space in the building.

"We have taken a cube of space roughly 200ft square and 80ft high," wrote Martin at the time. "Within this space we have modelled and sculpted out the shape of the component parts and, as you move through the foyers and promenades, if you are aware of the excitement of its vistas and its continual unfolding of space, we shall not have failed." They haven't.

For all its cool, rational logic, the RFH weaves a quiet magic on the 3m people who pass through its unpretentious portals each year (the numbers increased dramatically from 1983 when the foyer doors were thrown open all day).

The real wonder, though, is that it was built at all. In 1948, with Britain worn out by war, the only buildings approved for capital expenditure were homes, schools and factories. The RFH went ahead, however, with a budget of £2m (it came in less than 1% over budget), with Herbert Morrison, Lord President of Council and former leader of the London County Council acting as its guardian angel. In the event, the RFH took just 20 months to build, a remarkably short time given the constraints of the time and the radical nature of its design.

The RFH meant a great deal to the music world and to concert-goers who had been denied a major, purpose-built concert hall since 1941, when the Queen's Hall was burned out by a German incendiary bomb. The Royal Albert Hall, with its then decidedly dodgy acoustics, had always been a multi-purpose venue, for boxing as well as Beethoven.

Sir Malcolm Sargent was the musical advisor to the RFH and every attempt was made to create what might be described as a democratic acoustic. The aim was a sound that was equal and consistent when heard from any seat in the auditorium. This meant, in theory, that every seat could be sold at the same price - although in practice this has never been the case.

The stage was designed to optimise orchestral acoustics, so percussion and brass sections were sited on a concrete floor and the rest of the orchestra on timber. The reverberation time was intended to be 2.2 seconds (slightly warm) but ended up a rather cold 1.5. (A medieval cathedral, with its rich, echoing sound, is normally about 11 seconds.)

Yet, musically as well as architecturally, the RFH was judged a critical and popular success.The acoustic was praised by conductors and orchestras at the time for its "modern" crispness; today, a warmer sound is appreciated and the auditorium is to be subtly tuned as far as this is possible. Every last detail was intended to be the newest and the best.

Aside from the care that went into its musical properties, the RFH was a showcase of modern design - furniture by Robin Day, a distinctive bat-and-ball carpet by Peter Moro, who had worked on the De La Warr Pavilion, Bexhill-on-Sea, which was, in its much smaller way, a prototype for the RFH. The British public would have seen little to match it in modern intent, except, of course, for the stations, rolling stock and buses of Frank Pick's London Underground, much admired by Matthew, Martin, Moro and co, and made possible with the earlier political machinations of Herbert Morrison.

But . . . the RFH was never quite complete. Its backstage facilities were derisory and the face it presented to the Thames was a little grim, and temporary. In June 1964, the building was closed for eight months for a facelift. The big smile of its Thames-side elevation dates from this time.

Ever since, the RFH has been cluttered up inside, then stripped back a bit, then messed up again. Only recently has a considered, long-term plan been put into practice, with the architects Allies and Morrison commissioned to work through the building to both renovate and improve. Two of the practice's architects working on the RFH, Graham Morrison and Di Haig, were trained by Martin when he was professor of architecture at Cambridge. The new works, quiet and respectful, and due for completion in 2003/4, include a new recital room, the opening up of the garden roof terraces for the first time in many years, new bars and cafes extending on to terraces, new backstage areas and a general architectural wash- and brush-up. A slim new office will rise alongside Hungerford Bridge to house RFH and other South Bank Centre staff.

Meanwhile, the whole of the South Bank is being replanned under the direction of Rick Mather. A landscape architect is to be appointed in May after the RFH's 50th birthday celebrations and one of either Rafael Vignoly or FOA (Foreign Office Architects - just a name, and nothing to do with government wallahs) will be offered the commission to design a new arts building on the Jubilee Gardens site on the other side of Hungerford Bridge from the RFH. This was where the principal buildings of the 1951 Festival of Britain stood, including Powell & Moya's Skylon and Ralph Tubbs's Dome of Discovery.

Fifty years young, the Royal Festival Hall remains an evolving showcase of open, accessible, democratic architecture. It is as popular as it is a work of sotto voce triumph over austerity art.

The Royal Festival Hall, London SE1, celebrates its birthday throughout May, with a Birthday Gala on Thursday. Details: 020-7960 4301; www.rfh.org.uk

fields.headline: Labour of luvvie
fields.standfirst: Method-acting madness used to be for the Hollywood hardcore. Nowadays, they're all at it. Johnny Sharp wonders what happened to the noble art of faking it?
fields.trailText: The modern Hollywood actor is a proud creature. A diligent professional to the last, he (or she) will throw himself into each role without a shred of concern for his physical or creative limitations, not to mention sanity.
fields.body:
The modern Hollywood actor is a proud creature. A diligent professional to the last, he (or she) will throw himself into each role without a shred of concern for his physical or creative limitations, not to mention sanity.

It's no picnic, though. Recently, for example, Nicolas Cage has been telling anyone who'll listen about the hell he went through to learn the mandolin for his role as Captain Corelli. Poor lamb.

Meanwhile, his co-star Christian Bale had to learn how to throw a shing net like a real 40s Greek sherman. Not as simple as it might sound, since local shermen all disagreed over what was the authentic method.

You may ask, "Who the hell would have noticed he was throwing it the wrong way - apart from a few "experts" on 40s Greek shing methods, who don't know for denite either?"

That's the wrong attitude. If a job's worth doing, it's worth doing properly. Besides, that kind of realism-at-all-costs approach to acting can be a richly rewarding experience. The role may be demanding, but you get to learn important new life skills.

As an actor at the top of your trade, you've got to be prepared for anything. Picture the scene: your role, should you choose to accept it, is a chess grandmaster with a black belt in jujitsu. What do you do? Just pretend? "Heavens, no!" says any actor worth his equity card. "I couldn't possibly bring myself to fake it, I shall spend the next two years locked away perfecting both those skills! You want an amputee hermaphrodite unicyclist? Well I shall rise above the camera tricks, the prosthetics and the body doubles, and saw my own leg off, have a sex change and join the circus for six months!"

Luckily, no such roles have yet been created. But if they were, that's the kind of sacrice modern movie directors expect. The question is, though, will actors ever use these skills in their everyday lives? Or are they just wasting their time and energy on overzealous pursuit of cinematic realism?

Well, at least learning a musical instrument can help you win friends and influence people. The messiah of method, Robert De Niro, was one of the rst to go that particular extra mile, learning to play the saxophone for his part in Martin Scorsese's musical extravaganza New York, New York.

Since then, though, it's become almost de rigueur for any self-respecting luvvie. Emily Watson learnt the cello in order to star in the Jaqueline Du Pré biopic Hilary And Jackie. Meryl Streep learned the harp for Music Of The Heart,while Sean Penn learnt to play Django Reinhardt-style jazz guitar for Woody Allen's Sweet And Lowdown. Good for him. As long as he doesn't decide to make a record, like Gwyneth Paltrow's Duets or Jane Horrocks' Little Voice spin-offs.

Of course, not everyone has the ability or inclination to go to quite such lengths for what is, after all, a movie, and therefore, by denition, not real. Remember the mid-80s flick Crossroads, about a whizz kid blues guitarist? Oh well, anyway, Ralph Macchio, who starred, had to learn not to actually play the electric guitar, but to mime all the licks, nger-perfect. Still, now the acting jobs have dried up, he can always stand outside the subway station with a ghetto blaster behind him, miming nger-perfect guitar to the theme from The Deer Hunter.

You're all right if your new talent helps you look after yourself. Keanu Reeves spent six months becoming a martial arts expert for his stunts in The Matrix, while Catherine Zeta-Jones and Antonio Banderas had to learn how to swordght for The Mask Of Zorro. Having a sword round the house could be useful for dealing with any unexpected stalker problems. Brad Pitt, meanwhile, learnt bare-knuckle boxing for Guy Ritchie's Snatch, building on the preparation he'd already had for Fight Club. So jealous boyfriends should be no problem.

Even if they're fundamentally useless off-screen, some actors' learning feats are really very impressive. For instance, in preparation for his role in sporic drama The Horse Whisperer, Robert Redford actually learned how to horse whisper, a talent only the real horse whisperer has ever previously mastered.

The cast of Apollo 13 learnt to deal with zero gravity, a feat which only real astronauts would normally get to master. Maybe one day, when the rst package holiday trips to the moon are launched, they can take advantage.

Redford and Brad Pitt, meanwhile, learned to flysh for A River Runs Through It. Those empty hours between takes must just whizz by now. As long as they're near a river.

Some new experiences are less welcome, however. Richard E Grant had never touched a drop of alcohol before starring in Withnail & I. Director Bruce Robinson insisted he needed a chemical memory of drunkenness, so he and Paul McGann went on a bender one night. Richard was sick as a dog and hasn't drunk booze since, but he must have learnt something, judging by that performance.

It's no pain, no gain in the ruthless world of movie-making. How our hearts bled for Renée Zellweger when we read of her brave and moving attempts to eat like a normal person for Bridget Jones's Diary. Fact is, you're no-one in Hollywood these days unless you've undergone some epic period of self-denial in the name of art.

Ever since De Niro porked out for Raging Bull, misguided luvvies have come to believe that your talent as an actor can be judged by how successfully you can do something totally unnecessary, preferably health-threatening, to prepare for a role. But just as Dwayyn Starsky out of Screaming Vengeance's ability to play the guitar at 716 mph with his earlobe doesn't mean his music's any good, don't think that just because Tom Hanks can starve himself and grow a beard, and advertise Federal Express - all at once - that must therefore mean Cast Away is a good lm.

Besides, you suspect some actors are picking their roles just to learn glamorous tricks. Look at Tom Cruise. Mixology in Cocktail? Pool hustling in The Color Of Money? Racing cars in Days Of Thunder? Flying planes in Top Gun? Cool! One American tabloid even whispered that he hired a sex therapist to help make his erotic scenes with Nicole Kidman in Eyes Wide Shut more intense. He denied it, sued and won. Whether he has used the skill since is not known.

Of course, we don't know everything that goes on behind the scenes. We can only speculate on the rigorous training undergone by stars for their parts in various lms.

Was Meg Ryan taught to fake that orgasm? Surely she's too cute and delightful to have ever dreamed of such a deception_ And how did Julia Roberts prepare for her role as a street-walking prostitute in Pretty Woman? Anyone's guess.

One thing we can do is wish some of them had learnt more from their roles. Take Elizabeth Berkley, who played an aspiring actress in that timeless classic Showgirls. You'd have thought that as part of her research she might have learnt to act. But evidently not.

Ultimately, though, all these skills must surely enrich the already fascinating, full and fantastic lives of Hollywood stars. Maybe at parties, they all get together and try to outdo each other with their otherwise useless movie tricks? I sincerely hope so. Redford whispering horses in one corner, Cage twanging on his mandolin in the other, as Zeta-Jones duels with Banderas in the back yard. There's no business like show business! *

Still, now the acting jobs have dried up, he can always stand outside the subway station with a ghetto blaster behind him, miming nger-perfect guitar to the theme from The Deer Hunter. You're all right if your new talent helps you look after yourself. Keanu Reeves spent six months becoming a martial arts expert for his stunts in The Matrix, while Catherine Zeta-Jones and Antonio Banderas had to learn how to swordght for The Mask Of Zorro. Having a sword round the house could be useful for dealing with any unexpected stalker problems. Brad Pitt, meanwhile, learnt bare-knuckle boxing for Guy Ritchie's Snatch, building on the preparation he'd already had for Fight Club. So jealous boyfriends should be no problem. Even if they're fundamentally useless off-screen, some actors' learning feats are really very impressive. For instance, in preparation for his role in sporic drama The Horse Whisperer, Robert Redford actually learned how to horse whisper, a talent only the real horse whisperer has ever previously mastered. The cast of Apollo 13 learnt to deal with zero gravity, a feat which only real astronauts would normally get to master. Maybe one day, when the rst package holiday trips to the moon are launched, they can take advantage. Redford and Brad Pitt, meanwhile, learned to flysh for A River Runs Through It. Those empty hours between takes must just whizz by now. As long as they're near a river. Some new experiences are less welcome, however. Richard E Grant had never touched a drop of alcohol before starring in Withnail & I. Director Bruce Robinson insisted he needed a chemical memory of drunkenness, so he and Paul McGann went on a bender one night. Richard was sick as a dog and hasn't drunk booze since, but he must have learnt something, judging by that performance. It's no pain, no gain in the ruthless world of movie-making. How our hearts bled for Renée Zellweger when we read of her brave and moving attempts to eat like a normal person for Bridget Jones's Diary. Fact is, you're no-one in Hollywood these days unless you've undergone some epic period of self-denial in the name of art. Ever since De Niro porked out for Raging Bull, misguided luvvies have come to believe that your talent as an actor can be judged by how successfully you can do something totally unnecessary, preferably health-threatening, to prepare for a role. But just as Dwayyn Starsky out of Screaming Vengeance's ability to play the guitar at 716 mph with his earlobe doesn't mean his music's any good, don't think that just because Tom Hanks can starve himself and grow a beard, and advertise Federal Express - all at once - that must therefore mean Cast Away is a good lm. Besides, you suspect some actors are picking their roles just to learn glamorous tricks. Look at Tom Cruise. Mixology in Cocktail? Pool hustling in The Color Of Money? Racing cars in Days Of Thunder? Flying planes in Top Gun? Cool! One American tabloid even whispered that he hired a sex therapist to help make his erotic scenes with Nicole Kidman in Eyes Wide Shut more intense. He denied it, sued and won. Whether he has used the skill since is not known. Of course, we don't know everything that goes on behind the scenes. We can only speculate on the rigorous training undergone by stars for their parts in various lms. Was Meg Ryan taught to fake that orgasm? Surely she's too cute and delightful to have ever dreamed of such a deception_ And how did Julia Roberts prepare for her role as a street-walking prostitute in Pretty Woman? Anyone's guess. One thing we can do is wish some of them had learnt more from their roles. Take Elizabeth Berkley, who played an aspiring actress in that timeless classic Showgirls. You'd have thought that as part of her research she might have learnt to act. But evidently not. Ultimately, though, all these skills must surely enrich the already fascinating, full and fantastic lives of Hollywood stars. Maybe at parties, they all get together and try to outdo each other with their otherwise useless movie tricks? I sincerely hope so. Redford whispering horses in one corner, Cage twanging on his mandolin in the other, as Zeta-Jones duels with Banderas in the back yard. There's no business like show business! *

webTitle: Reviews: Steven Poole on new non-fiction

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole looks at The No-Nonsense Guide to Climate Change by Dinyar Godrej, Spooked: Espionage in Corporate America by Adam L Penenberg & Marc Barry, and Harry Potter and the Bible: The Menace Behind the Magick by Richard Abanes
fields.trailText: Steven Poole looks at The No-Nonsense Guide to Climate Change by Dinyar Godrej, Spooked: Espionage in Corporate America by Adam L Penenberg & Marc Barry, and Harry Potter and the Bible: The Menace Behind the Magick by Richard Abanes
fields.body:
The No-Nonsense Guide to Climate Change,
Dinyar Godrej
(Verso, £7)

US oil barons like to justify their pollutive habits by pointing out that theories of climate change do not enjoy total consensus. This is a dumb argument in a country where there is not even a total consensus on evolutionary theory, thanks to fundamentalists who want their children to be taught biblical fairy-stories in school. Some people will believe anything, and scientific dissent can always be bought. Godrej's excellent overview - one of a splendid new series of pocketable New Internationalist guides to issue politics - makes rigorously clear, on the other hand, just how much hard evidence there is. In short, CO 2 emissions can cause temperature changes that will drown cities and turn vast tracts of land into desert. Invaluable material with which to bait Dubya-supporting Americans on behalf of the "Majority World", as Godrej nicely terms the poor countries who are most at risk.

Spooked: Espionage in Corporate America
Adam L Penenberg & Marc Barry
(Perseus, £18.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Not many Le Carréish men in overcoats mooch around dark Berlin alleyways these days. Global trade being a more efficient and publicly palatable version of war, the spies with the coolest gadgets and the driest Martinis are those at work in corporate espionage - and a lot of them are bona fide ex-Cold War spooks, who find their skills highly prized by companies wanting to steal a march on competitors. This snappily journalistic collection of anecdotes reveals how practices range from low-tech gumshoe work - poking around in cardboard pizza boxes - to cutting-edge hacking: how a geek was paid by a Kashmiri terrorist to steal US military software. And there I was, thinking the corporate world was boring.

Harry Potter and the Bible: The Menace Behind the Magick
Richard Abanes
(Horizon, £9.99)

More fundamentalism: Abanes has clambered aboard the "Harry Potter teaches our kids Satanism" bandwagon and is riding atop it like an avenging Knight Templar, mullet haircut streaming in the wind and mad fire blazing from his eyes. The problem is that Abanes wants all children's literature to proselytise for the "right" Biblical values. But if that happened, kids would be so bored out of their wits that they'd give up reading altogether. He spends much of his book comparing Rowling's tales unfavourably with Tolkien and C S Lewis - naturally, as the latter two wrote crypto-Christian fables. Abanes is concerned that Harry's "magick" mirrors real rituals in Wicca - and so presumably readers are going to grow up wanting to burn people in enormous straw men. Bah - I read Stephen King when I was a kid, and it never did me any harm. Gibber.

webTitle: Audio: Richard III by William Shakespeare

fields.headline: Richard III by William Shakespeare
fields.standfirst:
(Naxos, £9.99; CD £13.99, 200 mn)
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: Branagh is a more honey-voiced than splenetic villain, leaving the text and a few hobbling steps at the start to conjure his deformity
fields.body: Kenneth Branagh dropped a thunderbolt last August. Would Naxos do Richard III with him? But it had to be within the next 10 days, because that was his only window. Naxos boss Nicolas Soames found the budget, studio and director, and mustered a spangled cast - including John Woodvine, Geraldine McEwan, Nicholas Farrell, Michael Maloney - and it was in the can a week later. This, the full text, is long and crowded, but the classic tragedy structure - the rise and fall of the principal character - becomes clearer. Branagh is a more honey-voiced than splenetic villain, leaving the text and a few hobbling steps at the start to conjure his deformity. He brings it off with a brio that belies his brief experience in audio. McEwan, a squeak short of melodrama as the cursing Queen Margaret, is magnificent.

webTitle: Bodies in Motion and at Rest by Thomas Lynch

fields.headline: Bodies in Motion and at Rest by Thomas Lynch
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on refreshingly uncynical essays
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on refreshingly uncynical essays
fields.body:
Bodies in Motion and at Rest
Thomas Lynch
(Vintage, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The male American essayist finds it incumbent on himself to produce at least one piece about fishing with a son. And Thomas Lynch, poet, undertaker, and, with the publication of his previous collection of musings, The Undertaking , renowned essayist, obliges here with "Fish Stories". His four-year-old had caught his first fish, and was torn between the desire to take it home to show his mother - which would, of course, asphyxiate it - and to let it live by throwing it back. He put it back, in tears: "Catch and release, like love and grief, are difficult notions. We've been fishing together ever since."

Lynch, at least, knows one possible reaction to this: "I know you're thinking that's cute enough to make you puke" - which, funnily enough, was exactly what I was thinking. But it was nice of him to give us permission to throw up, nodding to the decadent and cynical tendencies of the old-world Anglo-Saxon mind, even if he nevertheless carries on in exactly the same manner as before.

One must forgive him his cornball tendencies. They are, after all, an important - and, it would appear, sustaining - part of him. And he needs sustaining, one suspects. At one point, wrangling over the conspicuous failure of the Almighty to even begin to acknowledge the most modest supplication, he decides that prayer should not be a wish list but a matter of saying "thank you" to God: "Every day, every time, never fails, if I just say 'thanks' I'll get the answer, before the darkness comes - 'You're welcome,' it says. 'You're welcome.'" That, too, might seem emetic, but only out of context: it comes at the end of a 21-page dissertation on his son's, and his own, alcoholism. Aren't these Americans candid?

Essayists are meant to know all the answers, even if one of them is "I do not know all the answers". As an undertaker, Lynch stares the imponderable in the face day to day, and you can imagine that it is a comfort to many that the man charged with interring their loved ones should have worked out a way of talking to God that leaves him satisfied. He has been well prepared by his Catholic education, which would appear to be one of the few instances where "educated by nuns" does not mean "thrashed by nuns".

Perversely I do not seem to be leaving you with many reasons for reading this book. It not only repeats itself, but it repeats The Undertaking . There appears to be no sentiment so trite that he blushes to air it. Reflections on the close relationship between sex and death, for instance, or this: "Astronauts return from space convinced of the glory and grandeur of Creation. It is no less so when one witnesses nativity first hand, or looks into the void of death." (The first point seems fair enough. The other two are, I would venture, matters of opinion to say the very least. Birth makes a frightful mess of the sheets; and what was it Joyce - of whom Lynch knows full well - called God? The insatiable chewer of corpses, or something like.)

Look on this as a belated tribute to The Undertaking , the superior book. Besides, it is pleasant to read an uncynical voice, for once. Yet anyone who is driven to seriously contemplate the murder of his cat (I love cats but he makes a very good case for his position), or sends his bad poems off to magazines under the names of poets he dislikes, can't be a total goody two-shoes.

fields.headline: An offer you can refuse
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery looks at Omertà by Mario Puzo, Idioglossia by Eleanor Bailey, The Lion in the Room Next Door by Merilyn Simonds, and Never Trust a Rabbit by Jeremy Dyson
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery looks at Omertà by Mario Puzo, Idioglossia by Eleanor Bailey, The Lion in the Room Next Door by Merilyn Simonds, and Never Trust a Rabbit by Jeremy Dyson
fields.body:
Omertà
Mario Puzo
(Arrow, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Although it's the film adaptations that are the classics, Puzo set the parameters of the mafia novel. So this, his final, posthumous contribution, should be a easy read, especially now that the dons of high culture have made low culture respectable territory. Shame, then, about the lazy writing and the tired plot. The assassination of Don Aprile is prefaced by set-piece clan meetings, and cues double-dealings and tricky manoeuvrings within the families as the Don's nephew and the FBI try to find out the who and the why. Puzo writes with fairy-story simplicity, but Tony Soprano has long since muscled in and made this a genre where personality counts.

Idioglossia
Eleanor Bailey
(Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A quartet of women - Great Edie, the psychic granny; Grace, the woman in the attic; Maggie, the single mother; and Sarah, lost in looking-glass land - support this generational saga that has a welcome pessimism at its centre. Bailey's debut revolves around a terrible legacy handed down from mother to daughter. But with mental instability as the inheritance, Idioglossia cannot promise a happy-ever-after. It's a hard enough subject for any writer, and Bailey shows a mature sensitivity in her portrayal of the blight of mental illness. Her mistake, though, is to complicate her subsidiary characters and leave little space for a well-paced resolution.

The Lion in the Room Next Door
Merilyn Simonds
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Here is more delving into the past, with Simonds's examination of how the oddest pieces of our pasts stick to us. Three story-cycles move from childhood to early marriage, then to that marriage cracked. At home in Canada, the book is marketed as non-fiction, but the rest of the world has chosen to take these beautifully arranged fragments as invention. What in effect are jump-cut home movies work when the images - a cowboy outfit, for example - connect, or when Simonds's style kicks off an association within the reader. But, inevitably, not all of her memories are universally resonant.

Never Trust a Rabbit
Jeremy Dyson
(Duckbacks, £5.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

When comedians write fiction they like to show their cuddly side - Nigel Planer and Ben Elton adeptly slotted themselves into the space between Nick Hornby and Tony Parsons - and there is usually little crossover between the novelist and the caustic standup. With Dyson, one of the League of Gentlemen writers, you can see the link. In tales about cashpoints that hand out advice, a ghostly parallel Underground, and a tide that goes out never to return, Dyson's writing is heavily seasoned with Poe, Dahl and Wilde. These may not be tales of the totally unexpected, but Dyson's agile imagination is unfailingly entertaining.

fields.headline: Glorious evolution
fields.standfirst: John Dugdale  looks at The Diversity of Life by Edward O Wilson, and First & Last Things by Richard Hoggart
fields.trailText: John Dugdale looks at The Diversity of Life by Edward O Wilson, and First & Last Things by Richard Hoggart
fields.body:
The Diversity of Life
Edward O Wilson
(Penguin, £8.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Published in 1992, the first edition of Wilson's book - a mixture of green manifesto, prophetic jeremiad and lyrical catalogue of the earth's riches - helped to popularise the term "biodiversity". Updating it nine years on, he recognises (albeit before the US volte-face on the Kyoto agreement) that the necessity of conservation has won wider acceptance; but warns that population growth and destruction of resources have continued unabated. Like David Attenborough's recent TV series State of the Planet, which was informed by Wilson's ideas, The Diversity of Life makes vast evolutionary patterns vividly concrete through brilliant use of illustrations from nature.

First & Last Things
Richard Hoggart
(Aurum, £9.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Now 82, the cultural-studies pioneer follows his autobiography with a likably quirky credo. It takes in social solidarity, sensuality, family, books and memory as it sets out personal mainstays in a dumbed-down and increasingly market-driven era. As if feeling he needs to acknowledge the contributions of Messrs Montaigne, Auden and Emerson in summing up an Elysian seminar, the former don is maddeningly prone to sprinkle arguments with quoted aphorisms. Much sharper are the sections drawing on direct experience, whether Hoggart is recalling working-class Leeds in the 1930s or an exchange overheard yesterday in a Surrey supermarket.
